HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
White House to Press Airlines on Consolidation
The Clinton administration plans to issue a last-minute call to police the airline industry more closely in the wake of deals that would consolidate the airline industry in the hands of a few giant carriers.
 The departing transportation secretary, Rodney E. Slater, intends to release three studies criticizing the state of competition in air travel and lay out a blueprint for how the government can improve the situation. But after receiving strong criticism from the airlines, some academics and the White House itself, Mr. Slater will stop short of issuing a controversial set of guidelines first proposed three years ago that would have put airlines on notice about how aggressively they could respond to low-fare competitors. Page A1. 

Motorola to Lay Off 2,500 Workers
Motorola, following through with promises to cut costs as it struggles through a difficult first half of 2001, announced 2,500 layoffs that will shut down manufacturing at the company's last domestic cellular phone plant. C10.

Milken Return to Wall St. Unlikely
A pardon from President Clinton this week might improve Michael R. Milken's public image but it would not pave the way for the fallen financier to return to Wall Street, securities lawyers and people who know Mr. Milken said. President Clinton has been considering granting an 11th-hour pardon to Mr. Milken, who served almost two years in prison after pleading guilty to six felony counts of securities fraud in 1990. C10.

Utilities Seek Leeway on Bills
Pacific Gas and Electric and Southern California Edison, the two largest utilities in California, said they had millions of dollars owed to power generators due today but warned they might not have enough cash to pay them. Both utilities are hoping that negotiations last weekend will give them some leeway. C2.

Entertainment Writers Weigh Strike
The entertainment industry is facing a series of potential strikes by writers as well as actors that could cripple film and television production, starting in late spring. The writers have a series of financial demands, but what also seems to be driving the Writers Guild of America, representing 11,000 writers, are issues that have less to do with money than with giving the writers a new sense of respect. A1.

Curbs Sought on Money Laundering
The Clinton administration plans to announce voluntary measures meant to deter foreign leaders and their associates from hiding money in the United States, a leading destination for illicit wealth. A11.

From Alcoa Boardroom to Treasury
Paul H. O'Neill, the treasury secretary-designate, became chief executive of Alcoa in 1987 and quickly turned a Rust Belt laggard into the world's biggest and richest aluminum producer with a healthy bottom line. Just how Mr. O'Neill, a bureaucrat turned businessman, revived Alcoa's fortunes provides a glimpse into the man who has been designated to carry out -- and influence -- the Bush economic plan at a time of increasing financial uncertainty and general business unease. A1.

Nikkei Rallies on Mori's Remarks
The Japanese stock market rose after Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori said the government planned to take steps to stem falling stock prices. Mr. Mori said the government was considering a liberalization of regulations on corporate share buybacks that would allow companies to hold on to shares they purchase in the open market. The Nikkei index rose 158.49 points, or 1.19 percent, to 13,506.23. C11.

Maker of Mentos to Buy Van Melle
The Italian confectioner Perfetti said it would buy the two-thirds of Van Melle that it does not already own, bringing together Brooklyn chewing gum and Mentos mints, in a deal that values the company at $1 billion. C4.

Verizon Wireless Assigns Account
Verizon Wireless, a joint venture of Verizon Communications and Vodafone, named the New York office of the Bozell Group as agency of record on its account, including its national brand advertising. Billings were estimated at $300 million. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C10.

U.S. Markets to Reopen Today
All major financial markets in the United States, which had been closed yesterday in observance of Martin Luther King's Birthday, will reopen today.

HEADLINE: WINE TALK; 
A Cellar Master of a Certain Vintage

BYLINE:  By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
IT'S easy to get tired of New York in midwinter: the crowds, the angry drivers, the dirty snow. Some people head for Miami. Me, I take the A Train to Brooklyn. With the sun on the water, the Brooklyn Bridge soaring overhead and Lower Manhattan a thousand yards away, there is no place like it to see New York. It's a John Sloan painting and an Edna St. Vincent Millay poem and an afternoon spent taking it in will get you through to April better than a weekend in Paris.
 In fact, I had a second agenda when I walked down Old Fulton Street last week from the subway stop to the River Cafe, the restaurant nearly under the bridge. Someone had told me that the average time a California winemaker stays at any one job is four years. With new restaurants opening almost hourly, sommeliers in California and everywhere else seem to move every six weeks. I've heard that "Excellent choice, sir" line from wine stewards I'd swear were not old enough to drink two years ago. Joe Delissio has been the wine director at the River Cafe for 23 years. That has to be some sort of record, and I was curious to see how he was holding up. 
 Mr. Delissio started out as one of those "excellent choice" kids: He was 23 when Buzzy O'Keeffe, who owns the River Cafe, hired him as wine director. He has literally grown up with the wine boom.
"My father owned a saloon in Brooklyn," said Mr. Delissio, who is 46, "but I knew nothing about wine, nothing. It was what the guys drank in my father's place when they were off the hard stuff."
Mr. O'Keeffe didn't know much about wine either, and the Frenchman who had been buying wine for him had his own way of adding up bills. "I was working as a psychiatric therapist during the day and an aspiring rock musician at night," Mr. Delissio recalled. "Buzzy hired me because my mother, who did his books, vouched for me. Actually, it wasn't that hard. I bought the wine and I sold it. It's like Pete Rose used to say when someone would ask him how he did what he did -- 'I see the ball,' he'd say, 'and I hit the ball.' "
It was more complicated than he admits, starting as he did from zero. "At first I listened to the salesmen," he said, "even if I didn't like the wine. I figured I didn't know anything. Eventually, I decided that it was time to buy what I liked. I traveled to California and to Europe. And it was a lot easier after that."
Mr. Delissio no longer hovers over nervous guests, recommending Volnay with the veal. He chooses the wines, buys them, coddles them. He consults with the chef, Brad Steelman, to match wines with special dishes, like a Cune Reserve 1991 with the buffalo steak.
Mr. Delissio has worked with many River Cafe chefs, including Larry Forgione and Charlie Palmer. These days he trains others to push the Volnay. Right now it is Scott Calvert, who has been with the cafe for seven years but sommelier for only a few weeks.
Have tastes changed? "When I started, about a third of our liquor business was wine," Mr. Delissio said. "The rest was spirits. Now, 75 percent of our alcohol business is wine. In the 60's our wine sales were almost all French. So was our wine list. Then I got fascinated by American wines, long before they were really popular. And now we seem to be going back to French wines."
The Delissio theory: It's all economics. When French wine prices go through the roof, American wines become the favorites. When their prices balloon, the French come back. Wines are not inexpensive at the River Cafe but they can be less costly than at other places around town, particularly at the top end of the price list.
Like Harry's at Hanover Square, Veritas on East 20th Street and other restaurants that offer hard-to-find wines at decent prices, the River Cafe has a policy of buying and holding rare bottles. Thus, Mr. Delissio can offer seven vintages of Chateau Petrus, six of Chateau Rayas, a rare Chateauneuf-du-Pape and nine vintages of Le Montrachet from Domaine Ramonet. The average price for a bottle of wine is around $55.
The roughly 500-bottle list is not the longest in the city, but it is one of the broadest. Not many restaurants in New York offer California cabernets going back to 1969; few if any offer white Burgundy verticals from Ramonet and Leflaive, along with red Burgundy verticals from Leroy and Romanee-Conti. A Chateau Lafite-Rothschild 1982 goes for $1,000, but some restaurants charge three times that.
The large-bottle collection is exceptional as well. How about, for example, an imperial -- six liters -- of Beaulieu Vineyards 1991 Georges de Latour Private Reserve? Or a double magnum of the 1974 Robert Mondavi Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon? The cost is $600 and $1,200, respectively, but these bottles are not for ordinary mortals.
The cafe has an unexpectedly good selection of Spanish wines and an unexpectedly short selection of Italian offerings. Port, Madeira and Cognac are well represented. The sherries include a fino flown in fresh from Spain. 
"In the old days, people asked for recommendations," he said. "Now all they want to know is if it's from a hot new winery and does it have a high score from the critics.
"Suggest a wine with some age? Forget it. Everyone wants the most recent release from some fancy little winery that has no wine for sale, anyway. It's a dangerous trend."
Recently, Mr. Delissio began to oversee the wine operations at Mr. O'Keeffe's other restaurants, the Water Club and Pershing Square. And he has formed a consulting business to aid places whose sommeliers don't have 23 years' experience. There was a book last year, "The River Cafe Wine Primer" (Little, Brown), and he writes about wine for Bartender magazine.
With all this, I hope he doesn't leave the River Cafe. It's comforting, dealing with a pro.

GRAPHIC: Photo: WHAT HE'S SEEN -- Joe Delissio, right, the wine director at the River Cafe in Brooklyn for 23 years, has watched trends come and go. (Steve Hart for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Savannah Waring Walker

 BODY:
 THE AMERICAS

UNITED NATIONS: ZIONIST GROUP CLEARS HURDLE
A committee of the U.N. Economic and Social Council recommended that Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, be granted consultative status at the United Nations. Hadassah had applied in 1998 to join 2,000 other nongovernmental organizations, advocacy groups and charities allowed to participate in U.N. conferences and advise departments and agencies. Hadassah's application was delayed by objections from Arab countries. Christopher S. Wren

CHILE: PINOCHET DIAGNOSIS
Newspapers reported that tests showed that Gen. Augusto Pinochet suffers from a mild form of dementia -- a diagnosis that prosecutors say means he is fit to stand trial. Judge Juan Guzman, who wants to try General Pinochet on homicide charges, had ordered him to submit to a series of health tests. Newspapers said the general suffered from "a mild vascular dementia" caused by minor strokes in recent years. There was no official confirmation. (AP)

PERU: FINDING IN BERENSON CASE
A Peruvian judge found that a U.S. citizen, Lori Berenson, whose life sentence on terrorism charges was overturned last year, was a collaborator rather than a senior figure in the leftist Tupac Amaru guerrilla group. In a ruling closing his review of the case, Judge Julian Jeri said in Lima that Ms. Berenson had been a collaborator of the guerrillas when they mounted a failed attack on Congress in November 1995. But it was not proven that she had been a leader in the movement or had taken part in any major action on their behalf, he said. The National Chamber for Terrorism Cases now has 30 days in which to set a date for Ms. Berenson to give oral testimony in a civilian court. (Agence France-Presse)

EUROPE

YUGOSLAVIA: WAR CRIMES REBUFF
President Vojislav Kostunica of Yugoslavia, left, said during a visit to Athens that he would have no time to meet Carla del Ponte, the U. N. war crimes tribunal's chief prosecutor, who is to visit Belgrade next week to press for the extradition of Slobodan Milosevic, Mr. Kostunica's predecessor. Mr. Kostunica's remarks quickly drew criticism from his political alliance and are also likely to annoy Western governments. (Reuters)

TURKEY: QUAKE HITS ISTANBUL
A moderate earthquake shook Istanbul residents shortly before dawn, sending hundreds into the streets. There were no reports of serious injuries or damage in the quake, whose magnitude was measured at 4.2. Istanbul, with a population of more than 10 million, sits close to the North Anatolian fault line, which in 1999 unleashed two earthquakes that killed 18,000 people. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

RUSSIA: MEDIA BARON'S AIDE ARRESTED
Russian prosecutors struck another blow at Vladimir Gusinsky's independent Media-Most press empire, arresting the company's top financial officer on unspecified fraud charges. The official, Anton Titov, is one of several Media-Most executives interrogated or jailed in the inquiry, now nearly a year old. Mr. Gusinsky, who calls the inquiry politically motivated, is under house arrest in Spain while Russian prosecutors seek to have him returned. Michael Wines (NYT)

NORWAY: WHALE EXPORT BAN LIFTED
Norway, the only country that conducts commercial whale hunts, said it was lifting its ban on the export of whale meat and products. Whale hunts were resumed in 1993, but exports were barred for fear of international backlash. Norwegians eat whale meat but not the blubber, which is considered a delicacy in Japan and can now be exported there. Environmentalists argued that increasing profits from exports could lead to higher whale quotas and encourage other countries to resume hunts. (AP)

ASIA

SRI LANKA: ASSAULT ON REBELS
Government troops began a huge offensive to recapture a Tamil rebel stronghold in northern Sri Lanka, sending planes and tanks into the attack. At least 22 rebels, 18 soldiers and one civilian were killed, and 89 soldiers were wounded in the first 11 hours of fighting, said a military spokesman, Sanath Karunaratne. "We have recovered 22 bodies of terrorists, and there will be more," Mr. Karunaratne said. (AP)

VIETNAM: VISIT BY U.S. COMMANDER PUT OFF
In a setback for U.S.-Vietnamese ties, Hanoi has called off a visit by a top U.S. military commander, saying its military leadership is too busy to see him. A Ministry of Defense official said the planned visit on Monday by Adm. Dennis Blair, commander of the Pacific Fleet, would be postponed indefinitely. The sudden cancellation cast a shadow over hopes for improved relations between the countries that followed a visit by President Clinton in November. (AP)

AFRICA

MALAWI: EX-MINISTER ACQUITTED
Saying the state had not established its case, a magistrate court acquitted a former cabinet minister, Brown Mpinganjira, on charges of corruption relating to a $2 million contract scheme. Mr. Mpinganjira was accused of authorizing payments to "ghost" contractors to build schools two years ago. The projects were never completed, and the money was said to have been diverted toward campaigning for elections last year. (Agence France-Presse)

MIDDLE EAST

KUWAIT: WOMEN'S RIGHTS CASE REJECTED
The country's highest court rejected a case seeking to win women the right to vote and run for office. Judge Abdullah al-Issa, president of the Constitutional Court, said the man who filed the suit on behalf of his wife and four other women did not have power of attorney to do so. It was only the latest attempt to end male dominance of political institutions. The Legislature voted down an Emiri decree and a bill for suffrage in 1999. In July, the high court refused to hear four cases, also on a technicality. (AP)

CORRECTION-DATE: January 20, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A report by Agence France-Presse in the World Briefing column in some copies on Wednesday about an investigation in Peru involving Lori Berenson, an American imprisoned there, misidentified the official who acted in the case and misstated its legal disposition. The prosecutor, Maria Peralta, recommended that Ms. Berenson be charged as a collaborator with the Tupac Amaru rebel group rather than as a senior figure in it. The judge, Julian Jeri, did not issue a finding that she was a collaborator and did not close his review of the case. The report also misstated the deadline for setting a date for Ms. Berenson to give oral testimony in a civilian court or for the case to be dismissed. It is 3 days after a senior prosecutor receives the recommendation, not 30 days. The report also referred incorrectly to what the Peruvian government said in 1995 was a planned rebel attack on Congress. The authorities say they thwarted the attack before it occurred; the rebels did not mount an attack that failed.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Blue Chips Gain as Investors Avoid Technology Shares

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks rose yesterday as investors sought relief from worries about dwindling high-technology profits and scooped up Wall Street stalwarts like manufacturers, retailers and financial services companies.
 On Monday, financial markets were closed in observance of Martin Luther King's Birthday. 
 Technology stocks slipped as investors braced for earnings reports from Intel and a number of semiconductor equipment makers after the market closed. Traders will be scanning their statements carefully for clues to their profit performance in the months ahead. 
"The sense is all the negative news for this quarter isn't out yet," said Michelle Clayman, chief investment officer at New Amsterdam Partners. "Probably for a number of companies earnings may be disappointing for this quarter and maybe for another quarter."
The Dow Jones industrial average staged a late-day rally, climbing 127.28 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,652.66. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 8.33 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,326.65.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index, however, fell 7.95 points, or 0.3 percent, to 2,618.55. The drop was led by the semiconductor sector as well as marquee names like Microsoft, down 94 cents, to $52.56, and Veritas Software, off $5.81, to $90.38.
Intel, the Nasdaq's most actively traded issue, slipped 75 cents, to $31.38. Intel had said on Monday that it would buy Xircom, a maker of mobile computing gear, for $748 million, to complement its line of desktop computer components. Xircom climbed $6.59, to $24.66.
After the market closed, Intel said that its fourth-quarter net income rose 4 percent but that its first-quarter sales would fall about 15 percent. In after-hours trading shares of Intel edged up to $31.63.
Wall Street also awaited results from leading chip equipment makers, including Novellus Systems, and Teradyne.
"I have never seen an earnings period that has been greeted with more trepidation by technology investors," said Arnold Berman, technology strategist with Wit SoundView. "The list of worries so far is a lot longer than the list of surprises."
Signs that the economic slowdown has begun to hurt corporate America's bottom line have become more prevalent, and some analysts expect the worst may be yet to come.
Yesterday's economic data brought more evidence that the once red-hot economy is cooling. Business inventories rose more than expected in November as sales softened for the second consecutive month.
Among blue chips, General Motors was one of the biggest gainers. It rose $2.88, to $55.75, after its subsidiary, Hughes Electronics, said growth in its DirecTV service helped increase its fourth-quarter cash flow.
Investors scooped up drug stocks -- battered in recent weeks -- like Merck, which rose $1.88, to $83.31.
Manufacturers like Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, up $3.81, to $113.50, also benefited from the Nasdaq's lackluster performance.
Financial services stocks advanced after several companies posted strong earnings, among them Citigroup, a Dow component, up $1.56, to $54.69. Citigroup said its profits rose 11 percent, helped by solid growth in its large consumer banking business.
Bank of America recovered from an early slump, after the parent of the nation's biggest bank posted a 27 percent drop in earnings because of loan and investment losses. Its stock dropped as low as $47.75 before recovering, closing up $1.88, to $50.94.
In the Treasury market, bonds rose modestly, but gains were limited as investors struggled to digest a hefty supply of new corporate debt sold last week.
Analysts said Treasuries had a lift after a sharp sell-off on Friday as the market awaited more clear signs on what to expect from the Federal Open Market Committee at its meeting on Jan. 30-31. 
The price of the benchmark 10-year note rose 4/32, to 103 29/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.23 percent from 5.24 percent on Friday. The 30-year bond rose 15/32, to 109 12/32. Its yield fell to 5.60 percent from 5.63 percent on Friday.
The Treasury market was closed on Monday for Martin Luther King's Birthday.

HEADLINE: U.S. Bars Airport Near the Everglades 

BYLINE:  By DANA CANEDY 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 16 

 BODY:
In a victory for environmental groups and a blow to Miami-Dade County officials, the Clinton administration rejected a plan today to convert the former Homestead Air Force Base into a commercial airport and instead approved the property for more limited development.
 The decision comes after a protracted battle over the fate of the site, which is near two national parks: the Everglades, about 10 miles to the west, and Biscayne National Park, two miles to the east. Miami-Dade County and developers, backed by the county's mayor, Alex Penelas, want to use the property for a new airport to ease congestion from Miami International Airport. Environmental groups have vigorously fought the plan, contending that it would pose a threat to the two parks with air and noise pollution. 
 In announcing the decision today to permit only limited commercial use of the land, the Air Force said it had sought to balance environmental protection and economic development.
"Although we clearly are not giving the county what it sought," said F. Whitten Peters, secretary of the Air Force, "we are, to the greatest extent possible under the circumstances, attempting to leave future development decisions at the former base in the hands of local citizens, through their elected representatives."
Environmental groups praised the decision, calling it an important protection for the grassland, marsh, reefs and barrier islands in the national parks.
"This decision is a victory for common sense and public input over special interests," said Bradford Sewell, lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council, which was joined by the Sierra Club, the National Wildlife Federation and nearly 50 other environmental groups in opposing the airport plan. Many state and local elected officials also opposed it, as did Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt and Carol Browner, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency.
Homestead Air Base Developers, the group proposing to develop a commercial airport at the site, said it planned to fight the decision in federal court. 
Mayor Penelas, among the strongest local supporters of the airport, said he was disappointed by the decision not to allow it. 
"We're going to have an airfield capacity shortfall in about 12 to 15 years, and we need to prepare for that," he said.
The mayor added that the Homestead airport proposal was the most ideal solution and that he would not have supported the proposal had he believed it would pose an environmental threat.
Other proponents of the airport plan denounced the Clinton administration's decision.
"Basically we view this as a political decision not based in either science or law," said Ramon Rasco, general counsel for Homestead Air Base Developers.
"All of the studies over all of these years and all of the millions of dollars spent very clearly show that you can have an airport there that will be compatible with the Everglades and the environment," Mr. Rasco said.
The airport proposal began in 1992, after Hurricane Andrew devastated Homestead, a town about 25 miles south of Miami. Thousands of jobs were lost and the Air Force closed the base, dealing another blow to the local economy.
In 1994, the Air Force decided to turn the land over to the county for use as an airport. The plan was intended to relieve congestion at the Miami airport and to help spur development in Homestead. But the plan was fraught with controversy from the start.
In 1996, the Miami-Dade County Commission, with the support of Mayor Penelas, awarded a 70-year lease for the airport's development to Homestead Air Base Developers, a group of politically connected local developers. Environmental groups fought back, saying the airport would generate noise and air pollution that could harm the Everglades.
The following year, the Air Force and the Federal Aviation Administration decided to study the proposal and then reversed earlier approval of the airport.
The decision announced today, in which the Air Force will retain the runway and taxiways at Homestead but transfer the additional 700 acres to the county, seems to support a plan by a separate group of developers. They want to use the land for office and industrial parks, a golf course, water parks and an aquarium, hotels, shops and restaurants.
"Over time, it became clear that a commercial airport is not the only way of achieving desired economic development of southern Miami-Dade County," said Ruby B. DeMesme, assistant secretary of the Air Force, who signed the decision. "The choice is no longer simply between an airport and economic stagnation."

GRAPHIC: Map of Florida highlighting Homestead Air Force Base: The former Homestead air base is near two national parks.

HEADLINE: President of CNNfn Quits As a Revamping Begins 

BYLINE:  By JIM RUTENBERG 

 BODY:
C. Shelby Coffey III, the president of CNN's financial news network, CNNfn, has resigned from his position to pursue the creation of a medical foundation, Mr. Coffey said yesterday.
 His resignation represents the second announced departure of an important CNN executive since CNN's parent company, Time Warner, officially merged with America Online last week. On Friday, CNN announced that Bob Furnad, the president of CNN's Headline News, would leave to pursue a career teaching journalism and consulting with local television stations' news divisions. 
 Both announcements come as AOL Time Warner begins a companywide reorganization that is to involve elimination of hundreds of positions. Employees whose job titles are facing elimination could learn their fate as early as today.
The resignations of Mr. Furnad and Mr. Coffey revived questions about the fate of the CNN spinoff channels that each man headed -- Headline News, which has slipped in the ratings in recent years, and CNNfn, which has forever struggled to gain footing on the country's various cable systems. 
CNN executives said they were emphatic about keeping those networks intact and independent, though, they said, each could see some scaling back of operations under their new corporate parent, which expects all of the company's ventures to work more cohesively and with more of an eye toward making the most of their online businesses.
Executives said they were considering merging the operations of CNNfn with those of its corresponding Web site, CNNfn.com. Like all of CNN, CNNfn is expected to have some staff cuts.
CNN executives are expected to name Teya Ryan, Mr. Coffey's former deputy at CNNfn, to oversee Headline News. A replacement for Mr. Coffey's position was not announced yesterday.
For Mr. Coffey, leaving CNNfn is the latest move in a career in wnich he has occupied some of the most visible positions in journalism. He helped pioneer The Washington Post's Style section. After briefly serving as editor of U.S. News & World Report, he went on to edit The Los Angeles Times from 1989 to 1997. He become the second in command at ABC News before being named to take over CNNfn, as well as to oversee CNN's business news coverage in general, in late 1999.
The obstacles to Mr. Coffey's success at CNNfn were plentiful upon his arrival. The network was still in disarray from the unexpected loss of Lou Dobbs, its former president and leading on-air personality, the previous June. Meanwhile, many of its own corporate siblings, Time Warner's cable systems, would not carry the network, and its rival, CNBC, with much better distribution, was running away with financial news viewers as the economy in general, and the stock market in particular, continued to thrive.
All of this would be daunting even for a seasoned television executive with heavy experience in business news, let alone for someone like Mr. Coffey, who spent most of his career in print journalism dealing with general news and features.
Though the network continues to struggle for distribution, Mr. Coffey did have some impact. He revised its on-air look, ordered increased coverage of technology and put a heavier emphasis on the West Coast economic engine and extended the hours of operation from 18 to 24. He was also able to increase distribution from 15 million to 17 million homes. He revamped CNN's marquee business show, "Moneyline," which executives credited with helping it beat back a strong ratings challenge from CNBC's "Business Center."
But Mr. Coffey was only able to do so much. Briefly into his tenure Time Warner announced its merger with AOL, which effectively hindered Mr. Coffey from undertaking any radical plans. Months later, CNN reorganized its top management, putting two new layers of bureaucracy between Mr. Coffey and the CNN chairman, Tom Johnson, to whom he originally reported directly.
Mr. Coffey said he had been considering leaving the network since that management structure was imposed. "I was discussing this at dinner with Bill Moyers a few days ago, and he said, 'Shelby, why do you always pitch your tent on a volcano?' " Mr. Coffey said in an interview last night.
He said, however, that he believed that CNNfn could have a bright future under its new bosses, who could give it more promotional resources.
"I'm certain that CNNfn will be able to continue to do strong work," Mr. Coffey said.
Mr. Coffey said he would devote much of his time to setting up a foundation with his wife, Dr. Mary Lee Coffey, an emergency-room physician, devoted to bringing new emergency medicine technologies to developing countries.

HEADLINE: $111 Million for Times Sq. Redevelopment Site 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The last vacant parcel in the Times Square redevelopment area sold at auction yesterday for $111.1 million in what was expected to be the first step toward dismantling the vast Milstein real estate empire.
 For nearly half a century, Paul and Seymour Milstein presided over a family empire in New York that swelled to $5 billion and included office towers, apartment buildings, hotels and a bank. 
 Yesterday, Paul Milstein's family agreed to buy the parking lot on the southeast corner of 42nd Street and Eighth Avenue, across the street from the Port Authority Bus Terminal. Paul Milstein effectively agreed to buy out his brother and the Weiler family, who together had owned the property since 1984, when they bought it for $5 million. 
At a court-supervised auction, Paul's sons Howard and Edward Milstein made the winning bid for the 38,000-square-foot parking lot. Most real estate experts considered their $111.1 million bid to be a hefty price, given the uncertainty about the economy and the size of the tower that could be built. In recent weeks, nearly 12 qualified bidders dropped out. Only two bids were submitted.
One executive working with the winning bidder said Paul Milstein's family would have paid even more for what it considered to be a very valuable site. Paul's son Howard was ebullient. "I'm sorry we had to go through this process, but we're delighted to have been successful," he said yesterday. "We look forward to developing a wonderful new building for New York City."
Paul and Seymour Milstein had worked closely together for nearly five decades, but as the two brothers neared retirement, a bitter battle over succession began to take shape.
The bickering, especially the tension between Seymour Milstein and his nephew Howard, has been going on for years, but it became public more recently as family members filed a series of lawsuits and counterclaims against one another. The two sides are also warring over control of the Emigrant Savings Bank.
Last year, Seymour Milstein, who is 80 and owned a 20 percent stake in the parking lot, and Alan G. Weiler, whose family owned 50 percent, sought to dissolve the partnership and block Howard Milstein from unilaterally developing the site. A court eventually ordered the property to be sold at auction, with minimum bids set at $100 million.
But as the auction date neared, it was unclear whether anyone would bid. That would have sent the partners back to court. According to executives familiar with the bidding, Seymour Milstein and Mr. Weiler were so intent on ending the partnership that they teamed up with a developer, Douglas Durst, to make the only other bid, $100 million.
"We're very satisfied with the process," said Abby Hamlin, a developer who was advising Seymour Milstein and the Weiler family. "We're looking forward to the closing."
Since his family already owns 30 percent of the property, Howard Milstein and his family will have to pay $77.8 million.
According to one person involved in the dealings, they put down a $1 million deposit yesterday, and $2.5 million more is due within the week. The rest must be paid within 90 days.
"You have to assume that he has a tenant in hand who's willing to pay record rents in Times Square," said Joseph R. Harbert, chief operating officer for the New York region at Insignia/ESG, a real estate company, referring to Howard Milstein. "Otherwise there's no rationale for the price."
A state official said yesterday that it was unclear how big a building Howard Milstein could erect on the site. Two years ago, Mr. Milstein talked about building a 35-story tower of up to a million square feet, although state officials preferred something smaller. Last year, state officials transferred some of the development rights to a nearby parcel on Eighth Avenue, between 40th and 41st Streets, where The New York Times is negotiating to build a 1.37 million-square-foot tower.
Under rules for redeveloping Times Square, the Milsteins must include entertainment and retail uses, raising development costs.

GRAPHIC: Map of Manhattan: The sale of a parking lot on Eighth Avenue at 42nd Street is expected to be the first step in the dismantling of the Milstein real estate empire.

HEADLINE: Governor Presents $83.6 Billion Budget 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 16 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki proposed a $83.6 billion budget today that would raise state spending by 5.3 percent but cut financing for mass transportation and nursing homes while salting away $1.4 billion to guard against a slowing economy.
 It was the second year in a row that the governor has proposed an increase in overall spending above the rate of inflation. As in last year's plan, Mr. Pataki has veered away from the painful cutbacks and big tax cuts than he championed in his first five years in office. He also called for changing the way the state allots school aid to give districts more control over the money. 
 Mr. Pataki portrayed his budget, the first to exceed $80 billion, as a conservative and prudent plan that would protect the state from an economic downturn, while continuing his philosophy of cutting taxes, reducing the size of government and being fiscally cautious.
"We cannot, and will not, return to the dark days when government spent more than it could afford, then used gimmicks and raised taxes to make up the difference," Mr. Pataki said in his address to the Legislature presenting his plan. "Now more than ever it is imperative to remember that surpluses are meant to be saved, not spent. Virtually every reputable economist has been forecasting a national economic slowdown in the months ahead."
If the past serves as a guide, the state Legislature is likely to fight to add money to the budget during the months of negotiations to come. The governor's chief Democratic adversary, Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the Assembly, predicted that the Democrats would fight for more money for education, transportation and Medicaid. He said the governor's proposed changes to state financing for schools, which will raise spending by $382 million, would in fact provide $1 billion less to local school districts than the current aid formulas would dictate.
Mr. Silver also said it was unconscionable to slash financing for nursing homes and transportation projects when the state has a large surplus. He said the surplus would be more than $2 billion by the end of the next fiscal year.
"I'm really disappointed that we are cutting education and, specifically, nursing homes," Mr. Silver said. "There is no reform in the education formula the governor has proposed. The reform word is used to mask cuts in the education budget."
Senator Joseph L. Bruno, the leader of the Republican majority in the Senate, praised Mr. Pataki for a budget that "sets the tone for all of us here in this state, in the right direction." But he predicted that the governor's education plan would undoubtedly be fought in the Legislature. "Education will undoubtedly be the most contentious issue," he said. "It gets down to shares, to where the school aid flows."
Mr. Pataki largely ignored a landmark court ruling last week that ordered the state government to spend significantly more on New York City schools after finding that the state had not met its obligation under the state Constitution to urban students.
Saying he would appeal the court decision, the governor said his proposal to streamline the current school aid formulas and direct more of it to school districts with impoverished or immigrant students would solve the problems the court addressed. 
Specifically, Mr. Pataki proposed raising school aid by $382 million, to $14.1 billion. The governor called for distributing the increase according to formulas based on the poverty of the districts and on the cost of living.
Aides to the governor maintained that under this arrangement New York City would get about $5.2 billion, or 37 percent, of the entire school aid pie, which is proportional to its share of students.
The governor's budget was also notable for what it omitted. It would do very little to offset the gaping hole in the five-year capital plans for the State Transportation Department and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority which were created when state voters rejected a $3.8 billion bond act in November. Mr. Pataki promised to draw about $250 million from a reserve fund to keep construction on two large upstate highway projects under way, but he left the M.T.A. to contend with filling a $1.6 billion shortfall in its already shaky capital plan. In the next fiscal year alone, the M.T.A. would have to come up with $320 million to keep its projects going.
"There's $250 million in the budget to deal with the road and bridge portion, and nothing for mass transit, zero, zip, nada, capital money for transit projects," said Gene Russianoff, a staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, an advocacy group for subway riders.
For his part, Mr. Pataki said the M.T.A. would have to find a way to finance the projects on its own. Among the major capital projects that could be endangered are the Second Avenue subway, the extension of the N train to La Guardia Airport and a plan to connect the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central Terminal.
Assemblywoman Catherine T. Nolan, a Democrat of Queens and one of the four members of the review board that must approve the M.T.A. capital plan, said: "It was a surprising omission, given the gravity of the need. It's very upsetting that he proposed some pay-as-you-go for upstate and not for the metro area."
The budget does include increases of about $150 million for bridge and highway construction and about $120 million in new operating aid for mass transit systems, including $81 million for the M.T.A. That increase will do nothing to help the M.T.A. capital plan, however. 
Mr. Pataki plans to cut $322 million in Medicaid reimbursements to nursing homes. He argues that private nursing homes are reaping enormous profits and banking them instead of plowing them back into capital improvements and increasing staff size.
Assembly Democrats, however, said staffing shortages at nursing homes would only be worsened by the cuts and vowed to fight them.
"This is really back to the bad old days of Medicaid cuts," said Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried, a Manhattan Democrat and chairman of the health committee.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Chiquita Brands Faces Prospect of Bankruptcy
Chiquita Brands International, the largest producer of bananas in the world, says it cannot pay its debts and will probably have to go into bankruptcy court because, it contends, the Clinton administration has not been able to force the European Union to trade fairly.
 Chiquita says that European quotas against bananas grown in Latin America, as Chiquita's are, have cost the company $200 million a year since 1992 and have brought it to the brink of bankruptcy. Page A1. 

Affirmative-Action Rules Rejected
A federal appeals court struck down affirmative-action rules intended to increase job opportunities for minorities and women in the broadcasting industry after finding that they were unconstitutional. The decision was the second since 1998 in which the court vacated federal affirmative-action rules imposed on broadcasters, all but ending prospects that the industry will face obligations to recruit minorities and women in the near future. A16.

Inventories Increased in November
Inventories of unsold goods at American companies piled up in November as sales fell for the second consecutive month, adding to mounting evidence of a slumping economy. The inventory-to-sales ratio, which measures how long it would take businesses to exhaust their inventories at the current sales pace, rose to 1.36 months in November. C2.

Bayer and CuraGen in Joint Venture
Bayer and CuraGen announced that they would spend as much as $1.5 billion to use CuraGen's gene-hunting technology to develop drugs for diabetes and obesity. C3.

Globalstar Strives to Save Cash
Globalstar, the financially troubled satellite venture aimed at providing phone and data services to mobile customers beyond the range of land-based systems, said yesterday that it had stopped payments on loans and its other major debts to save cash. C3.

Calvin Klein Steps Up Warnaco Fight
Calvin Klein sent a letter to Warnaco Group, the company that manufactures Calvin Klein jeans and underwear, saying that Warnaco's debt was now large enough that it violated the terms of their licensing deal. C4.

Humble Beginnings on Wall Street
A dozen or so years after college, David H. Komansky, chairman of Merrill Lynch & Company, said he was a controller in a printing company, "at loose ends and going nowhere fast." At the urging of his father-in-law, he sought a position on Wall Street. "I interviewed with about 20 firms," he said. "I was going about it in a scientific way, taking the first firm that called. It was Merrill Lynch. I had $700 to my name." The Boss. C5.

President of CNNfn Steps Down
C. Shelby Coffey III, the president of CNN's financial news network, CNNfn, has resigned from his position to pursue the creation of a medical foundation. It was the second departure of a CNN executive since CNN's parent company, Time Warner, officially merged with America Online last week. C6.

California Avoids Blackouts Again
California narrowly escaped statewide blackouts for the second time in a week as the major utilities moved closer to bankruptcy and several plants shut down unexpectedly. A14.

HEADLINE: Mr. Pataki's Misstep on Schools 

 BODY:
Gov. George Pataki plunged into the problems of New York City's schools yesterday with an announcement that he would appeal a landmark judicial ruling that called for drastic increases in education aid to the city. That is a serious mistake that will only slow efforts to rectify the glaring deficiencies that led to Justice Leland DeGrasse's historic ruling that the state has failed to guarantee a sound, basic education to city schoolchildren as required by the State Constitution. At the same time, the governor proposed an $83.6 billion budget for the year beginning April 1 that will include a modest step toward ensuring that the city gets more education aid, though nowhere near the scale needed to remedy the defects cited by Justice DeGrasse.
 State officials contend that Mr. Pataki had to appeal because it would be irresponsible to commit the state to large expenditures on the basis of a single judge's opinion. We hope that Justice DeGrasse's decision is upheld by the appellate justices, putting it beyond further resistance by state officials. Meanwhile, the legal maneuvering does not excuse the Legislature from moving more forcefully to redress the deficiencies highlighted by Justice DeGrasse. 
 In his budget yesterday, Mr. Pataki increased school spending over all to more than $14 billion and proclaimed an important principle for Albany, that state school spending should be channeled to those districts that need it the most, and not to those with the most political clout. To reach that goal, the governor would consolidate about 70 percent of state aid now spread through nearly a dozen different programs into one program and give greater spending flexibility to each district -- a potentially useful approach provided it does not become an excuse for cutting vital spending in special education or other areas. He would ensure that every district gets at least a small increase in the consolidation and would spread the largest increases to New York City and needy upstate schools. 
But the overall increase in school spending would be only $382 million, not enough to make much of a difference for city schools. Democrats, led by Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, were right to promise yesterday to increase it. The governor's proposed budget also cut back on increases in city school aid in separate programs for early childhood education that had been agreed upon last year. These cuts need to be restored.
The Republican-controlled State Senate has long championed aid formulas that favor the G.O.P. base in the suburbs and upstate. Mr. Pataki said yesterday that he did not want a judge determining school aid formulas. But the best way to avert that possibility would be to ensure that the formulas do not deprive some students of their rights. The most persuasive part of Justice DeGrasse's ruling was not his attack on the arcane aid formulas. It was his conclusion that because of collapsed school buildings, unqualified teachers, poor textbooks and materials and other factors, New York City pupils are not getting the sound, basic education required by the State Constitution. To address that finding, the Legislature and governor need to concentrate less on formulas than on the situation in the schools themselves, and to make sure that the money is provided to overcome the system's shortcomings. Some of this money may have to be provided by the city's budget as well as the state's. 
In other areas, Mr. Pataki proposed a prudent budget that includes only limited tax cuts and spending restraint in other areas. He argued that with the state about to face an economic slowdown, this is no time to embark on expensive new programs. Governor Pataki is to be commended for his caution, but the cuts that he proposed for nursing homes, transit projects and revenue sharing for New York City are punitive and need to be restored by the Legislature.

HEADLINE: A Hong Kong Stalwart Resigns 

 BODY:
The early resignation of Anson Chan as Hong Kong's second-ranking official is an unmistakable warning that the territory's democratic safeguards are being eroded under Beijing's rule. Mrs. Chan, appointed by the last British governor, Chris Patten, as the independent director of Hong Kong's non-political civil service, has made herself a symbol of the autonomy China pledged to respect in Hong Kong when it resumed sovereignty over the territory in 1997. Her decision last week to step down more than a year before the scheduled end of her term signaled that she no longer felt able to guarantee Hong Kong's autonomy in the face of increasing interference from mainland China. 
 Some of the worst fears about heavy-handed Chinese rule over Hong Kong have so far not come to pass. Just last weekend some 1,200 members of the Falun Gong sect, which has been heavily persecuted on the mainland, were allowed to hold a mass gathering in a concert hall owned by the Hong Kong government. Hong Kong's economy has also recovered surprisingly well from the 1997 Asian financial crisis, which closely coincided with the transition to Chinese sovereignty. 
 But the news has been less encouraging on issues of democratic accountability and institutional independence in the territory. The chief executive, Tung Chee-hwa, is answerable only to Beijing, which appointed him. Under Mr. Tung's unpopular administration there have been serious encroachments by China on the authority of Hong Kong's courts, repeated government pressures on the news media and abuses of academic freedom. 
Mrs. Chan's efforts to keep the civil service clear of politics earned her a rebuke last fall from China's deputy prime minister, who called on her to be more supportive of Mr. Tung. Although Mrs. Chan now portrays her resignation as motivated simply by a desire to spend more time with her family, it seems fair to conclude that she could no longer in good conscience remain associated with this government. 
The West should not respond to her departure by resigning itself to further erosion of Hong Kong's autonomy. It should redouble its efforts to hold China to its commitment to respect Hong Kong's basic political and economic freedoms until at least 2047. Another credible and independent civil servant, Donald Tsang, stays on as Hong Kong's financial secretary and is a likely candidate to succeed Mrs. Chan.
The incoming Bush administration has indicated that it will apply more critical standards to China than the Clinton administration has, and it points out that in some areas Beijing's actions may conflict with American interests. Chinese pressure on Hong Kong's independent institutions is one obvious example.

HEADLINE: Pity the Vote Counter? What About the Caterer? 

BYLINE:  By MARIAN BURROS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 

 BODY:
Democrats and Republicans were not the only ones on tenterhooks for the 37 days it took to decide who would be the next president. Washington's caterers, party planners, calligraphers, equipment rental companies, not to mention hostesses, were also chewing their fingernails. 
 "It was a very tense time," said Carolyn Peachy, one of the most formidable of Washington's event and party planners. "We were in list hell for four weeks because there are so many new people. Now we are in response hell." 
 Parties for hundreds have been organized in less than a week. Invitations are not engraved; in fact, sometimes they are faxed. There is no time for comparison shopping among caterers. Invitations sent to 100 people bring last-minute responses from 200 as people call and ask to be invited. 
In an ordinary inaugural year there would have been plenty of time to ask a new member of the administration to be the guest of honor, to find out who should be be on the guest list and where to send the invitations. And plenty of time for the responses. But most of the planning for this inaugural did not start until Jan. 2. 
"There is so much you cannot do until you know who you are doing it for and what you are doing it around," Ms. Peachy said. "It's a question of style. They have things in Texas they do not have in Tennessee, such as margaritas."
And that is why Buffy Cafritz, a Washington hostess, is having margaritas instead of martinis this year at the quadrennial bipartisan after-the-balls party on Saturday night. 
Telescoping the planning into a shorter period does have some advantages. Clients cannot spend as much time making decisions about the menu, about the color of the tablecloths, even about which caterer they should hire.
"Decisions have to be made faster, and in some ways that's better because no one has time to dally," said Bill Holman, a partner in the catering company Design Cuisine. "It's let's go. Boom. Boom."
But time crunches can also be more costly. "If fabric for a tablecloth has to be flown in from California or North Carolina, they're going to put a premium on it," Mr. Holman said. "We were calling Turkey today looking for something. Now it's beyond insanity. The fabric people are saying, 'What's going on there?' and I tell them, it's the inaugural, now shut up and buy it and fly it in.' " 
Time constraints also put an end to the usual competition among caterers. "Literally, there was no time to collect bids," said Eric Michael, who with is brother, owns the catering firm Occasions. "No tastings, no haggling. We had fewer meetings, offered fewer menus. But in reality caterers at a certain level are pretty close in price."
Despite general inflation, catering prices over the last eight years have been fairly stable.
"I'm probably charging the same price per head I did eight years ago," said Carol Bloom, an owner of the catering firm Windows. "Everybody is on a tight budget. Nobody's asked me for beluga caviar or foie gras. The last time was when Reagan was inaugurated. We were importing food from everywhere and no one cared about the cost. For the last eight years, we've been doing mashed potatoes and meat loaf. Dinners used to be $175 a person. Now it's $75 to $110. "
Even the dinners for the Republican donors who contributed from $15,000 to $20,000 are "not a pull-out-all-the-stops dinner," said the caterer Eric Michael. "If it were, it would be four or five courses instead of three and the main course choices wouldn't include chicken." 
Dinner on Friday night for the big givers -- $175,000 over four years -- will start with lobster and caviar, though it is not beluga.
Corporations and politicians are sensitive about all the money that is being spent on inaugural festivities and many want to keep a low profile. A note next to the names of House members and senators who have reservations at the Caucus Room restaurant during the inauguration festivities says do not give out.
The Marriott Corporation, which is holding a dinner on Saturday at the Corcoran Gallery of Art for 400 people did not want its menu released.
But not all the new people coming to town are worried if they look like big spenders. "I've noticed a completely different clientele," said Jean Jacques Retourne, the maitre d'hotel at Citronelle. "They are Beverly Hills kind of people: women with a lot more makeup and men with a lot of Cartier watches. And I'm seeing a lot more fur coats." 

CORRECTION-DATE: January 19, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about preparations for inaugural events in Washington misspelled the surname of a partner in Design Cuisine, a caterer. He is Bill Homan, not Holman.

HEADLINE: Highlights of the Pataki Budget Plan 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed state budget for the fiscal year that begins April 1 is the seventh spending plan he has issued as governor. In his budget, he proposed overall spending of $83.6 billion, a figure that includes federal aid for programs like welfare and Medicaid. If enacted, the budget would represent a 5.3 percent increase in state spending.
 The portion to be raised by the state totals $57.4 billion, up 4.9 percent. Of that, the general fund, which includes most tax revenue, would rise 3.6 percent, to $41.3 billion, though the definition of the fund has changed over the years to artificially limit its growth. 
 The following are some proposals' highlights:

Education
Governor Pataki proposed consolidating 11 school aid categories and giving local districts far greater latitude in spending the money. Among the categories affected would be those for special education, and for students with limited knowledge of English -- moves that critics say could be the subject of court fights for years.
Over all, the governor proposed increasing school aid by $382 million, or 2.8 percent, to about $14.1 billion. When adjusted for inflation and the rising student population, that is a decline in spending per pupil.
The governor called for freezing spending for prekindergarten classes, reducing class sizes in elementary schools, and a package of related programs. Those efforts, the pet project of the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, were created under a 1997 agreement between the governor and the Legislature that called for them to grow to more than $600 million this school year, and $1.2 billion next year. Since the agreement, the governor has repeatedly tried, without success, to scale back the programs.
Mr. Pataki proposed strengthening the state law that prohibits school districts from using increases in state aid to make up for a decline in the districts' spending from their own tax revenues. And he proposed a system of incentives so that school systems that improve can receive more state money.

Health Care
Mr. Pataki proposed a 5 percent increase in Medicaid spending, the largest portion of the budget, to $32.4 billion. That reflects both the rising basic cost of Medicaid, the health insurance program primarily for the poor, and the expansion of programs enacted in recent years to help low-income working people obtain coverage. But he also said he would try to cut more than $300 million in Medicaid spending on nursing homes and at-home care.
About half the money for Medicaid programs is provided by the federal government, and the rest comes from the state and local governments.
Mr. Pataki is seeking a 20 percent increase in the Health Department budget, to almost $800 million. The rise would pay for a variety of programs already enacted, including increased subsidies for prescription drugs for the low-income elderly and efforts to combat the West Nile virus.

Tax Cuts
The governor's budget reflects $1.8 billion in tax cuts enacted in previous years that will take effect in the new fiscal year. He also proposed more than $500 million a year in new tax cuts, some of which would be phased in over several years.
Among those are several aimed at helping manufacturers and other businesses. The tax breaks would include expansion of the "empire zone" program, in which companies receive tax breaks for moving to blighted areas, and also help property owners cover the cost of cleaning up environmental contamination. And the governor is seeking to expand a program that reduces homeowners' property taxes.

Transportation
Mr. Pataki's budget proposal largely ignores the voter rejection in November of a $3.8 billion bond act for mass transit and highway improvements.
Of that figure, $1.6 billion was earmarked for New York City's subways and buses, and for the metropolitan region's commuter rail network. The money would have helped pay for such projects as the proposed Second Avenue subway line, and a connection between the Long Island Rail Road and Grand Central Terminal.
The governor proposed spending $250 million for highway projects to make up a small part of the loss of money from the bond act. 

CORRECTION-DATE: January 22, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Articles on Wednesday and Thursday about Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed budget referred imprecisely to his proposal for school aid. His office says that his proposal for a 2.8 percent increase, when adjusted for projected declines in inflation and student enrollment, would still result in a net increase. Only if inflation and enrollment followed current trends would it amount to a slight decline in real dollars.

HEADLINE: Inventories Rise; Sales Fall for 2nd Month 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 

 BODY:
Inventories of unsold goods at American companies piled up in November as sales fell for the second consecutive month, adding to mounting evidence of a slumping economy. 
 Stockpiles of goods nationwide rose 0.5 percent to a seasonally adjusted $1.22 trillion in November, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. Sales dropped 0.3 percent, to $896.3 billion. 
 "Weakening domestic demand kept inventory accumulation high," said Stan Shipley, a Merrill Lynch economist. 
The inventory-to-sales ratio, which measures how long it would take businesses to exhaust their inventories at the current sales pace, rose to 1.36 months in November, the highest since April 1999.

HEADLINE: PATAKI TO APPEAL DECISION BY JUDGE ON AID TO SCHOOLS 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA with ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 16 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki said today that New York State would appeal a landmark court ruling that ordered a major increase in spending on New York City schools, even as he proposed a budget that contained a small rise in school aid.
 The governor proposed combining 11 categories of state aid to local schools into a single lump sum, giving districts far greater latitude in spending the money. His plan, a bid to reform a notoriously cumbersome set of financing formulas, addresses one issue raised in the court case, but is likely to meet with resistance as the Legislature considers his budget in the coming months. Page B6. 
 At a news conference after his annual budget message, Mr. Pataki repeatedly refused to directly address last week's ruling by Justice Leland DeGrasse of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, except to say that he and the Legislature should determine state policy and decide how much to spend. 
"You can't have a judge running an entire educational system," he said. "We will challenge that decision because we want to make sure that that responsibility rests with the elected officials."
An appeal to the Appellate Division of Supreme Court, and after that possibly to the Court of Appeals, would almost certainly void the Sept. 15 deadline that Justice DeGrasse set for overhauling the way the state finances public education. It could delay a resolution until after the 2002 election, which would give the governor the chance to reverse some or all of a ruling that amounts to political dynamite as he faces re-election.
Complying with the judge's ruling could force the state to come up with more than $1 billion a year for the New York City schools, and any of the mechanisms for doing that would anger a significant part of the Legislature and the electorate.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Harold O. Levy, the city schools chancellor, expressed muted disappointment at news of the governor's plans, saying that they agreed with the judge's basic point that the city schools should receive more aid.
"I would have preferred that he didn't appeal," the mayor said at a news conference tonight at Gracie Mansion. "We believe that the judge's decision is right."
The governor deflected a barrage of questions about the court ruling by saying several times that he had all but eliminated the inequity that has historically sent less state aid per pupil to New York City schools than the statewide average.
But Justice DeGrasse's ruling dealt primarily with the adequacy of school financing, not just the equity. He found that the state had not met its obligation, under the State Constitution, to provide a "sound, basic education" to the city's children -- a goal that he said would simply require much more money.
He also concluded that the system violated federal civil rights laws, because black and Hispanic children are more likely than whites to receive a substandard education.
Mr. Pataki would not say, despite repeated prodding, whether he thought spending on New York City schools was adequate. But he made it plain that he believed that the judge had overstepped his authority and that parts of his ruling, at least, were simply wrong.
Several times, the governor noted that state aid to schools had risen sharply in the last four years, but he added, "Simply adding money isn't enough."
Mr. Pataki proposed today a $382 million increase in state aid to schools, to $14.1 billion in the next school year. Of that increase, $202 million would go to New York City.
In real terms -- adjusted for inflation and the rising student population -- what the governor has proposed is actually a slight decline in school aid, both statewide and for the city. This is, of course, merely the opening bid of an annual poker game, in which the governor starts with a low number that he knows the Legislature will drive up in budget negotiations.
Mr. Pataki made no mention of the court case or the judge's decision in his 30-minute budget address or in the budget documents. He took up the subject only under repeated questioning at the news conference.
The governor said he wanted to strengthen the state's "maintenance of effort" law, which seeks to prevent local governments from using state aid as cover for reducing their own spending on a function. He gave no details, but lawmakers in both parties said adjusting that law would go nowhere near addressing Justice DeGrasse's decision.
The judge's ruling, which capped an eight-year-old lawsuit filed by a group called the Campaign for Fiscal Equity, signaled a need to increase the budget for New York City's schools by $1 billion to $2 billion a year, in addition to the current $12 billion in city, state and federal aid.
Albany lawmakers say there are two obvious ways to do that. One would be to decrease spending on relatively wealthy suburban areas that are the governor's base of support. The other would be to simply come up with new money for schools, by taking it out of the state's coffers or forcing the city to produce the money. Either approach would carry a heavy political price for the governor, a Republican, and many legislators, Republican and Democratic.
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, a Democrat who is planning to run against Mr. Pataki next year, sees education funding as a potent issue, and he has repeatedly called the current system inadequate. "All his appeal does is delay the solution," Mr. McCall said today.
Though nearly every state political figure, regardless of party, had expected the governor to appeal, he had refused to say before today that he meant to do so. His aides said Mr. Pataki simply needed time to have his lawyers review the 200-page ruling, but Democrats here complained that he was ducking the issue.
"There is no reform in the education formula the governor proposed," said Sheldon Silver, a Democrat and the Assembly speaker. "I think the 'reform' word was used to mask cuts."
The state funnels aid to local school districts through more than 50 categories, most earmarked for specific purposes, like prekindergarten classes or computers. Behind each number is a bewildering set of formulas -- renegotiated each year in a fundamentally political process by the governor and legislative leaders -- that determine how much each district will get from each category.
Justice DeGrasse's ruling said the system should be scrapped and replaced with a more transparent approach that bases aid to districts on their actual needs. 
Immediately after the judge's decision, legislators from both major parties pointed out that the city's own spending on its schools had risen more slowly than the state's, and said any additional money should come from the city's own budget. That prompted Mr. Giuliani to insist that the state was to blame for the schools' problems, and should pay to fix them.
Mr. Pataki today proposed folding 11 of the largest school aid categories into one, so that about 70 percent of the aid to districts would be relatively unencumbered, up from about half. He would eliminate aid earmarked for special education, for aiding students with limited knowledge of English and for programs for gifted children, among others, letting districts spend the money as they see fit.
While legislators and local school officials generally laud the goal of giving districts greater flexibility, each of those pots of money represents a hard-won gain for an alliance of parents, lawmakers and school administrators, who might be reluctant to give it up.
Assemblyman Steven Sanders, a Manhattan Democrat who heads the Assembly Education Committee, dismissed the governor's proposal as "the makings of another lawsuit," saying he questioned both the legality and the propriety of the move.
Even the governor's chief legislative ally, Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader of the Senate, would not say in any detail what he thought of Mr. Pataki's proposal, calling it simply "a good beginning."
But aides to the governor said Justice DeGrasse's ruling could put pressure on the Legislature to accept Mr. Pataki's streamlining plan.
Michael A. Rebell, the executive director of the Campaign for Fiscal Equity, said he hoped that the Legislature would move ahead with the governor's plan to revamp the formulas, rather than wait for an appeals court to rule.
