HEADLINE: The Other Energy Crisis 

BYLINE:  By Daniel Yergin and Tom Robinson; Daniel Yergin is chairman and Tom Robinson is managing director of Cambridge Energy Research Associates.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
A new energy shock is rolling through millions of mailboxes -- this winter's natural gas bill. Surprised homeowners are finding bills as much as double last year's. The wholesale price (paid as gas enters pipelines for transit across the nation) has increased more than threefold.
 Natural gas does not have the drama of oil, but it provides 25 percent of the energy America uses. The price surge is becoming one of the drags on the economy. The importance of natural gas, an environmentally attractive fuel because it burns cleanly, will increase as the country becomes more dependent on it. While now 15 percent of our electricity is generated by burning natural gas, more than 90 percent of electricity from new plants now in development will come from it. 
 The last similar natural gas price shock was in the mid-1970's, and the cause was too much regulation. For decades, the federal government had set natural gas prices, and it had kept them too low, providing little incentive for drilling. The resulting shortage contributed to the economic disruptions of the 70's. It took a huge Congressional battle late in that decade to deregulate prices.
Many thought supplies were limited and deregulation would cause prices to skyrocket. But instead, increased competition drove prices down. As drillers responded to market forces and drilling technology advanced, supplies became ample. Residential prices, adjusted for inflation, fell 30 percent between 1985 and 1999.
So what happened this winter? We knew months ago that a big storm was brewing in the market. The oil and gas price collapse of 1998-99 forced energy companies to slash their budgets for developing new reserves of both oil and gas. That led to a decline in gas production capacity in the United States of about 6 percent since 1997.
Meanwhile, the strong economy and new gas-burning power plants coming on line led to increased consumption. Then came this very cold winter, with average temperatures across the country in November and December lower than in any other year in the 106 years weather data have been collected. Heating demand increased in December 2000 over December 1999 by an amount greater than the annual consumption of Finland, Norway and Sweden combined.
So is this yet another example of deregulated markets failing? Quite the contrary -- and these events are quite unlike those in California's power market. The high gas prices in December led to fuel switching and plant shutdowns, market-driven responses that helped prevent severe problems like those in the 1970's.
And energy companies are already stepping up their investments. Drilling for natural gas is beginning to rise, and development efforts are tapping into new gas fields in the deep waters of the Gulf of Mexico, off the shore of eastern Canada and in the Arctic.
There are, unfortunately, two constraints. One, a shortage of workers and equipment, is a legacy of the price collapse two years ago. The other is the time it takes to get new supplies into the system; much new gas will not be available until 2003 or beyond.
Those who forget the problems before deregulation may be tempted to turn back to price caps. That would be disastrous, stifling the very investments that will help lower prices in the future. One lasting lesson of a half century of energy policy is that markets will respond a lot faster than old-fashioned regulation.

HEADLINE: Many Sense the Good Times Slipping Away 

BYLINE:  By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: JANESVILLE, Wis., Jan. 15 

 BODY:
When he glimpsed the stone behemoth rising out of the prairie here in southern Wisconsin last fall, Paul Terpstra thought it was a new grammar school, or maybe an apartment complex.
 "And then I realized, 'Oh my goodness, it's a single-family house,' " recalled Mr. Terpstra, a 40-year-old engineer. "And I thought to myself, 'Can this extravagant spending go on forever?' " 
 But just as a glorious autumn slipped into slap-in-the-face winter, Mr. Terpstra has sensed the economy starting to grow cold. Stocks have tumbled, growth has slowed, and companies are cutting back. An old mill here is moving much of its production overseas, and just across the Illinois state line, 10 miles or so to the south, the Motorola plant announced today that it would lay off 2,500 workers.
Add to all that the uncertainty that accompanies a changing of the guard in the White House, and many Americans now seem to be growing skittish about an economy that once seemed unstoppable.
"It was just too good for too long," said Mr. Terpstra, who had stopped at the library on Main Street to check out a book. "Now you can feel there's an edginess." 
Janesville, a middle-class town of 60,000, is the home of a General Motors plant that makes the Suburban sport utility vehicle, a prime symbol of the fat, hard-charging economy. On a shipping lot near the plant, a sea of shiny new vehicles reflects the nation's voracious appetite, and its ability to foot the bills, at least for now.
After taking prosperity for granted for years, people in Janesville say they can hear the economy's brakes starting to screech. 
"We've been overdue for a pullback," said Raymond Dooley, a retired farmer and insurance salesman here. "We've forgotten that it's natural for the business cycle to swing both ways. Let's just hope it's not too rough."
In much of the country, people are just now seeing signs of economic slowing, and starting to voice fears about a recession. But for workers in the dot-com world, brutal reality hit months ago.
Richard Friedhoff, a 45-year-old technology consultant who works in Silicon Valley, said high-flying dreams had given way to a hard-nosed pragmatism there.
"You used to have everyone in their third year of college flying out here with a business plan with aspirations of becoming fabulously wealthy by age 30," Mr. Friedhoff said. "Those days are over. There is zero interest in people without credible track records, solid ideas and management skills. No one even wants to be caught talking to such a person in a Starbucks."
To be sure, there is scarcely a consensus that the economy is headed for the tank.
President Clinton, who views prosperity as a gemstone of his legacy, says the country's economic foundation remains rock solid. But President-elect George W. Bush has been talking about the slowdown for weeks, conveying a none-too-subtle message that he should not be blamed for any economic distress early in his administration. 
To some Americans, the reality falls somewhere between the roses and the rocks.
Jennifer Robischon, co-owner of an art gallery in Denver, said some economic vagaries were to be expected, given the changes brought by an election year.
"We're not running for the hills," Ms. Robischon said. "The stock market is reflecting a political year."
She added, "They seem to get scared quicker on either coast than in the middle of the country."
Frightened or not, plenty of people in Janesville say they are bracing for leaner times. Jason Dowd, 30, who stays at home to care for four young children while his wife manages a restaurant, said he and his family had started to cut back on discretionary spending. They bought much less during the recent Christmas season than a year ago, he said.
"There's just a lot of uncertainty now," said Mr. Dowd, expressing concerns that the new president would chart a different economic course. "People were used to Clinton. They felt comfortable. Now they're not so sure what Bush is going to change, or if it will work."
Of the Bush tax-cut proposal, which the president-elect has most recently promoted as insurance against a recession, Mr. Dowd was skeptical, saying that whatever version emerged from Congress would most likely favor the affluent. And a Republican president, he said, is likely to tolerate higher unemployment rates.
Not everyone, though, saw a slowing economy as all bad. Wendy Zanoni, a 33-year-old customer service representative for a utility company here, said her family was counting on even further drops in interest rates. "We're waiting to refinance the house," Ms. Zanoni said.
But for Mike Fertal, a student searching for part-time work in Chicago, the hunt has suddenly become tougher. "I can't find a job," said Mr. Fertal, who had stopped at Marshall Field in Chicago to file an application. "I've gone to Armani, Kenneth Cole and some of the other independent stores. All of them are cutting back on their part-time help."
Kelly Skinner, 29, of Dothan, Ala., said she and her husband, who has just completed his residency as a doctor, were trying to pay off credit-card debt and putting off "life-changing decisions," uncertain what the economy would look like six months from now.
Most people say they are not sure about the cause of any slowdown. But they tend to agree that Americans cannot forever buoy the economy by spending to the hilt. And they say people have become more than a bit spoiled.
"We've gotten to the point where people expect that the world owes you a great big house and a great big fancy new car," said Mr. Terpstra, the engineer. "For a while, almost every new house was being built with a three-car garage. That wasn't enough. Now they're building them with four-car garages."
He shook his head and managed a pained chuckle.
"Is that what we really need?" he said. "In this country, we pay so much attention to image that sometimes we lose sight of reality."

HEADLINE: December Figures Point to a Slowdown 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 

 BODY:
A sharp drop in industrial output in December provided strong evidence of a slowing economy, while a moderating inflation index appeared to clear any obstacles that could block another interest rate cut.
 The nation's industrial engine sputtered to its biggest drop in two and a half years last month, while consumer prices rose only modestly at the end of a year in which a surge in energy costs pushed overall prices to their biggest gain in 10 years, the government said today. 
 Production by factories, mines and utilities fell 0.6 percent in December, the third consecutive decline and the biggest since June 1998, the Federal Reserve said. It was the first such string of declines since the recession of 1991. Output dropped 0.3 percent in November and in October. Analysts had expected a 0.5 percent fall in December. 
In a separate report today, the Federal Reserve cited manufacturing as one of the many areas of the economy that experienced a softening in December.
In its anecdotal beige book summary of economic conditions, the Fed also pointed to disappointing holiday sales, cooling home building and softening commercial real estate activity as signs the economy slowed last month.
The Labor Department reported today that the Consumer Price Index, the main inflation gauge, rose only 0.2 percent in December, identical to its November gain, and matching expectations, as higher prices for home fuel, utilities and food more than offset lower costs for gasoline and clothing.
The core index, which excludes energy and food, rose 0.1 percent in December after a 0.3 percent gain in the previous month. It was the smallest increase in a year.
In December, energy costs rose a slim 0.2 percent as lower prices of gasoline were more than offset by large increases in the cost of home fuel and utilities.
Food prices were up 0.5 percent in December after being unchanged in the previous month. Prices for clothing fell 0.4 percent.

HEADLINE: Internet Research Firm Announces Layoffs of 80 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
Jupiter Media Metrix, the Internet research firm in Silicon Alley, is laying off about 80 employees because of slackening revenue, particularly in the last quarter, company officials said yesterday.
 The job cuts will reduce the company's work force of 1,000 by 8 percent and are expected to save the company $7 million. 
 The layoffs make Jupiter Media Metrix one of the first older Silicon Alley companies to make drastic cutbacks in response to the economic slowdown. 
According to Jupiter Media Metrix's third-quarter financial statements, the company lost about $10.9 million on revenues of $65.2 million in the first nine months of 2000, up from a loss of $5.6 million on revenues of $39.9 million during the same period a year earlier.
The company expects revenue for the fourth quarter of 2000 to be $38.2 million to $38.5 million, instead of the $39.5 million to $42 million the company had earlier forecast.
"The rapidly softening economy directly impacted our revenues, and left us with expenses that were based on previously planned, higher growth rates," Tod Johnson, the chairman and chief executive of Jupiter Media Metrix, said yesterday.
Jupiter Media Metrix's stock price rose 5 percent, or about 43 cents, to close at $8.43 yesterday. The stock is down 82 percent from its 52-week high of $47.87 last March.
Jupiter Media Metrix was formed last year by the merger of Jupiter Communications, an Internet analysis firm, and Media Metrix, an online research company, which essentially became the Nielsen Media Research of the Internet industry by providing data on visits to Web sites.
Joshua Harris, an early Silicon Alley pioneer, founded Jupiter in 1986, and by the mid-1990's it had grown into one of the first Internet consulting and analysis firms.
Mr. Harris went on to found Pseudo Program, an online television company that went out of business last year.
Sandra Notardonato, an analyst at Adams Harkness & Hill of Boston, said: "The biggest flaw is that you can no longer be an Internet research analysis firm. You have to be broad-based, and it has to include existing technologies and emerging technologies. You can't just be an Internet company."
Ms. Notardonato said that many of Jupiter Media Metrix's competitors, like Forrester Research of Cambridge, Mass., have made the necessary adjustments.
"About a year ago, Jupiter was in the right spot in the Internet economy, but it is very difficult to move as rapidly as the market changes," she said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Technology Shares Push Nasdaq Higher as the Dow Falls

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Technology stocks rose yesterday, but gave up hefty gains made earlier in the day. Blue-chip stocks fell even as the latest economic reports reinforced investors' thinking that more Federal Reserve interest rate cuts are in store.
 The Nasdaq composite index ended the day up 64.23 points, or 2.45 percent, at 2,682.78, the highest close in about a month. Earlier, the Nasdaq reached a session high of 2,756.63. More than 2.81 billion shares traded hands on the Nasdaq yesterday in one of its busiest days. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 68.32 points, or 0.64 percent, to 10,584.34. And the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 2.82 points, or 0.21 percent, to 1,329.47.
Investors took cues yesterday from the December Consumer Price Index, which rose 0.1 percent, falling short of the expected rise of 0.2 percent. The report encouraged the buying of technology stocks but also led to defensive selling, which in turn weighed on the Dow.
The rate excludes food and energy. The overall December index grew 0.2 percent, matching expectations.
Intel, the most active Nasdaq stock yesterday, fell 88 cents, to $30.50, after spending most of the day higher. The company warned late Tuesday that investors should expect a 15 percent decline in first-quarter revenue.
The Dow was also held down by Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, which fell $3.50, to $110, after reporting quarterly earnings that were below expectations. 3M blamed slowing growth in the United States and the strong dollar for the shortfall.
Leading the gains was Juniper Networks, which provides Internet networking services. Its shares rose $8.19, to $136.19, after beating quarterly earnings estimates and raising its full-year forecast.
The chip equipment maker Novellus Systems climbed $5.63, to $44.38, and the communications chip maker Applied Micro Circuits jumped $10, to $80.38, after they both beat expectations.
I.B.M., which announced better-than-expected earnings after the markets closed yesterday, closed up $3.94, or 4.25 percent, to $96.69.
Investors are hoping more cuts in the Federal Reserve rate can cushion the slowing economy and keep the slowdown from cutting too deeply into corporate profits.
The Fed cut interest rates for the first time in one and a half years on Jan. 3, lowering its key rate target by half a percentage point. --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices rose for a second day as financial problems continued for two of California's biggest utilities and investors sought the relative safety of government debt.
"People are starting to realize that the problems in California are worse than they thought, and there's a flight to quality" into Treasuries, said Peter Cordrey, who was buying two-year notes for the $130 billion he helps invest at Prudential Securities in Newark.
The benchmark 10-year note rose 16/32, to 104 12/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell 5.16 percent from 5.23 percent.
The most active 30-year bond rose 17/32, to 110 19/32, as its yield fell to 5.52 percent from 5.60. Thomas Connor, head of government bond trading at J. P. Morgan Chase, said the move came after the Treasury announced that it would buy back as much as $1.75 billion in 30-year bonds today.
Bonds and notes advanced after a California lawmaker said the state's two biggest utilities, the Pacific Gas and Electric unit of PG & E and the Southern California Edison unit of Edison International, were expected to declare bankruptcy, even if a bill intended to maintain the flow of power was passed, investors said.
Edison defaulted on some outstanding notes, and on payments to power generators and the California Power Exchange yesterday. Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service lowered credit ratings on both utilities to below investment grade, or junk status.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL; 
Some Slights Endure for Winfield

BYLINE:  By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
During the eighth inning of a Saturday night game at Yankee Stadium in mid-September 1985, George Steinbrenner plopped down in the first seat of the first row of the press box, a sheet of paper in his hands. The second-place Yankees were a few outs away from losing a second successive game to the first-place Toronto Blue Jays, and Steinbrenner was not happy.
 Displaying the statistics on the paper that showed Ken Griffey 0 for 8 for the three-game series, Don Baylor 0 for 7 and Dave Winfield 3 for 11, the Yankees' owner said to a young reporter: "Where is Reggie Jackson? We need a Mr. October or a Mr. September. Winfield is Mr. May." 
 Contrary to popular misconcepion, Steinbrenner did not label Winfield as Mr. May (in contrast to Jackson's Mr. October) for his 1-for-22 performance in the 1981 World Series. But the timing is important only for historical accuracy. Winfield would not have appreciated the derogatory remark whenever it was uttered. 
"It was irreverent, it was off-color, it was improper, it doesn't fit," Winfield said yesterday at a news conference for him and Kirby Puckett, the two newest members of the Hall of Fame. "I always rejected it. It doesn't apply. It was an inappropriate remark at the time. I didn't appreciate it then."
Steinbrenner, who did so much to make Winfield's life miserable in the eight-plus years he played for the Yankees, never appreciated the type of player he had. All he did was look at Winfield's hitting statistics. When they lacked lusty numbers, he criticized Winfield.
Unlike players and managers from other teams, Steinbrenner never understood the contributions Winfield made with his outfield defense and his base running. Memory might be playing tricks, but it's hard to recall when the man stopped at second on a single to the outfield. First to third was routine for Winfield.
Asked what he missed about no longer playing baseball, Winfield said: "I miss going first to third in somebody's face. I miss throwing someone out from the outfield."
Later he explained those facets of his game.
"Going from first to third, scoring from first on a double, for a big guy, those are things I really enjoyed," he said. "You can hit a ground ball right at an outfielder and if you're busting your backside from home plate, you have a chance for a double. Those are things I enjoyed. Playing defense is something you have to work on and something you have to love. When I first started, I wasn't a good defensive outfielder. I focused on it, enjoyed it, worked on things like charging the baseball. Little things that you do consistently become big things. Defense was a big part of my game."
Steinbrenner has belatedly recognized Winfield as an all-around player. He issued a statement yesterday expressing his delight at Winfield's election to the Hall and said he was "probably one of the greatest athletes I have ever known." 
Steinbrenner also acknowledged the problems the two men encountered, though he didn't say he instigated them, and said that "today we are good friends." Winfield didn't go that far, but said more than once that Steinbrenner had "apologized for what he's said and what he's done."
The Yankees will honor their latest Hall of Famer with a day this season and may retire the No. 31 he wore with them. Contrary to his success with other players, Steinbrenner is not expected to be able to buy Winfield's selection of the Yankees cap to appear on his Cooperstown plaque. Winfield may opt for the Yankees, but not because of any economic overtures from their owner.
Winfield tried hard yesterday to avoid the negative aspects of his time in New York, a city he said he loved and never wanted to leave as a player. "Everybody used to tell me, 'You should leave, you don't have to endure the circumstances,' " he said. "I said, 'I'm not going anywhere.' I had laid my roots here."
But he begrudgingly talked briefly about his 1984 competition with Don Mattingly for the American League batting championship. Not the race itself, but the undercurrent that engulfed the clubhouse. Most of their teammates were clearly pulling for Mattingly, raising questions about the possibility of race as a factor.
"There was nothing between Donnie and I," Winfield said. "We lived different lives. He was a young player who had a lot of support. I just know what I experienced the entire year. It was much different than my teammate did at the same time."
Mattingly won the title, .343 to .340, by collecting four hits to Winfield's one in the final game. After their last at-bats, the players clasped hands and walked off the field together. But Winfield was gone from the clubhouse when the door was opened to reporters.
"You wonder sometimes, where was the support during the course of the year?" Winfield said, reluctantly recalling his departure that day. "I made sure I packed my stuff because everybody might say, 'I was with him all year.' Aaahhh, that wasn't the case. I went through a lot. If I had won the batting race, I probably would have talked not just about the race; I probably would have talked about a lot of other things. But I didn't win and I'm not going to talk about it. Donnie won, put the spotlight on him. He deserved it. There wasn't a platform, so I wasn't going to make one."
Winfield has a big new platform now. He plans to use it only for positive matters, not unappetizing batting-race memories or labels.

GRAPHIC: Photo: At a news conference with Kirby Puckett, right, Dave Winfield discussed the highs and lows of his career. (Jeff Zelevansky for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: After a Last Push to Find Victims, Salvadorans Hope to Rebuild 

BYLINE:  By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR, Jan. 17 

 BODY:
With the death toll from Saturday's earthquake nearing 700 and no survivors found in recent days, Salvadoran authorities are preparing to shift their energies from search and rescue to rebuilding. Today they announced what is expected to be a final push by international teams to find those people who were buried with their homes when a wall of dirt smothered the neighborhood of Las Colinas in a suburb of the capital. 
 "That is one of the hardest decisions of the coming days," said Mario Acosta, the minister of the interior and president of the National Emergency Committee. "The families of many still hold on to the hope of finding loved ones alive. It is a possibility, and that is why we sent out today scout teams to give a response to the families. By Friday, we will end it and enter another stage." 
 After several days of local speculation that some cut-off communities were devastated by deaths, rescue crews found structural damage but few new fatalities. Government agencies have stopped issuing estimates of how many people are still missing, they said, because more and more people are turning up after having been unable to communicate with frantic relatives.
Crews working with everything from machetes and saws to dynamite and bulldozers have cleared many roads, and food, water and medicines are beginning to flow even into remote areas. Public health specialists, worried about epidemics from poor sanitation, have begun to analyze medical needs and assess how to rebuild damaged hospitals where some 800 beds are now unusable. 
The bigger challenge will be replacing more than 20,000 homes, especially in poor rural communities where houses were built with fragile wood and adobe. Some 47,000 other homes were damaged.
Nearly 46,000 people were ordered to evacuate their homes, including 800 families who had to leave a government shelter on Tuesday night after an unusually strong aftershock cracked its walls. 
"The most important part after the immediate emergency is the physical and psychological reconstruction," Mr. Acosta said. "There is not one family who has not been touched by this earthquake." 
International aid is still arriving, and the government has hired two accounting firms to ensure that all assistance ends up helping people and not sitting idle or diverted for profit. 
Relief workers long active in the region said the earthquake was but the latest blow to this country, which was not only battered by Hurricane Mitch in 1998 but was also recovering from a deadly dengue fever epidemic. "They couldn't have been more weak or vulnerable to begin with," said Paul Bell, regional director of the Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance of the United States Agency for International Development. 
Still, President Francisco Flores urged citizens this week to face their challenge with the same courage and stoicism as past generations and said that such calamities had helped build "much of the Salvadoran character."
Yet while he and government ministers appealed for solidarity, opposition members of Congress seeking concessions were blocking the proposed budget, possibly slowing the redirecting of credits from the Inter-American Development Bank that were to be used for rebuilding.
"This is not the time for political illusions," Mr. Acosta said. "This is the time for all of us to dress in blue and white, our national colors, and help."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
I.B.M. Swims Against Tide With Strong Profit Report

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
I.B.M. reported quarterly earnings yesterday that were slightly better than Wall Street's expectations, and perhaps more encouragingly, it told investors that it was "comfortable" with analysts' earnings projections for this year.
 Unlike a string of technology companies that have warned investors that a slowing economy has caused them to scale back expectations for 2001, including Intel as recently as Tuesday, I.B.M. said most of its business showed few signs of weakening. 
 I.B.M. executives said the company's strength overseas, its emphasis on selling a wide variety of services in addition to hardware, and its focus on large global customers that intend to keep investing to expand their electronic commerce capabilities helped shield the company from some of the pressures felt by other technology giants. 
In addition, the company said it was benefiting from the rollout of several important new products, including its latest mainframe computer, and payments from other companies eager to use I.B.M. electronics innovations in their own products. Royalty income alone topped $1.6 billion last year, John Joyce, I.B.M.'s chief financial officer, said. That figure went beyond the "more than $1 billion" estimate that I.B.M. used in previous reports. 
"We look forward to another good year at I.B.M.," said Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the company's chairman and chief executive, in a statement issued with the earnings.
Last year certainly ended on a high note for I.B.M., the world's largest computer company. It said it earned $2.67 billion, or $1.48 a diluted share, in the last three months of 2000, a 32 percent increase from the $1.12 a share reported a year earlier, when earnings were $2.09 billion. Revenue was nearly $25.62 billion, up 6 percent from $24.18 billion in the last three months of 1999. 
The earnings were 2 cents a share more than the consensus forecast of $1.46 reported by First Call/Thomson Financial, which tracks analysts' projections. The revenue projection for the quarter had been $25.5 billion.
But the quarter was stronger than those figures suggest.
Revenue grew 12 percent if the effect of the strengthening dollar on sales in foreign currencies is removed. In each of the company's major businesses, profits and revenue grew faster in the fourth quarter than at any other time in 2000, sending the company into this year with strong momentum.
"They're cooking," said Ulric Weil, an analyst who follows the computer industry for Friedman, Billings, Ramsey in Arlington, Va. "They beat the revenue consensus, despite the really negative currency impact."
The news was even better than optimistic investors anticipated. I.B.M.'s share rose $3.94, to $96.69, during trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The earnings were released after trading ended. After hours, the stock rose as high as $103.44.
In the company's conference call with analysts, Mr. Joyce acknowledged that I.B.M.'s personal computer business and hard disk drive business faced a tough climate. He noted, though, that I.B.M. had sharply reduced its involvement in the home computer market last year as part of its drive to return the unit to profitability after years of losses. Driven by sales of I.B.M.'s laptops and small servers for e-businesses, the company's personal computer business was profitable, with sales increasing 15 percent in the fourth quarter, despite declining desktop sales.
Mr. Joyce also cautioned that I.B.M. would have to reduce its expectations if the economy took a significant turn for the worse. "We don't have a better crystal ball than you do," he told analysts. 
But for the moment, the news is upbeat. Parts shortages that crimped sales in the third quarter have largely abated, although the company said it did not expect to catch up with demand for its popular new z900 mainframe before the end of the current quarter. 
I.B.M. also said it had largely cleaned up another sore spot in third-quarter earnings: poor execution of sales plans by its software sales force. While reported revenue for that segment were down slightly from a year ago at $3.6 billion, they represent a 6 percent gain when adjusted for the currency changes.
I.B.M. hardware sales grew 10 percent from a year ago, to $11.4 billion, with profit margins jumping 3.5 percentage points to top 30 percent.
I.B.M.'s services business, with $9.2 billion in revenue, a 5 percent increase from a year ago, ended 2000 with a backlog of $85 billion, up sharply from $60 billion a year ago. 
Europe and Asia were particularly strong performers for I.B.M. during the quarter. European revenue of $7.4 billion represented an 18 percent increase in the quarter from 1999, once currency adjustments were taken into account. Mr. Joyce characterized it as the region's strongest performance ever for the company.
But revenues in the Asia-Pacific region, which totaled $5 billion, grew at an even faster rate of 20 percent, adjusted to 1999 currency translation rates. 
Some analysts said the quarter was bolstered by the introduction of the z900, pent-up demand for RS6000 computers that were not sold in the third quarter because of parts shortages and the arrival in December of upgraded storage products. "They had three product cycles at their backs," said Thomas Kraemer, who follows the company for Merrill Lynch. "That's as good as it gets."
I.B.M. said strong efforts to use the Internet to become more productive also contributed to its success. Mr. Joyce said that I.B.M. had cut $1.5 billion from customer service expenses by handling more queries electronically and that it saved $350 million by using the Internet for internal training. The company also saved money by selling $9 billion in goods -- 65 percent more than a year ago -- via IBM.com.
"The good thing about this is that I don't have to change my model," said John B. Jones Jr., an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney in San Francisco. "I've been bullish and I had gotten nervous."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
BOEING BEATS 4TH-QUARTER ESTIMATES, BUT STOCK DROPS

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 Boeing said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profits rose 36 percent, beating Wall Street forecasts, as it squeezed more cash out of its aerospace business despite shrinking revenue. But the shares of Boeing, the world's largest maker of aircraft, fell $2.25, to $58.75, after three major airlines reported weaker quarterly earnings, hinting that future aircraft orders would suffer. Boeing, based in Seattle, said it earned $877 million, or $1.01 a diluted share, excluding one-time charges, up from $662 million, or 74 cents a share, a year earlier. The results beat analysts' average expectations by 10 cents a share.

HEADLINE: Pataki's New School Plan Falls Short of Necessary Overhaul, Officials Say 

BYLINE:  By KATE ZERNIKE 

 BODY:
School officials across the state said yesterday that Gov. George E. Pataki's budget fell far short of the bold proposal they believe is necessary to change the way the state finances its schools, offering neither enough new money nor substantial changes.
 When a state judge last week threw out the formulas the state used to determine how much aid it offered schools, saying the formula shortchanged New York City, officials at many districts outside the city cheered the decision. They said the system was arbitrary and unfair to them as well. 
 But yesterday, the schools said that the revised formula proposed in the governor's budget on Tuesday merely tinkered with the financing and that his decision to appeal the judge's ruling suggested that he did not believe major change was necessary. The new formula would not solve the fundamental flaws for most districts in how aid is distributed, they said, adding that in some areas it might actually create more problems. For example, a district that had a high number of learning-disabled students might get far less aid for them than it did for its other students.
"The genie is out of the bottle," said Lawrence M. Cummings, lead coordinator of the Midstate School Finance Consortium, which represents more than 200 districts in the state. "With the judge's decision, enough people have said we have to have dramatic reform. I don't think what the governor has proposed is going to be sufficient to stem that tide."
Under the current formula, the state gives money based on the relative wealth of a community, a figure derived from calculating how much its property is worth and how much income its residents earn. The state earmarks the money for a few dozen categories, allowing districts to spend the money for only those specific purposes. 
The governor would essentially change the formula by collapsing 11 of the categories into one called flex aid, which would allow districts to spend the money however they choose. He would also increase state aid by $382 million, to $14.1 billion in the 2001-2002 school year. But adjusted for inflation and for increases in school enrollment, that would actually amount to a slight decrease.
The districts welcomed the flexibility. In some years, they have had to return money they desperately needed for reducing class size because they did not have enough classroom space to do so. Under the flex aid formula, those districts would be able to use the money toward other expenses. 
But in some ways, the new formula might also hurt them, superintendents and other school officials said. The formula still caps state aid to districts. Special education, for example, now a separate category, would be included in flex aid. Special education is a federal entitlement, so if many students in a district need these expensive programs, the state money it gets to pay for that may exceed the total flex aid cap, preventing the district from using the money for other items.
"One of the problems with the new formula is that it did not do away with these caps," said Nathaniel Clay, superintendent of the Hempstead School District. "There's nothing in what Pataki is proposing that begins to even put in place what the judge recommended."
Many superintendents, particularly those from suburban cities, say that even taking into account factors like income and tax base, the formula would not provide a fair share of their costs, compared with what it gives other districts. Across the state, there are wide disparities between how much the state gives toward districts' per pupil spending and how much the districts contribute. 
On average, school districts pay $1.36 for every $1 the state contributes, according to State Education Department figures for 1997-98. But while the towns in Hamilton County in northeastern New York, which spend the most local money per student, pay $6.50 for every $1 the state contributes, those in Allegany County, to the southwest, pay 36 cents for each dollar they get from the state.
There is also a disparity between state spending in districts in counties with the same relative wealth. Those in Columbia County, for example, paid an average of $6,042 per pupil in 1997-98 and received $3,664 per pupil from the state. New York City, which is slightly wealthier, paid less, $4,158, and received more, $3,680.
The problem with the proposed new formula, districts said, is that it does not fundamentally restructure how the wealth is calculated, or what percentage the state contributes.
Any new formula, many superintendents and board members said, should require a minimum threshold of local spending. Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky of Westchester proposed a bill yesterday to do so. 
Mr. Cummings, of the Midstate School Finance Consortium, said a revised formula should include a foundation budget, which would set a minimum amount each community must spend on its schools, and a minimum amount to be contributed by the state. Other states faced with similar lawsuits have done this.
"You cannot reform this incrementally," Mr. Cummings said. 
And that, most agreed, will take more money. "He still has not provided sufficient funds to place all children on track to meet the new achievement standards," said Pamela Betheil, president of the Eastern Suffolk County Board of Cooperative Educational Services. "They have to give more money."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 22, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Articles on Wednesday and Thursday about Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed budget referred imprecisely to his proposal for school aid. His office says that his proposal for a 2.8 percent increase, when adjusted for projected declines in inflation and student enrollment, would still result in a net increase. Only if inflation and enrollment followed current trends would it amount to a slight decline in real dollars.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY BRIEFING: HARDWARE; 
CHIP MAKER MISSES FORECASTS

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 Advanced Micro Devices reported fourth-quarter net income yesterday that narrowly trailed forecasts and joined its larger rival Intel in predicting that slack sales of PC's would hurt first-quarter sales. Advanced Micro Devices said its net income for the quarter more than doubled to $177.9 million, or 53 cents a share, from $65.1 million, or 21 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 21 percent, to $1.18 billion. Analysts had expected the Sunnyvale, Calif.-based company to earn 55 cents a share. In light of weak demand for personal computers and slowing worldwide economies, the chip maker said it expected that normal seasonal weakness in first-quarter demand for PC processors coupled with the effects of excess PC inventories in distribution channels would hurt PC processor sales in the first quarter of 2001.

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: EUROPE; 
STRONG JOB PICTURE IN BRITAIN

BYLINE:  By Alan Cowell 

 BODY:
 British unemployment in December remained as low as it has been in 25 years, and the tight labor market drove wages up at a 4.2 percent annual rate in the previous three months, the government reported. 
Rising labor costs led analysts to back away from forecasts of an imminent cut in interest rates and suggested that the British economy was not slowing down the way the American economy appears to be. But with inflation well below the government's 2.5 percent target and the American slowdown considered likely to affect Britain eventually, investors still expect a rate cut later this year. HEADLINE: California in State of Emergency Over Power 

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 

 BODY:
Gov. Gray Davis of California declared a state of emergency late this evening after the state was forced to cut power temporarily for hundreds of thousands of people on a swath from Oregon to Bakersfield. 
 While planned, controlled blackouts have occurred before in the state on a modest scale, this was the first time that they were carried out over such a large area. And despite frantic efforts by utilities and state officials to line up enough power for later in the week, the prospect of continuing blackouts put pressure on the governor to step in and take emergency actions. 
 Governor Davis provided few specifics in his announcement, other than saying that the state's two largest utilities, Pacific Gas and Electric and Southern California Edison, were on the verge of being forced into bankruptcy and that he was ordering a state agency, the Department of Water Resources, to become the principal purchaser of electricity from the big generating companies that supply the state. 
"The imminent threat of widespread and prolonged disruption of electrical power to California's emergency services, law enforcement, schools, hospitals, homes, businesses and agriculture constitutes a condition of extreme peril to the safety of persons and property within the state which, by reason of its magnitude, is likely to be beyond the control of the services, personnel, equipment, and facilities of any single county or city," Governor Davis said in his declaration.
The emergency declaration recognized that one of the factors that caused the blackouts and threatened more in the days ahead was the fact that the big generating companies were resisting selling their power to utilities that might never be able to pay for it. The governor said four of these generators, Duke, Southern, Reliant and Dynergy, were prepared to finally put the utilities into bankruptcy court, but had agreed to wait now that the state, which enjoys a solid credit rating, had stepped in and would be the primary buyer of their power. The governor said the arrangement was contingent on the Legislature's passing a bill on Thursday giving the state the ability to buy power on a large scale.
Today's blackouts began at 11:40 a.m. and ran for three hours in Central and Northern California. About 500,000 utility customers at a time in checkerboard patterns were denied power by Pacific Gas and Electric for about an hour, then had service restored as another block was blacked out.
For weeks a financial crisis at utilities, transmission bottlenecks and shortfalls in electricity generation have pushed the state's teetering power system to the brink. Today, as those financial problems worsened, a sudden drop in hydroelectric generation pushed the system over it. 
There were signs that financial concerns were a critical factor in the blackouts. Pacific Gas and Electric and Southern California Edison have said they are being driven toward bankruptcy because the soaring price of power on the wholesale market has risen far higher than what they are able to charge their customers by state regulations. 
Southern California Edison has already had to delay repayment of nearly $600 million in debt this week, and late today Pacific Gas and Electric said it would do the same. Given that reality, some generating companies have reportedly been unwilling to sell power to the utilities, which has aggravated the shortages. 
In San Francisco at midday, the rolling blackouts seemed to be dribbling. Certain streets of certain neighborhoods were left without power, but never whole neighborhoods. Downtown, A.T.M.'s stopped working, traffic lights went off on certain streets, and two students at the Hastings College School of Law were stuck in an elevator and had to be rescued.
People around the state also tried to improvise, with mixed success. For instance, in Davis, a university town about 15 miles west of Sacramento, Marylou Hedriana, the chef and owner at Chocolat, a bakery, said she had just put tart shells in the oven when the power went off there unexpectedly.
"They were lost," she said. "Now we have to start all over again at step one."
She added that she had been unable to contact anyone at Pacific Gas and Electric, frustrating her efforts to plan around the blackout. "We couldn't plan our day," she said. "We sent two employees home."
The blackouts hit portions of San Francisco, Sacramento, Modesto, Turlock and other cities. The utility spread them out carefully so that no single neighborhood or city bore the brunt of the electricity cutoffs.
At 1:40 p.m., the California Independent System Operator, which oversees the transmission system, said that it had purchased additional power, some of it from BC Hydro, a major generator in Canada, and that it was able to order all customer power restored.
But there was still great uncertainty, about both the evening peak demand hours and the coming days. Officials at the Independent System Operator said that as demand soared in late afternoon the usual peak period, new rotating blackouts could be ordered, this time in the southern part of the state, to the customers of Southern California Edison. 
The officials added that perhaps a million customers each hour could be affected. These officials said they were forced to order the planned blackouts to avoid uncontrolled shutdowns that could have moved unpredictably through the system.
On top of that, tens of thousands of businesses across the state that have signed up for what is called interruptible power were blacked out to a far greater degree.
Under their contracts, they had agreed to be shut down first in case of shortages, in return for rates that are about 25 percent lower than normal, and so they had already had their power cut off since early in the morning.
Most of these businesses agreed to lose power for only about five hours at a time, but many were forced to shut down for 10 hours or more, underscoring the mounting economic impact of the state's energy crisis and the lack of policy options being offered by state officials.
"We are trying to manage the picture here today, but we've come to the end of the road here as far as supply within California and out-of-state resources go," said Jim Detmers, the managing director for operations at the Independent System Operator.
One of the most maddening aspects of the crisis is that officials have no way of knowing from one day to the next what the situation will be, frustrating efforts by businesses and other power users to make plans and worsening the economic impact. Given the fact that a decline in water supplies had reduced power today, officials were reduced to praying for rain.
"I'm afraid we just have to take this day by day," said Terry Winter, the chief executive of the Independent System Operator. Some of the people who manage the transmission system expressed concern that they were being forced to improvise on a daily basis to keep the lights on in California and were not receiving more help from the governor and the Legislature. 
The lawmakers have passed some bills and have discussed taking other measures, but they have not yet implemented changes that could bring immediate relief to the overtaxed power system.
Public officials in Davis said they were prepared, however. The fire chief, Rose Conroy, said the planning began last summer, when the utility first warned of the possibility of the rotating blackouts. The city was notified as to which blocks would be affected and responded by sending fire fighters out today. They "knocked on doors and asked, 'Are you O.K.?' " at residences of invalids, Ms. Conroy said, providing a sense of security to residents.
Mr. Winter said the output from hydroelectric dams was cut by about 2,000 megawatts today, out of a peak demand of slightly more than 30,000 megawatts.
The State Assembly late Tuesday evening passed a bill that would have the state, which enjoys a strong financial standing, buying the power, then selling it to the utilities. But that bill must still be passed by the State Senate and would have no effect for several weeks at the earliest.
Those immediate financial problems led to some grim portents in the market where the power companies buy and sell electricity. The amount of contracts negotiated at what is called the California Power Exchange, the market set up by the state for the utilities to buy power from generating companies, plummeted today.
Jesus Arredondo, a spokesman for the Power Exchange, said 82,000 megawatts had been traded on the market today. That is power that will be supplied on Thursday. That level is down from 160,000 megawatts traded last Wednesday and 300,000 megawatts two weeks ago, more normal levels of business.
"That's dirt, it's like nothing," Mr. Arredondo said of the level of trading today. He added that it clearly indicated that the prospect of more blackouts on Thursday was high.
"You look at the precipitous drop in the contracts, and it's due to credit," Mr. Arredondo said.
A major transmission bottleneck in central California also contributed to today's problems. Near Bakersfield is a stretch of transmission lines known as Path 15. Power traveling from the south to the north of the state, the normal flow at this time of year, must traverse those lines, but their capacity is lower than the grid just above and below it, slowing the flow.
David Freeman, the chairman of Los Angeles's municipally owned Department of Water and Power, said the transmission grid at midday resembled "L.A. freeway-type logjams." Describing the shortages today, Mr. Freeman, who once ran the Tennessee Valley Authority and New York State's power authority, said: "It's not all that complicated -- we just have a shortage. All the conspiracy theories -- you don't need to go there."
The blackouts caused a variety of problems. At the University of California Hastings College of Law, in San Francisco, two students were trapped in elevators for 15 minutes before being rescued. At a Safeway in San Mateo, south of San Francisco, employees had to guide a handful of shoppers around the aisles using flashlights.
At the Peninsula Community Foundation, a nonprofit agency across the street from the darkened Safeway, Judi Powell, a program officer, said the lights blacked out suddenly just before noon without warning and that people tended to make do with natural light. The real problem, she said, was that without computers much of the work at the foundation came to a standstill, which means a report she had to complete went unfinished.
J. Steve Tedesco, president of the San Jose Silicon Valley Chamber of Commerce, complained: "How did the utilities select these areas? Why did they select downtown, and why did they select noon?"
Some employers said they did receive warnings of impending blackouts.
Hewlett-Packard received word that its power could go out sometime in the afternoon at its Palo Alto headquarters. Earlier in the day, blackouts had hit three other Hewlett-Packard offices around Silicon Valley, affecting around 400 employees, said David L. Berman, a company spokesman.
In the Santa Rosa region, which is used to blackouts from powerful winter storms that have battered the region, it was strange to cope with a power outage on a brilliantly clear, blue, calm winter day.

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing; 
RECORD-LOW UNEMPLOYMENT

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 New Jersey's average unemployment rate for last year -- 3.8 percent -- equaled the state's lowest annual rate ever, the State Department of Labor said yesterday. 
The 2000 rate matched a record set in 1988, the department said. The 1999 average was 4.6 percent. The jobless rate for December was 3.9 percent, down from 4 percent in November, according to the state's preliminary figures. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Bankruptcy Judge May Be Solution to California Energy Crisis 

BYLINE:  By LAURA M. HOLSON 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 

 BODY:
Politicians and power company executives have bickered for months about how best to solve California's energy problems, but ultimately it may come down to this: a bankruptcy court judge may be the only person with the authority to ask for the rate increases and cost cuts that a growing chorus of analysts say are necessary, but that nobody in the state has been able to agree upon.
 Bankruptcy filings by the state's two largest utilities, Southern California Edison and Pacific Gas and Electric, would only make it harder for them to borrow money. This would further shake the confidence of power-generating companies that are already threatening not to sell them electricity, fearing that they will not be paid. 
 But there is growing recognition that a trip to bankruptcy court could give many parties in the current debacle -- particularly the politicians -- a convenient way out. Everyone, that is, except consumers, who are almost certain to be forced to pay a large chunk of the $12 billion the two utilities owe power generators now. A prospective law being discussed in the state legislature does not address the payment of the current bills. 
"It may be the best thing that happens if this goes to bankruptcy court," said Donato J. Eassey, an analyst with Merrill Lynch in Houston. "I don't think there is room for gamesmanship. Somebody has to grab this snake by the head and strangle it."
The threat of bankruptcy for the utilities is more real than ever. Today, Pacific Gas and Electric and its parent, the PG& E Corporation, said they had defaulted on $76 million of commercial paper. And Southern California Edison said this week that it would not pay $596 million it owed bondholders and power generators.
On Tuesday, the State Assembly passed legislation that would allow the state to step in and buy power at cheaper rates on behalf of the beleaguered utilities, a bill put together, in theory, to appease all parties, including the utilities and the power generators. So far, it has proved to do anything but that. The measure, Wall Street analysts say, does nothing to solve the most immediate crisis: the utilities are quickly running out of cash. And while Gov. Gray Davis still insists that bankruptcy is not an option, neither he nor the legislature has proposed a solution to pay past bills, the crux of the utilities' problems today.
"They can put all this effort into getting a deal done, but it does not mean you avert bankruptcy," said Jon Raleigh, a power and utilities analyst with Goldman, Sachs in New York. "One reason is any legislative action will take time to implement."
Already, power-generating companies are threatening to force the utilities into bankruptcy, hoping that they will have more luck appealing to a bankruptcy judge than to politicians. "All of the power generators are coming under pressure to pay their own bills," said Jan Smutny-Jones, executive director of the Independent Energy Producers, a trade group in Sacramento. They are under pressure particularly from suppliers selling natural gas to the power plants to keep them running. But the generators have been reluctant to force bankruptcy so far, fearing that they would seem predatory after reporting millions in profits last year. 
Mr. Eassey of Merrill Lynch suggests that the power generators could force the utilities to file for bankruptcy as early as next week. But the utilities themselves are adamant that bankruptcy is not the answer. With their bonds downgraded to junk ratings on Tuesday, it will already be difficult for them to repair their damaged images with investors. Tom Higgins, a senior vice president of Edison International, the parent company of Southern California Edison, said a bankruptcy would be disruptive for customers and for the state's economy. Further, Edison defaulted this week to conserve cash and stave off bankruptcy. 
Still, some utilities, particularly PG& E, have already taken steps to protect their nonutility assets from being tapped by creditors in the event of insolvency.
Since California's most recent power problems started to become evident in late November, federal and state political leaders, company executives and consumer groups have blamed one another. 
Mr. Raleigh of Goldman, Sachs said that a bankruptcy could be a saving grace for Governor Davis and many of the state legislators who have been criticized for doing too little too late to solve the energy crisis. Earlier this month, the California Public Utilities Commission agreed to allow the utilities to temporarily raise rates for consumers and businesses by 7 to 15 percent. The governor has since said that he will accept increases in that range, but not higher.
But most analysts think that, barring another solution proposed by state leaders in coming days, a rate increase is necessary to solve the immediate crisis. "Governor Davis boxed himself into a corner when he said he won't raise rates," Mr. Raleigh said. Then it would be up to a bankruptcy judge, who would need the approval of the Public Utilities Commission, to propose higher rates. If rates went up that way, he said, the governor "can be the one to say he was not the one to raise rates."
Mr. Davis, though, balked at that notion, saying: "Nobody in their right minds wants a bankruptcy. We are working night and day on a bipartisan basis to keep the lights on."
Bankruptcy lawyers said that any rate increases would not occur within days of filing, but would be carefully reviewed and considered in light of all that has happened in California. And the California commission could reject the proposal.
Mr. Eassey said a judge would require the utilities to cut other costs first -- limousines and planes, for instance -- before tapping consumers.

HEADLINE: Bush Wanders Off Center 

BYLINE:  By Ted Halstead; Ted Halstead is president of the New America Foundation and co-author of the forthcoming "The Radical Center."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
In nominating John Ashcroft for attorney general and Gale Norton as interior secretary, President-elect George Bush is ignoring what over the past decade has become the first law of American politics -- veer not from the center.
 Newt Gingrich and Congressional Republicans defied this principle and paid the price, Mr. Gingrich with his political life. If Mr. Bush persists in betraying the center that helped elect him, he, too, will pay -- with a diminished presidency. 
 America's new political center, reflected in the growing number of independent voters, is surprisingly broad and deep. Some 35 percent of Americans now describe themselves as independents, compared with 33 percent who say they are Democrats and 31 percent who identify as Republicans, according to a Gallup poll conducted earlier this month.
Together with large numbers of centrist Republicans and Democrats, these independent-minded voters are neither conservative nor liberal in the traditional sense. Rather, they represent a genuinely new center in American politics -- one whose agenda lies outside left and right as opposed to between them. These new centrists are socially tolerant yet supportive of law and order, fiscally conservative but accepting of government intervention for economic fairness or security, concerned about the economy yet worried about the environment.
The new center is wielding ever more power through instant polls, focus groups and an active presence in mainstream environmental, consumer and church-based groups. As we saw in the last presidential campaign, its influence is growing as that of religious conservatives and liberal special-interest groups is shrinking.
The nominations of Mr. Ashcroft and Ms. Norton are vulnerable, then, not because they are the target of liberals but because the nominees hold positions that are antithetical to the values of this rising center.
John Ashcroft's opposition to abortion -- even in cases of rape or incest -- conflicts with the pro-choice attitudes of these voters. And his faith-based approach to public policy raises worries about his commitment to the rule of law and to the separation of church and state -- both important principles of the new center. Not surprisingly, the latest polls show more Americans opposing Mr. Ashcroft's appointment than supporting it.
Similarly, Gale Norton's environmental record clashes with the conservationist ethic of most centrist Americans. They are flexible in their approach to protecting the environment, but Ms. Norton's criticism of regulations affecting public lands suggests she would allow logging, mining and grazing interests a much greater access than before, which would be anathema to most centrists. Even the Republicans for Environmental Protection opposes her nomination.
If the Democratic leadership allows these nominations to go forward without question, it, too, will be held accountable by this center, which looks to the opposition to be a check against the party in power. There is no hiding from responsibility in a media age that makes clear, through instant polling, where the public stands.
Mr. Bush ran as a compassionate conservative, not as a member of his party's right wing. At times during the campaign, he sounded like a convinced new centrist. He spoke eloquently of restoring purpose to American life and of tearing down the walls that keep America divided. In his effort to marry progressive ends with conservative means, there was more than a hint of potential greatness -- for both his presidency and the country. But by straying from the center, with his appointments of Mr. Ashcroft and Ms. Norton, Mr. Bush risks squandering the potential for an effective presidency.

HEADLINE: Softball for Powell, and With No Sweat 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 

 BODY:
As a 63-year-old four star general acquainted with the old world of the Soviet Union and its weapons, Gen. Colin L. Powell set out today to convince his polite Senate inquisitors that he was suited to be secretary of state because he knew the new world of the Internet and the information revolution. 
 Only a few moments into his testimony, General Powell, dressed in a sharply tailored suit that could adorn any top corporate executive, was talking about e-mail, the speed of communication and his transforming experience as a director of America Online. 
 But just as the Internet was essential to the new world, so was national missile defense, said General Powell, who stressed repeatedly in his confirmation hearings before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that the Bush administration was determined to move forward with the plan, even in the face of allied opposition. 
"I have also been through several things like this over the years where people see something new come along and they are terrified," General Powell said comparing the fears in Europe about national missile defense with fears in the 1980's when there was public opposition in Britain and Germany to the installation of American Pershing nuclear missiles to deter the Soviets. But, the general declared, "If it's the right thing to do, you do it anyway." 
Under deferential questioning from the senators, General Powell gave a broad-brush tour of a Bush foreign policy, referring often to consulting with the president-elect though never playing down the State Department's role in deciding matters of policy from North Korea to the Middle East to Africa. 
Although he made tens of millions of dollars in the last seven years on the strength of his inspirational speaking skills, General Powell's delivery was almost rote as he rarely answered questions in depth. He had met with each of the senators on the committee in the privacy of their offices last week, so he seemed to be acting on the premise that today was as much about symbolism as substance, more about appearance than conviction. 
In a very gentle warning, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, predicted that a possible source of tension between General Powell and the committee was the very attribute that the general, as an experienced Washington in-fighter, flirted with today. Senator Biden described it as "your legendary capability of being closemouthed and avoiding saying exactly where the principal you represent stands." 
General Powell was scarcely asked about when and how he would apply his military doctrine -- known as the Powell doctrine -- that calls for a clear definition of goals and overwhelming force to accomplish them. Nor was he asked about his view of the role of American soldiers in peacekeeping tasks beyond the specific example of Kosovo and Bosnia.
In that instance, General Powell broke no new ground in his testimony or in answers to questions, saying that the Bush team would "carefully" review the commitments made by the Clinton administration to the NATO peacekeeping force in the Balkans. 
European leaders have expressed alarm that even the threat of withdrawing American troops from the Balkans missions would weaken NATO and destabilize Kosovo and Bosnia just at a critical moment of their repair. As if to respond to that concern but not willing to concede the apparent contradiction that withdrawing troops would affect NATO, General Powell said in his testimony that NATO was the "bedrock of our relationship with Europe." 
"It is sacrosanct," he said. "Weaken NATO, and you weaken Europe, which weakens America." 
The backbone of General Powell's presentation was the determination of the Bush administration to press ahead with national missile defense. The general brushed aside a suggestion from Senator Biden that if the United States could get an ironclad agreement ending North Korea's long-range ballistic missile development programs, as well as its sale of missile technologies to Iran, then a missile defense system could be built that would pose fewer concerns to America's allies. 
"There are still other nations that are moving in this direction, particularly Iran," he replied. "And until Iraq comes into compliance and we could be assured of what they're able to do, I would say that at this point, we should continue to move ahead as aggressively as possible." 
On Iraq, General Powell made the case that sanctions, as he has said before, needed to be reinvigorated and that this could be done by pointing out more vigorously to nations in the region that Saddam Hussein was threatening them with weapons of mass destruction.
General Powell seemed to express some skepticism on a policy of trying to overthrow Saddam Hussein, a policy favored more strongly by others in the Bush team. "It's easy to say let's just go in and take over the land," he said. "But we really have to make sure we have an understanding of how this is actually going to be operationalized, and that there really is some sound basis for believing that people could be successful once they go onto Iraqi territory." 
Elsewhere in the Middle East, the general distanced himself from the all-out Clinton effort to reach an accord between the Palestinians and Israelis, saying that Syria was needed for a comprehensive settlement. 
On the crisis in Congo, General Powell described the situation as "very confused" and warned that Congo was the most difficult peacekeeping task for the United Nations. "The Congo is not a nice little place like Sierra Leone, or even a little place like Bosnia and Kosovo," he said. "It's a huge place. And the number of people who get sucked up in such a mission is very, very large." 
Under questioning by the ranking Republican on the panel, Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, the general seemed to provide answers to Mr. Helms's liking. He said that the Bush team was in favor of expanding NATO beyond the three new members added during the Clinton years, but he was not specific. 
On the International Criminal Court, of which President Clinton said he favored ratification, General Powell told the panel not to be "standing on your tippy-toes waiting for the Bush administration to ask for any -- any -- movement toward ratification of the treaty." 
And on Cuba, the general fully satisfied Senator Helms by calling Fidel Castro an "aging starlet" who would be faced with a continued economic embargo from the Bush White House. In his prepared testimony, General Powell gave the impression that that the Bush administration would not seek passage of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty at all, though in his oral delivery he modified that to say they would not seek passage in the current Congressional session.

HEADLINE: Whitman Promises Latitude To States on Pollution Rules 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 

 BODY:
Gov. Christie Whitman of New Jersey said today that as the country's top environmental regulator she would give the states greater latitude in heeding federal pollution-control rules.
 In remarks to a Senate committee considering her for director of the Environmental Protection Agency, Governor Whitman also said all environmental regulations should be made subject to strict cost-benefit tests, and she vowed to "move beyond the command-and-control model" of protecting the environment. 
 As governor, Mrs. Whitman was criticized for cutting New Jersey's environmental enforcement budget and relying too heavily on voluntary compliance. While she promised today to oversee "a strong federal role" in environmental protection, her testimony signaled an inclination to allow greater flexibility to industries and the states than the Clinton administration allowed. 
Mrs. Whitman also said she would review a string of environmental regulations issued in recent months by the Clinton administration, including a clean-air rule for big trucks and buses that critics said would unwisely burden industry and the economy.
Several Democratic senators, including Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, urged Mrs. Whitman and the incoming administration of President-elect George W. Bush to uphold that rule. But otherwise, Mrs. Whitman faced not a single note of criticism during her one-day hearing and appeared to be headed for speedy confirmation.
Among the senators who questioned Mrs. Whitman was Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, in her debut as a member of a Senate committee. Mrs. Clinton said she intended to vote to support Mrs. Whitman.
Though her critics had vowed to make racial profiling in New Jersey an issue in her nomination, Senator Jon S. Corzine, the freshman New Jersey Democrat, was the only member of the panel to ask Mrs. Whitman about the issue. In her reply, she promised to be sensitive to racial concerns in dealing with the environmental problems of the cities.
Mrs. Whitman has admitted that New Jersey state troopers improperly singled out blacks and members of other minorities for traffic stops.
Democrats and Republicans alike greeted Mrs. Whitman warmly today on Capitol Hill, reflecting her stature as someone who was frequently mentioned as a possible vice-presidential candidate.
Senator Robert G. Torricelli, the New Jersey Democrat who introduced her to the Senate panel, called her nomination "a very wise selection" and noted that she was from a state with one of the country's best coastal management programs and the largest number of Superfund hazardous waste sites.
In signaling her plan to review Clinton administration directives, Mrs. Whitman made remarks consistent with earlier ones by Mr. Bush. She said the agency had "an obligation to review all the rules" issued recently by the White House, including those adopted last month to tighten emissions and clean-fuel requirements for buses and big rigs, the nation's heaviest polluters on the highways.
The oil industry has warned that the measures, which would not take effect before 2006, could cause fuel shortages and price increases affecting the transportation industry. One Republican senator, James M. Inhofe of Oklahoma, a member of the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee, which heard from Mrs. Whitman today, has said he plans to try to get Congress to reverse the rules.
Mrs. Whitman did not spell out how the agency might be more flexible under her than in the past. But she called for a "new era of cooperation" among state and federal governments, businesses and environmentalists, and said, "Government cannot do it alone."
She said she would emphasize market-based incentives for protecting the environment, underscoring a Bush campaign theme. But she also said the agency would continue to enforce existing environmental rules.
"We will offer the carrot when appropriate and always preserve the stick of enforcement," Mrs. Whitman said.
She also emphasized that decisions in making environmental rules should always consider their effect on the economy.
"No longer do we debate about whether we need to protect our environment," Mrs. Whitman said. "Instead, we discuss how we can keep America green while keeping our economy growing."
Mrs. Whitman was asked how she would address a broad variety of environmental issues, including whether she would pursue a costly agency plan to remove PCB's from the Hudson River and how she might combat the flow of air pollution into the Northeast from Midwestern power plants.
She made no commitments on those issues except to say that she would review the agency's rules.
