HEADLINE: OPEC Ratifies Oil Cutback; Iraq Remains a Puzzle 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: VIENNA, Jan. 17 

 BODY:
As ministers from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries ratified a decision today to reduce oil production by 5 percent, the biggest threat to the group's efforts to artfully balance supply and demand loomed from Iraq, one of its own.
 OPEC nations decided to lower the daily production target by 1.5 million barrels of crude oil a day beginning Feb. 1. The total output of the group, which produces about 40 percent of the world's oil, is expected to decline to 25.2 million barrels a day. 
 Those figures do not include Iraq's export quota -- which is set by the United Nations as part of the arrangement stemming from Persian Gulf war sanctions that followed the end of hostilities in 1991. Through much of the fall and winter, Iraq has withdrawn a significant share of its oil exports from world markets, in a campaign to undo or at least soften the sanctions. It is now pumping less than half its previous output of 2.3 million barrels a day. 
Analysts say that OPEC's move this week to reduce production has given Iraq great influence on world oil prices -- and consequently, on the broad economy. For Iraq, the bolstering of its influence comes at a propitious time, as George W. Bush, a son of the man who waged war against Baghdad, takes the helm of a shaky American economy and as more countries and international oil companies express the desire to see the sanctions lifted.
In Washington, a senior Pentagon official who will remain in office under the new administration said today that while President Saddam Hussein's actions had proved annoying, his previous efforts to disrupt the flow of oil had not significantly rattled the world oil markets.
Senior members of the incoming Bush team -- many of them veterans of gulf war policy decisions -- have criticized the Clinton administration for standing by while international pressure against Mr. Hussein has waned. But they have offered few specifics on how they intend to get tough on Iraq.
OPEC has wagered that it can shore up oil prices by reducing output, without further damaging the weakened economies of the United States and Asia. Many analysts agree that barring an unexpected shock, OPEC might just succeed in its effort to stabilize oil prices in the range of $22 to $28 a barrel. Yesterday, crude oil for February delivery fell more than 2 percent, to $29.60 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, as traders expressed relief that OPEC would not be making deeper cuts than the market had expected.
Energy Secretary Bill Richardson, who met with OPEC leaders in Europe and the Middle East over the weekend to urge restraint in reducing production, said in Washington today that he was disappointed with OPEC's action. "As both the United States and the European Union expressed, we remain concerned that any cut in production has the potential to lower stock levels and contribute to volatility in the market," Mr. Richardson said.
OPEC's new secretary general, Ali Rodriguez of Venezuela, said at a news conference here that the group's decision to reduce output was predicated on the assumption that Iraq would again increase its exports. Mr. Rodriguez said the Iraqi oil minister, Amir Muhammad Rashid, had assured him that Baghdad would be pumping 2 million to 2.3 million barrels a day by the end of the month.
But many analysts in Vienna were less optimistic. "OPEC believes that the Iraqis will reverse course and pump 2.3 million barrels a day," said Raad Alkadiri, country risk analyst with the Petroleum Finance Company, "and that is the most dangerous assumption OPEC is making. There is no guarantee, based on Iraq's political agenda to dismantle sanctions, that it will resume pumping two million barrels a day."
OPEC's announced plan to reduce output by 1.5 million barrels a day may actually result in a drop closer to a million barrels a day, because some members chronically exceed their official quotas. But if Iraq continues to withhold about a million barrels a day, the overall reduction in supply could send prices rocketing and weaken the American economy. 
"The thing to watch over the coming weeks is what Iraq will do -- how many tankers will leave the gulf with Iraqi oil," a member of a non-OPEC delegation in Vienna said.
If Iraq indeed keeps exports to a trickle, Saudi Arabia -- as the largest producer in OPEC and its de facto leader -- may feel compelled, as it has intermittently over the last year, to increase its own output to make up for the Iraqi supplies, industry analysts said. But the Saudis might be able to replace only part of the oil that Iraq took off the market. 
As OPEC tightens supplies and wild cards like Iraq come into play, analysts in Vienna predicted that world oil markets could be susceptible to the same volatility that prevailed last year, with relatively lofty prices occasionally spiking even higher, into a range around $35 a barrel. The risk of setting off such price increases is one that OPEC appears willing to take, regardless of potentially dire consequences for the world economy. 
"Last year is a good example of what we can have this year," Mr. Alkadiri said. "OPEC would rather deal with prices when they are $35 a barrel than $25 a barrel."

HEADLINE: Financial Problems in Government Are Rife, Nation's Top Auditor Says 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 

 BODY:
The comptroller general of the United States, the nation's top auditor, said today that President-elect George W. Bush would inherit a government that is riddled with weak management, lacks many of the skills needed to run federal programs and cannot fully account for the use of taxpayers' money.
 The comptroller general, David M. Walker, found serious weaknesses in accounting and financial management throughout the government, from the Defense Department to the Internal Revenue Service, the Forest Service to the Federal Aviation Administration. 
 While politicians prepared for Inauguration Day festivities and for high-profile debates over tax cuts and education policy, federal investigators told Mr. Bush of problems festering below the surface of the government. 
The Pentagon's financial statements are in such poor condition that they cannot be audited, Mr. Walker said, and most other agencies do not comply with federal accounting standards. As a result, he said, he cannot certify the accuracy of consolidated financial statements for the government as a whole. Federal auditors have been complaining about this problem for several years.
President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore often boast of "reinventing government," saying they have made it more efficient while reducing its size.
But the comptroller general, who is head of the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, said federal agencies were poorly equipped to meet challenges of the 21st century because their employees lacked the necessary skills in information technology, science, economics and management.
Federal agencies "drastically reduced or froze their hiring efforts" in recent years, Mr. Walker said. "This helped reduce the number of employees, but it also reduced the influx of new people with new skills, new knowledge, new energy and new ideas -- the reservoir of future agency leaders and managers."
In a report to Mr. Bush and to Congress, the General Accounting Office described 22 "high-risk areas" in which it said the government was vulnerable to waste, fraud, abuse and mismanagement. Eight of the 22 problems, including overpayments to military contractors and Medicare fraud, have been on the list since 1990, suggesting that they defy easy solution.
Today, for the first time, the accounting office said the government's failure to recruit and retain skilled employees was one of its biggest problems, severely impairing the ability of many agencies to perform their missions. Too often, the report concluded, the government has treated its employees as "costs to be cut rather than assets to be valued."
Senator Fred Thompson of Tennessee, the senior Republican on the Committee on Governmental Affairs, said, "The fact that the federal government does not adequately hire and retain the right people is a root cause" of the difficulties at many agencies.
Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, the ranking Democrat on the panel, said the problem could worsen because "more than one-third of government workers will be eligible for retirement in five years."
Mr. Walker said some reduction in the number of federal employees was justifiable, but he added: "The question is, How was it done? What type of strategic work-force planning took place in order to make sure that we achieved the short-term reductions in head count without mortgaging the future? For the most part, that was not done."
The armed services "face shortages among junior officers and problems in retaining intelligence analysts, computer programmers and pilots," the report said.
With many employees eligible for retirement, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has difficulty finding nuclear engineers to monitor the safety of atomic power plants. The Department of Veterans Affairs cannot find enough nurses or people to examine health claims. And the Immigration and Naturalization Service does not have enough intelligence experts to combat the problem of alien smuggling.
Likewise, the accounting office said, the loss of skilled employees at the nation's space agency may jeopardize safe operation of the space shuttle and could force cutbacks in the number of flights. And the federal Medicare agency does not have enough people with the skills needed to evaluate advances in medical technology.
The accounting office said five federal programs had been taken off the list of high-risk activities because they had made progress toward solving problems found by federal investigators.
The programs showing major improvements were the National Weather Service, which has bought $4.5 billion worth of equipment to improve its forecasts; the farm loan programs of the Agriculture Department, which has sharply reduced the number of delinquent borrowers, and the Superfund program, which cleans up abandoned hazardous waste sites. The year 2000 computer problem and the 2000 census were removed from the list because their deadlines had passed.
Federal auditors also found progress at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, which received high marks for correcting problems in its community development programs.
But the new high-risk list still includes HUD programs to insure home mortgages and to subsidize rents for low-income families. In 1999, the accounting office said, the department paid $935 million in "excess subsidies" -- about 5 percent of all subsidy payments -- to tenants who underreported their income or did not report it at all.
In its report, the accounting office said these were some of the biggest problems facing Mr. Bush and the new Congress:
*The government erroneously pays billions of dollars a year to low-income families claiming earned-income tax credits. Some families falsify their income and Social Security numbers, overstate the number of children they have and use other schemes to obtain refunds to which they are not entitled.
*The Internal Revenue Service has failed to collect more than $100 billion in owed taxes. In the last three years, the government has radically reduced the number of cases in which it seized property to satisfy tax obligations. This may encourage taxpayers to understate their tax liabilities.
*The government's effort to update its air traffic control system has been plagued with cost overruns and delays. The Federal Aviation Administration has not followed standard practices in buying computer software for a vast network of radar and communications equipment.
*The Health Care Financing Administration, which runs Medicare and Medicaid, has no reliable way to keep track of overpayments to doctors, hospitals and home health care agencies. So it cannot recover the money owed to the government.
Clinton administration officials say the Medicare agency is much improved. But the accounting office said, "The Health Care Financing Administration has a long way to go to achieve sound financial management."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Powell's Opening Statement to Foreign Relations Committee 

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the opening remarks yesterday by Gen. Colin L. Powell, President-elect George W. Bush's choice for secretary of state, when he testified before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc.:
 These proceedings mark the 64th renewal of a long and honored tradition that began when the 26 members of the first United States Senate met to consider the nomination that was before them then, that of Thomas Jefferson of Virginia. When Jefferson took office in 1790, a cynical and tired Europe laughed in derision at the thought that "popular government," as it was called then, might work in even one country, much less the whole world. In fact, just a few decades ago, noted experts in academic journals wrote of the weakness and possible demise of democratic institutions in the face of rising dictatorial power of the kind we saw represented by the Soviet Union on the red side of the map. 
 Those articles were appearing at the very moment that Jefferson's ideas of liberty and self-government were about to prove another generation of cynics absolutely dead wrong, ideas that were going to, as Jefferson prayed, flow through time and spread their happy influence over the face of the earth as people behind the Iron Curtain and around the world threw off the yokes of totalitarianism. 
Jefferson's ideas and Jefferson's prayers were ahead of the time in which he lived, and ahead of the man himself. I have to pause in my admiration of Jefferson during this week of celebration of the life of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., and reflect on how Dr. King helped to answer Jefferson's prayers for black Americans, whose forebears at that time were considered to be property, slaves, even in Jefferson's own custody. 
I am before you today as Jefferson's admiring successor, thankful for all the sacrifices that were made by Dr. King and so many others to make Jefferson's dream possible for people like me, a dream that I hope that will continue to inspire my fellow Americans and inspire people around the world, because there is still so much that needs to be done here at home and around the world to bring that universal Jeffersonian dream to the whole world. 
President-elect George W. Bush understands that dark shadows still linger over the edges of the American dream for so many. He intends to remove those shadows. He will be a president for all Americans, and he will be a leader who faithfully represents the ideas of freedom and justice to the entire world. . . .
And if confirmed, I promise that I will argue with you, I will debate with you, as I did in the past. But it will always be in the best spirit of cooperation, to make sure we get the right answer for the American people, and that we pursue the president's foreign policy as he has divined it from the will of the American people. 
We will need to work together well because we have a great challenge before us, but it is not a challenge of survival anymore; it is the challenge of leadership, for it is not a dark and dangerous ideological foe we confront, as we did for all those years, but now it is the overwhelming power of millions of people who have tasted freedom. It is our own incredible success, the success of the values that we hold dear, that has given us the challenges that we now face. . . .
The ideological "-isms" which challenged us for the last 50 years have all died away -- fascism, Naziism, Communism -- leaving only the dregs of abused and misused power in their wake. Yes, dictators remain, but they are relics of the past, and the "-isms" they practice can't destroy us, can't overthrow us, can't end our way of life the way the threat of the Soviet Union was able to do so. These regimes and these dictators can be dangerous, and they require our attention, but they can't hurdle the Atlantic in 30 minutes, the way I used to worry about Soviet forces doing just a few years ago. 
Democracy and free markets work, and the world knows it. And there is no finer example of this than America and her allies, who together comprise the strongest economies in the world, helping to reshape the entire world by -- willing to trade openly and encourage others to do likewise. 
And there should be no question in any world leader's mind that the first and most essential ingredient for success in this 21st century is a free people, and a government that derives its right to govern from the consent of such people. 
So a guiding principle of President-elect Bush's foreign policy will be that America stands ready to help any country that wishes to join the democratic world; any country that puts the law in place and begins to live by that rule, any country that seeks peace and prosperity and a place in the sun. In that light, there is no country on earth that is not touched by America, for we have become the motive force for freedom and democracy in the world. And there is no country in the world that does not touch us. We are a country of countries with a citizen in our ranks from every land. We are attached by a thousand cords to the world at large, to its teeming cities, to its remotest regions, to its oldest civilizations, to its newest cries for freedom. This means that we have an interest in every place on this earth; that we need to lead, to guide, to help in every country that has a desire to be free, open and prosperous.

HEADLINE: HUD Candidate Would Seek More Homes for Minorities 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 

 BODY:
President-elect George W. Bush's choice for secretary of housing and urban development, Melquiades R. Martinez, told a Senate committee today that he would work to ensure that more minority families owned homes and would fight any effort to reduce the department's budget.
 "Despite record-high levels of homeownership, African-American and Hispanic-American homeownership rates remain below 50 percent," Mr. Martinez said. "That is not acceptable." 
 In a two-hour confirmation hearing, Mr. Martinez, the chairman of Orange County, Fla., persuaded Democrats and Republicans that his qualifications included not just public service in Florida, but also his personal history, beginning with his flight from Cuba as a teenager. He has become wealthy as a personal-injury lawyer.
"I came to America with a suitcase and the hope of a better life," Mr. Martinez said. "I know the value of homeownership because I have witnessed its great power throughout my entire life."
Nearly every senator cited this "compelling personal story" as one reason that Mr. Martinez will win easy confirmation. He would become the first Cuban-American to hold a cabinet post.
Mr. Martinez, 54, who also served as chairman of the Orlando Housing Authority and the Florida Growth Management Study Commission under Gov. Jeb Bush, assured the committee that he was not part of the wing of the Republican Party that had tried to abolish HUD.
"Far from being a caretaker, I intend to be a very active secretary," Mr. Martinez said, suggesting that the department's mandate should be expanded to include taking a leading role in managing the explosive urban growth brought on by the recent stretch of national prosperity. 
Pointing to a looming housing problem in rural areas as well as cities, Mr. Martinez said the number of poor people desperate for housing had grown while the number of affordable houses for sale had diminished. He also cited a growing need of housing for the elderly. 
"Unless we make sure that everyone is participating in this great economic expansion and until we ensure that barriers to home ownership are torn down for everyone," he said, "until then, our job is not done." 
Before his nomination, Mr. Martinez was best known for his public support of the Miami relatives of Elian Gonzalez in their losing battle to keep Elian in Florida after his mother drowned while fleeing from Cuba across the Florida Straits. Later, Mr. Martinez was named one of eight co-chairmen of Mr. Bush's campaign in Florida.
Advocacy groups that had been wary of Mr. Martinez and his thin record on housing said today that they were not opposed to his confirmation and looked forward to working with him.
"We were encouraged that he understands the country is facing a serious problem that there is not enough affordable housing for low-income families," said Sheila Crowley, president of the National Low Income Housing Coalition. "He also understands the need for more affordable rental units."
Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, the Maryland Democrat who is the chairman of the Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs until Saturday, when the Republicans take over, opened the hearing by announcing that the long-troubled housing agency had been removed from the government's "high-risk" category because of management changes under Andrew M. Cuomo, the departing secretary.
"You're inheriting a better HUD," Mr. Sarbanes said. "But it doesn't mean all the problems are solved."
In October, Congress approved a $32.4 billion budget for HUD, including a record $1 billion in new grants to help the estimated 200,000 homeless people nationwide. But Congress remains skeptical of the agency's ability to manage the complicated housing programs that were plagued with scandal in the 1980's.
Mr. Martinez said he would like to shift some of the more than 300 HUD programs to state and local governments, in part to cut out the red tape that bedeviled him as a local Florida official applying for HUD grants. 
Echoing Mr. Bush's campaign theme of compassionate conservatism, Mr. Martinez said he hoped to create partnerships with religious organizations and nonprofit groups to help solve housing problems. And once again, he pointed to his work in Florida as a model.
"When we needed after-school care for children," he said, "we didn't expand government programs but went into partnership with the Boys and Girls Clubs." 
He also pointed to Mr. Bush's plan to provide tax credits to financial institutions that help low-income families finance houses as a major initiative he will promote as secretary.

HEADLINE: TREASURY CHOICE VARIES FROM BUSH ON TAX OUTLOOK 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary-designate Paul H. O'Neill today struck a cautious note on tax cuts that departed from the position taken by President-elect George W. Bush, calling on Congress to reduce tax rates but expressing doubts that broad cuts would ignite the slowing economy.
 In his first public comments since Mr. Bush selected him to head the Treasury Department and serve as the leader of the new administration's economic team, Mr. O'Neill supported tax cuts with words that were noticeably less rousing than Mr. Bush's. He said he favored tax relief because he did not see the harm in lowering the tax burden while the government had big surpluses. 
 But in a three-hour confirmation hearing in front of the Senate Finance Committee, he did not spell out the benefits of tax cuts in any detail. The former Alcoa executive and Nixon and Ford administration budget expert also cast a shadow of doubt on Mr. Bush's contention that tax cuts are the right antidote to the looming economic downturn. 
He said the Federal Reserve, through its control of monetary policy, was the "first line of action" to fight a downturn and suggested that even cuts of the magnitude Mr. Bush has promised would likely have relatively little immediate impact on the nation's economy.
"I'm not going to make a huge case that this is the investment we need to make sure we don't go into a recession," Mr. O'Neill said. "But if we are going to do it anyway, then the sooner the better."
In a friendly but frank exchange on taxes with the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, who has urged immediate and sweeping tax reductions, Mr. O'Neill dismissed a cut in the capital gains tax, which Mr. Lott has favored, as likely to have minimal stimulatory effects on today's sluggish economy. 
Mr. O'Neill also praised the Clinton administration's record of fiscal discipline and economic stability as "wonderful." He said the Bush administration should aim to collect enough in taxes to pay for government operations each year without going into debt -- even when the economy barely expands.
"The tax system should be structured so that even with low or no growth, we are not borrowing from our children," Mr. O'Neill said.
That position differs in some respects from the view held by some supply-side economists, who steadfastly defend President Ronald Reagan's tax cuts of the early 1980's as having revolutionized the economy, even if they also contributed to giant budget deficits.
Lawrence B. Lindsey, Mr. Bush's chief economic aide, is a leading proponent of Reagan-era tax cutting and the main architect of Mr. Bush's tax cut plan, which is estimated to cost $1.6 trillion over 10 years.
With Congress so closely divided between the two political parties, Mr. Bush may need every ounce of political support he can get on cutting taxes. Any sense that some senior officials within Mr. Bush's own camp view tax cuts as less urgent than Mr. Bush seems likely to play into the hands of Democrats, many of whom favor smaller reductions in tax rates.
Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, who headed the committee hearing today, and several other Democrats on the panel argued that while some tax cutting was called for, Mr. Bush's was so large that it threatened to turn projected surpluses into deficits when new spending was factored in. 
Several Democrats also argued that tax cuts would almost certainly kick in too late to make much difference in combating the current slowdown.
Mr. O'Neill said he was comfortable with estimates the Bush team had made that projected fiscal surpluses would cover the president-elect's spending plans, Social Security overhaul and tax cuts without creating new deficits. 
But if tax cuts sometimes seem like Mr. Bush's economic first love, Mr. O'Neill gave them more of an air kiss. The government has some extra money, he suggested several times, so why not return some to the people.
"It's desirable to have a situation in which we send it back when we don't need it," Mr. O'Neill said of government revenue, adding, "but we should be in balance even with a weak economy."
During the presidential campaign, Mr. Bush made the case that large-scale tax relief was vital despite the seemingly robust economy because it offered "insurance" against a future downturn.
More recently, amid signs that a slowdown has occurred, Mr. Bush has argued that tax cuts have become urgent because they are needed to rescue the economy from a potentially painful slump.
The statements by Mr. O'Neill do not necessarily signal a split within the Bush administration. Mr. O'Neill firmly echoed comments made by his boss when he made clear that Congress would receive tax-cutting legislation within weeks of Mr. Bush taking office. He also left open the possibility that the president-elect will decide to speed up some forms of tax relief to put money in people's pockets sooner.
But Mr. O'Neill does seem likely to let the Fed, run by his friend and former Ford administration colleague Alan Greenspan, take the lead in managing the ups and downs of the economy rather than seeking to have the administration try to influence economic fluctuations with the budget. He also seems more likely than some other members of Mr. Bush's team to argue the case for fiscal caution when the administration debates its economic plans.
His comments illustrate why some conservatives distrust Mr. O'Neill's economic instincts. As a budget official in the Nixon and Ford administrations, he developed a reputation as a pragmatic thinker on fiscal matters, inclined to run a lean and efficient government, but skeptical of ideological extremes.
As the chief executive of Alcoa, the leading aluminum manufacturer, he remained outspoken about public policy and did not always back consensus Republican positions. He fought strongly for deficit reduction during former President George Bush's term and offered crucial business support when Mr. Bush decided to raise taxes at that time, a deeply unpopular decision among conservatives.
Mr. O'Neill has also explored solutions to global warming. He once called for the government to slap a new tax on fuel to reduce energy use and raise new revenue. The latter position directly conflicts with that of the president-elect, and Mr. O'Neill has disavowed it.
His willingness to speak out on such topics has given him the label of maverick.
Mr. O'Neill also jested with senators about his tendencies toward outspokenness today.
During the discussion on taxes, which dominated the relatively breezy hearing, Mr. O'Neill provoked laughter when he said, "I'm thinking about whether I can still get away with being a maverick for a few more days." He quickly added, "I think I will be."
He then responded to a question about the impact of corporate tax cuts on investment, again displaying some skepticism.
"As a businessman I never made an investment decision based on the tax code," he said. "If you give money away I will take it, but good business people don't do things because of inducements."
No senator objected to Mr. O'Neill's qualifications to head the Treasury and his confirmation, expected as early as Saturday, seems assured.
Mr. O'Neill used the hearing to address some uncertainties about his leanings on other economic matters. Currency traders have speculated that his business background will make him more sympathetic to arguments that the dollar is overvalued against other currencies, possibly leading to a departure from the Clinton administration's steadfast strong dollar policy.
"I am in favor of a strong dollar," Mr. O'Neill said. "I can't imagine why anyone would think to the contrary."
Though Mr. O'Neill did not get into a protracted dispute with any of the senators, he seemed at times less willing to pander to their individual concerns than is typical during confirmation hearings.

HEADLINE: North Korea Leader Kicks the Tires in Shanghai 

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Jan. 17 

 BODY:
The North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, today toured a Buick plant run in a venture with General Motors. 
 Apparently Mr. Kim, who also visited the city's stock exchange, is interested in seeing how economic reforms have reshaped this city since he last visited here in 1983. 
 China's prime minister, Zhu Rongji, flew in from Beijing to accompany the reclusive North Korean leader whose visit was kept so secret that few residents knew he was here.
At the General Motors plant, the Chinese president of the joint venture showed Mr. Kim around. 
Mr. Kim is a renowned lover of luxury automobiles, but few employees at the Buick plant were allowed to see him. . A group visiting from Thunderbird, the American Graduate School of International Management, in Arizona, was even trapped in a conference room at the Buick plant by the blanket of security that descended when Mr. Kim's entourage unexpectedly arrived. 
Mr. Kim also visited the Shanghai Stock Exchange, the most important of China's two stock exchanges in the city's gleaming financial district. But again, few other people at the exchange caught a glimpse of the North Korean leader or were even aware that he was there. China's 10-year-old stock markets, while still immature by Western standards, have played a key role in financing state-enterprise reform. 
In addition, Mr. Kim was reported to have visited China's most advanced semiconductor plant, a joint venture with NEC of Japan. 
Reporters scrambling around town for a sighting finally spotted Mr. Kim this evening leaving the Grand Theater after a private concert of Chinese folk songs and orchestra music. But the reporters were kept behind a fence about 25 yards away.
The consensus among analysts of North Korean politics and media pundits is that Mr. Kim, whose country's economy is in shambles after decades of Stalinist policies, is considering Chinese-style reform. Shanghai is the country's showcase of those reforms, which have been gradual and have been accompanied by tight political controls. 
Mr. Kim is expected to leave Thursday for Shenzhen, the special economic zone bordering Hong Kong where China's most aggressive economic reforms began.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
The nation should know where a Treasury nominee stands on world issues.

BYLINE:  By Jeff Madrick; This column appears here every Thursday. Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine and a new collection of essays, "Unconventional Wisdom: Alternative Perspectives on the New Economy." Mr. Madrick, Virginia Postrel, Alan B. Krueger and Hal R. Varian rotate as contributors.

 BODY:
FEW of President-elect George W. Bush's cabinet choices have been as widely praised as Paul H. O'Neill, the candidate for Treasury secretary. Even organized labor has complimented Mr. O'Neill, formerly the respected chief executive of Alcoa.
 But the next Treasury secretary faces formidable problems, and the confirmation hearings yesterday only scratched the surface, with the senators largely concentrating on domestic issues. Mr. O'Neill, of course, says we can avert recession and manage a "soft landing" if we have a tax cut. But if the objective is to stimulate the economy, why propose a tax cut that would go largely to the wealthy, who would save, not spend, their newly found cash? 
 International issues, however, may well prove to be more urgent over the next four years, and so far the Bush team has shown a disturbing taste for insularity. In President Clinton's two terms, Robert E. Rubin and company had to deal with crises in Mexico and Asia, several in Russia, the collapse of Long-Term Capital Management and a world in which levels of poverty rose tragically and contributed to dangerous internal conflicts. During the Clinton administration, the trade deficit reached record levels yet again, and the dollar soared to unusually high levels -- both crises in waiting.
Here are some questions I wish that the senators had pursued more persistently and that Mr. O'Neill had answered more fully:
How long can the United States live with ever-higher trade deficits?
One damaging economic mantra of the last two decades has been that when America buys much more from abroad than it sells, it merely reflects the nation's economic strength. The problem is that the rising trade deficit also results in enormous borrowing, as foreigners must invest those dollars, usually by lending to America. Even the centrist Institute for International Economics now warns that this cannot go on forever. If investors lose confidence in American investments and sell the dollar aggressively, especially if the stock market continues to fall, America will find itself short of capital just as inflation is being fueled by rising import prices. It would make it hard to cut interest rates enough to stimulate a sagging economy.
Is the high dollar undermining our export industries?
The Wall Street point of view has so long dominated Washington policy-making that the nation has almost forgotten how damaging a high dollar can be to American industry. Wall Street liked the high dollar because it attracted investment from abroad. But it also raises the prices of the nation's exports, and discourages further investment in these industries. How do you reduce the trade deficit if you do not sufficiently invest in export industries? 
Wall Street is suspicious of Mr. O'Neill's basic-industry background, and he showed some sensitivity to market psychology when he announced at the outset of the hearings that he supported the Clinton administration's high-dollar policy. One can only hope he takes a more rounded view in practice.
If the American economy slows down, will economies in Asia and elsewhere be vulnerable again to financial crisis?
Everyone wants a soft landing here -- a slowdown in the rate of economic growth that stops short of recession. We are told that this would at last reduce the trade deficit, as Americans buy fewer imports. It would reduce inflationary pressures. It would enable the expansion to continue.
But analysts often talk as if America were in a vacuum. One serious consequence of an American slowdown would be a sharp drop in exports by the recovering Asian nations, whose finances are still generally shaky. Given America's high levels of debt, it is not so obvious that the nation will as easily withstand a repeat of 1997's crisis.
How would the Bush administration reform the world's financial architecture?
It is going on four years since the Asian financial crisis. Yet despite suggestions for reform from thinkers as diverse as Barry Eichengreen of the University of California at Berkeley; Joseph Stiglitz, formerly of the World Bank; and George Soros, the financier, almost no reforms have been started.
It is important to know more clearly what role Mr. O'Neill believes "hot money" had in the crisis. The flow of such short-term debt was encouraged by the aggressive loosening of controls demanded by the Clinton administration. Might Mr. O'Neill favor modest controls? Also, there are as yet no new provisions that require Western lenders to Asian investors to suffer the consequences of losses on those investments. This has led to a widely criticized "moral hazard," enabling rich institutional investors to make loans with little risk.
Will the Bush administration be concerned about growing competition from the euro?
The United States was able to attract capital from abroad to compensate for its low savings rate in part because investors worldwide believed the safest place for their money was the dollar. But if the euro, the single currency adopted by 12 European nations, gains credibility, it could well become a competing reserve currency. Contrary to some flippant American analyses, the euro has been a significant success abroad. All the more reason for America to put its finances in better balance.
Will the Bush administration attack worker abuses and environmental degradation abroad?
A case can be made that the World Trade Organization is not the place to demand ultimatums over worker rights and environmental standards, although some moderate conditions for trade make sense. But the carrot might work better than the stick, as the economist Jagdish Bhagwati of Columbia urges. We might, for example, be able to reward countries with financial benefits for improved working conditions. We might be able to use institutions like the International Labor Organization more effectively.
How seriously will the Bush Administration commit itself to reducing poverty around the world?
In my view, such a humanitarian objective is reward enough on its own and would only reinforce America's own values. But it is also good politics. Nothing is more important to peace in Kosovo, for example, than economic development. The same is generally true of South Asia and Africa. There is no better social policy than economic growth, but evidence is clear that social programs are also necessary to alleviate poverty. A sensitive hand at the Treasury concerning these matters would be helpful.
A confirmation hearing is not a traditional forum for complete frankness. But I would very much like to know that beyond paying simple lip service the Bush team is truly aware that domestic and international economic concerns are inseparable. In today's world, insularity would only backfire.

HEADLINE: Clinton Spends a Day Back in Arkansas, Where It All Started 

BYLINE:  By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 17 

 BODY:
Returning to the city where his political career began a quarter-century ago, President Clinton told Arkansans today that he had never forgot his roots as a "little boy on South Hervey Street" even as he rose to the highest office in the land.
 It was the final out-of-town trip of the Clinton presidency, and Mr. Clinton said there was no more fitting place for such a symbolic journey than the state capital where he presided as governor for nearly five terms and where, one fall day in 1991, he announced his bid for the presidency on the white-columned portico of the Old Statehouse. 
 This afternoon, the president stepped onto the rostrum of the House chamber -- where he appeared regularly as a new governor with his eye on an even bigger prize -- and spoke for nearly an hour of the long journey he had traveled and the many challenges that would outlast his presidency. 
"I will leave office at noon on the 20th, amazingly grateful that somehow the mystery of this great democracy gave me the chance to go from a little boy on South Hervey Street in Hope, Ark., to the White House," he said.
While the trip was heavy with nostalgia, there was a bit of fence-mending on the agenda as well. The president, addressing a joint session of the Legislature, sought to quell hometown critics who have complained that he had turned his back on Arkansas when he headed east.
Mr. Clinton said he had appointed 460 Arkansans to positions in his administration over the last eight years, including aides and cabinet secretaries. He also recited the multiple helpings of pork he had delivered his home state this year alone, including $38 million for water projects, $592 million in highway money and more money to rebuild the bridges spanning the Great River and State Highway 82.
Although Mr. Clinton has new residences in New York and Washington, he made clear today that he would continue to return regularly to Arkansas, where his presidential library, complete with a presidential apartment, will be built.
"I call him our home boy," said State Senator William Walker Jr., who was a young representative in Mr. Clinton's days as governor. "We're happy to share him with D.C. and New York."
Mr. Clinton was in a reflective mood today as the days of his presidency dwindled to a precious few.
"For all the storms and all the sunshine, there has never been a day -- and tonight will be the same when I get home -- that I haven't landed on that helicopter on the back of the White House lawn and not felt a thrill, not felt like a 17-year-old boy visiting the White House for the first time," Mr. Clinton said. "And when I walk out of the White House for the last time and I sit at the inauguration of my successor, and I leave this office, I will leave more idealistic and more hopeful about my country than the day I took the oath of office, and that's how you ought to feel."
He invited some high school classmates aboard Air Force One on the flight from Washington and recounted how he had recently reread his first inaugural speech as governor, which he delivered in 1979.
Although on the ground for only about five hours, Mr. Clinton packed his schedule tight. He shook every hand extended to him in the Capitol and met privately with legislative leaders in his old offices, where he used to keep an Arkansas-made fiddle on the mantelpiece and portraits of Lincoln and Churchill on the walls.
Later, he visited a sick friend in the hospital and held a rally at the airport for several hundred backers. On the flight home, the last of almost 500 flights over the course of his presidency, Mr. Clinton invited a group of journalists who had covered his 1992 campaign to join him for dinner and reminisce about the last eight years.
In his remarks today, Mr. Clinton mentioned the recent election controversy between Vice President Gore and President-elect Bush but he did not repeat the assertion he made last week that Republicans had achieved victory only by unfairly stopping the count.
Today, he urged lawmakers in Arkansas and other states to work to ensure that their ballot-counting methods were sound and that no such disputes over punch-card systems occurred in the future.
"I personally think that the pencil system I use on my absentee ballot here from Pulaski County is a lot better, a lot less subject to messing up, and can also be counted by machine, so it can be counted more quickly," the president said.
Arkansas played a critical role in refining Mr. Clinton's political philosophy as well as his political combat skills.
He lost his first congressional bid in 1974. Two years later, he became attorney general and then, in 1978, the youngest governor in the country. Voters ousted him in 1980, sending the ambitious young man home to lick his wounds. But Mr. Clinton clawed his way back to the state house two years later. He was re-elected in 1984, and again, for four-year terms, in 1986 and 1990.
"Everything that I have been able to do as president is, in no small measure, a result of the life I lived and the jobs I had in Arkansas," he said today before leaving Little Rock. "My conviction that politics requires a vision and a strategy based on sound ideas and a belief that you can make a difference -- from education reform to economic policy to welfare reform and health care to building one America -- those things were formed here."

HEADLINE: Washington's Guessing Game 

 BODY:
Official Washington seems a little confused these days. President Clinton's long goodbye and President-elect George W. Bush's truncated transition seem to have dampened the anticipatory mood that usually grips the capital before an inauguration. Perhaps things will perk up a bit now that Mr. Bush and his wife, Laura, are in town. A city that loves its history will also be glad to see former President George H. W. Bush. As the younger Mr. Bush remarked, this inauguration will be the first since 1961 in which a father has watched his son take the oath. It will also be, of course, just the second time in the nation's history that the son of a former president has achieved the same office.
 But history is not the only thing that matters to Washington. There is also the forward-looking local sport of sizing up the new leader. On that score, a subdued puzzlement reigns on Capitol Hill. Not since Ronald Reagan's advent in 1981 has there been deeper curiosity over how a new chief executive will govern and what he really wants. And it does not take a lot of snooping around to discover that Republicans and Democrats alike are beginning to suspect that President-elect Bush is far more conservative than either side suspected during the campaign. 
 Based on his cabinet appointments, his advocacy of a big, regressive tax cut and his initial statements on foreign relations, the president-elect now stands closer ideologically to Mr. Reagan than to his own father. For example, Congressional Democrats are being told that Mr. Bush does not like the idea of making his $1.6 trillion tax cut fairer by aiming it at payroll taxes that workers pay. Such targeting would give a much quicker boost to the flagging consumer economy than income tax reductions that will take two or more years to take effect. But Mr. Bush seems instinctively drawn to the classic conservative agenda of trimming high marginal rates, capital gains and estate taxes.
If Mr. Bush does turn out to be as aggressive as he now appears on, say, limiting federal support for abortion rights, building a missile defense system and giving the extractive industries wider access to federal lands, several questions will arise. Did the news media and his debate opponents interrogate him with sufficient energy on his core ideology? Did Mr. Bush knowingly disguise himself as a standard-issue suburban moderate, or did he simply luck into having John McCain line up on his left and Steve Forbes on his right during the Republican primaries? Democrats on Capitol Hill are beginning to consider another theory. In this view, Mr. Bush really did start out as a moderate, but has leapt to the right because his advisers have concluded that the closeness of the election was due to his failure to bond with the most zealous part of the G.O.P. base.
Perhaps this is a good time to remember that a new president sometimes takes a while to discover, or invent, his essential governing persona. Part of the excitement of the Clinton years lay in watching Mr. Clinton define exactly what third-way Democratic politics amounted to. In the campaign, Mr. Bush's speeches stirred the expectation that he wanted to invent a new, distinctive kind of Republicanism, consistent with the party's past but capable of really delivering on the kinder, gentler part of his father's vision.
Yesterday, in a farewell speech in Texas, Mr. Bush returned to the inclusive language of respect and cooperation. He is expected to repeat those themes in his inaugural address. But words alone cannot solve the policy puzzle being played out in the nation's capital, because so far, the message beamed from Austin to Washington has been stark and familiar.

HEADLINE: Norton Hearings to Pose Test for Bush's Plan to Change Policies on Use of Public Lands 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 

 BODY:
The public hearings that begin on Thursday into Gale A. Norton's selection as interior secretary loom as an important test of the big shifts in public-lands policy that President-elect George W. Bush has signaled will be a priority once he takes office.
 Of all Mr. Bush's views, his support for oil drilling in an Alaska wildlife refuge, a position shared by Ms. Norton, and the likelihood that he will rein in President Clinton's land-protection actions have struck some of the hottest buttons on Capitol Hill, and hearings before the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources may serve to show how deep the opposition might be. 
 Not a single senator, Democrat or Republican, has announced an intention to vote against Ms. Norton. Republican senators have expressed strong support, even those who, like Senator Robert C. Smith of New Hampshire, oppose the plan to drill for oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, among other differences.
But in a sign of possible opposition, a number of Democrats, including Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, have likened Ms. Norton to her onetime mentor, James Watt, a Reagan administration interior secretary. 
After a time in which major environmental groups have influenced administration policy making, Ms. Norton, a former attorney general of Colorado, would bring to the post instead a long affiliation with conservative groups that have been supported in large part by the industries most interested in opening more federal lands to development.
These groups include the Political Economy Research Center of Bozeman, Mont., where Ms. Norton was once a fellow; the Mountain States Legal Foundation of Denver, where she began her political career and with which she has worked closely even recently; and the Washington-based Defenders of Property Rights, where she served until early this month on the board of advisers.
Senators are likely to question Ms. Norton closely on her views, past and current, about some of those groups' legal challenges to laws that she would be required to enforce if she wins Senate confirmation.
As Colorado's attorney general, Ms. Norton refused to defend the state against a challenge to a minority set-aside rule that she opposed. That action has prompted questions about whether as interior secretary she would wholeheartedly enforce the Endangered Species Act and other laws she has opposed in the past.
In trying to block her confirmation, opponents including 18 environmental groups have waged an advertising and letter-writing campaign denouncing her as "an anti-environmental extremist." Ms. Norton's appearance at the hearings will be her first since she joined Mr. Bush on Dec. 29 when he announced her selection for a post that she described as carrying an "awesome responsibility." In that appearance, Ms. Norton, 46, described herself as an avid hiker and skier with a special fondness for the "beautiful and special places," and that is an image her supporters have sought to reinforce in response to the campaign against her.
A letter to "fellow Republicans" from Jim Nicholson, the party chief, described Ms. Norton as a "strong environmentalist" who had "worked for more than 20 years in a balanced way on environmental and land issues." And in a television appearance over the weekend, Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, said, "Most of us who represent states out in Middle America think that her views are very moderate and appropriate." Ms. Norton's critics have acknowledged that they have an uphill battle in their effort to block her confirmation.
But until Mr. Bush takes office on Saturday, the committee carrying out the hearings on Ms. Norton will be headed by a Democrat, Senator Jeff Bingaman of New Mexico, and he has promised that Ms. Norton would face "tough questions." Senator Frank H. Murkowski of Alaska, the Republican who will take charge of the panel after Saturday, has been a longtime champion of opening more land in his state and others to oil drilling, and he has been an enthusiastic supporter of Ms. Norton.
As the designee for interior secretary, Ms. Norton has already echoed Mr. Bush's vow to open parts of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska to oil exploration, a position that would seek to overturn more than 15 years of policy and for which the president-elect said last weekend he expected her to "come under fire." She is also expected to use the hearings to back Mr. Bush's announced plans for a swift review and possible reversal of some of Mr. Clinton's most ambitious initiatives putting vast tracts of public lands off limits to development. "There's going to be some property in these giant chunks of land that we can use and not damage the environment," Mr. Bush said in a recent interview.
It would be unusual for senators to oppose Ms. Norton simply because of her support for Mr. Bush's policies. But she is likely to be held to a stricter standard for some of her other stances, particularly a long record of defense for property rights that she said in a 1991 speech might even extend to a "right to pollute."
The context of that statement made clear that Ms. Norton was not suggesting that polluters be given carte blanche, but making the case instead that the government should compensate property owners who were required to heed environmental laws.

HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; 
2 Views on the Rate Of Black Fatalities

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IN the endless campaign to increase seat belt use, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and the Ad Council are about to roll out a television commercial aimed at African-Americans.
 Public safety ads directed to a particular group are unusual. But government officials think the campaign makes sense because surveys show that African-Americans are less likely than other car occupants to buckle up, and they have a higher death rate than whites in vehicle crashes. 
 The advertisement, produced by the Leo Burnett agency, is mostly filled with familiar images from the civil rights struggle and photos depicting moments of black achievement, with the subject matter becoming apparent only at the very end. 
The new effort has not received a universal welcome. A safety analyst is offering a reinterpretation of the problem: African-Americans are more likely to die in crashes, he says, because they are more likely to be pedestrian victims, a problem that a seat belt campaign will do nothing to address.
The analyst, Charles Komanoff, agreed that blacks were less likely to wear seat belts. But he added: "Even though blacks are engaging in more risky behavior inside cars, they're not inside cars as much. Black people don't spend as many hours driving around as white people do; it's the economics, the demographics and where they live."
Mr. Komanoff, who is an advocate for pedestrians, bicyclists and public transportation, assumed that if everyone wore belts, the risk of death would fall by half. Using figures from the Centers for Disease Control for 1997, he counted the number of pedestrians and cyclists aged 14 and under struck and killed by vehicles, compared with those who died in cars while unbelted.
The number of pedestrians and bike riders was 2.5 times as high, he said, and for black children, it was 3 times as high. "This suggests that efforts to reduce childhood mortality from motor vehicles should focus on changing driver behavior on streets and in neighborhoods where children are present, rather than on stiffening or enforcing laws requiring seat belt use," he said.
According to his analysis of the Centers for Disease Control figures, among blacks there are 16.45 fatalities a year per 100,000 people, compared with 15.87 among whites. For those actually inside vehicles, the figures were 8.79 for blacks and 9.37 for whites; the overall figures are higher for blacks because their death rate as pedestrians was higher: 3.25 per 100,000 people, compared with 2.05 for whites.
The number of pedestrian deaths, like the number of highway deaths in general, has declined, to about 4,700 in 1999 from 5,300 in 1997. Pedestrian deaths are mostly a local concern; the Transportation Department puts more emphasis on drunken driving, seat belt use and vehicles' safety flaws.
As with advertising for any product or cause, the challenge in seat belt ads is to keep the appeal fresh. The Ad Council, a public service organization established by the advertising industry, has tried to do this by varying the message over the years. In 1985, the Ad Council introduced Vince and Larry, also created by Leo Burnett, who clowned their way through countless crashes. They were so popular that they spawned a line of children's crash-dummy toys.
But in January 1999, the Transportation Department decided that the humor was not effective and pulled the campaign in favor of a harder line. The Ad Council introduced two "shock" ads, which started out soft but ended in heart-stopping crashes.
In one, a husband makes a midnight run to buy ice cream for his pregnant wife, but is hit by a car as he leaves their driveway. In another, two carloads of teenagers giggle and wave until the boys' sedan is struck by a speeding van. (The old ads and the new one, plus a Volvo video called "Clive Alive," can be viewed at www.nytimes.com/autos.)
The new 30-second ad will start turning up next month as a public service announcement. Using black-and-white photos, it is meant to evoke African-American progress: the first shot is of a man drinking from a water fountain marked "Colored," followed by pictures of the police turning dogs on demonstrators, Rosa Parks sitting defiantly at the front of a bus, Martin Luther King, Jackie Robinson and Colin Powell.
But then there is a screech of brakes, a crash, and a screen that says, "Car crashes are the second-leading cause of death among young African-Americans." The final screen is the familiar "Buckle up."
Peggy Conlon, president of the Ad Council, said her organization had produced some Spanish radio ads to promote seat belt use, but that most such campaigns were not aimed at a particular ethnic group.
The Transportation Department said it was making progress in increasing seat-belt use in general, with about 71 percent buckled in 1999. Blacks are catching up; their rate of use lagged whites' by 10 percentage points in 1996, but is now only 4 points behind, the department said last month when it released a report by independent experts.
But statistics point to a different dimension of the picture. Among whites under 21 who died in crashes, 86.5 percent were in vehicles and 10 percent were pedestrians. (The rest were cyclists or their status was unknown.) Among blacks, only 77 percent were in cars; 18.7 percent were pedestrians.
A spokesman for the traffic safety administration, Tim Hurd, said this was no reason to slack off on persuading more African-Americans to buckle up.
But Mr. Komanoff argued that the focus was wrong, and disputed the premise of the Transportation Department's recent report, that lower use of seat belts constituted a public health crisis. "If it is," he said, "then there's a public health crisis that's twice as big and twice as important -- that blacks are being killed walking or cycling."
Pedestrian deaths could be reduced by redesigning streets to favor pedestrians, he said, and by changing drivers' habits. Persuading people to drive better would benefit both pedestrians and the people inside cars.

HEADLINE: A Felon Seeks Vindication: Will Milken Be Pardoned? 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
MICHAEL R. MILKEN is proud and unrepentant.
 With the Clinton administration down to its final hours, an unanswered question is whether Mr. Milken, the one-time king of junk bonds, will get the pardon he has requested, and with it a claim to vindication. 
 Mr. Milken has cut a wide swath since he left prison in 1993. Until the Securities and Exchange Commission stopped him, he helped arrange some big corporate deals, using the network of friends he had built up when he was the most powerful investment banker in America. 
His Milken Institute organizes conferences in which he sits around talking with panels of Nobel laureates in economics, trading ideas about how to improve the world. He gives away lots of money and always has an entourage. His Web site features pictures of him with Jimmy Carter, Tipper Gore, Mark McGwire, Jesse Jackson, Colin Powell, Kofi Annan, Gray Davis, Arnold Palmer and Ted Turner.
It has been long enough since Mr. Milken's fall from power to evaluate his career. He was a brilliant financier who popularized high-yield financing and came to control the junk bond market in the mid- to late 1980's. Some companies that he financed made good use of the money; others did not. A case can be made that the fear of hostile takeovers he put into executive suites helped make American business more competitive. Some savings and loan institutions suffered from the bonds Mr. Milken sold, but he was not responsible for the crisis in that sector.
Like most people who know Mr. Milken, I like him. He is smart and engaging. At 54, he has more to contribute to society, and I wish him well. But so far as I know, he has never faced up to the reality of the way he abused his power.
Mr. Milken declined to be interviewed, but his spokesman referred me to his Web site, www.mikemilken.com. It is quite a site. On it you will learn of his "legal dispute with government regulators," in which "intense pressure on him and his family" led him to "admit conduct that resulted primarily in violations of securities regulations that had not been prosecuted as crimes before." His prosecution was a "vengeful response by America's business and regulatory establishment." Notwithstanding erroneous press reports, "he had no involvement in insider trading."
That is historical revisionism at its most impressive. The S.E.C. charged him with numerous violations of insider trading laws in concert with Ivan Boesky, the disgraced former takeover stock speculator. It accused him of conspiring with Mr. Boesky to defraud clients of Drexel Burnham Lambert, the brokerage firm Mr. Milken dominated.
Mr. Milken avoided pleading to those charges, but he did admit market manipulation of a type that was clearly illegal. "This is," said David S. Ruder, a professor of securities law at Northwestern who was S.E.C. chairman at the time the charges were filed, "an array of illegal conduct that is unparalleled in the history of the federal securities laws." He added that the S.E.C. had a lot of corroboration on the insider trading charges, including testimony from Mr. Milken's colleagues at Drexel.
"If Milken can do what he did to the securities markets, and then be pardoned for it, the integrity of the markets is clearly in jeopardy," Mr. Ruder said.
Innocence should not be a prerequisite for a pardon. But in cases of serious crimes where guilt was clear, contrition should be. If Mr. Milken gets his pardon, he will no doubt view it as an exoneration. For those who believe in respect for the securities laws, it will be a sad moment.

HEADLINE: Publisher Is Named at The New Yorker 

 BODY:
David L. Kahn, the associate publisher of The New Yorker, was named publisher of the magazine yesterday, said Steve T. Florio, the chief executive of Conde Nast, a subsidiary of Advance Publications. 
 Mr. 
Kahn, 39, succeeds David Carey, who resigned this week to become the chief executive of the newly formed Business Information Group at Gruner & Jahr, overseeing Fast Company and Inc. magazines. 
 Mr. Kahn has been associate publisher of The New Yorker since May 1999, when he came to the magazine from Saveur, where he had been the publisher. As associate publisher at The New Yorker, he oversaw advertising sales in the United States.
"The magazine has been high and it's been low, and we're entering a golden age for The New Yorker," Mr. Kahn said. "Our work, as David Remnick and I have recognized, is just beginning." Mr. Remnick is the magazine's editor.
Mr. Kahn said the recent downturns in the advertising market in the magazine industry were not a cause for alarm for The New Yorker. 
"We keep our finger on the pulse of the advertising economy as well as the general economy," he said. "What The New Yorker has is, if you will, an insurance policy in that we have a very broad-based business, categorically speaking. I think the trend for the magazine itself will outweigh any downswing in the economy."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
I.B.M. Rally Drives Nasdaq To Best Close in 5 Weeks

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks soared higher yesterday as a rosy earnings forecast from I.B.M. propelled the Nasdaq market to a five-week high.
 The upbeat sentiment on Wall Street was also bolstered by fresh evidence that the economy was rapidly running out of steam, which heightened speculation the Federal Reserve might cut interest rates even further to bolster business activity. 
 The Nasdaq composite index blazed to its best finish since Dec. 13 as the I.B.M. cheer spread to other high-technology companies. The Nasdaq ended up 85.71 points, or 3.19 percent, to 2,768.49. 
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 93.94 points, or 0.89 percent, to 10,678.28. The rally by I.B.M. -- up $11.63, to $108.31, to its highest close since mid-October -- made up about three-quarters of the Dow's gain. That offset a loss by Caterpillar, another Dow component, which fell after it forecast a 5 percent to 8 percent drop in profits for 2001.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 18.50 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,347.97.
For the second consecutive trading session, Intel was the Nasdaq's most heavily traded share, gaining $1.69, to $32.19, even though earlier in the week it offered a poor sales outlook and its quarterly earnings just squeaked past Wall Street's forecasts.
"The market seems to be saying it has already factored in the bad news," said Michael Farr, president of Farr, Miller & Washington, a Washington-based fund that manages $379 million. "This trend may have just turned in the past few days -- for the short term." 
Underpinning the market were growing hopes the Fed would come to the economy's rescue with more aggressive interest rate cuts after a key business conditions index dropped sharply, analysts said.
The manufacturing sector in the mid-Atlantic region contracted in January to its most dismal level in more than a decade, the regional Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said yesterday.
"People are willing to look over the lack-of-earnings valley because of the Fed," said Paul Cherney, an analyst at S.& P. MarketScope. "The Fed has bolstered confidence that we will pull through this."
The central bank's next policy-setting meeting is scheduled for Jan. 30-31, less than two weeks away. It is widely expected to lower its key fed funds rate by at least a quarter- point. Earlier this month, the Fed surprised financial markets with a hefty half-point cut.
Apple Computer, which reported its first loss in three years, but beat lowered expectations and said it would return to profitability soon, climbed $1.88, to $18.69.
Caterpillar, the giant maker of construction and mining equipment, fell $2.91, to $41.75. It posted strong profits for the latest quarter but forecast a drop in earnings for 2001, citing slowing sales in North America and price competition from rivals.
Boeing, the aerospace giant and Dow component, fell $1.38, to $57.38, after Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown cut its near-term rating on the stock because of an expected growth slowdown in the airline industry.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
 (By Reuters) -- Treasury bond prices surged again yesterday after a report showing a sharp decline in business conditions in the mid-Atlantic region helped build hopes the Fed would move aggressively to cut interest rates in coming months.
The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said its January business conditions index slumped to minus36.8 in January from minus 4.2 in December. The index, which dropped to its lowest level since December 1990, was far lower than the minus 8.2 economists surveyed by Reuters had forecast.
The data overshadowed earlier jobs and housing starts data that had been slightly more robust than the market had expected, causing government bond prices to dip initially.
The benchmark 10-year note rose 15/32, to 104 27/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.10 percent from 5.16.
The most active 30-year bond rose 21/32, to 111 8/32, as its yield fell to 5.47 percent from 5.52.

HEADLINE: December Rise Ends Down Year for Home Building 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 

 BODY:
Residential construction edged up in December with a surge in new single-family home projects, the government said today, but for all of 2000, housing starts reached their lowest level since 1997.
 The unexpected 0.3 percent gain in new housing projects in December, to a seasonally adjusted 1.575 million units, was bolstered mostly by a 6 percent rise in groundbreaking for single-family homes, the Commerce Department said. Analysts had been expecting a 3.3 percent decline in housing starts. Building permits fell 6.6 percent in December, attributed in part to the cold weather that affected much of the nation. 
 "We are getting a huge lift in this industry from dropping interest rates," said James Glassman, an economist with Chase Securities.
Economists say the gain in starts, coupled with an upward revision to the November number, was a sign that the number of new housing projects had stabilized after a downward trend in the first half of 2000.
"This should provide more ammunition in the case that the economy is having a soft landing," said Paul Christopher, economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis.
That relatively upbeat news was followed by a bleak report from the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia showing that the manufacturing sector in the mid-Atlantic region contracted sharply in January, turning in its worst performance in more than a decade.
For the year, housing starts fell 4.4 percent, to 1.59 million units.
A separate government report today showed that the number of newly unemployed workers plunged an unexpectedly steep 37,000 last week, to its lowest level in more than three months.
But analysts have warned against reading too much into the weekly figures for unemployment claims, saying distortions from the harsh weather and the holiday season would mar the true picture of the labor market, which had been exceedingly tight throughout 1999 and for about the first 10 months of 2000.

HEADLINE: Officials Call Economy Down, But Not Out, in the Philippines 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: MANILA, Jan. 18 

 BODY:
As tens of thousands of anti-government protesters choked the streets of this city's business district for a third day, three top advisers to President Joseph Estrada acknowledged that the political turmoil was damaging the economy of the Philippines.
 But they said that the collapse of Mr. Estrada's impeachment trial on Tuesday would not propel the country into a recession, though it could mean several more months of political uncertainty and social unrest. 
 "We've gone over and over the numbers, and in the worst-case scenario, we'll still have 2 percent growth," said Jose T. Pardo, the finance secretary. 
That is half the rate of growth that the Philippines recorded last year, and it would put the country behind almost all its Asian neighbors. Still, it is a positive statistic, and Mr. Estrada's aides said it would be no small feat for a country consumed by the legal travails of its leader, who was being tried on corruption charges.
"The year 2000 was one of the worst in our history," said Edgardo Angara, executive secretary to Mr. Estrada. "The whole year was a series of disasters, natural and man-made. Coming out of that horror, it's quite respectable."
Business leaders are more pessimistic, noting that the crisis has scared away foreign investors, caused local companies to cancel expansion plans, and prompted wealthy Filipinos to move their money offshore. That in turn has drained the Philippine peso and the stock market. After plunging 6 percent on Wednesday, shares fell another 1.4 percent today, and the peso traded near its all-time low of 55 pesos to the United States dollar.
"The economy is falling faster and more unpredictably than anybody could have imagined," said Guillermo M. Luz, the executive director of the Makati Business Club, which represents some of the biggest Philippine companies. "I would not discount the possibility of a recession," he said. 
With Mr. Estrada's impeachment trial suspended indefinitely and with him showing every sign of digging in, business people worry that the Philippines will be rudderless for the next six months. 
The Makati Business Club has demanded that Mr. Estrada resign even before his fate is decided in the Senate. The president is accused of taking more than $10 million in kickbacks from illegal gambling and from tobacco taxes. He has denied the allegations and says he will leave only if convicted. That prospect became much less likely on Tuesday, after the Senate voted to exclude potentially damaging evidence against Mr. Estrada. Prosecutors from the House resigned in protest, and the trial was halted.
Senator Franklin M. Drilon, who voted to allow the evidence, said he did not believe the trial would resume until July, after legislative elections. A new Senate, with fewer of Mr. Estrada's allies, might yet convict him, Senator Drilon said. But by then the damage to the economy would be done. 
Mr. Estrada's advisers said the impeachment trial could resume as early as next week if the House appointed new prosecutors. One of the prosecutors who resigned, Joker Arroyo, hinted today that the old team might return if Mr. Estrada agreed to testify, something he has resisted. 
The advisers said most foreign investors were steering clear of the Philippines until it resolved the president's case as well as a stock-manipulation case involving one of Mr. Estrada's friends.
"Clearly, we have to win back the confidence of portfolio investors," said Rafael Buenaventura, the governor of the Philippine Central Bank. "Maybe they'll start coming back now that the Nasdaq has cooled off in the United States."
Mr. Buenaventura said he was less concerned about the peso, which on Wednesday suffered its biggest one-day drop since July 1997. He said it was "emotionally driven," and not worth fighting with the usual remedy of higher interest rates.
Mr. Buenaventura said he was optimistic that the peso had stabilized at 55 pesos to the dollar. Once the crisis subsided, he said, it would bounce back to what he called its proper level: 47 pesos to the dollar.
Given the furies swirling around them, Mr. Estrada's advisers seem remarkably calm.

HEADLINE: Nortel Reports Solid Quarterly Earnings 

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
Nortel Networks, the largest maker of fiber optic equipment, reported strong growth in earnings and revenue for the fourth quarter yesterday, but warned that tight financing for communications companies might cause sales to reach only the low end of estimates in the months ahead.
 Nortel said net earnings, excluding costs from acquisitions, were $825 million in the quarter, or 26 cents a share, matching estimates of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. Including acquisition costs, Nortel had a net loss of $1.41 billion, or 46 cents a share. 
 The company's revenue of $8.82 billion in the fourth quarter, a 34 percent increase from the year-earlier period, narrowly beat a First Call estimate of $8.65 billion. Robust sales of fiber optic equipment fueled much of the growth of revenue and earnings at Nortel, which is based in Brampton, Ontario.
But concern over the effect of a slowing economy on the communications industry led Nortel to caution investors that revenue and earnings should grow 30 percent this year, compared with previous estimates of 30 to 35 percent. Expectations that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates if the economy deteriorates encouraged it to maintain relatively aggressive estimates, the company said.
"The slowing economy presents its challenges, but Nortel is still in a solid position to sell to big clients that haven't been hit by the negative financing climate," said Eric Allard, director of research at Smith & Thomas Asset Management.
Signs of strain at some of the small, relatively young communications companies formed to compete with big local and long-distance phone companies have been a major source of concern. Still, Nortel appears to be weathering the changes in the communications industry better than Lucent Technologies, one if its main rivals, which has recently struggled with slower revenue and earnings growth.
"A lot of our customers are looking closer at who they think will be in a stronger position in a couple of years when doing big equipment purchases," John Roth, Nortel's chief executive, said in a telephone interview. Asked if he was making a statement about the fortunes of Lucent, Mr. Roth replied: "The long-term prospects of suppliers are becoming much more important." 
Nortel's stock climbed $1.94, to $36.69 yesterday, and rose as high as $38 in after-hours trading after its earnings were released, amid a wider rally in shares of communications equipment companies.
Even so, industry followers say nimble new competitors are waiting in the wings.
"The explosion of venture capital investment in new fiber optic companies is bringing some potential competitors to fruition," said John Simpson, a portfolio manager at Oeschle International Advisors in Boston.
Mr. Simpson cited ONI Systems, a maker of fiber optic equipment that went public last May, as one company that Nortel needs to watch out for. Shares in ONI, which is based in San Jose, Calif., rose $3.94, to $42.
