HEADLINE: Troubled Nonprofit Group Gives Up Management Duties 

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
The Banana Kelly Community Improvement Association, a once-vaunted but more recently troubled nonprofit organization in the Bronx, has announced that another non-profit, Promesa Enterprises, will take over day-to-day management of about 27 of its buildings, its social service operations and its finances.
 Separately, 14 of Banana Kelly's other buildings, which it owns in partnership with the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, a national nonprofit organization, are being turned over to another outside manager. 
 Banana Kelly, established in 1978 when the Bronx was being decimated by arson and abandonment, was once praised as a national model for residents trying to restore housing and their neighborhoods. But in recent years, it has been criticized for financial mismanagement and the deteriorating conditions of its buildings. 
Promesa, an acronym for Puerto Rican Organization to Motivate, Enlighten and Serve Addicts, was founded as a drug rehabilitation program. Over the years, it, too, expanded into housing and other services, and it also has a troubled past.
In 1992, Promesa's chief financial officer was murdered after discovering discrepancies during an audit, and another employee was convicted of hiring two teenagers to kill her. The teenagers were also convicted. A subsequent city investigation of the organization's finances found that tens of thousands of dollars were missing.
But Promesa's chief executive officer since 1996, Ruben Medina, has been credited with restoring its reputation. Promesa reimbursed the city for the missing money and is now a $30 million corporation with about 400 employees. On Wednesday, Representative Jose E. Serrano announced a $2 million grant to Promesa for economic development.
Under the agreement with Promesa, Mr. Medina will become Banana Kelly's acting administrator. Yolanda Rivera, Banana Kelly's board chairwoman since 1985, will remain in that role and also assume the role of president, according to a news release. Since 1991, she has served at various points as president, chief executive officer and executive director, an arrangement that has been criticized because nonprofit groups traditionally have day-to-day management that is distinct from their boards.
Banana Kelly referred all questions about the management contract to Mr. Medina, who said he did not want to comment until he had had more time to examine Banana Kelly's situation.
Over the years, Banana Kelly's government financing has shrunk dramatically and its economic development plans have gone unrealized. Tenants say they have paid the price for those trends and for mismanagement at the organization.
Concern about tenants' living conditions and Banana Kelly's finances prompted the Local Initiatives Support Corporation to give an outside manager control of the 14 buildings that it has held in partnership with Banana Kelly.
Mark Yahr, a program vice president for the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, which provides financial and technical assistance to neighborhood-based housing groups, said the it would decide after a year or so whether to return the buildings to Banana Kelly or to give them to other community-based organizations.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Sun Says Second-Quarter Earnings Met Expectations

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 

 BODY:
Shaking the profit woes faced by many other high-technology companies these days, Sun Microsystems Inc. said today that its quarterly earnings met Wall Street's expectations. The company added that although sales soared 44 percent, it still missed targets because of a sudden downturn in December.
 Sun reported net income of $552 million, a 56 percent increase from the year before, when it earned $354 million. The company posted earnings, not including costs related to acquisitions, of 16 cents a share, compared with 10 cents a year before, for the second fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 31. 
 "I always prefer the tough times," Scott McNealy, the company's chief executive, told analysts in a conference call. "It's where we can separate the followers from the leaders, and we're leading here in the marketplace." 
Sun was one of few companies to avoid surprising Wall Street with earnings warnings during the quarter. Companies like Intel, Hewlett-Packard and even Microsoft warned early that the slowdown in personal computer sales would cause revenues to miss expectations.
Revenues increased from $3.554 billion to $5.115 billion, an increase of 44 percent. But after the company predicted that its growth percentage would be in the high 40's, analysts set their revenue expectation to $5.29 billion, according to consensus estimates by First Call/Thomson Financial.
"They had to control expenses pretty dramatically to deliver the numbers" that analysts expected for earnings, said Richard Chu, a managing director with SG Cowen.
Based on the lower-than-expected sales last quarter and a shaky economic climate, Michael Lehman, Sun's chief financial officer, revised his revenue estimates for the year slightly downward. Instead of percent growth "in the mid-30's" predicted last quarter, Mr. Lehman said, Sun's revenues will grow 30 percent to 35 percent.
"There are a couple of companies out there that said they have no idea how things are going to go in the next few months" Mr. Lehman said in an interview. "We're not saying that."
Sun executives remained bullish in their outlook, saying the company picked up market share during the quarter. Revenue grew 34 percent in the United States, 53 percent in Europe, 38 percent in Japan, and 70 percent in the rest of the world, they said.
Orders, which indicate future sales, were $4.953 billion, up 32 percent from the previous year but less than the company's expectations of a growth percentage in the high 30's.
In the quarter, Sun completed its purchase of Cobalt Networks for $2.061 billion in stock. The company said it took a charge of about $130 million, or 4 cents a share, in accounting charges because of the acquisition.
Today, Sun released its first product using Cobalt technology and, in doing so, set its sights on the lower end of the server market. Sun has historically specialized in high-end computer servers that cost as much as $1 million and can handle a wide range of tasks, like managing computer networks and e-mail. But the Cobalt product is a so-called server appliance, which is designed to perform one task well and can be linked to other server appliances to handle increased demand. And Sun's new line of Netra servers, also announced today, is its first offering priced less than $1,000.
The company said it was taking aim on personal computer makers like Dell and Compaq, which have pushed harder into the low-end server market in an effort to offset declining PC sales.
"When one looks at Sun objectively, you realize that here's a company that's been on a tremendous roll for the last two years, thus comparisons are difficult to do," said George D. Elling, an analyst with Lehman Brothers.
Sun also announced today that AOL Time Warner had agreed to spend $400 million on Sun computer servers and services in the next two years to support its America Online network. The deal increased AOL's commitment to Sun to $900 million. Before its merger with Time Warner, AOL agreed to buy $500 million in services and equipment from Sun as part of AOL's purchase of Netscape Communications in 1998.
On news of the AOL commitment, investors pushed Sun shares up $2.50, nearly 8 percent, to close at $34.88. Sun announced its earnings after markets closed. Sun shares fell 63 cents to $34.25 after results were released.

HEADLINE: Cell Phones for the World's Poor; 
Hook Up Rural Asia, Some Say, And Ease Poverty

BYLINE:  By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SUKABABO, Indonesia 

 BODY:
This village in northern Sumatra is home to 832 people who live on less than 50 cents a day farming the rich volcanic soil. No one can use the Internet. Cellular signals do not reach it. The nearest telephone is more than three miles away.
 "If I miss my parents, I just come back to my village," said Priska Ika, a gregarious 20-year-old visiting her home from college in the city of Medan, 50 miles to the northeast. 
 During the heady days of the dot-com boom, the hope was that a coming era of telecommunications would help communities in the developing world like Sukababo narrow the digital divide between rich and poor, becoming more closely linked to the wider world. In a country where fewer than 2 of every 100 people use the Internet, the reasoning went, wireless devices on a new global standard would bring e-mail to people too poor for personal computers. And digital radio waves would embrace communities telephone lines have yet to reach. 
The new era begins this year. From Japan, a so-called third generation of cellular telephone technology giving individuals much greater mobile access to the Internet is ready for Europe, then the United States and the rest of the world.
But it will not be coming here to Sukababo. With technology stocks slumping, the telecommunications industry reeling at the cost of its wireless future, and rising doubts that even rich-country users will quickly embrace the new technology, a more pessimistic forecast for the third generation, or 3G, is emerging. 
"It's an illusion to think that 3G will close the digital divide," said Bertrand Bidaud, a wireless industry analyst at the Gartner Group in Singapore.
The problem is that despite rapid urbanization, most people in the developing world still do not live in cities. They live in scattered villages like Sukababo, part of a rural sprawl too thinly spread and too poor to justify expensive new networks. Costly licenses and equipment militate against the spread of mobile phones to poor communities, especially rural ones, putting the burden on governments to lure operators into seemingly unprofitable areas. 
More than just debunking dot-com hyperbole, this starker assessment of the potential in the developing world for third-generation wireless contradicts the very basis of the International Telecommunications Union's plea 15 years ago for the new standard's development -- to accelerate the spread of communications.
Now, some doubt whether the time is right for the rural poor to be connected at all. Microsoft's chairman, William H. Gates, quarreled with some of the priorities of technology enthusiasts at a recent industry conference, saying that the Internet was useless to people who lacked basics of life. 
At the "creating digital dividends" conference in Seattle a couple of months ago, Mr. Gates was highly skeptical. The premise was that "market drivers" could be used "to bring the benefits of connectivity and participation in the e-economy to all of the world's six billion people." Mr. Gates would have little of this.
"Do people have a clear view of what it means to live on $1 a day?" he asked. "There's no electricity in that house -- none." 
When a moderator brought up solar power, Mr. Gates shot back: "No. You can't afford a solar power system for less than $1 a day." And, "You're just buying food, you're trying to stay alive." 
Still, many high-technology executives, politicians and development experts insist that without Internet access, thousands of poor communities are speedily falling into the global economy's wake.
"Those people won't take advantage of the benefits that can come out of e-commerce and access to information," said Bernard Drum, an official at the World Bank in Jakarta, Indonesia's capital. "And people who do take advantage of those opportunities will be ahead of the game."
Being connected means more than shopping on eBay. Internet evangelists believe that the Web can help bring better education and health care to rural areas, and make them wealthier, too. 
"Poor people are poor because they're stuck in an environment that is stifling," said Iqbal Z. Quadir, a former New York investment banker who returned to his native Bangladesh in 1996 to build a rural cellular network with Grameen Bank. "If they are connected, the environment changes and everyone's life gets better."
Mr. Quadir's GrameenPhone lends money to village women to buy cellular telephones. They in turn sell fellow villagers time on the phone to do things like call relatives abroad. Today, GrameenPhone's rural resellers connect 2,800 villages and pocket $2 a day -- equivalent to a large chunk of average income. 
E-mail would not do much good in rural Bangladesh, Mr. Quadir says; only 4 of every 10 people can read. But throughout Southeast Asia, roughly 9 of 10 people can read.
Cellular operators in Southeast Asia witnessed long ago how rural populations can benefit from being connected. In Thailand, one operator found shrimp farmers calling Bangkok to get prices -- and the upper hand on middlemen. Similarly, Smart Communications, a Philippine cellular operator, learned that vegetable farmers who had never had regular fixed-line phone service were using mobile phones to market their produce in Manila. 
Sukababo offers a good contrast. The village sits on a rolling volcanic plateau where people farm a variety of crops: everything from bananas to chili peppers. Rice paddies girdle the hills. Coconut palms shade ripening corn. 
Modern life has intruded: traditional thatched-roof houses on stilts have given way to corrugated iron topped by power lines and satellite TV dishes. Leonardo Ginting, 11, can watch movies on video compact discs, but has never heard of the Internet. In a few years, he will head to the nearest high school, 12 miles away, a move that will cost his family almost half the average income here. Advocates of rural connectivity say that the Internet can bring the classroom to Sukababo. 
The Internet could also help local farmers. Sukababo lost its corn crop a few years ago to blight, and farmers here have not been able to grow a decent one since, said Bagi Kita Ginting, the village headman, and no relation to Leonardo. He has never heard of the Internet, either. Farmers elsewhere are able to learn about crop diseases and resistant strains from the Web.
If only Sukababo could get a dial tone. In theory, the laws of supply and demand should drive the wireless industry to develop so that it can deliver some version of its product to anyone willing to pay for it. Sukababo, after all, has shampoo, store-bought clothes and television sets. Children even play with beeping toy mobile phones.
But communications technologies have yet to yield equivalent economies of scale. Though costs have come down significantly, many executives argue that incompatible mobile phone technologies operating at conflicting frequencies have interfered with cellular's propagation.
In the countryside, "it's simply not economically feasible to put up cellular networks," said Ramon R. Isberto, public affairs director of Smart Communications, the Philippine operator. "You'd have to put up a lot of base stations for very little traffic. It's not a workable business case."
The International Telecommunications Union first proposed the development of third-generation cellular technology as a global standard to solve this problem. But corporate bickering over rival technologies ultimately led it to endorse three different versions. "Unfortunately, because of some differences in technologies, we couldn't take one simple standard," said the group's secretary general, Yoshio Utsumi.
Whatever the choice, the cost of building a third-generation network could be more than double the expense for existing digital networks, said Tay Soo Meng, vice president for mobile networks at Singapore Telecommunications. Raising funds will not be easy, particularly in today's tougher financial environment, analysts say. 
Cellular operators in developing countries, therefore, are likely to hold off, relying in the meantime on technical upgrades of existing digital networks that offer Internet access at slower speeds. Even then, analysts say, they are likely to concentrate on cities, where incomes are higher and they can reach more customers in a smaller area.
Experts say the only way the new technology will ultimately reach villagers is if governments play a more active role in pushing networks outward. The Philippines, for instance, required cellular operators to extend their digital service to every major population center. Because the Philippines, unlike some other countries in the region, is at least 50 percent urban, many people are now within reach of a cellular network.
How governments award licenses will also be crucial, analysts say. Most recommend against auctions, pointing to Britain's and Germany's multibillion-dollar auctions last year to show how fierce bidding inflates prices. Instead, experts recommend picking operators with the best network plans. Others warn that such beauty contests favor incumbents, many of them controlled by the crony conglomerates that still dominate Asian economies.
Nonetheless, the Philippines may have no choice but to auction off licenses, said Edgardo Cabarrios, director of the common carriers authorization department of the National Telecommunications Commission. The law requires an auction process if, as is likely, bidders outnumber licenses. Indonesia is also leaning toward auctions, said Sasmito Dirdjo, director general of the transportation and communications ministry. 
Some think that governments should adopt a laissez-faire approach, intervening only to ensure fair competition. "In Indonesia, where the government has a history of confusion and chaos," Mr. Drum of the World Bank said, "they should create an enabling environment, creating incentives, and let the private sector do it."
Others maintain that the Internet, like power and water, is a public utility that will never be distributed equitably if left to business. The best comparison is with the development of Interstate highways in the United States, said Ken Gibson, the head of McKinsey & Company's Indonesian office. "If it had been left to the private sector," he said, "the Interstates would never have been built."
Other technologies could deliver Internet service to rural areas. Satellites, for instance, have been used to beam access to a few showcase villages in South Africa and Borneo. Microwaves are linking villages in Bhutan. 
But these technologies are expensive and, so far, they lack the mass-market appeal to pay for themselves.
Mr. Utsumi says he is optimistic that third-generation technology will gain popularity in industrial nations quickly enough to bring equipment costs down to levels affordable in poorer countries.
Development experts, in the meantime, hope that plain old telephone lines can be extended to create community telecenters, where rural residents can call or use the Internet. In Indonesia, for example, no-frills Internet cafes are already springing up in cities and in college towns. 
The key to moving the latest telecommunications to the world's hinterlands may lie not in new technology, development experts say, but in harnessing the collective buying power of the rural residents.
"The real secret is to create a digital identity for people who are using shared access points," said Paul Meyer, an American who started the first Internet service in Kosovo. 'We have to get over the mentality that consumers are people who have a PC or a phone."
The Internet would find a warm reception in Sukababo. "It would be great if we could have it," Mr. Ginting, the headman, said after Ms. Ika explained what the Internet is. "Now we have to go to Munte," three miles away, "just to make a phone call."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Homeowners' Equity Share Has Fallen to Record Low
For most American families, their home is their biggest investment, and after years of prosperity in which home prices rose substantially, family wealth has increased as well. But millions of households borrowed heavily against their homes, often to support ever greater spending.
 The borrowing has been so extensive that homeowners have let their ownership shares deteriorate over the last two decades to the lowest level on record, the Federal Reserve reports. Page A1. 

Day 2 of Power Cutoffs in California
Northern and central California endured a second, more extensive day of rotating blackouts affecting several million customers, but officials said that large purchases of power by the state under the governor's emergency decree helped avert even more cutoffs. A1.

Surprise Resignation at Ad Agency
Chris Jones, 45, left, the youngest chief executive in the history of J. Walter Thompson in New York, the world's fourth-largest advertising agency, resigned unexpectedly for health reasons, executives there said. Mr. Jones, who became chief in January 1997, is being succeeded by Peter A. Schweitzer, 61. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C4.

North America Operations Hurt Ford
Fourth-quarter profit at Ford dropped 40 percent as slower sales in a weakening American economy crippled profits in the automaker's North American operations. C5.

I.B.M. Propels Stocks Higher
Stocks soared on the strength of I.B.M., which rose after a positive earnings report. The Nasdaq composite index rose 85.71 points, or 3.2 percent, to 2,768.49, its best close since Dec. 13. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 93.94 points, or 0.9 percent, to 10,678.28. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 18.50 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,347.97. C5.

Collaboration on Supercomputer
In a melding of nuclear research and genetic research, Celera Genomics, Sandia National Laboratories and Compaq Computer say they will work together to develop what could be the world's fastest supercomputer. C3.

Sun Microsystems Meets Estimates
Sun Microsystems said that its quarterly earnings met Wall Street's expectations. The company added that although sales soared 44 percent, they still missed targets because of a sudden downturn in December. C3.

Residential Construction Climbs
Residential construction edged up 0.3 percent in December, to 1.575 million units, bolstered mostly by a 6 percent rise in groundbreaking for single-family homes, the Commerce Department said. Analysts had been expecting a 3.3 percent decline in housing starts. The report contained a note of caution as building permits fell 6.6 percent in December, attributed in part to the cold weather that affected much of the nation. C5.

Daimler Seen in Talks With Lernout
DaimlerChrysler is in early discussions to acquire voice-recognition technology from Lernout & Hauspie, the scandal-plagued Belgian company that is in bankruptcy, executives close to the talks said. C4.

Teenager Pleads Guilty to Hacking
A 16-year-old computer hacker who goes by the name Mafiaboy pleaded guilty in Montreal to 56 charges related to attacks last year on some of the busiest commercial Web sites in the United States. A13.

HEADLINE: On the Eve of the Bush Presidency 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Treasury Choice Varies From Bush on Tax Outlook" (front page, Jan. 18): 
 Treasury Secretary-designate Paul H. O'Neill appears to recognize that tax cuts for the wealthy are unlikely to have significant stimulatory effects on the economy. 
Yet while monetary policy may be the first line of action in fighting the downturn, tax cuts, which he favors, may indeed help. 
 Consider this proposal: Give each taxpayer an equal one-time, lump-sum tax rebate. This would increase consumption. Even more important, it might receive bipartisan support, as it would benefit every American equally in absolute terms while being progressive in relative terms. 
Moreover, this plan is prudent because it postpones more permanent cuts until there is more clarity about the extent of the downturn. The size of the tax cut could be negotiated separately. This could be the new administration's first success.

ERAN BINENBAUM
Berkeley, Calif., Jan. 18, 2001

HEADLINE: California Endures A 2nd Straight Day Of Power Blackouts 

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 

 BODY:
Northern and Central California endured a second, more extensive day of rotating blackouts today affecting several million people, but officials said that large purchases of power by the state under the governor's emergency decree helped avert additional cutoffs during the afternoon.
 The blackouts, in the region covered by the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, began about 9:50 a.m. and continued until a little after noon, with most customers losing power for about an hour at a time. 
 The controlled power shutdowns were spread thinly and widely through many neighborhoods and across hundreds of miles, in cities including San Francisco, Sacramento and Modesto. While most people said they coped with the disruptions, there were growing concerns about how prolonged blackouts could harm the state's economy, as well as nervousness in the Legislature, now the focus for solutions, about the impact on the state's budget.
Gov. Gray Davis announced late Wednesday evening that he was declaring a state of emergency. That would permit the state to buy electricity for utilities; officials said that the governor hoped to spend about $400 million on the purchases -- a figure the State Senate approved this evening -- but that given the demands, that sum might get the state only through next week. 
Officials at the California Independent System Operator, which oversees the electricity transmission system, said the Department of Water Resources, the agency designated to make the purchases, had been buying roughly 1,200 megawatts an hour of electricity that might not have been available otherwise because of concern over whether the private utilities would be able to pay for it.
Given the fact that power rates in the overheated wholesale market were running $200 to $800 per megawatt an hour, that means the emergency program was costing California about $600,000 an hour. It is reselling the power immediately to private utilities, but they have about 75 days to pay the state, said Jim Detmers, the managing director for operations at the system operator.
Since the utilities have already been missing debt payments, the state was bearing an enormous risk that it could be stuck with those costs.
And there are signs that the costs will rise considerably in coming days. Mr. Detmers said that, given the expected shortages and the reluctance of power-generating companies to sell to the utilities, the state's purchases could easily rise to 2,000 megawatts an hour and more.
The governor's declaration put great pressure on the Legislature to move faster to devise solutions to the crisis.
The Legislature has already passed bills that will restructure the agencies that oversee the state's power system and that prohibit the major utilities from selling off generating plants -- measures that are unlikely to bring any short-term relief to the badly overtaxed system.
But even some legislators sympathetic to the governor's proposals said that the uncertain cost of the state's financial intervention left them queasy, and did not make it any clearer what the real solution would be. Several lawmakers and other state officials said that the governor and the Legislature were going to have to decide whether taxpayers or ratepayers were going to bear the real cost of the crisis, many billions of dollars, and accept potentially painful political repercussions.
The governor is a Democrat, and Democrats control both houses of the Legislature.
"This crisis is so open-ended and so expensive potentially in a short period of time we could cross the billion-dollar mark very quickly," said Assemblyman Tony Cardenas, chairman of the Budget Committee in the Assembly. "Me and my colleagues in the Assembly are all saying we are not going to head down that road of an open checkbook. It's a slippery slope."
Philip Angelides, the state treasurer, said the emergency measures would not pose problems, as long as they were temporary.
"This is something we can handle right now," Mr. Angelides said. "The notion here is not to do this long-term."
While most cities, businesses and individuals around the state appeared to be coping well with the temporary power shutdowns, there were indications that the costs of the disruptions and the overall impact on the economy were growing more threatening.
So far, the economic impact appeared modest and uncertain. Moody's Investors Service said today that it was maintaining its strong rating of California's credit, but that it was watching developments closely.
"A protracted period of electricity market instability and unreliability could cause us to revisit our rating outlook, as it would produce a more substantial dampening effect on the economy in the long term," Moody's said.
Even though Southern California has not been hit with the planned rolling blackouts, many industrial customers, who agreed to have their power cut first when shortages were severe in return for lower rates, have been shut down for several days, with little prospect for getting back up soon.
Elaine Cullen, an official at the Los Angeles Economic Development Corporation, said that a number of large industrial concerns in the San Gabriel Valley northwest of downtown Los Angeles had lost their power and temporarily laid off hundreds of employees, moving some of their production to plants in other states.
"When they send production out of the state, and the uncertainty here remains so high, we're not sure how much of that will come back afterwards," Ms. Cullen said.
Cities are also spending money on police, and other staff overtime, as well as moving to a state of emergency preparedness, though they said the sums spent so far had not been significant.
The city of Fremont in the San Francisco area, with 210,000 residents and a high-tech industrial base, estimated its costs on Wednesday at $5,000. The figure included $1,000 spent on overtime hours for police, $200 for fire department, and $2,300 for costs of activating and running the city's Emergency Operations Center, which organizes the municipal response to an emergency.
The city has also taken itself off the power grid, and is no longer receiving its electricity from Pacific Gas and Electric. Fifteen city buildings, including 11 fire stations, a police building, a jail and two municipal office buildings, now rely on generators.
On the coast, in Pacifica, population 40,000, David N. Carmany, the city manager, said he was concerned that there might be blackouts during rush-hour or late at night on the beautiful but dangerous Pacific Coast Highway, Highway 1.
Mr. Carmany said the city was deciding whether to try to run four stoplights along the route with portable generators, or to use the police, but he was concerned about the safety of officers in the dark.
"The idea of all those commuters on Highway 1 after dark is not a pretty picture," he said. And he said that the surf advisory merely put added pressure on the strained city.
The problems were not restricted to the cities. 
Bob Vandergon, assistant agriculture commissioner for Fresno County, which has been hit with rolling blackouts, said that citrus farmers in the area were concerned that if they lost power during one of the overnight freezes that seem imminent they could lose their crops. The farmers use wind machines and pump well-water into irrigation canals to keep the oranges from freezing, and so if electricity were interrupted it could do serious damage.
In Sacramento, legislators wrestled with a problem that most conceded consisted of a series of politically unpalatable choices -- making taxpayers, ratepayers or the shareholders of the utilities pay most of the billions of dollars of losses being incurred -- with no clear indications of the best direction. 
The generating companies, which are owed billions of dollars by Pacific Gas and Electric and Southern California Edison, with muddy prospects of being paid, have expressed exasperation with what they consider the slow pace and unrealistic expectations of the Legislature. 
Steve Ledbetter, the chairman of Reliant Energy, a Houston-based power generating company, said there was improved cooperation among the key players, but no signs of a real solution in sight, particularly with the two major utilities now missing debt payments and their finances deteriorating by the day.
"Their banks refuse to extend additional credit, yet suppliers such as ourselves, not just in California but throughout the entire Western market, are being forced to assume their credit risk with no promise of payment," Mr. Ledbetter said. "This is unreasonable and unfair, and it cannot be allowed to continue."
In Washington, Paul H. O'Neill, President-elect George W. Bush's choice to become treasury secretary, at his confirmation hearing described California's electricity program as "lunacy," in large measure because of the effort to keep retail prices down and avoid rate increases.
"The State of California assumed that they could defeat economics," Mr. O'Neill said, adding that trying to hold retail electric prices down when supply is short "makes no sense."
The Legislature has been constrained by the fact that Governor Davis has flatly insisted that ratepayers should not be forced to pay for the problem by having their rates increased further.
"I believe we get this done without another rate increase," Governor Davis said.
Mr. Cardenas, the Budget Committee chairman, said that it would be hard to ask taxpayers to carry much of the burden, but that there was little appetite for raising utility rates sharply.
Mr. Angelides said that, in his view, the state's utility ratepayers would ultimately have to bear the burden, but more large businesses than residential customers.
"Ratepayers may be asked to become lenders," he said. "The tab that the utilities have had to take on doesn't go away. It's a matter of how you apportion it. The shareholders of the utilities will have to pay some of that and the business sector, which argued for deregulation, will have a share of it."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
VIGNETTE ANNOUNCES LAYOFFS AND ISSUES PROFIT WARNING

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 The Vignette Corporation, a maker of software for Internet commerce, said yesterday that it would lay off 15 percent of its workers because the economic slowdown was hurting demand. The company also said that it expected to lose money in the first quarter, and it revised downward its forecast for full-year profits in 2001. Shares of Vignette, based in Austin, Tex., fell $4.69, or 38 percent, closing at $7.81; stock prices of rivals like Interwoven and Art Technology also fell on the news.

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing; 
JOB GROWTH CONTINUES

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
 New York City's economy continued to surge in December, despite the national economic slowdown, according to figures released yesterday by the New York State Department of Labor. 
Employers created more than 20,000 new jobs in the city in December, bringing the total increase for the year to 90,000, 2.4 percent more than in 1999. That growth rate is far stronger than the national average of 1.5 percent or the statewide average of 1.8 percent. The unemployment rate in the city, when adjusted for seasonal factors, was unchanged in December at 5.6 percent. Statewide, the unemployment rate dipped slightly to 4.5 percent from 4.6 percent; the national average was unchanged at 4 percent. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing; 
CON ED PROFITS DOWN

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 Consolidated Edison said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 8.4 percent after a customer rate cut but that it would meet or exceed earnings forecasts for this year. 
Profit from operations fell to $111.4 million, or 52 cents a share, from net income of $121.6 million, or 57 cents, a year earlier, said Hyman Schoenblum, vice president of corporate planning. The company was expected to earn 51 cents, the average estimate of five analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. Con Ed said New York City's strong economy increased sales and helped offset the rate decrease.

HEADLINE: Equity Shrivels as Homeowners Borrow and Buy 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
When Erica Hutchinson and her fiance, Lynn Corbett, bought their brownstone in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn for $175,000 three years ago, they persuaded a bank to lend them $230,000. Their argument was that the value of their new home would jump once they used the extra mortgage money to gut the three-story building and fill it with new bathrooms, a new kitchen, new flooring, new windows -- new everything.
 They were right, of course. The Corbetts, now married, say that after several years of a flush New York economy their brownstone would easily sell today for at least $370,000. Their bankers seem to agree. The couple recently added a $30,000 home equity loan, using the new money to pay off credit card bills. "The construction costs were more than we had anticipated so we charged them," said Ms. Corbett, who is 30, like her husband, "and we paid for our wedding with credit cards, too." 
 For most American families, their home is their biggest investment, and after years of prosperity in which home prices rose substantially, family wealth has increased as well. But like the Corbetts, millions of households borrowed heavily against their homes, often to help support greater spending. 
The borrowing has been so extensive, in fact, that homeowners, after building up equity through much of the 1960's and 1970's, have let their ownership shares deteriorate over the last two decades to the lowest level on record, the Federal Reserve reports. The borrowing even accelerated in the 1990's, helping to explain how Americans managed to easily outspend their incomes through two long economic expansions.
Now a slowing economy catches the average household owning less of a stake in its home than in any economic slowdown since the advent of the modern mortgage in the 1930's. If a recession develops and people start worrying that they have too little equity left to continue borrowing safely against their homes, the blow to spending could turn a mild recession into a prolonged one. That would certainly happen, economists say, if a downturn causes home prices to fall, shrinking even more the equity stake that households still have in their homes.
"When you make borrowing dependent on your home, then you erode the fire wall that protects your standard of living and we are going into this slowdown with the fire wall clearly eroded," said Nicolas Retsinas, director of the Joint Center on Housing Studies at Harvard. "The home is not just a financial transaction, it defines who you are and what kind of community you live in. When all of a sudden you get into trouble, you can't just rip it up like a credit card."
The average homeowning household owed lenders 46 percent of the market value of its residence during last year's third quarter, up sharply from about 30 percent in 1982 and 40 percent in 1991, at the start of the current economic expansion, the Fed reports show. For a typical family with a home worth the median market value of $144,000 late last year, that meant their equity was $77,760 while their debt was $66,240.
That still sounds like a relatively safe cushion. But American society once exalted a different norm -- a 20 percent down payment and the balance paid off through a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage. The Champagne toasts and mortgage burnings that celebrated the final payment are gone today. Instead, a growing number of Americans are approaching or entering retirement still making hefty home payments.
In many ways, the shift makes sense. Home equity loans and the refinancing of mortgages have become vehicles for converting standard consumer debt into loans that usually enjoy tax breaks, lower interest rates and smaller monthly payments. Millions of people have managed to borrow against their homes at rates under 10 percent, while channeling other funds into retirement plans and into a stock market that until recently achieved average returns of 15 percent or more a year.
Whatever the justifications, the family home is now more at risk as collateral for the spending that underpins economic growth.
The vulnerability cuts two ways. For people like the Corbetts, convinced that their brownstone on St. James Place can only rise in value as their neighborhood improves, there is still room to borrow more and spend it avidly, softening any downturn. "We are definitely ahead of the game," said Ms. Corbett, who works in the fashion industry. Her husband runs a Boy's Town center in Brooklyn and their income is $120,000 a year, not counting the $1,300 a month they receive as rent for an apartment in their brownstone.
But for homeowners like Thomas Murray, an executive for a Cincinnati company that cleans food processing plants, even a leveling off of home prices would be chilling. He is painfully aware that if he sold his four-bedroom brick suburban home for the $220,000 that he thinks he can get for it and then paid off his mortgage and his home equity loan, he would walk away with -- as he puts it -- "$8, maybe $9."
"If I had to take a pay cut or had to accept another job for a lower level of pay, then I would have the credit card problem again, and no equity left in my home to solve it," said Mr. Murray, 36, who landed his present job last spring at a sharp increase in salary, to above $100,000. Over the last five years, he had made less than $80,000 a year. As a result, the family accumulated $20,000 in credit card debt, which he and his wife recently converted to a $25,000 home equity loan.
"Car repair, dental bills, mandatory home repairs, clothing for the kids, birthday parties, you cannot afford all this and stay out of debt," Mr. Murray said. "Unless you have a big enough income, which I have -- now."
The big concern among economists is not a relatively short recession, but a longer one, lasting a year or so. "In a brief recession, the extra borrowing and spending would even soften the downturn," Mark Zandi, chief economist at Economy.com in West Chester, Pa., said. Indeed, a new surge in mortgage refinancing as interest rates fall -- the fourth surge since 1993 -- is likely to give a lift to spending as some people go further into debt, pocketing the extra mortgage money without increasing their monthly payments.
"But in a longer recession," Mr. Zandi said, "housing prices would weaken and many homeowners could easily find themselves owing more on their homes than the homes were worth."
If that happened, the abrupt pullback in spending as these families tried to work down their debts and preserve their homes would exacerbate a recession. Many Japanese behaved in just this way after the collapse in real estate prices in that country a decade ago.
Or, with monthly mortgage and home equity payments in the United States at a record level as a percentage of disposable income, trouble on the job -- layoffs, for example, or cutbacks in overtime pay -- could quickly restrict spending, also deepening a recession.
Alexander Wright, a 40-year-old aircraft mechanic for Northrop Grumman in Jacksonville, Fla., is currently going through just this experience. He is among the millions of relatively new homeowners who could not meet the old requirements for a down payment to purchase a home, but achieved his goal as lenders relaxed their standards, offering mortgages that cover nearly the entire cost of a home.
Mortgage insurance has encouraged this expansion of homeownership. So has the increasingly popular practice of packaging mortgages into bonds that are then sold to many investors, thus spreading the risk of default. Government-sponsored programs aimed at allowing lower-income families to buy a home with little money down have helped as well. Together with the robust economy, these forces have propelled homeownership to a record 67.7 percent of all households, although many of the new homeowners own only a modest stake in their homes.
Mr. Wright and his wife, Carvetta, an assembly line worker in a microchip plant, are in this situation, having purchased their three-bedroom ranch house several years ago for $64,500, obtaining a mortgage for the entire amount.
"I've done a lot of renovation, doing the work myself, and I would price the house now at $82,000," Mr. Wright said. He has worked the mortgage down to under $55,000.
But the family also owes $30,000 on a home equity loan the Wrights took out to pay off credit card bills and to help buy a car. With two teenagers, they were paying off the debt without undue sacrifice, Mr. Wright said, until his overtime suddenly stopped last June. Repair work at Northrop Grumman had slowed. The Wrights' combined annual income is about $54,000, and the overtime once added $10,000 a year. Without it, the payments on the debt continue, but family spending is curtailed.
"I am going to try not to draw down the $4,000 that remains on my home equity credit line," Mr. Wright said. "We are trying to tough it out. We don't go out anymore, and we try not to buy the name-brand clothes that the kids want, none of that Tommy Hilfiger stuff. We had two dogs, and we got rid of one." 
If Mr. Wright is worried, David Murphy, who owns a home in Madeira, an upscale Cincinnati suburb, certainly is not. The Murphys -- he sells computer systems to hospitals, she is an electrical engineer -- completed a lavish $130,000 kitchen renovation last year, borrowing the full sum to expand the space to make room for a stone fireplace and archway. They installed new custom cabinets, granite counter tops and a Sub-Zero refrigerator.
That was only the latest renovation to a three-bedroom home that the Murphys bought nine years ago for $225,000, putting $50,000 down and borrowing $175,000. The upgrades include an entertainment room and an outdoor cooking center, and the debt against the home has risen to $400,000. But Mr. Murphy is confident that he could sell his home for $550,000 today. A bank appraiser told him that the $130,000 kitchen remodeling raised the selling price of the home by the full amount spent on the renovation.
Is that accurate? Or are people overly optimistic about the values of their homes?
"We are stunned by the optimism that shows up in our surveys," said David F. Seiders, chief economist at the National Association of Home Builders in Washington. "The attitude used to be that remodeling is great, but don't expect to get it back in resale value."
Mr. Murphy could well be right about his home. But what if he is wrong? "There is not yet a problem with house prices," Mr. Seiders said, "but if this slowdown continues, you could see problems."

HEADLINE: Turkey Tries to Step Up Sell-Off of State Companies 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Jan. 18 

 BODY:
Turkey's privatization officials will hit the road next week in Europe to try to drum up interest among potential buyers for a stake in the state-owned telephone company, a deal many analysts see as a litmus test for the country's economy.
 Under pressure from the International Monetary Fund, the government agreed last month to sell 33.5 percent of Turk Telekom and provide management rights to the buyer after an offer last year to sell 20 percent failed to attract any bids. 
 Analysts said the transaction would help answer questions about whether Turkey had the political will to speed up its privatization program and meet a number of I.M.F. deadlines for overhauling the economy. 
"More important than the money generated from selling Turk Telekom, investor confidence will be positively affected," Oner Ayan, manager of the Turkey desk at Raymond James & Associates in New York, said in an interview via e-mail. "Failure of Turk Telekom privatization may be a disaster." 
As part of a three-year economic overhaul program started last January, the government promised to curb inflation, cut its budget deficit and sell many state-owned enterprises to private investors. Progress has been made on inflation and the deficit, but political leaders have been slow to push privatization, particularly for what are regarded as the state's crown jewels, Turk Telecom and Turkish Airlines.
The effort took on new urgency when a financial crisis swept Turkey's financial markets in late November and early December. The I.M.F. agreed to provide a $7.5 billion emergency loan to stop the crisis, but the government had to adopt deadlines for selling the larger stake in the telephone company and for selling 51 percent of Turkish Airlines. Missing the deadlines would jeopardize the I.M.F. money.
The sale of the airline is expected to be the easier of the two transactions, despite objections to the sale from the transportation minister. Turkish Airlines loses money, but it has profitable international routes, one of the world's newest fleets of aircraft and a new international airport. Analysts expect a foreign airline to team with a large domestic company to bid on Turkish Airlines, which company officials value at $2 billion to $2.5 billion. The deadline for the sale is March 31. Swissair and Lufthansa are known to have expressed interest in Turkish Airlines.
After the failure to sell part of Turk Telekom last year, the I.M.F. insisted that the stake be raised and that the offer include strong management rights for the buyer, including control of a management committee.
But there are questions about whether the management rights have the strength to attract enough bids to push the value of the stake into the $10 billion range expected by the government. Analysts also questioned the viability of the sale when Europe's telecommunications industry faces rising debt and falling valuations. 
They also said that including a cellular phone license as part of the Turk Telekom package might have come too late because of concerns that the market was saturated.
Turkey is supposed to invite formal bids by March 30 and select the winning bid by the end of May, according to its agreement with the I.M.F.
The two sales are only one financial hurdle on the horizon. By the end of the month, regulators must decide which ailing banks to sell, which banks to dissolve and which power companies to sell. Parliament must decide whether to pass laws to open the way for more privatization in tobacco, alcoholic beverages and power generation.
From Turkey's viewpoint, there has been progress toward the I.M.F. goals. Inflation last year was 38 percent, above the target of 25 percent but half the 1999 rate and the lowest level since the mid-1980s. The goal for 2001 is 12 percent, followed by single digits the following year. Government spending has also been curbed, reducing the budget deficit.
Partly because of fears ignited by the financial crisis, analysts expect economic growth to slow to about 1 percent in the first quarter of this year and remain sluggish in the second quarter. The slowdown should trim inflation further, but lagging investment and production will not make life easier for most Turks.
"Turkey has been locked down at $3,000 per capita income for 10 years, and we cannot break the chains and improve the standard of living," said T. Gungor Uras, an economist and former official with the state planning organization. "Under the targets in the I.M.F. agreement, it is impossible to increase investment and production."
Some businesses have felt the squeeze already, and there have been reports of big drops in retail sales. Civil servants, who are in contract negotiations this month, are balking at the 10 percent raise required under the I.M.F. program, although there is a provision for an adjustment if inflation rises.
But some experts say that after years of double-digit inflation eating away at real wages, Turks are willing to wait a bit longer because they see inflation falling.
"In inflationary times, people are much more nervous," said Haluk Tukel of the Turkish Industrialists' and Businessmen's Association, which is made up of the country's largest private companies. "People see prices going down now, and they can see possible growth."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Turkey has agreed to sell stakes in two state-owned businesses, Turk Telekom, whose booths are above, and Turkish Airlines, below, to qualify for an emergency loan of $7.5 billion granted by the International Monetary Fund to stop a financial crisis late last year. The airline stake is expected to be easier to sell than the stake in the phone company. (Photographs by Staton R. Winter for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Microsoft Proves a Lure After Internet Stints 

BYLINE:  By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: REDMOND, Wash., Jan. 17 

 BODY:
At a recent orientation for about 200 new employees at the Microsoft Corporation, Joseph Vansyckle found he was hardly alone in raising his hand when the company's chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, posed a question. Just how many of these "new employees," Mr. Ballmer wondered, had actually worked at Microsoft before? 
 "There were about 10 to 15 hands in the air," said Mr. Vansyckle, a product manager who had left the software giant in 1999 for stints at Drugstore.com and Amazon.com, both based in Seattle, before returning to Microsoft's Redmond campus this month. Many had gone off to local Internet companies or other high-technology start-up ventures, and had exciting if nerve-wracking tales to tell of their experiences. 
 But, as Mr. Vansyckle, 29, explains it, they also seem to have returned with a new appreciation for what they had at Microsoft -- not just the financial resources to develop software, but also decent salaries and a variety of other personal benefits. 
"A really good health plan, a really good 401(k)," he said. "That played a really big part in my coming back. The stability of Microsoft was important. When you get toward 30, those things become much more important." 
The world's largest software maker is certainly not immune to the ferocious slump that has hit the high-technology industry. But as Internet companies lay off workers or even close their doors altogether, Microsoft has recently gone on something of a hiring and acquisition binge.
In doing so, the company is providing a safety net in the Seattle area for some of the industry's brightest young talent and demonstrating that in the suddenly turbulent world of the New Economy, being an industry titan holds out at least one decidedly Old Economy appeal: the prospect of relatively stable employment. 
Microsoft, which has never had to impose widespread layoffs in its 25-year history, hired 11,800 people in 2000, bringing its total work force to an all-time high of 41,600. It has more than 5,000 official job openings now, and company recruiters say that applications are up more than 10 percent from a year ago, even more so from college campuses. 
In the last six months, Microsoft has rehired 103 former employees, company officials say, including, in a fitting touch of symbolism, its first official hiring: Marc McDonald, issued badge number 00001 in 1976 when the company was known as Micro-Soft and based in Albuquerque, returned recently when Microsoft acquired the electronic publishing company he was working for. 
And Microsoft has taken on other workers who were initially lured to the siren call of the Internet world, perhaps even by the chance to take off with a small company much as early Microsoft employees once did. 
"I think working for a typical dot-com, it's almost like doing the extreme-sports thing," said Christopher Chapman, a software engineer who was laid off in November from the Seattle office of Stamps.com, an online postage service. 
"For someone who's 23, I think it's a cool rush to be in a situation like that," added Mr. Chapman, who got a job a few weeks later with Microsoft in a division that develops training materials for the company's software. "But coming to Microsoft, walking in and knowing they have a whole system from A to Z, everything's been worked out and they know what they're doing, well you appreciate that, too. I guess it depends on where you are in your life." 
Microsoft has plenty of problems. There is its antitrust battle with the federal government. There is also its reputation as the industry bully, an image expressed in "AntiTrust," a new movie in which Tim Robbins plays a Bill Gates-like software chieftain who orders thugs with bats to take out rival programmers. 
But with cash reserves of more than $20 billion, Microsoft is in a position to snap up smart workers at struggling small Internet companies in the Seattle area and beyond. 
Some Microsoft employees hired a year or two ago do share an unhappy distinction with workers at Internet companies: their stock options are underwater, in the industry lingo. But even Microsoft's stock woes seem to have an upside. Many new employees say they are convinced that the company's stock, mired in the $50 range, well off the peak just short of $120 that it hit in 1999, is bound to recover, making this an attractive time to go to work there. 
Perceptions among bright young programmers may be changing, too. For a good part of the last decade, computer whiz kids generally shunned the company's suburban, corporate campus for start-ups in Seattle's bohemian neighborhoods. Now many of them talk of the virtues of a Microsoft career.
"How many dot-coms or start-ups can you name that have really done something revolutionary?" asked Ori Amiga, 23, a program manager in Microsoft's "dot-net" division, part of the company's strategy to shift much of its software from packaged products to services available over the Internet. "Very few, compared to the tens of thousands out there." 
Mr. Chapman, who came to Microsoft after being laid off by Stamps.com, put it another way: "They win. I wanted a company that was a winner. I wanted to wind up at a company with a lot of resources, a place that knows what it takes." 
Many new workers here say they do not worry about Microsoft being split in two in the antitrust battle. They believe that the company will prevail on appeal or that the Bush administration will settle the case. At the very least, they see themselves working for one of two strong companies.
Even those who live in Seattle but do not work for Microsoft remain positive about the company. Many residents own shares in the company and thus wish it -- or at least its stock price -- well.
"The fear and loathing of Microsoft as too big and too dominant is found almost everywhere but Seattle," said Glenn Pascall, a senior fellow at the Institute of Public Policy at the University of Washington, who studies the company's impact on the local economy.
But, Mr. Pascall said, there is some irony that Microsoft is seen as "a place for those who had the great dot-com adventure and now need a safe harbor." Some economic downturns that have led Boeing, the region's largest employer with three times as many workers as Microsoft here, to layoffs have prompted workers from the aerospace company to start their own businesses.
"The notion of Microsoft as a mother ship that gathers up the wounded chicks after the shake-up is the reverse of the entrepreneurial impetus Boeing has inadvertently provided with its layoffs," Mr. Pascall said. "This is a bit like the Boeing story but with a new chapter added, which is the return of the departed employee."
For now, the returnees seem grateful. Mr. Vansyckle, who is now a product manager in the company's dot-net division, said he had no regrets about leaving Microsoft to work in e-commerce. 
"I would not have traded my experience there for anything," Mr. Vansyckle said. "But working at a company like Microsoft, you have unlimited resources. You've got the money to do it. From the company's point of view, the only problem is, you've just got to choose what it is you want to do."

HEADLINE: Ford 4th-Quarter Earnings Fell 40% as Sales Slowed 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 18 

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company said today that its earnings dropped 40.4 percent in the fourth quarter as slower sales in a weakening American economy crippled profits in its North American operations.
 For the last five years, Ford executives have taken considerable pride in their robust earnings in the United States, the result of having bet heavily and early on the boom in sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks. But the company's profits as a percent of sales plunged to 2.4 percent in the fourth quarter from 5.5 percent in the period a year earlier. 
 The deterioration in Ford's finances was all the more striking because North American profit margins at Ford's archrival, General Motors, actually improved slightly in the fourth quarter before one-time charges, to 3.6 percent from 3.5 percent. G.M. also took a one-time charge of $983 million to shut down Oldsmobile. 
Ford's net income dropped to $1.08 billion in the fourth quarter, or 57 cents a share, compared with $1.81 billion, or $1.47 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales fell to $42.6 billion from $43.9 billion.
Excluding the results of Visteon, the huge auto parts subsidiary that Ford spun off last June, and one-time items, Ford said it earned $1.2 billion, or 64 cents a share, in line with Wall Street expectations, which had been reduced after Ford issued two earnings warnings in December.
Henry D. G. Wallace, Ford's chief financial officer, said that Ford had suffered from slowing sales for all automobiles and because it halted production of one of its most profitable models, the Ford Explorer sport utility vehicle, in November to prepare factories for the introduction of a new Explorer in February.
Ford also had heavy marketing expenses for the expiring model of the Explorer, Mr. Wallace said. The company tried to reassure customers about the vehicle's safety after a recall on Aug. 9 of Firestone tires linked to more than 100 deaths, almost all of them in Explorers that rolled over after tread separated from a tire.
Struggling with the Explorer's troubles as well recalls of other models, Ford fell short as well in its pursuit of cost reductions last year. 
But some financial analysts were skeptical of Ford's explanations, saying that they suspected that the company faced a more serious problem: eroding profits per vehicle on sport utilities and pickup trucks as more foreign automakers enter the market.
"Profitability is deteriorating in North America; at any level of the market, these guys are not as profitable as they used to be," said Rod Lache, an auto analyst at Deutsche Bank Alex. Brown.
Mr. Wallace denied in an interview that light truck profit margins had suffered, saying that the decline in overall sales volume, combined with the Explorer design change, had been responsible for the declining profits of Ford's North American operations, which earned $607 million, compared with $1.47 billion a year earlier. While G.M. said on Wednesday that it lost money in every region overseas during the fourth quarter, including a staggering loss of $463 million in Europe alone, Ford managed to do much better abroad. In Europe, Ford eked out a $33 million profit after losing $30 million a year earlier. Ford's profits in Asia inched up to $20 million in the fourth quarter from $10 million a year earlier. Ford's losses in South America narrowed to $31 million from $100 million a year earlier.
Ford Credit, the automaker's unit for car loans and leases, posted a 33 percent increase in profits, to $410 million, capping a year of double-digit increases in profits. 
Bibiana Boerio, the chief financial officer of Ford Credit, said that his unit had not been hurt by the Ford Explorer's troubles because the number of Explorers being returned at the end of leases, instead of being bought by the lessor or the dealer, had been in line with expectations.
Ford Credit had also assumed for several years that the resale value of Explorers would erode somewhat this winter because of the pending introduction of the new model and because other sport utility models are coming on the market and has, thus, been able to resell Explorers for what it anticipated, she added.
For all of last year, Ford earned $3.47 billion, or $2.30 a share, down from $7.24 billion, or $5.86 a share. The spinoff of Visteon resulted in a one-time charge of $2.25 billion. Sales rose to $170.06 billion last year from $160.66 billion.

HEADLINE: Microsoft Sees Some Good And Some Bad 

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Jan. 18 

 BODY:
Capitalizing on strong sales growth for its Windows 2000 desktop operating system at the end of the year, Microsoft reported quarterly earnings today that met Wall Street's scaled-back expectations. 
 The company reported record revenue of $6.59 billion for the quarter ended Dec. 31, an 8 percent increase over the $6.11 billion for the 1999 quarter. Net income and diluted earnings per share were $2.62 billion and 47 cents a share, up marginally from the $2.44 billion, or 47 cents a share, a year earlier. The earnings per share met a consensus estimate of Wall Street analysts reported by First Call/Thomson Financial. 
 On Dec. 14, Microsoft took the unaccustomed step of warning Wall Street that it would have lower revenue than previously expected as a result of a downturn in the PC market and in corporate purchases.
Today's earnings news was announced after the markets closed. Microsoft's shares ended the trading day at $55.63, up $2.69, and went as high as $58 after hours. The stock has tumbled from $115 last March amid concerns about the government's antitrust case and the computer industry's slowdown.
"There's a little relief that they didn't drop any more bad news on us," said Richard Sherlund, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "That will give the stock a boost. Maybe it's O.K. to go back in the water."
Despite the strength of its operating systems sales, the company added a gloomy note by reporting that revenue for its Office software declined for the second quarter in a row. Revenue from those programs, known as desktop applications, was $2.49 billion in the latest quarter, down 2 percent from $2.53 billion a year ago. 
The declines are the first for the company's desktop programs, which dominate the PC software market. As a result, analysts are questioning whether the company will be able to continue to persuade consumers to shift from one generation of its software to the next.
"Office represents the single largest product for this company," said Sanjiv Hingorani, a Wall Street analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein in New York. "What is going to cause Office revenues to grow in the future?"
Microsoft said its earnings had come in near the top of its reduced forecast, largely on the strength of last-moment corporate purchases for its Windows 2000 desktop operating system at the end of last month.
"The quarter ended a little better than anticipated," said John G. Connors, chief financial officer. 
Indeed, Mr. Connors said that part of the slightly better performance might have come because of the added incentive given to Microsoft's sales force by the gloomy warning two weeks before the end of the year.
At the same time, he said that with worldwide PC growth leveling off, the company's annual growth in the future would be more modest. 
"Our growth prospects are really healthy, but it won't be the 20 percent of the past," Mr. Connors said.
Further evidence of a global slowdown in PC sales came today in a preliminary survey released by Dataquest, the market research firm. That survey indicated that worldwide shipments of PC's totaled 134.7 million in 2000. Global sales increased 14.5 percent for the year, while sales in the United States were up 10.3 percent.
For the fourth quarter, worldwide PC shipments rose 10 percent, and United States shipments were up 6.4 percent, far below forecasts. 
Microsoft said its server business had continued to accelerate during the quarter, and cited several customers as evidence of its success.
Analysts said, though, that Microsoft's strength in software for servers, the workhorses of the Internet, had yet to be fully developed. That suggests that the company has not yet begun to make huge inroads into the business of its toughest software competitors, like Sun Microsystems and I.B.M.
"I didn't see the upside on the server side of the business," said David Readerman, a partner and director of Internet strategy for Thomas Weisel Partners in San Francisco. "It's still largely on the desktop side."
The company is clearly looking for new growth outside the personal computer market.
Yet those businesses, which generally have lower margins than its traditional core PC business, may not be the safe havens that Microsoft is searching for. In December, it cited revenue shortfalls in its consumer Internet business, MSN, as one reason it was forecasting a shortfall, and today Mr. Connors said that the company's $400 rebate promotion had in effect been too popular. The company saw 500,000 new customers in the quarter, but revenue was significantly lower than planned because so many of the new customers took advantage of the rebate.
Over all, however, Microsoft gave none of the signs of a beleaguered giant. While acknowledging that it would be affected by any economic downturn, Mr. Connors said, "Going into 2001, Microsoft is as well positioned as we've ever been."

HEADLINE: METRO BRIEFING 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
 NEW YORK

MANHATTAN: A.C.L.U. ACCUSED OF BIAS -- A former employee of the American Civil Liberties Union said yesterday that she was suing the organization for age and race discrimination. The woman, Maria A. Torres-Sylvan, who is 50 and Hispanic, worked as a computer operator at the A.C.L.U.'s national headquarters in Manhattan for nearly 17 years. In 1998, when Adrienne Stein, a white woman in her 30's, became the direct supervisor, Mrs. Sylvan said, several older employees began to feel unwelcome. Last April, she said, she was replaced by a 23-year-old white man. An A.C.L.U. spokeswoman said the charges were groundless. Sherri Day (NYT)

MANHATTAN: MORE SUBWAY CARS -- Hoping to ease the rush-hour crush on the busiest subway lines, New York City Transit officials voted yesterday to increase their order for new subway cars by $185 million for 150 additional cars. The increase means that over the next two years, 1,550 new subway cars will appear on the IRT lines -- the Nos. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 and 9 -- replacing all 1,400 of the oldest trains. Lawrence G. Reuter, transit president, noted that the train fleet included about 6,000 cars, so the expansion was relatively small. But he said he expected some improvement in the subway system, where ridership has risen steeply. Randy Kennedy (NYT)

UNIONDALE: POWER USE RISES 9 PERCENT -- The Long Island Power Authority said yesterday that while Long Island's population had barely grown last year, electricity use by the average household had shown a 9 percent increase. The utility's 2000 population survey said that Suffolk County's growth was 1.2 percent and Nassau's 0.2 percent. It said that the strong economy, lower electric rates, expanded construction and new technology were the reasons power use was growing faster than expected. Tina Kelley (NYT)

ROCHESTER: JUDGMENT IN STUDENT HOMICIDE -- A jury awarded $1 million yesterday to the mother of a 13-year-old girl who was killed by a classmate in the first student slaying at a public school in Rochester. A 12-year-old girl used a steak knife to stab the 13-year-old, Stephne Givens, in the neck outside Jefferson Middle School on Sept. 21, 1995. They had been quarreling over a boy, witnesses said. A State Supreme Court jury said the city school district had failed to adequately supervise the students, and ordered it to pay $430,000 in damages to Stephne's mother, Aledia Givens. The 12-year-old and her mother were ordered to pay $570,000. (AP)

OYSTER BAY: PETITIONERS SEEK RETAIL MALL -- The Nassau Suffolk Building Trades Council yesterday delivered 6,000 petitions to John Venditto, the supervisor of Oyster Bay, that support plans to build a mall on the grounds of the Cerro Wire and Cable Company plant near Syosset. "It means an awful lot of employment for our construction workers," said John M. Kennedy, the council's president. Some of the town's residents oppose the mall, although it is expected to generate more than 2,000 construction jobs. But Morton Weber, a lawyer for the developer, the Taubman Company of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., said, "The rest of the town realizes it is so essential for the economics of the town, and jobs." Tina Kelley (NYT)

ALBANY: COURT RULES ON ACCUSED PEDIATRICIAN -- The appellate division of the State Supreme Court has ruled that Stuart M. Copperman, a pediatrician from Merrick, on Long Island, who is accused of molesting some of his teenage patients, cannot practice, even with a chaperon, while he is appealing the revocation of his license. The ruling was made on Friday but made public on Wednesday. It is considered a victory for the State Health Department, which revoked the doctor's license in December. Tina Kelley (NYT)

NEW JERSEY

TRENTON: SCOOTER HELMET BILL -- Children 14 and younger would have to wear a helmet while riding a scooter under a bill approved by an Assembly committee yesterday. The measure is in response to the death of an Elizabeth boy, Andy Pinto, while riding a scooter in September. The measure, which passed the Assembly Law and Public Safety Committee and will go to the full Assembly for consideration, amends a law that requires children to wear helmets while riding bicycles or using skateboards or in-line skates. Parents of children who do not wear helmets would be fined $25 for the first offense and $100 for subsequent offenses. (AP)

SOUTH BOUND BROOK: POLICE CHIEF DISCIPLINED -- The chief of the South Bound Brook Police has been placed on administrative duty, the Somerset County prosecutor said yesterday. The action follows a restraining order granted to the chief's former wife last week and an assault complaint on Wednesday by his neighbor. The chief, Robert A. Verry, had his weapon seized and his duties suspended temporarily on Friday by the prosecutor, Wayne Forrest. Mr. Forrest said he would decide on permanent measures after consulting with the mayor and other authorities. Chief Verry did not return telephone calls. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

NEWARK: PORT AUTHORITY GRADUATION -- The police force of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which was recently criticized by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, will graduate 77 new recruits from its academy training program today. The increase in the force, to 1,300, will make it the nation's 26th-largest police agency. Mayor Giuliani had charged the agency with failing to stem an increase in crime at the city's airports. The force, disputing the criticism, said that one-third of its class was made up of former New York City police officers. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

NEWARK: 3 INDICTED IN GAS SCHEME -- Two company presidents and another official were indicted yesterday in an alleged conspiracy to falsify laboratory results and sell hundreds of millions of gallons of substandard gasoline. Charged in an 11-count federal indictment were Richard Kaminski, 53, of Houston, former president of Caleb Brett U.S.A., a petroleum testing laboratory; Waldo Schroeder, 53, president of Blending, Marketing and Service Inc.; and his brother, Mark Schroeder, 43, a Blending operations manager. (NYT)

CONNECTICUT

NORWICH: SHRINE SEIZED -- The city has taken title to a hillside religious display known as the Sanctuary of Love because the owner cannot pay overdue taxes and utility bills. Tenants of the apartment house on the property are moving out so the city can condemn the area and close the shrine. The owner, Salvatore Verdirome, 80, who worked for 30 years building the sanctuary by hand, may stay in his apartment with his caretaker until the city can assess whether the apartment meets housing regulations. (AP)

HARTFORD: APPELLATE JUDGE NAMED -- Judge Joseph Flynn, who has served as deputy chief court administrator since late 1999, was named yesterday to the state's Appellate Court. Judge Flynn, 60, a Democrat from Ansonia, has been a judge since 1985. His promotion to the state's second-highest court was announced by Gov. John G. Rowland. He will serve on the Appellate Court on an interim basis, pending confirmation by the Legislature. (AP)

HEADLINE: Caterpillar Expects Lower Profit 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., Jan. 18 

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc., the largest maker of construction and earth-moving equipment, said today that its profit would fall and that its sales would be little changed this year because of the slowing economy and higher spending.
Caterpillar shares fell $2.91, to $41.75, a drop of 6.5 percent. 
 Caterpillar said its profit would be 5 percent to 10 percent less than it earned in 2000. Analysts had expected earnings to rise this year. 
 The company had said that fourth-quarter net income rose a greater-than-expected 10 percent, to $264 million, or 76 cents a share, compared with $239 million, or 67 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales rose 1.9 percent, to $5.11 billion from $5.02 billion. Analysts had expected the company to earn 64 cents a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial.
Caterpillar's profit had dropped seven out of the last nine quarters as higher interest rates, low commodity prices and weak overseas economies crimped sales of backhoes and cranes. 
Caterpillar plans to spend $350 million to initiate a quality-control program and upgrade computer systems to improve productivity, Lynn McPheeters, the chief financial officer, said in an interview. Profit would increase without the higher spending, he said.
North American sales of machinery in 2001 will be hurt from excess industry capacity and pricing competition, while sales in the rest of the world will probably increase, Mr. McPheeters said. The company, based in Peoria, has sought to counter increased competition from rivals like Deere & Company and CNH Global N.V. by offering incentives to dealers, which include reduced interest rates and price cuts.
