HEADLINE: Congress Asked to Help Police the Rogue Diamond Trade 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 18 

 BODY:
Seeking to distance the trade in spangled tiaras and humble engagement rings from the taint of so-called conflict diamonds, a leading industry group has urged the United States Congress to ban the import of tainted gems and to support a new system of certification across the $7 billion global market in uncut stones.
 The proposal by the World Diamond Council was intended to bring governments, including the United States, directly into the policing of the rogue diamond trade rather than leave it to the United Nations and the industry itself. 
 "This is a bold move by the industry to ask to be controlled," said Eli Izhakoff, a retired New York diamond executive who heads the council, a group established by industry leaders, including the giant De Beers company, in an effort to disassociate the legitimate diamond trade from the illicit trade. 
"It's a major undertaking," Mr. Izhakoff said in an interview today at the close of a two-day meeting of the organization. 
The De Beers chairman, Nicky Oppenheimer, said, "It is time for governments, particularly those whose countries are the major exporters and importers of rough diamonds, to effect appropriate legislation to ensure that the trade in rough diamonds without proper certification of origin is outlawed."
The meeting was the latest step by retailers, cutters and uncut diamond wholesalers to avert a boycott, similar to one against the fur trade, that seemed inevitable two years ago after reports that rebels in Angola and Sierra Leone were using diamond sales to finance their uprisings.
Since then, the issue has drawn in the United Nations and the governments of the United States and Britain and has raised questions about the involvement of several countries from Congo to Ukraine.
The latest call for legislation emerged a day after De Beers, which has controlled the world trade in uncut stones for most of its 112 years, announced a landmark agreement with the luxury goods retailer LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton to break into the retail trade with branded cut diamonds. 
De Beers's own measures against conflict diamonds and its support for global measures to undermine the conflict diamond market are widely seen as part of an effort to shield its retail venture from association with so-called blood diamonds.
The diamond retail trade, far more lucrative than the rough diamond business, is worth an estimated $50 billion, half of it in the United States, where De Beers is barred from doing business directly because of long-running antitrust disputes.
But, council participants said, the United States is a minor importer of uncut stones, the bulk of which are controlled by De Beers in southern Africa and its contracts with suppliers in Canada and Russia. 
Mr. Izhakoff said the council's certification proposal, ensuring that diamonds reaching the markets were exported under strict controls, was intended "to create a conflict-free rough diamond zone" that would affect the entire business. 
"We want to make it impossible," he said, "to trade in conflict diamonds."
But some attending the conference questioned the effectiveness of the certification program in light of Russian opposition to the monitoring of diamond exports and to the creation of a global database of exports. 
"Without Russia, the whole system isn't going to work," an industry executive said. Russia is the second-largest exporter of rough diamonds after Botswana, whose industry is controlled by De Beers. 
Russia is "very leery of controls from outside," Mr. Izhakoff said.
Specifically, the council said it would like to see legislation in Washington that would create a closely monitored system of certificates of origin "in which packets of newly extracted rough diamonds would be sealed, documented and recorded in databases all under the supervision of government officials."
In addition, the council has proposed that efforts to circumvent the control be punishable by fines of up to $250,000 and two-year jail terms. The proposal would also provide for the president to negotiate a global agreement enforcing the use of certificates of origin. 
Delegates to the London conference said the proposals foresaw a certification process using formal documentation as well as encrypted, electronic systems to ensure that packages were not tampered with.

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on
Page 12.

Now Playing

"ALL THE PRETTY HORSES," starring Matt Damon and Henry Thomas. Directed by Billy Bob Thornton; written by Ted Tally (PG-13, 112 minutes). Yes, very pretty. Also, slow, portentous and banal. Mr. Thornton and Mr. Tally have faithfully adapted Cormac McCarthy's beloved novel, but they have also inadvertently laid bare its essential emptiness. Mr. Damon and Mr. Thomas play a couple of young cowboys who venture into Mexico in the late 1940's. They find mystery, love, violence and betrayal, but their adventures are presented with such solemn, stylized detachment that it's hard to care much about them. Penelope Cruz struggles with an impossible role as Mr. Damon's love interest. The only spark of life or humor in the picture comes from young Lucas Black, in the role of a scrawny prepubescent runaway who fancies himself a dangerous outlaw and unwittingly becomes one (A. O. Scott).

"ANTITRUST," starring Tim Robbins, Ryan Phillippe, Rachael Leigh Cook and Claire Forlani. Directed by Peter Howitt (PG-13, 120 minutes). Overplotted and overdirected, this thriller about high-tech corporate skullduggery is clever and likable enough to make you feel a bit sorry about the lousy timing of its release. Mr. Phillippe plays an earnest young geek seduced away from his friends' Internet start-up by a Bill Gates-like cyberguru (Mr. Robbins). Like most Hollywood movies about corporate villainy, "Antitrust," waving the banner of the open-source movement, feels a bit phony. But Mr. Howitt and the production designer, Catherine Hardwicke, do a nice job of capturing the ambience and idioms of the New Economy workplace (Scott).

* "BEFORE NIGHT FALLS," starring Javier Bardem. Directed by Julian Schnabel (R, 125 minutes). Mr. Schnabel's romanticized portrait of the exiled gay Cuban poet and novelist Reinaldo Arenas, who died of AIDS, imagines pre-Castro Cuba as a pagan paradise of endless erotic promise ruined by the puritanical Communists, whom Arenas initially embraced then turned against. Mr. Bardem's arresting performance paints Arenas as an emotionally volatile daredevil. But this biography, which incorporates swaths of Arenas's writing, is sketchy, and the star's thick Spanish accent is daunting. It's still quite indelible (Stephen Holden).

* "CAST AWAY," starring Tom Hanks and Helen Hunt. Directed by Robert Zemeckis (PG-13, 143 minutes). The core of this contemporary Robinson Crusoe story is an unforgettably gripping survival drama. Mr. Hanks is a Federal Express employee shipwrecked on a desert island after a plane crash. Physical survival depends on things like rubbing two sticks together to start a fire and cracking open coconuts. For companionship, he paints a face on a volleyball and names it Wilson. As in all his films, Mr. Hanks makes his character compelling by infusing him with a childlike openness. But the interrupted love story that frames the survival sequences is sappy and formulaic (Holden).

"CHOCOLAT," starring Juliette Binoche and Johnny Depp. Directed by Lasse Hallstrom (PG-13, 121 minutes). In the late 1950's during Lent, a free-spirited chocolatier (Ms. Binoche) takes on the hypocritical forces of morality in a small French town: in other words, "Like Water, for Footloose." Mr. Hallstrom puts an impressive group of actors through their crowd-pleasing paces, a cast that includes Lena Olin, Victoire Thivisol, Judi Dench, Leslie Caron, John Wood, Alfred Molina (who's asked to do the work of several actors) and Mr. Depp. Ms. Binoche is such an aggressively wholesome proponent of good times -- D. H. Lawrence's "Mary Poppins" -- that the sanctimony practiced by the mayor (Mr. Molina) seems a lot more inviting (Elvis Mitchell).

* "CROUCHING TIGER, HIDDEN DRAGON," starring Chow Yun Fat, Michelle Yeoh and Zhang Ziyi. Directed by Ang Lee (PG-13, 120 minutes). Mr. Lee puts his particular stamp on the Hong Kong action film, and it results in "Sense and Sensibility" with a body count. Mr. Lee and the writer James Schamus are careful to invoke all the conventions of the genre, affectionately exposing them to parodic excess: there's so much high-flying swordplay that the movie seems to have repealed the laws of gravity. Mr. Lee also gives the proceedings a soulfulness not endemic to the genre. Mr. Chow comes across as the Cary Grant of the blade. But Zhang Ziyi is the real focal point of the film, and she claims it for herself (Mitchell).

"DOUBLE TAKE," starring Orlando Jones and Eddie Griffin. Directed by George Gallo (P-13, 88 minutes). A shell game of a movie that will do anything to hustle a chuckle out of an audience. Mr. Jones is a smooth-talking investment banker named Daryl who finds himself implicated in a multi-million-dollar swindle while mysterious killers dog his tracks. The motormouth Mr. Griffin is a small-time con man who agrees to take on Daryl's identity as a life-saving gesture. "Double Take" has a criminal lack of attention -- it ruthlessly sacrifices its own logic on a regular basis for a cheap laugh (Mitchell).

"THE FAMILY MAN," starring Nicolas Cage. Directed by Brett Ratner (PG-13, 120 minutes). A Christmas drag. The hardworking Mr. Cage, deft and minimal, stars as a single, wealthy buccaneer of a Manhattan capitalist who's magically tossed into a life he could have had but chose to walk away from. He's transformed into a suburbanite with a temperamental minivan, two kids and a wife (Tea Leoni in a welcome return to the screen). This is not his beautiful wife, this is not his beautiful car, this is not his father's Oldsmobile. He's trapped in New Jersey in a movie that's a little of "Groundhog Day," a little of "A Christmas Carol" and a little of "It's a Wonderful Life." Despite a few laughs and Mr. Ratner's requisite confidence in fish-out-of-water comedy, the movie is forlorn and flat. Mr. Cage seems as depressed with money as he is without it; in Hollywood propaganda terms, this means the wealthy have souls, too. But, apparently, no shame (Mitchell).

* "THE HOUSE OF MIRTH," starring Gillian Anderson. Directed by Terence Davies (PG, 140 minutes). One of Edith Wharton's greatest novels has been adapted by this English director into a powerful but extremely somber feminist allegory in which Ms. Anderson (somewhat miscast as Lily Bart but powerful nonetheless) is a precociously modern woman crushed by the cruel hypocrisies of New York society in 1905. More Dickensian than Whartonian in its telling, the story of Lily's downfall still has a crushing force. Laura Linney is exquisite as the treacherous, two-faced Berthe Dorset, who engineers her destruction (Holden).

"MISS CONGENIALITY," starring Sandra Bullock, Michael Caine and Benjamin Bratt. Directed by Donald Petrie (PG-13, 105 minutes). Ms. Bullock plays Grace Hart, a slovenly, barely socialized F.B.I. agent who goes undercover at a beauty pageant where she discovers, much against her will, her feminine side and wins the love of her studly co-worker. The picture is contentedly second-rate -- it seems made for airline viewing -- but a supporting cast that includes Candice Bergen as the pageant's brittle director, William Shatner as its dotty host and Mr. Caine as a pink-shirted Pygmalion provides a few nice comic moments (Scott).

"SHADOW OF THE VAMPIRE," starring John Malkovich, Willem Dafoe and Eddie Izzard. Directed by E. Elias Merhige (R, 90 minutes). Mr. Merhige's ambitious and uneven film is based on an audacious premise: that Max Schreck, who gave a haunting performance in F. W. Murnau's silent classic "Nosferatu," was really a vampire. As played by Mr. Dafoe, Schreck is both sinister and oddly sympathetic, and his struggle with the megalomaniacal Murnau (Mr. Malkovich) gives the film a flavor of Gothic behind-the-scenes comedy. Mr. Dafoe's intriguing performance and Mr. Merhige's keen visual intelligence -- most evident in his uncanny re-creations of scenes from "Nosferatu" -- offset the picture's dubious central metaphor, which is that moviemaking is, at bottom, a form of vampirism (Scott).

"STATE AND MAIN," starring Alec Baldwin, Philip Seymour Hoffman, William H. Macy, Sarah Jessica Parker and David Paymer. Written and directed by David Mamet (R, 102 minutes). Mr. Mamet's satire about a Hollywood film crew on location in a picturesque Vermont town offers an amusingly jaundiced inside view of narcissists and other movie types bumping heads and corrupting the townies. Mr. Baldwin and Ms. Parker are the spoiled stars, Mr. Paymer the shark producer, Mr. Macy the hysterical director and Mr. Hoffman the depressed screenwriter. Funny but unpolished, uncinematic and unevenly cast (Holden).

* "TRAFFIC," starring Michael Douglas, Catherine Zeta-Jones, Dennis Quaid, Benicio Del Toro, Don Cheadle and Luis Guzman. Directed by Steven Soderbergh (R, 140 minutes). Not since "Nashville" or maybe even "The Godfather" has Hollywood turned out an epic as resonant as Mr. Soderbergh's densely layered study of the Mexican drug trade and its devastating impact on the United States. In weaving together multiple stories, this intricate thriller, adapted from a British mini-series, jumps from Tijuana to Washington to San Diego to suburban Ohio. Mr. Douglas is the new American drug czar, Ms. Zeta-Jones the ruthless wife of a busted drug lord and Mr. Del Toro a Mexican policeman. Mr. Cheadle and Mr. Guzman are a team of government agents whose bust of a cynical midlevel dealer (Miguel Ferrer) precipitates much of the drama. Shot with hand-held cameras, "Traffic" builds into a profound and gloomy meditation on greed, violence and contemporary ennui. Perhaps last year's most remarkable acting debut belongs to Erika Christensen as Mr. Douglas's angry, drug-addicted 16-year-old daughter (Holden).

"WHAT WOMEN WANT," starring Mel Gibson, Helen Hunt, Alan Alda and Marisa Tomei. Directed by Nancy Meyers (PG-13, 123 minutes). "Tootsie" for the slow-witted. Mr. Gibson plays a happy chauvinist ad executive who suddenly gets the power to read women's thoughts. Before "Women" settles into sentimentality, Mr. Gibson's ring-a-ding 60's-style swingle is a gas to watch. He's happy to be liberated from having to slam a clip into a Glock. But unlike the Rock Hudson-Doris Day comedies that inspired "Women," no one bothered to define the women, and they're so uncomplicated it's a form of neglect. Ms. Tomei makes a huge impression as a damaged-goods actress who falls into Mr. Gibson's clutches (Mitchell).

* "YOU CAN COUNT ON ME," starring Laura Linney, Mark Ruffalo, Matthew Broderick, Jon Tenney and Rory Culkin. Written and directed by Kenneth Lonergan (R, 111 minutes). This small, realistic gem, set in an upstate New York town, looks deeply and empathetically into the loving but strained relationship between Sammy (Ms. Linney), a single mother with an 8-year-old son, and Terry (Mr. Ruffalo), her wastrel brother who returns home after serving a jail sentence. The two share a special bond, having lost their parents in a car crash when they were children. Mr. Broderick is Sammy's stuffy new boss at the bank where she works as a loan officer. The tensions that erupt may not be the most melodramatic domestic problems ever filmed, but they're the stuff of life, and Ms. Linney's and Mr. Ruffalo's performances are achingly perfect (Holden).

Film Series

"THE DECALOGUE." When Stephen Holden, film critic of The New York Times, compiled his list of the 10 best films of 2000, he included a work created in 1988-89. And he called it a masterwork. He was discussing "The Decalogue," a cycle of 10 fables loosely based on the Ten Commandments and created for Polish television by Krzysztof Kieslowski (1941-1996). "The Decalogue," set in and around a Warsaw housing development, was released in theaters only last year. Beginning today, an opportunity to see this remarkable mini-series on the large screen arises again with the start of showings of 35-millimeter prints in the BAMcinematek repertory program at the BAM Rose Cinemas. The films, each about 55 minutes and subtitled in English, are to be shown in sequence at the rate of two weekly. The series begins with Decalogues I (Thou shalt have no other gods before me) and II (Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain). The first deals with the consequences of a father's allegiance to science and technology and the second with the workings of fate on an ailing husband and the unborn child his wife has conceived by another man. Screening times for the first week are 2 and 9:30 p.m. today through Sunday and 9:30 p.m. Monday through Thursday. "The Decalogue" continues through Feb. 22 at the BAM Rose Cinemas at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene. Tickets: $9; $5 for children under 12 and the elderly and for students at weekday screenings. Information and full schedule: (718) 636-4157 (Lawrence Van Gelder).

HEADLINE: TRANSITION IN WASHINGTON; 
Excerpts From Senate Hearing on Norton's Selection as Interior Secretary

 BODY:
Following are Gale A. Norton's opening statement yesterday at her confirmation hearing for secretary of the interior and excerpts from questions and answers between Ms. Norton and Senators Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico; Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska; and Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc.:

Ms. Norton
 I'm glad to have this chance to tell you something about the goals that President-elect Bush and I share and which we hope to achieve, if you see fit to confirm me as secretary of the interior. 
 As you all know, America is a land of singular beauty. Americans are proud of the many exquisite national treasures within our shores. President-elect Bush believes, as I do, that the top priority of the Department of the Interior must be to conserve those natural treasures. One of President-elect Bush's priorities is to protect our national park system. We plan to return scientists to our parks and to work with Congress to eliminate the major maintenance backlogs that have been obstacles to resource protection, and to do that within five years. This initiative would help restore our national parks and ensure a positive legacy of protecting our cultural, natural and recreational treasures for Americans today and in the future. 
The great wild places and unspoiled landscapes of this country are the common heritage of all Americans, and we must both conserve them and manage them for Americans living today, and for the Americans of the future, our children and our children's children. That is our goal. I don't think any of us here today would disagree on that goal. In that, I believe, lies the basis for common ground. We have the opportunity for bipartisan environmental cooperation and leadership. 
I've worked for more than 20 years on environmental issues. I'm proud of my accomplishments: preserving endangered species, cleaning up mountain valleys polluted by mining, working to convert the Rocky Mountain Arsenal from a place polluted by pesticides and nerve gas residues to a wildlife refuge.
Based on these experiences, I am firmly committed to a process of consultation and collaboration. We should listen to all voices and involve all citizens. That is fair. It is also wise. People are a magnificent resource for ideas, for knowledge, for insights.
I've lived and worked here in Washington. I have also lived and worked in the great American West. Those of us here in Washington need to be good partners with Americans living in other parts of this country and in our territories. America is a stronger nation because of the diversity of its people. These people hold many different views and perspectives. We need to work with them, to involve them, to benefit from their creativity and their capacity to innovate.
One top priority that I want to mention to you today concerns the special responsibilities of the secretary of the interior with regard to American Indians. I think we should all recognize that the situation in Indian country is not as it should be. There is much that I believe we can do, in partnership with our nation's proud Native American tribes, to improve conditions and provide a more hopeful future.
President-elect Bush has said many times that he will leave no child behind. To accomplish that requires that we improve the schools that serve more than 50,000 Native American children. A good education is the key to a better life for any child, whether that child lives in Washington, D.C., or Miami, Fla., or on a reservation in New Mexico.
Recognizing the historic relationship of the federal government and native American tribal governments, I will work very hard to achieve real results for every Indian child.
President-elect Bush has proposals to build conservation partnerships, to help states, local communities and private landowners to conserve wildlife habitat, watersheds and open space. I'm excited by the chance to work together on these proposals. Working together, there is much that we can do to promote conservation in the United States.
Mr. Chairman, members of the committee, I will be candid in telling you that I am both a conservative and a conservationist. I see no conflict there. In fact, I am a compassionate conservative and a passionate conservationist. I believe that, too, is entirely consistent.
If confirmed as secretary of the interior, I intend to make the conservation of America's natural resources my top priority. Using consultation and collaboration, forging partnerships with interested citizens, we can succeed in our effort to conserve America's most precious places. What's more, we can achieve this while maintaining America's prosperity and economic dynamism, while respecting constitutional rights and nurturing diverse traditions and cultures.
It won't always be easy. It will require a lot of hard work and the willingness to be creative, to think outside the usual boxes.
That is the mission that President-elect Bush has asked me to undertake. With your help, your wisdom and your cooperation, I believe that we can succeed.
Thank you very much.

Questions and Answers

SENATOR BINGAMAN -- A few years ago, according to writing that you did, you described yourself as a free-market conservative, an advocate of judicial restraint, as well as a champion of states' rights. And over the years, you have taken some positions on the takings clause, for example, on the federal taxing power, on the 10th Amendment, on the now long-discredited theory about economic due process, which seem, at least as I read some of those earlier writings of yours, to be at odds with mainstream legal thought.
Can you give this committee assurance that if confirmed, you would feel comfortable enforcing the existing laws and regulations of the Department of Interior as they now stand?

MS. NORTON -- Mr. Chairman, I have served eight years in the capacity of the state attorney general, enforcing the laws of Colorado and of the United States. And I feel very comfortable in enforcing the laws as they are written. I will be fully committed to ensuring that our nation's environmental laws and laws for the protection of natural resources will be fully enforced.

Q. Many of the Republican members of Congress, some on this committee, have been sharply critical of the environmental initiatives and policies of Secretary Babbitt and of President Clinton and his administration. Which, if any, of those legal or policy positions that have been adopted by the Department of Interior during this last eight years would you depart from or attempt to change?

A. There are many things that have been adopted over the past few years. We will be looking at what needs to be changed, in our views, and the many things that will remain the same. We will examine issues across the board and apply the best legal standards, as well as the views that I believe many of us would share, to ensure that we are doing the best to preserve our natural resources. At this point, I'm not sure where we may depart from the past administration, but we will carefully examine those things and work with this Congress in order to examine issues.

Q. One issue that the president and the secretary of interior, the current secretary of interior, have been roundly criticized about by Republicans here in the Congress is this issue of designation of national monuments. I believe this president has designated 19 areas as national monuments under the authority that he has under the Antiquities Act. Do you believe that the president's use of that Antiquities Act, President Clinton's use of that Antiquities Act, was appropriate or not?

A. The goal of preserving lands is an admirable goal, and I share the goal of trying to be sure that we are identifying those areas that ought to be natural treasures and setting those aside. The process in which those decisions were made is one that causes me concern. Many of those decisions were made through a top-down process without consulting the people who are most affected by those decisions. President-elect Bush has established his view, and I certainly share that, that decisions about the land should be made in a process that includes the people who are affected by those decisions.
And I would certainly hope that in the future we would hear input from those of you on this committee, from governors, from local communities before we take actions that are going to deeply impact people's lives.

Q. Would you advocate repeal of the Antiquities Act or some changes in that basic statute?

A. The Antiquities Act is something that has been very useful in the past. It has shown its ability to preserve some of our most important national monuments. I would like to see a process of involvement of the people most affected by decisions. That certainly would be the practice that would be followed in a Bush administration if I am selected to be secretary of the interior. Whether that would require changes in that statute for the long term is a decision that I have not made in terms of what we would advocate and obviously would require Congressional action in order to make any of those changes. . . .

SENATOR MURKOWSKI -- Do you feel that you can bring together within this new administration the wherewithal and the policy makers to resolve and make some decisions about how we're going to relieve our dependence on imports of 56 percent going up to, we heard this morning, 62 by the year 2004? Our greatest source seems to be coming now from Saddam Hussein. We fought a war in '92; we lost 147 lives. We can't address what to do with our nuclear waste. Oil prices continue to go up. We're looking towards natural gas; now we're using it faster than we're finding it. You're going to have to come up with some of these answers with your collective colleagues. How do you propose to do it?

A. The issue of Americans being so dependent on foreign oil is, obviously, a great cause for concern. The idea that people in California, this very day, are facing serious shortages of energy is another great cause of concern. We will have to pull together all of our resources and work across departmental lines to find ways of addressing those issues.
Obviously, it's going to be difficult to find short-term answers. We'll have to do a lot of planning to be able to find long-term answers. We would hope to work with you to find the right kinds of solutions that would balance environmental protection, as well as finding ways of providing the kind of energy resources that need to be available.

Q. I think it's appropriate that I bring up the issue of ANWR Alaska National Wildlife Refuge , because some would be disappointed if I didn't. In any event, many members of our environmental community have opposed your nomination because of the president-elect's position on environmentally responsible oil and gas exploration in that small portion of the Arctic coastal plain in my state of Alaska. However, the reality is you nor the president currently has the authority to open up this area. Only Congress has that authority.
And in this regard, I have two questions for you. If Congress is to undertake the debate on this issue, will you commit to aid those debates with the very best science available from the Department of Interior?

A. Absolutely. I view the role of the Department of Interior as helping provide the information to this Congress so that you can make an informed decision. We hope to look at the issues of how we can provide the best scientific evaluation of the environmental consequences, how we can do any exploration and production, if it is done, in the absolute most environmentally conscious way that we can have that happen.

Q. My second question is, if Congress approves a measure to allow exploration and development of the coastal plain and it becomes law, will you uphold the law Congress passes and use all the powers afforded to you to mitigate any potential negative environmental consequences?

A. I will certainly follow any laws that are passed, to be sure that the protection of the important resources of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge are preserved at the same time that any exploration or production would take place.

Q. Thank you. Now moving over to Prudhoe Bay, which was discovered 30-some odd years ago. In the search for oil in Prudhoe Bay, which has been providing this nation with about 20 percent of the total domestic crude oil produced for some 27 years, and it's falling off now as Prudhoe Bay declines, but not looking for it, but as a sidelight, we found some 36 trillion cubic feet of natural gas. Nobody paid much attention to it because of the cost of getting that gas out when gas was $2.16 per thousand cubic feet, which is what it was a year ago. Now gas is $8.40. And as we look at our reserves and the fact that we're pulling down our reserves, there is more and more thought given to marketing that gas.
In order for this to become a reality it's going to take a transportation system and it's going to require an investment of about $10 billion, the largest single construction project that would be on the horizon, and larger than anything that we've undertaken in this country.
Should the owners of the gas decide to move forward with such a project, the Department of Interior, through the Joint Pipeline Office, will have an awful lot to say about the permitting and development. My question to you is, if confirmed, will you act in your role as secretary to provide all the resources needed to the Joint Pipeline Office in Alaska to help expedite a project of this magnitude if indeed it becomes a reality?

A. I'm aware of the important need for natural gas not just because our economy is expanding and there's more demand for energy, but also because natural gas is seen as one of the ways of having the cleanest supply of energy. So it's important for us to have some mechanisms to be able to draw upon gas resources.
I will look forward to working with you to learn more about that issue. It's not one that I have had the opportunity, obviously, to discuss the details on. I will look forward to working with you so that we can resolve that issue. . . . 

SENATOR DORGAN -- You have written that there is little consensus over whether global warming is occurring. Do you think there's any kind of a scientific consensus at all that there is some significant climate change occurring or global warming occurring?

A. Global warming is an issue that has seen scientific information developing over time. And the further we go through the process, the more information we have available.
The article that you referred to is something that was written several years ago. I will maintain an open mind and receive new scientific information as it is put forward.

Q. But my question is, do you think there's a consensus on any side of this issue? Some would say, you know, while there are doubters, certainly, and some respected doubters, there seems to be a fairly overwhelming consensus among most scientists that something is occurring in the area of global warming. Do you share that view?

A. It does seem, based on my evaluation, which is not a scientific one, that there is beginning to be more of a consensus that global warming is occurring. There is still disagreement as to the causes and the long-term future. And obviously, there is disagreement about what ought to be done in that regard. I will certainly rely on scientific information as it becomes available and evaluate the information as it is presented to me.

HEADLINE: TRANSITION IN WASHNGTON: THE PRESIDENT-ELECT; 
G.O.P. Begins a Party 8 Years in the Making

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 

 BODY:
Forty-eight hours before settling into the Oval Office, President-elect George W. Bush kicked off a Republican takeover of Washington today with a whirl of celebrations, private dinners with big contributors, and a concert and fireworks show attended by thousands of supporters.
 Holding hands with his wife, Laura, Mr. Bush descended the steps of the Lincoln Memorial this afternoon to the strains of Aaron Copland's "Appalachian Spring" in the first major event leading to his swearing in Saturday as the 43rd president of the United States. Then he took a seat on the reviewing stand for an eclectic performance by singers, actors and athletes -- everyone from Ricky Martin to Andrew Lloyd Webber, Muhammad Ali and Mr. Bush's own choice for secretary of state, Colin L. Powell, who introduced Dara Torres, the Olympic swimmer -- in the chilly, damp night air. 
 It was on the same steps, eight years ago, that Bill Clinton celebrated the imminent takeover of the White House from another Bush. So today's ceremonies had the air of a political restoration, punctuated by the presence of many of Mr. Bush's father's advisers, who have resurfaced in the new administration. 
On Capitol Hill, the arguments over two of Mr. Bush's selections, John Ashcroft for attorney general and Gale A. Norton for interior secretary, continued to boil. But Mr. Bush -- perhaps buoyed by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's unanimous endorsement of General Powell today -- sounded only moderate, inclusive notes, the same notes expected in his Inaugural Address. 
"I want everybody to hear loud and clear that I'm going to be the president of everybody," Mr. Bush said this morning to a meeting of the Republican National Committee, acknowledging indirectly that he had lost the popular vote, even while winning 30 states and the electoral vote. "Whether they voted for me or not, I'm their president."
Corporate America certainly demonstrated that he was its president: General Motors held a glittering cocktail party this evening on the roof of the Kennedy Center for Mr. Bush's White House chief of staff, Andrew H. Card Jr., who until last year was the company's chief lobbyist here. Carmakers, other major corporations and law firms have events planned through the weekend. 
Mr. Bush was so busy running among dinners here this evening -- the cost to attend was $2,500 a plate -- that his spokesman said he had had no time to watch Mr. Clinton's farewell address on television.
Mr. Clinton used the speech to warn against three dangers: failing to pay down the national debt, retreating from the policy of engagement and open trade with great powers and the developing world, and ignoring racial and ethnic divisions.
But within the Bush camp, some aides focused not on the message but the timing, complaining that once again Mr. Clinton would not give up the stage -- insisting that he be given network broadcast time at a moment that Mr. Bush's supporters believe should belong to the president-elect.
As the Bush team spread through Washington, greeted by Republicans the way the French greeted the Allies retaking Paris, the White House was a sea of melancholy.
Surrounded by boxes of papers being shipped off to the National Archives, Mr. Clinton's aides sent e-mail messages that had the sound of the last transmissions from a sinking vessel. Many were forwarding addresses and phone numbers, now that they would no longer be instantly accessible through the White House operators. A senior aide in the Treasury Department sent invitations to a "disinauguration party."
Other members of the Clinton inner circle said they were leaving town for the weekend, unable to bear the sight of Mr. Bush taking office while Al Gore, his rival in the election, retreats to suburban Virginia.
But Mr. Clinton's top economic advisers over the past eight years flew back into town Wednesday, gathering at the Hotel Washington for a subdued celebration of their contributions to an economy that kept booming until the last few months of the administration.
"I worked with many great people in this administration," former Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, now the head of Citigroup's executive committee, told his former colleagues Wednesday night. "And I'm reminded of that every day because so many of them are in my waiting room, looking for jobs." 
In fact, many of them are moving only blocks from the White House. The current treasury secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, will be running into the head of the National Economic Council, Gene Sperling, at the Brookings Institution. 
William S. Cohen, the secretary of defense, is starting his own consulting group, but will spend time at the Center for Strategic and International Studies -- alongside enough former Clinton assistant secretaries and national security staff members to put together a daily meeting in a mock situation room.
Movers have been sweeping through the White House with such care that come noon on Saturday, there will be barely a shred of paper left on any desk in the West Wing, and no data on the computer hard drives. All of that will be shipped to the archives, leaving the Bush team to move into what is certainly the most prime real estate in Washington, and probably the barest.
"We'll leave it," one staff member said, "exactly as we found it on the afternoon of Jan. 20, 1993."
On the Mall, the combination of unpleasant weather, the early dismissal of Washington's bureaucracy to avoid traffic foulups, and heavy security kept the audience for the inaugural concert small and unusually subdued. It did not matter: many members of the largely youthful crowd said they came less to see Mr. Bush than to watch the show.
Anna Trai, a 19-year-old from Germantown, Md., said Ricky Martin was why she arrived at 9 this morning. After he was introduced by Vice President-elect Dick Cheney, Mr. Bush himself joked, "there's a lot of excitement in the air, and I'm not sure if it's because people came to see you, or Ricky Martin."
But Mr. Bush said he found it "humbling" to realize that he would soon be among those who followed Lincoln to the presidency and said, "I am honored to serve, and I am ready to start."
 Ms. Trai found herself pressed up near a chain-link fence far from the Washington Monument, the closest that security personnel would allow people without tickets to get to Mr. Bush. It was one of many precautions being taken for fear of a terrorist attack; the subway will not even stop at some stations on Saturday.
In Washington's packed hotels, the focus was on the future. This morning Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's chief strategist, dissected the election results for the Republican National Committee, suggesting ways to build on Mr. Bush's narrow victory. 
He noted that Mr. Bush got 35 percent of the Hispanic vote, the highest percentage by a Republican since 1984. "This is a dynamic and growing part of the electorate that shares our values," he said, declaring it was "our mission and our goal" to get a higher percentage of the Hispanic vote. He said that would "require all of us in every way and every day working to get that done."
He said Mr. Bush and his agenda had drawn more moderate voters than Republicans had in the past, proving that there was a "gigantic coalition" available if Republicans framed their debate with Democrats correctly. Mr. Rove also noted that Mr. Bush had received fewer votes from blacks than Bob Dole, the Republican nominee in 1996. "As a country and as a party," he said, "that has to be unacceptable to us."

Bush shared a stage yesterday at the Lincoln Memorial with the singer Ricky Martin. (Reuters)(pg. A26)

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS; 
Schaap, Writer and Commentator, Has a New Subject: Himself

BYLINE:  By Richard Sandomir 

 BODY:
Had the long-distance runner Pheidippides not dropped dead in 490 B.C. after running 25 miles from Marathon to Athens to tell the Greeks they had beaten the Persians, he might have hired Dick Schaap to write his life story.
 You can picture writer and first marathoner sequestered for three weeks at an Aegean resort to chat about the marathoner's life and storied military career. And Schaap would write the book in two months. 
 Schaap, silver-haired and 66 years old, has seemingly been around forever. He is renowned as the co-author of 13 autobiographies, as a print journalist, as an ESPN and ABC News commentator and as the father of the ESPN reporter Jeremy Schaap. 
Now, after writing books about other people, he has written one about himself, "Flashing Before My Eyes" (William Morrow), a breezy and delightful work of staggering anecdotage featuring a cast of just about everybody he has ever met.
Schaap hoped to call the book "Name-Dropping." But the economist John Kenneth Galbraith and the comedian Alan King had already used it. Dropping names is Schaap's forte. By my count -- and I confess to counting the equines, cats and dogs that Schaap has commiserated with -- he drops 531 names in his book. 
Nearly two a page.
"For years," he said, "I used 'Name-Dropping' as the title of the speech I gave because name-dropping is my living, dropping names into sentences and microphones."
Schaap is connected to more people than Kevin Bacon, whose film career with ensemble casts created a parlor game that quickly links him to everyone in Hollywood history.
He played lacrosse against Jim Brown, surrendering four goals.
His housemate during a summer spent at a steel company was the "Gong Show" creator and host, Chuck Barris.
He introduced Cassius Clay to Harlem and Sugar Ray Robinson.
He took Bobby Fischer to a Knicks game and prowled drug dens (to research a story) with Peter Falk.
Along with his second wife, he slept at Wilt Chamberlain's mansion.
Years later, after Chamberlain wrote of his 20,000 female liaisons, Schaap's wife, Trish, touched the great center on his elbow and asked, "Does that count?"
He covered the 1960 World Series in Pittsburgh and, while there, befriended the comedian Lenny Bruce, who was performing in the city. They discovered they had both grown up in Freeport, N.Y.
He is the most-used talking head in ESPN Classic's "SportsCentury."
"Mark calls and I ask, 'Do you want a quote or an anecdote?' " Schaap said, referring to Mark Shapiro, ESPN Classic's top executive.
"He's got all this information locked up in his head," Shapiro said.
ESPN Classic is making a two-hour documentary based on Schaap's book, in which Schaap will shift to talking about himself.
One recent Sunday, after he taped his weekly ESPN panel show, "The Sports Reporters," Schaap walked into Barney Greengrass, the Manhattan loxsmith. He was greeted by Gary Greengrass, the owner, who is connected to Schaap by more than sliced nova: he was a high school intern at Channel 4 when Schaap delivered the nightly sportscast.
His people collection is so large that he omitted an index to prevent friends from putting the book back on a store shelf once they had seen what he had written about them.
Like any memoir, Schaap's is an exercise in ego. He has a thriving one, but he's happy to laugh at himself. In an early draft of the book, he said, he tried to top his tales about others, then omitted his toppers to be more self-deprecating.
"If you're going to write about yourself, I felt, you should make yourself the butt of the jokes," he said. "Or, you can do it the way Romain Gary did it in his autobiography. Lie. He wrote about falling in love as an 8-year-old with a 7-year-old girl. To impress her, he said he ate his galoshes."
Schaap's professional life has been charmed as he moved from Newsweek to The New York Herald Tribune to Sport magazine to Channel 4 to ABC to ESPN. 
He is inextricably connected to sports, but is as personally attached to the theater, which he reviews regularly for the ABC News overnight show "World News Now."
So with all this stuff crammed in his brain and in cartons, it was time to ask himself to write his autobiography. "It was a pleasure to write in my voice," he said. "I was accessible, so I knew how to reach me, which isn't always easy with an athlete."
What is not on view in Schaap's tome is a glimpse into his inner life. Obviously, Schaap refused to open up very much to himself.
"I'm not very reflective," he said reflectively. "Maybe if you don't reflect, you don't hurt as much."
Omitted from the book, but revealed over Schaap's cheese omelet, is the judgment of one of his six children, Joanna, a poet and editor, who was named for Schaap's pal Joe Namath, whose memoir he wrote and whose talk show he was co-host of.
"She once wrote me an angry note saying my progress from being friendly with Lenny Bruce to being friendly with Billy Crystal showed how far I'd fallen," Schaap said. "She's also written poems where I perceive myself to be the villain."
Such villainy may be an intrafamily notion, because to generations of sports fans he has presented a knowledgeable, avuncular image.
"I'm very lucky that people think I'm a nice guy," he said in his raspy voice, "whether I am or not."

AIRWAVES
PHIL SIMMS has signed a new contract worth at least $2 million annually to continue as CBS's lead National Football League analyst. . . . BRENT MUSBURGER has also agreed to a new multiyear deal at ABC Sports.

HEADLINE: TRANSITION IN WASHINGTON: THE ENERGY DEPARTMENT; 
Few Answers and Few Waves At Energy Designee's Hearing

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 

 BODY:
President-elect George W. Bush's choice for energy secretary, Spencer Abraham, today disavowed the position he had taken as a senator to dismantle the Energy Department, answering the only question put to him about his energy record at a congenial confirmation hearing.
 Mr. Abraham was pressed a little harder on what the federal government should do about the California electricity crisis, but he refused to comment, saying he did not want to upset negotiations there among utilities, generators and state legislators. 
 Although Mr. Abraham has been selected to head a department facing many contentious issues, members of the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources failed to extract specifics from him on most of the questions they asked. 
Most senators referred to the nominee, who is a former colleague, as Spence, but informality did not squeeze out the bizarre. Following Senate tradition, the nominee was introduced by the senators from his own state, Michigan, one of whom is Debbie Stabenow, a Democrat who defeated Mr. Abraham in November in his bid for a second term. The state's other senator, Carl Levin, also a Democrat, referred to the presentation as "American democracy at its ironic best." 
In about three hours, most of it taken up by panel members voicing their own opinions on subjects ranging from electricity shortages and gasoline mileage to nuclear waste, Mr. Abraham made these points: 
*The electric generation industry's shift to building plants that run almost exclusively on natural gas is creating an unbalanced system. 
*The National Nuclear Security Agency may be conducting too many lie-detector tests, subjecting even Mr. Abraham himself to the procedure.
*Nuclear waste cleanup may need to be altered so the nation can "begin to gain some ground on the cleanup of these sites."
"Overhead and security issues have consumed so much of the budget," Mr. Abraham complained. Environmental management will cost about $6.75 billion this year, he said, about a third of the department's spending. Hardly any land has been completely cleaned, but the work has cut the risk of spread of contamination in some cases, department officials say.
Mr. Abraham referred to the need for a "balanced" energy solution, including increased domestic production of oil and gas, conservation and more use of renewable energy sources, and decreased reliance on imported oil. But he offered no specifics about how to achieve these goals.
Environmental groups complained today that as a senator from Michigan, Mr. Abraham opposed increases in fuel economy standards; today he said he thought the market was moving faster than was possible for the government to turn out fuel-efficient hybrid vehicles.
After a break for lunch, the committee approved Mr. Abraham's selection by unanimous voice vote. But while members were supportive, several offered words of caution. Senator Frank H. Murkowski of Alaska, a Republican who will become chairman of the committee after the presidential inauguration, told Mr. Abraham, "This is not necessarily a glamorous position."
While committee members seemed eager to pass legislation intended to cut reliance on oil imports, one, Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, said Congress would have to do better than in 1979, after the last oil crisis.
The major bills then, he said, were the Synfuels Act, a billion-dollar effort to make liquid vehicle fuel from solid fuels; the Natural Gas Policy Act, which controlled the price of that fuel; the Fuel Use Act, which forbade the use of natural gas in power plants; the Windfall Profits Tax, which put price limits on oil, and the Energy Allocation Act, which gave government the power to distribute scarce supplies.
All were later repealed, he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Congeniality held sway yesterday as Spencer Abraham testified before his former Senate colleagues on his selection as energy secretary. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: TRANSITION IN WASHINGTON: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
Selling Point Is a Sore One

BYLINE:  By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 

 BODY:
One of George W. Bush's selling points during the primary campaign last year was inclusiveness. In two campaigns for governor, he and his backers argued, he had done better among blacks and other minorities than most other Republicans, and he would do so in the presidential race.
 Mr. Bush urged his party to remember that it carried "the mantle of Lincoln." As if in response, the Republicans gave unusually prominent roles to African-American speakers and performers at their convention in Philadelphia. 
 None of it made much difference. He won only 9 percent of the black vote, tying Ronald Reagan for the worst showing by a Republican presidential nominee in many years.
On Saturday, African-Americans will be prominent among those protesting at Mr. Bush's inauguration, even though he has chosen for his cabinet the first black secretary of state and a widely respected black educator.
Ask black politicians about the appointments, and they quickly change the subject to Florida, where, they assert, antiquated voting equipment and unfriendly electoral officials in minority precincts illegitimately tipped the outcome to Mr. Bush.
"A majority of African-Americans think that the election was stolen," said David Bositis, an analyst of minority voting at the Joint Center for Economic Studies, a think tank here.
The bitterness that many black voters and their white allies feel toward the president-elect was on vivid display as the Senate Judiciary Committee pressed Mr. Bush's choice of former Senator John Ashcroft as attorney general.
With attention centered on Judge Ronnie L. White of the Missouri Supreme Court, an African-American, and Mr. Ashcroft's success in blocking his nomination as a federal judge, the session was supercharged with racial tension.
Senator Charles E. Schumer, the New York Democrat, said Mr. Ashcroft had applied a double standard, campaigning for Judge White's defeat last year on grounds that he was soft on crime while voting to approve other, more liberal white judges. Senator Alan J. Dixon of Illinois, regarded as a moderate Democrat in his home state, joined in the attack, suggesting that Judge White had been vilified for Mr. Ashcroft's selfish political ends.
Describing Mr. Ashcroft as "racially insensitive," Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware said at a committee hearing on Wednesday: "People are suspect not because they believe you are a racist. They are suspect because they believe your ideology blinds you not just to the law but to the facts."
As they always do, the senators cloaked the intensity of their feelings in polite legislative language. But Senator Dixon's suggestion that Mr. Ashcroft had derailed Judge White's nomination in an effort to save his own political skin in an ultimately unsuccessful re-election campaign went well beyond the politesse usually observed by sitting senators in dealing with a former colleague. So did Senator Edward M. Kennedy's red-faced suggestions that Mr. Ashcroft had spoken treasonously, or something close to it, in arguing that citizens needed firearms to defend themselves against a potentially tyrannical central government.
Senator Arlen Specter, a Pennsylvania Republican, said that today's session was the roughest he had sat through in more than 21 years on the committee -- rougher even than the notably contentious Supreme Court confirmation hearings for Robert H. Bork and Clarence Thomas. Several other Republicans warned the Democrats to moderate their language and remain collegial.
In a sense, Mr. Ashcroft has reminded African-Americans of some of the president-elect's own missteps. Mr. Bush spoke at Bob Jones University in Greenville, S.C., during the campaign, although it had a history of forbidding interracial dating; Mr. Ashcroft, it turned out, spoke there, too. Mr. Bush refused to call for the removal of the Confederate battle flag from the South Carolina Capitol; Mr. Ashcroft, it turned out, gave an interview to a magazine called Southern Partisan that avidly celebrates the Confederacy.
In a brief time, the Missourian has become the leading symbol of Mr. Bush's difficulties with black voters. He is highly likely to be confirmed, and as attorney general he will help Mr. Bush solidify his political base. But his presence at the Justice Department will make it very difficult for the department and the administration to establish effective communications with African-Americans other than the tiny group of black Republicans.
No matter how many black judges Mr. Ashcroft has voted to confirm, no matter how vocally he has decried segregation, the black community seems determined to view him as walking, talking evidence that Mr. Bush is deaf to its interests.
Speaking at Northwestern University early this week, before he was knocked off stride by the revelation that he had fathered a child out of wedlock, Jesse Jackson stated the indictment: "Ashcroft, if he gets through, will determine who is prosecuted, who is targeted, who will be judged, who will go to jail. He cannot be trusted."
Mr. Bush's popularity among black voters apparently sank with the attempt to use the Philadelphia convention as a symbol of a new, open attitude.
Black leaders denounced the convention as phony, and several described it as "a minstrel show."
Mayor Willie Brown of San Francisco said that it reminded him of a National Basketball Association game: "All the people on the stage are black, and all the people in the audience are white."
Studies by the Joint Center found that Mr. Bush's favorable rating among black voters dropped from 43 percent in May 1999, when he was pondering a run for president, to 29 percent at the end of September 2000, when the campaign was nearing a climax. The more African-Americans saw of Mr. Bush, said Mr. Bositis, who designed the polls, "the less they liked him."
More fuel went onto the fire in the November imbroglio in Florida, with Kweisi Mfume, president of the N.A.A.C.P., charging that there had been disproportionate purging of voter rolls and other chicanery in mainly African-American precincts.
Now Mr. Bush, about to cross the threshold of the White House, faces continuing challenges from a new black militancy to his legitimacy and his ambition to be the president of all Americans, as he put it tonight. 

CORRECTION-DATE: January 20, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A front-page news analysis article yesterday about the nomination of John Ashcroft as attorney general misidentified the senator who suggested that Mr. Ashcroft had vilified Judge Ronnie White for selfish political ends. It was Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, not Alan J. Dixon, who left the Senate in 1993. The article also referred incorrectly to Mr. Ashcroft's views on a civil rights issue. He has deplored segregation, not desegregation.

HEADLINE: Jackson Says He Fathered Child in Affair With Aide 

BYLINE:  By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 18 

 BODY:
The Rev. Jesse Jackson acknowledged early today that he had fathered a child out of wedlock with an employee in his civil rights organization, the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition. 
 Mr. Jackson, in a statement issued because a supermarket tabloid, The National Enquirer, was preparing to disclose the information, said he would be curtailing his public activities while "taking some time off to revive my spirit and reconnect with my family." 
 One of the nation's most prominent political leaders and civil rights activists, Mr. Jackson is a Baptist minister and a former aide to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. He sought the Democratic nomination for president twice, in 1984 and 1988.
Mr. Jackson, a friend of President Clinton's, was a special envoy to Africa and served as a spiritual adviser to the Clinton family during the impeachment proceedings over Mr. Clinton's extramarital affair in the White House.
Today Mr. Jackson, who has been married for 38 years, said in the statement: "This is no time for evasions, denials or alibis. I fully accept responsibility, and I am truly sorry for my actions." 
Advisers to Mr. Jackson said he had had an affair with Karin L. Stanford, whom he met when she was an assistant professor of political science and African-American studies at the University of Georgia and writing a book about Mr. Jackson's impact on foreign policy, "Beyond the Boundaries: Reverend Jesse Jackson and International Affairs," which was published in 1997.
Mr. Jackson hired Dr. Stanford to be director of the Washington bureau of the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition, a nonprofit organization that seeks economic and political power for minorities, and aides said they became involved after she joined the organization. In May 1999, Dr. Stanford gave birth to Mr. Jackson's child, a girl.
"As her mother does, I love this child very much," Mr. Jackson, 59, said in the statement, "and have assumed responsibility for her emotional and financial support since she was born."
A Jackson adviser said Mr. Jackson was paying Dr. Stanford, who is 39, about $3,000 a month to support their daughter. He also paid about $40,000 in expenses to help her move to Los Angeles from Washington, the adviser said, adding that the money came from Mr. Jackson's personal savings. 
Efforts to reach Dr. Stanford by telephone were unsuccessful. 
Jackson advisers said that after the baby was born Mr. Jackson told his wife, Jackie, and their five children, including Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr., Democrat of Illinois. The congressman issued a statement today, saying, "Over the course of nearly four decades of marriage, my father and our family have survived many dangers and endured many crises and, with God's help, we hope to endure this one as well."
In his statement, the senior Mr. Jackson, who declined to be interviewed, alluded to the fact that he was also a product of an out-of-wedlock union. 
"I was born of these circumstances, and I know the importance of growing up in a nurturing, supportive and protected environment," he said, "so I am determined to give my daughter and her mother the privacy they both deserve." 
A spokesman, John Scanlon, said Mr. Jackson would keep his short-term public commitments, although it was unclear whether he would still participate in protests in Washington at President-elect George W. Bush's inauguration. Mr. Jackson's other forthcoming events include a conference, scheduled for next week, of the Wall Street Project, an initiative that seeks to persuade corporations to provide more opportunities for women and minorities by increasing their hiring and capital investment in rural areas and inner cities. 
Mr. Scanlon said he did not know how long Mr. Jackson would be keeping a low profile. 
Supporters urged people not to condemn Mr. Jackson.
"I remind people that Reverend Jesse Jackson should not be judged by just this situation," the Rev. Al Sharpton said in a news conference in New York City. "We should remember that for 35 years, it was Jesse Jackson who walked a picket line, that marched, that went to jail, that went to foreign shores to bring home prisoners of war for this nation. It was Jesse Jackson that raised issues that others didn't raise. Jesse Jackson should not be seen just in one limited and one-dimensional act."
Jake Siewert, a White House spokesman, said President Clinton was aware of the situation, but he said did not think the president had talked yet with Mr. Jackson. 
"This is a family matter that Reverend Jackson has vowed to deal with on his own," Mr. Siewert said. "And our thoughts and prayers are with him."

HEADLINE: TRANSITION IN WASHINGTON: THE INTERIOR DEPARTMENT; 
Interior Choice Faces Sharp Questioning

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 

 BODY:
Facing skeptical Senate Democrats, Gale A. Norton presented herself today as both a conservative and a conservationist and said her past legal views would not prevent her from enforcing environmental laws if she became secretary of interior.
 But on the first day of her Senate confirmation hearings, Democrats sharply questioned whether Ms. Norton's record on positions that she had taken as a lawyer, a government official and a politician would be compatible with her new post. 
 "I have no doubt that Ms. Norton is a very decent and capable person," said Senator Jeff Bingaman, the New Mexico Democrat acting as the committee's chairman. "But I have doubts about whether some of the policies she has promoted are consistent with the responsibilities of the secretary of the interior." 
"For over 20 years, she has consistently championed the interests of the individual over the public, the states over the federal government, and economic development over environmental protections," Senator Bingaman said.
Ms. Norton, 46, a former attorney general of Colorado who has been a longtime critic of federal regulation, spoke softly and carefully throughout her appearance. She gently suggested that her record had been distorted and at one point notably distanced herself from her onetime mentor, James Watt, the interior secretary who resigned under pressure in the Reagan administration.
"I mean no disrespect to him, but I am my own person," Ms. Norton said.
The challenges by the Democrats and Ms. Norton's efforts to address them formed the central dynamic in the two-hour hearing over a nomination that has been bitterly opposed by environmental groups and has become one of the most controversial of the choices to President-elect George W. Bush's cabinet.
Republicans who spoke on Ms. Norton's behalf were unanimous in predicting that she would win confirmation. Frank H. Murkowski, the Alaska Republican who will lead the committee after Inauguration Day, described the interior secretary-designate as one who "has been accused only of guilt by association, has been tarred with innuendoes and brushed with, I think, misinterpretation."
In her testimony and her response to questions, Ms. Norton said that on a number of occasions in the past, she had challenged laws that she might soon be obliged to enforce, most notably the Endangered Species Act. But like John Ashcroft, Mr. Bush's embattled attorney general choice, she said those past stances would not stand in the way of her carrying out her responsibilities.
"I feel very comfortable with enforcing the laws as they are now written," Ms. Norton said.
Ms. Norton's testimony, in a brief opening statement and in her answers to questions from nearly a dozen senators, outlined her views about public lands, which are markedly different from those embraced by the Clinton administration.
She said she had been concerned at the way President Clinton had moved over the last year to designate nearly two dozen new national monuments. She said those decisions and others by the outgoing administration would be reviewed.
When asked her views about permitting snowmobiles on public lands, she struck a tone clearly intended to appeal both to conservative off-road enthusiasts and conservationist nature lovers. "I value the preservation of our lands, and I value the ability of people to use those lands in an appropriate way," she said.
In advance of the hearings, a coalition of 18 environmental groups fighting the nomination took out a newspaper advertisement in The Washington Post and two Capitol Hill publications that displayed an image of just one-half of Ms. Norton's face and described her as "so far on the fringe" that "she's off the page."
The groups, led by the League of Conservation Voters, accused Ms. Norton of having failed to take action against corporate polluters while attorney general in Colorado. "America deserves an interior secretary who will protect our air, water and natural resources not the polluters who seek to exploit them," the advertisement said.
At today's hearing before the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources, several Republican senators criticized that attack in sharp terms as being out of bounds. But several Democrats said the critics had raised legitimate questions, and they said they remained to be persuaded that Ms. Norton's ideological views and her calls for changes that would give more decision making power to the states would not conflict with her federal responsibilities.
"You have to convince me in these hearings that as you provide flexibility to the states in these areas, your bottom line will be unwavering," said Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon. "All federal laws must be complied with, and you have to enforce them." 
In response to particular questions, Ms. Norton insisted that she had never advocated "a right to pollute," as a line in a 1991 speech had seemed to suggest. She also said that she had once declined to represent the state of Colorado in defending a minority set-aside policy not because she disagreed with the policy, but because the state's position was not legally defensible.
The state's position was ultimately rejected by the Supreme Court, in a decision that Ms. Norton described as a vindication of her views.
Throughout her appearance, Ms. Norton seemed to be trying hard to put a different gloss on an image that until now has been largely shaped by critics. Rather than emphasize her advocacy of drilling in Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, for example, she named as one of her proudest accomplishments as the Interior Department's solicitor general in the 1980's her work toward the protection of the California condor, an endangered species.
She also singled out as a top goal one mentioned by Mr. Bush in his presidential campaign: a major effort to increase financing for the national parks to overcome a backlog in maintenance and upkeep.
A onetime member of the Libertarian Party, Ms. Norton did not entirely try to disguise her conservative views, criticizing what she described as the "top-down" process by which the Clinton administration designated the national monuments without waiting for approval from Western states.
"I have lived and worked in Washington," she said. "I have lived and worked in the great American West. Those of us here in Washington need to be good partners with Americans living in other parts of this country and in our territories."
But in answer to those who have said her priority would be on oil drilling and logging on public lands, she also said that if confirmed by the Senate, "I intend to make the conservation of America's natural treasures my top priority."
"I will be candid in telling you that I am both a conservative and a conservationist," she said. 'I see no conflict there."
Ms. Norton was introduced to the committee by Colorado's two Republican senators, Ben Nighthorse Campbell and Wayne Allard, and by the state's Republican governor, Bill Owens. Governor Owens told the committee that he had once worked as an aide to Senator John Tower, and he expressed concern that Ms. Norton might suffer a fate similar to that of his former boss, whose nomination to become defense secretary under President George Bush was defeated after a round of stormy confirmation hearings.
"What I really hope is that we don't take this fine person, and tear her apart through this process," Governor Owens said.

HEADLINE: TRANSITION IN WASHINGTON: THE PRESIDENT; 
In Farewell Talk, Clinton Looks Back and Forward

BYLINE:  By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 

 BODY:
President Clinton said goodbye to the nation tonight, using his final televised address to look back at his administration's accomplishments and warn the incoming president against retrenching from the world or squandering the country's economic prosperity.
 Mr. Clinton wished President-elect George W. Bush well. But he also bluntly repeated the policy differences he has with his successor, the ones that he hammered away at during the hard-fought presidential campaign. 
 Mr. Clinton spoke of the economic good times that marked his years in office and urged Mr. Bush not to veer away from fiscal responsibility. He never mentioned Mr. Bush's tax-cut plan directly but was clearly trying to nudge the new administration to scale it back in favor of continuing to pay down the debt.
"Staying on that course will bring lower interest rates, greater prosperity and the opportunity to meet our big challenges," he said. "If we choose wisely, we can pay down the debt, deal with the retirement of the baby boomers, invest more in our future and provide tax relief."
Mr. Clinton also spoke of the interconnectedness of today's world and the need for the United States to stay engaged. Again, he was directing his remarks at Mr. Bush, this time contesting the belief that America's military had overextended itself through far-flung peacekeeping missions.
"America cannot and must not disentangle itself from the world," he said. "If we want the world to embody our shared values, then we must assume a shared responsibility. If the wars of the 20th century, especially the recent ones in Kosovo and Bosnia, have taught us anything, it is that we achieve our aims by defending our values, and leading the forces of freedom and peace."
Speaking from the Oval Office -- the same site he had used previously to announce military strikes and plug major legislative initiatives -- Mr. Clinton once borrowed the word "compassionate" that has become a mantra of the incoming Bush administration.
He said that the next president would have to address the growing gap between those thriving under globalization and the many still struggling to survive. "This global gap requires more than compassion," he said. "It requires action. Global poverty is a powder keg that can be ignited by our indifference."
Mr. Clinton also spoke of the importance of tolerance in the United States, challenging Mr. Bush to follow through on his pledge to unite the country.
"We must remember that America cannot lead in the world unless here at home we weave the threads of our coat of many colors into the fabric of one America," he said.
It was a brief farewell by historical standards, and at just under 10 minutes was one of the shortest speeches by the loquacious Mr. Clinton. He had huddled with aides until the very last minute, reworking portions of it as he prepared for the 8 p.m. speech, which was broadcast by all major networks.
Aides said the president kept the speech short because he believed he had already made a detailed case of what he had accomplished in office. 
Still, Mr. Clinton did not miss the opportunity to rattle off the statistics of progress that are now a part of his memory -- the number of new jobs, students receiving financial aid, new homes built.
"In all the work I have done as president, every decision I have made, every executive action I have taken, every bill I have proposed and signed, I've tried to give all Americans the tools and conditions to build the future of our dreams, in a good society, with a strong economy, a cleaner environment, and a freer, safer, more prosperous world," he said.
Then, Mr. Clinton signaled that even once he departed Washington on Saturday, ceding the executive mansion to Mr. Bush, he would not really be going away.
"My days in this office are nearly through," he said, "but my days of service I hope are not. In the years ahead I will never hold a position higher or a covenant more sacred than that of president of the United States. But there is no title I will wear more proudly than that of citizen."
With that, Mr. Clinton pumped his fist in the air.

HEADLINE: Mr. Clinton's Farewell 

 BODY:
With a proud defense of his record and a stern warning against disengagement from the world's problems, President Clinton bade farewell to the nation from the Oval Office last night and graciously offered best wishes to President-elect George W. Bush. The crisp seven-minute televised speech predictably omitted any reference to the ethical lapses that will always shadow Mr. Clinton's reputation. Instead he made a final bid to be remembered as a man of accomplishment and offered polite but pointed advice to his successor. The speech also marked a final nostalgic turn in the president's long goodbye tour of the places that figured in his extraordinary journey to the White House in 1992. 
 The tradition of a presidential farewell speech began with George Washington in 1796. In a subtle nod to history, Mr. Clinton's alluded to Thomas Jefferson's warning against "entangling alliances" by asserting that the United States could not now "disentangle itself from the world." It was an apt formulation from a president who expanded free trade, intervened to prevent economic collapse in Mexico and Asia and strove to combat disease, ethnic cleansing and regional warfare in the Balkans, the Middle East and Africa. The comment also seemed aimed at concerns that President-elect Bush could reduce American involvement abroad. 
 It was said yesterday that Mr. Clinton was working with his aides in sometimes frantic fashion to put together his farewell address -- and that he loved every minute of it. With Mr. Bush clearly on his mind, he urged a continued emphasis on fiscal responsibility and paying down the federal debt. It was an obvious final warning against the large tax cuts that Mr. Bush has said he still wants. Mr. Clinton's comment that engagement in the world requires "more than compassion -- it requires action" seemed to be addressed to Mr. Bush's theme of compassionate conservatism. In all, his speech was a repetition of the idea that harnessing free enterprise and having an activist government can go hand in hand.
Mr. Clinton leaves office with extraordinarily high approval ratings, a sign perhaps that Americans are willing to hear the wisdom of departing leaders. The president used the occasion to try to inculcate the idea that he had presided over a prosperous era and left the country in excellent shape. As in so many earlier speeches, he spoke of "putting people first" while also preparing the economy and its workers for the 21st century. 
In less than two days, Mr. Clinton will become the first president in history to be succeeded in office by the son of the man he defeated in the first place. In spite of the disappointments and costly personal lapses of his presidency, Mr. Clinton said goodbye last night in the spirit in which many Americans can remember him, one of facing up to a world in turmoil and striving to ease hatreds abroad and at home.
