HEADLINE: TRANSITION IN WASHINGTON: THE PARTY POSITIONS; 
At Hearings, Cracks Appear in Bush's Party Line

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 

 BODY:
After a campaign in which George W. Bush demanded absolute loyalty from his staff and kept internal debates out of public view, some of his cabinet choices have inched away from the party line in their confirmation hearings. 
 In doing so, they illustrate the challenge to the new administration of maintaining a seamless front under the pressure of governing. 
 On three of the biggest issues facing Congress and the new administration -- education, tax cuts and helping the elderly pay for prescription drugs -- members of the president-elect's team spoke this week in terms that were different in nuanced ways from those used by Mr. Bush in the campaign and its immediate aftermath. 
Mr. Bush's choice for attorney general, John Ashcroft, also seems to have staked out a slightly different position from the president-elect on an element of the highly charged debate over abortion. 
On Thursday, a day after Mr. Ashcroft told the Senate Judiciary Committee that he would not seek opportunities to challenge Roe v. Wade, the Supreme Court's landmark ruling on abortion rights, Mr. Bush said in an interview with Fox News that he would not rule out having his Justice Department argue for a change in the law.
Further muddling the incoming administration's position, Laura Bush, the president-elect's wife, told NBC News in an interview broadcast today that she did not think the Supreme Court decision should be overturned.
To some degree, the differences on such high-profile issues are not surprising given the array of pressure from interest groups and the complexity of trying to move an agenda through a Congress that is almost evenly divided between the two parties. In that sense, his new team might have been reflecting a calculated decision to shade or back off campaign promises in order to increase the odds of winning legislative victories or quick confirmation of cabinet choices.
It is also possible that the relative independence of Mr. Bush's cabinet choices reflected his decision to hire well-known men and women with established reputations and considerable executive experience, and to grant them authority and responsibility to carry out his plans.
But there is also the risk that a team of strong-willed, independent executives will stray, perhaps inadvertently, from the new president's thinking, creating the impression if not the reality of internal disagreement or even disarray.
In Mr. Bush's case, the transition from a tightly managed campaign, and an administration as governor of Texas that could proceed at a relatively leisurely pace, to the maelstrom and intense scrutiny of presidential politics, could be particularly abrupt. Like any new administration, this one will have to adapt to the reality that every utterance from anyone in a position of influence will be amplified and parsed for political meaning.
"That's one of the toughest challenges that any new president faces," said Leon E. Panetta, a former chief of staff to President Clinton. "The transition from what is usually a very tightly run campaign in which the candidate alone makes the news, to an administration of literally thousands of political appointees, each of whom in their own way suddenly realizes the power they have to make news, can be difficult."
None of Mr. Bush's cabinet choices has broken with him in any substantial way. All have loyally and enthusiastically endorsed his basic goals and philosophy. 
But in a town where the slightest shift in political tone and changes in the smallest detail can make news or break legislation, the secretaries-in-waiting seemed to have voices and thoughts of their own at their confirmation hearings.
Roderick R. Paige, Mr. Bush's choice to be secretary of education, put some daylight between himself and the president-elect's stated goal of giving parents of students in some failing public school districts vouchers to subsidize private school tuition. 
Asked about vouchers last week by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, Mr. Paige replied, "Not a priority, Senator," a response that amounted to waving a white flag on the initiative even before it was formally proposed.
Paul H. O'Neill, the prospective treasury secretary, gave a subtly but distinctly different rationale for tax cuts than the one used by Mr. Bush for the last month. Mr. Bush has been saying that tax cuts would be a critical antidote to a crumbling economy, but Mr. O'Neill said the real justification is that the federal government is running a surplus and it would be prudent to return it to the public in the form of tax cuts.
"I would not make a huge case that this is the instrument to ensure that we don't go into recession," Mr. O'Neill told the Senate Finance Committee.
Tommy G. Thompson, who is Mr. Bush's selection to head the Department of Health and Human Services, signaled that he might not push hard for one of the president-elect's main campaign promises, to provide states with an immediate infusion of $12 billion a year in federal financing to help them provide prescription drug coverage for the poorest of their elderly citizens. 
Faced with skepticism about the proposal from members of both parties, Mr. Thompson said that if Congress could quickly come up with a comprehensive plan to provide drug coverage to all Medicare beneficiaries, that would be good enough.
"Whatever can move the fastest, this administration will be very happy about," said Mr. Thompson, the governor of Wisconsin.
Mr. Bush's aides have said there are no differences in thinking or approach between the president-elect and his appointees. 
Ari Fleischer, Mr. Bush's spokesman, said today that Mr. Ashcroft's statements about not seeking to overturn the Supreme Court decision had to do with his commitment to enforcing the law as it now exists. Mr. Fleischer did not close off the possibility that Mr. Bush might someday seek to overturn the decision, but he said that for now Mr. Bush would concentrate on making abortions more rare.
He declined to comment on Mrs. Bush's remarks.
Asked about the administration's commitment to vouchers as part of its education proposals, Mr. Fleischer said Mr. Bush would stick to his plan as set out during the campaign. On tax cuts, Mr. Fleischer said this week that there was no rift between Mr. Bush and Mr. O'Neill.

HEADLINE: TRANSITION IN WASHINGTON: PUBLIC SENTIMENT; 
A Nation's Voices: Concern and Solace, Resentment and Redemption

BYLINE:  By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 19 

 BODY:
Clearly the Blind Faith Cafe was not named with today's political climate in mind.
 On the eve of the inauguration of a president who won office after one of the most contentious and divisive elections in memory, a more apt name for a vegetarian restaurant in the Democratic-majority suburban town of Evanston, Ill., might be the Who-Do-You-Think-You're-Kidding Cafe. 
 "We'll have an inauguration that a lot of people are not excited about, and it's just like it's a cartoon," said Joanna Baker, a 39-year-old executive search consultant and yoga enthusiast, who was eating a barbecued seitan salad and worrying what a Bush presidency would mean for abortion rights and other issues she cares about. "It's like it's not really real."
At the next table, another Democrat, Dr. Ken Moses, a 58-year-old psychologist, gave a wry grin while describing how he was adjusting to the White House transition. 
"I happen to be a therapist that deals with nothing but profound losses," Dr. Moses said. "The issue of disappointment and how to deal with it is my trade."
Here in the Chicago area, and across the country in Miami, Denver and Boston, there is a sense that the nation has been through an extraordinary upheaval, and many people have been left a little stunned. 
Among supporters of Vice President Al Gore, there is resentment and disappointment. Among some of those who voted for George W. Bush, there is concern about whether he will be able to accomplish much, given a Congress so evenly divided and a mandate that is at most tenuous in the wake of his inability to win the popular vote.
And among people of both parties, there is a feeling that the electoral system needs to be fixed. 
Still, in interviews with dozens of people, no one seemed to feel that the nation was ill equipped to handle all that had happened.
Many Gore supporters said they had become resigned to a Bush presidency. Some said they took solace from their expectation that Congress would keep Mr. Bush from enacting what they viewed as his most extreme proposals, like a $1.6 trillion tax cut and school vouchers. Some also said they were impressed, by and large, with his cabinet choices, although most were strongly opposed to his selection of John Ashcroft for attorney general.
And many seemed to have adopted an attitude that in the end, Washington is Washington: the apparatus of government is still in place, skilled politicians and career civil servants still keep things running, and ultimately nothing apocalyptic is likely to happen. Dr. Moses, for example, said that he felt "embarrassed for the country" but that "I really do trust the system."
"There are enough people in Congress and in the government," he said, "that the system will work, and life will go on."
Joseph Flaherty, a 59-year-old former actor in Boston, exemplified the way some Democrats felt. 
"For the first time really in my adult life, I became alarmed at the man about to become president," Mr. Flaherty said at the South Station train terminal. "I fear that in my lifetime he is the single most unqualified person for the job."
But Mr. Flaherty said he had become "a little more reassured, simply because he has apparently been well advised, and he is keeping a relatively low profile, and he is trying to establish himself as a very cool, moderate person."
Further, Mr. Flaherty said, the country has an obligation to unite behind Mr. Bush.
"We cannot play the masochist simply because we do not like the person in the Oval Office," he said.
Perhaps what has helped some Democrats come to terms with the outcome of the election is that many were not passionate about Mr. Gore; they thought both candidates were opportunistic and self-interested. 
"There was an air that Bush was pulling every string," Ms. Baker said, "but I know that the Democrats were pulling every string they had, too. Their strings just weren't connected to the right places."
One staunch Gore supporter, Lloyd Athearn, an administrator for a nonprofit organization in Golden, Colo., said: "I think Bush stole the election fair and square. No one really won, which means the public punted."
Mr. Athearn and other Democrats interviewed did not seem disillusioned by a Supreme Court whose 5-to-4 decision gave Mr. Bush victory. But he said changes in the voting system were essential, starting with money for more modern equipment. 
Even supporters of Mr. Bush wondered how effective he would be. 
"I think it's going to be very hard for him to patch things up with the American people," said Mario Leteri, a Republican businessman in Miami. "For one thing, the Democrats are going to be on his back the whole time, and I'm sure will make his life miserable. He has definitely tried hard. He had a Democrat introduce him in his acceptance speech, and that shows how hard he's trying. Will it work in the long run? Probably not."
Vicki Ohoson, an independent in Denver who said she had voted for Mr. Bush, expressed concern "for the people that didn't vote for him, the people that still aren't happy."
"There's a lot of heat," Ms. Ohoson said. "We've got a country that's really divided, a national split. I think it's going to take some really special events and gestures to jump that chasm."
Another Bush supporter, 90-year-old Jeanette Peterson, who was shopping at an Evanston bookstore, said: "I think after the president goes in, there will be a lot of talk for months about the way the voting was handled. Different groups will mobilize. He's going to have a tough time."
Andy Oh, a graduate student at Northwestern University's business school, said expectations for Mr. Bush were "very low," because "he didn't get a mandate."
Mr. Oh, who approved of Mr. Bush's economic proposals but liked Mr. Gore on social issues, said he would advise Mr. Bush to first try to appropriate money for fixing the electoral system. Then, he said, if Mr. Bush can compromise by reducing the size of his tax-cut proposal, he can get a tax bill passed, and "that would go a long way to make me feel better about the situation."
As for the Democrats, he said, they "have to be careful not to go to an extreme and purposely try to make Bush look bad."
Among Gore supporters, African-Americans, many particularly suspicious of the Florida voting, tended to be feeling the greatest anger.
"I am extremely frustrated," said Theresa Thornton-Young, an employee of the Miami-Dade County school board. "The only way Bush can heal us is for him to get out of office and give it to Gore. I do not accept him."
But another black Gore supporter, Jamela Larson, a real estate agent in Miami, said: "At first it was a little tough to accept that George W. had sort of imposed himself, but with time I have gotten used to the idea. In a way, I feel bad for George W. The pressure is definitely on him. Honestly, now that I've had some time to digest all this election thing, I am kind of glad that Gore didn't win, because that would have meant that the pressure would have been on for him as well."
Ms. Larson was not the only Gore backer trying to find a silver lining. Ms. Baker said she thought that Democrats would be able "to raise a lot of money, just like the Republicans did during Whitewater," and as a result could regain control of at least one house of Congress in 2002.
She said she was "nervous about Bush's Supreme Court appointments, but people get on the bench and sometimes they don't act in ways that people who appoint them expect them to." 
And, perhaps grasping at straws, she suggested that a conservative current in the country might precipitate a cultural rebellion among artists and writers. 
"Someone said to me one advantage to this is that art might get more subversive because that's what happens when conservatives are in power," Ms. Baker said. "And that could be good."
Whatever the perspective, Democrat or Republican, the news today that the independent counsel had decided against prosecuting President Clinton, in exchange for Mr. Clinton's admission that he had made false statements in the Paula Jones case and his agreement to a five-year suspension of his license to practice law, seemed welcome. 
"We don't need to reward or rehash or reprimand -- we just need to end it," said Mike Shorten, a Republican sales representative having lunch in downtown Chicago.
Gail Hays, on a cigarette break outside her Chicago office, said of the agreement: "I think the whole country is winning with this. It's not a question of the Democrats or Republicans. We're all moving on."

HEADLINE: TRANSITION IN WASHINGTON: OVERSEAS -- RUSSIA; 
No Honeymoon Likely for New President's Foreign Policy Team

BYLINE:  By Patrick E. Tyler 

 BODY:
Every president takes office believing he can set the foreign policy agenda for his administration, only to discover that a major portion of that agenda has already been set by the world.
 The crises of the world do not take a time-out for a new American leader. President Clinton arrived hoping to focus on domestic issues, but was immediately faced by crises in places like Somalia, Haiti and Taiwan, along with hardy perennials like Russia and the Middle East. 
 President-elect George W. Bush was confronted by the killing of the president of Congo this week, and might see the election of a hawkish prime minister in Israel and the crumbling of the peace accord in Northern Ireland in his first month in office. Further down the line, Mr. Bush's enthusiasm for a missile-defense system is certain to generate fierce opposition in Europe and in Russia.
Much has been said, too, about Mr. Bush's inheriting the problem of Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi strongman against whom his father went to war, but whom he left in power. In recent years, Washington's focus has been on simply keeping sanctions against Iraq in force over growing opposition, especially from Russia and France.
In Asia, the first big decision, due in April, will be whether to sell destroyers, advanced weapons and radar systems to Taiwan -- a decision that could prompt China to respond by accelerating its own military buildup.
Beyond that a host of other challenges, large and small, will vie quickly for American attention. What follows is a tour of those likely to prove most urgent.
If Mr. Bush makes good on his pledge to unfurl a missile-defense umbrella over the United States, Washington and Moscow would be entering an era of profound disagreement about how to maintain global security against the use of nuclear weapons, even as they continue to work to reduce their number.
The prospect of missile defense threatens to drag the onetime superpower rivals, as well as China, India and Pakistan, into a new arms race, many experts say. Russia and China are alarmed that a new American "shield" might undermine deterrence -- that concept of strategic stability that comes from knowing that the terrible cost of using nuclear weapons is the certainty of retaliation.
Last year, Russia demonstrated that it intended to pursue an active foreign policy in Europe and Asia to defend what President Vladimir V. Putin sees as Russian national interests, whether the issue is missile defense or a desire to thwart the eastward expansion of NATO to the Baltic states in the north and to Georgia to Russia's south.
Mr. Putin insists he is not looking for a confrontation with the United States -- in fact, the opposite. Moscow, he says, will seek cooperation within a relationship where differences of opinion can be aired openly and frankly.
But those differences are sharp: Moscow is building a nuclear power plant in Iran and will now sell weapons to Iran's army. Russia and France have been courting Iraq, once a major market for each, and oppose continued sanctions against Baghdad.
Mr. Putin, a pragmatist thus far, realizes he needs assistance from Mr. Bush to strengthen the Russian economy. He will look to the United States and Europe for support in restructuring foreign debt, attracting investment and gradually integrating Russia into western institutions, including the World Trade Organization. For that, he needs a calm Western front. Patrick E. Tyler

HEADLINE: TRANSITION IN WASHINGTON: OVERSEAS -- THE BALKANS; 
No Honeymoon Likely for New President's Foreign Policy Team

BYLINE:  By Steven Erlanger

 BODY:
Every president takes office believing he can set the foreign policy agenda for his administration, only to discover that a major portion of that agenda has already been set by the world.
 The crises of the world do not take a time-out for a new American leader. President Clinton arrived hoping to focus on domestic issues, but was immediately faced by crises in places like Somalia, Haiti and Taiwan, along with hardy perennials like Russia and the Middle East. 
 President-elect George W. Bush was confronted by the killing of the president of Congo this week, and might see the election of a hawkish prime minister in Israel and the crumbling of the peace accord in Northern Ireland in his first month in office. Further down the line, Mr. Bush's enthusiasm for a missile-defense system is certain to generate fierce opposition in Europe and in Russia. 
Much has been said, too, about Mr. Bush's inheriting the problem of Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi strongman against whom his father went to war, but whom he left in power. In recent years, Washington's focus has been on simply keeping sanctions against Iraq in force over growing opposition, especially from Russia and France.
In Asia, the first big decision, due in April, will be whether to sell destroyers, advanced weapons and radar systems to Taiwan -- a decision that could prompt China to respond by accelerating its own military buildup.
Beyond that a host of other challenges, large and small, will vie quickly for American attention. What follows is a tour of those likely to prove most urgent.
Even with Slobodan Milosevic deposed, the Balkans are not going away. Mr. Bush has said he would "very much like to get our troops out" of the Balkans, where more than 9,000 American soldiers are stationed in Bosnia and Kosovo. But the Europeans and the Kosovar Albanians will oppose that.
The 1995 Dayton agreement was an American-imposed peace and Bosnia and Herzegovina is an American-designed country. Five years later, the peace is holding, but the country is badly riven by ethnic nationalism. Will a Bush administration redesign Bosnia and the Dayton accord if it intends to withdraw troops?
Kosovo, still formally a province of Serbia, is now administered by the United Nations and patrolled by NATO-led troops. With Mr. Milosevic gone, the push for independence, which is what most ethnic Albanians want, is becoming a dream deferred.
Kosovo is becoming more explosive, with new attacks on Serbs by the supposedly disbanded Kosovo Liberation Army outside of Kosovo but under the eyes of American peacekeeping troops.
The new democratic government in Belgrade wants to retaliate, and Kosovars trust Washington to protect them. Will a Bush administration confront the ethnic Albanians, let alone the looming and unanswered question of Kosovo's final status?
President Vojislav Kostunica of Yugoslavia is trying hard to hold on to Montenegro, Serbia's last partner in what remains of the Yugoslav Federation. Montenegro's president, Milo Djukanovic, is pressing for independence, and has scheduled a referendum on the matter this summer.
Will a Bush administration oppose Montenegrin independence and give the help Mr. Kostunica he thinks he needs, risking some Republican wrath, especially in the Senate? If Montenegro becomes independent, what answer will Mr. Bush give to Kosovo's Albanians? Or to the Bosnian Serbs, who want independence for their part of Bosnia and Herzegovina?
How hard should a new president push Mr. Kostunica to hand over Mr. Milosevic to the international tribunal on war crimes? American aid to Serbia, aimed at consolidating the anti-Milosevic victory there, will be cut off on April 1 unless Mr. Bush can certify to Congress that the new government is cooperating with the tribunal. That may mean that Belgrade must arrest some suspected war criminals.
Mr. Bush will have to consider how much pressure to place on the government when popular unhappiness with a bad economy, power shortages and a restive Montenegro is reaching its peak. Steven Erlanger

HEADLINE: TRANSITION IN WASHINGTON: OVERSEAS -- IRAQ; 
No Honeymoon Likely for New President's Foreign Policy Team

BYLINE:  By Neil MacFarquhar

 BODY:
Every president takes office believing he can set the foreign policy agenda for his administration, only to discover that a major portion of that agenda has already been set by the world.
 The crises of the world do not take a time-out for a new American leader. President Clinton arrived hoping to focus on domestic issues, but was immediately faced by crises in places like Somalia, Haiti and Taiwan, along with hardy perennials like Russia and the Middle East. 
 President-elect George W. Bush was confronted by the killing of the president of Congo this week, and might see the election of a hawkish prime minister in Israel and the crumbling of the peace accord in Northern Ireland in his first month in office. Further down the line, Mr. Bush's enthusiasm for a missile-defense system is certain to generate fierce opposition in Europe and in Russia.
Much has been said, too, about Mr. Bush's inheriting the problem of Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi strongman against whom his father went to war, but whom he left in power. In recent years, Washington's focus has been on simply keeping sanctions against Iraq in force over growing opposition, especially from Russia and France.
In Asia, the first big decision, due in April, will be whether to sell destroyers, advanced weapons and radar systems to Taiwan -- a decision that could prompt China to respond by accelerating its own military buildup.
Beyond that a host of other challenges, large and small, will vie quickly for American attention. What follows is a tour of those likely to prove most urgent.
"Bush Is Criminal," says a floor mosaic at the front entrance of the once gleaming Rashid Hotel in downtown Baghdad, and the portrait in stone depicts a rather sinister Bush senior. The artwork harks back to the 1991 Gulf War, when the first President Bush advocated toppling Saddam Hussein. The sentiments have not changed much on either side, nor, with the new administration, have the personnel.
The Arab press refers to the new president almost universally as "Bush, al-ibn," or Bush, the son, and an unbowed Saddam Hussein is expected to quickly test the new president to free Iraq of the fetters in place since his father was president. Mr. Hussein's target would be the measures the United States has pushed to hobble his regime: economic sanctions, military overflights and limits on armaments.
Just as likely, Iraq will probably continue testing missiles and continue to welcome flights at its refurbished Baghdad airport -- some in defiance of the blockade. It will also continue to refuse to admit any United Nations weapons inspectors.
International support for the sanctions will be ever harder to muster. Even France and Russia, who American officials say favor keeping some control over Iraq's checkbook, favor easing the United Nations policy of reviewing whatever Baghdad buys with its oil money.
Middle Eastern governments will be reluctant to support tougher sanctions given the growing anti-American sentiment among Arabs due to Washington's support for Israel. Doing something to alleviate suffering in Iraq has become a popular means of defying the United States. Neil MacFarquhar

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home; 
Ave Atque Vale

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON 

 BODY:
This country has made greater gains in the eight years of Bill Clinton's presidency than in any comparable period in memory. Personal income is way up, unemployment startlingly low. Decades of federal budget deficits have turned into huge surpluses. 
 Not just economic but social indicators have improved. Crime is sharply down, as is the rate of teenage pregnancy. On the Wall Street Journal editorial page the other day Francis Fukuyama wrote: "The relentless cultural decline that at the beginning of the 1990's seemed like a fact of nature ground to a halt and, miraculously, reversed direction while Bill Clinton was president." 
 None of this has moved the Clinton-haters. George F. Will, the conservative columnist, wrote of Mr. Clinton last week: "Other than by soiling the office, he was a remarkably inconsequential president, like a person who walks across a field of snow and leaves no footprints." 
Neither facts nor logic can move the true haters. Mr. Will, for example, attributed the budget surplus in part to a Republican Congress and said Mr. Clinton's policies "did not interfere with the private wealth creation" that made it possible. 
The fact is that President Clinton had to drive his budget-balancing measures through Congress over solid Republican opposition, spending great early political capital to do so. Republicans had talked for years but had done nothing. He did it. The low interest rates that were then possible opened the way to the longest economic boom in our history. 
Mr. Clinton is criticized, right and left, for borrowing the Republicans' clothes on the budget and other matters. Another way to look at that is to say that he recognized the need for change in Democratic Party policies that were mired in the past. 
There is much to criticize in Mr. Clinton's record as president. When he denied to the American people that he had had sexual relations with Monica Lewinsky, I wrote that he would and should be judged by the people if the denial was false. He was so judged, and for some Americans that episode will always put him beyond the pale. 
Far-right zealots backed Paula Jones's dubious lawsuit against him, and brought Linda Tripp and her tapes to the independent counsel Kenneth Starr. But their nastiness could not excuse Mr. Clinton's lying under oath, as in his plea agreement with Mr. Starr's successor, Robert Ray, he has now admitted he did. 
In policy terms, I think his great failure as president was on civil liberties. He signed the cruel Immigration Act of 1996 into law without a murmur of protest. He allowed the destruction of federal habeas corpus, rejecting a compromise that would have saved its essential role as protector of constitutional rights. He carried on the drug war as its futile savagery became more and more obvious.
On those issues I thought he lacked a commitment to justice -- or was prepared to barter it away for the political advantage of countering right-wing charges that Democrats are soft on crime. But on other issues he was courageous. 
It took great courage to bring the Irish Republican Army into the political process in Northern Ireland, and he got closer than anyone has to settling that conflict. The Middle East peace process is in ruins now; but if there ever is peace, it will be along the lines Mr. Clinton courageously laid out. After a halting start in Bosnia, he brought Slobodan Milosevic's war crimes to an end there and in Kosovo -- despite hangdog Republican opposition. 
For someone in the White House he was extraordinarily human -- "an Oprah guest," Michiko Kakutani wrote in The New York Times, "who feels our pain because he struggles like the rest of us with his weight, his marriage and his golf game." Some of his critics were disgusted by that quality. They wanted a more distant president, one they could revere. Well, Harry Truman is generally admired now, and he was not on any pedestal. 
With all his flaws, Bill Clinton as president was a bigger man, a more generous man, than those who hated him. Maybe that played a part in their dislike: their recognition that he was more intelligent, more vital, more interesting than they could ever be. A reader of mine, George Bayliss, said it was "sheer animal jealousy." 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: TRANSITION IN WASHINGTON; 
Statements of Clinton and Prosecutor and Excerpts From News Conference

 BODY:
Following are statements on the agreement reached by President Clinton and the independent counsel Robert W. Ray, and excerpts from a news conference held in Washington yesterday by Jake Siewert, a spokesman for the president, all as recorded by Federal News Service Inc.:

Mr. Clinton
 Today I signed a consent order in the lawsuit brought by the Arkansas Committee on Professional Conduct, which brings to an end that proceeding. I have accepted a five-year suspension of my law license, agreed to pay a $25,000 fine to cover counsel fees and acknowledged a violation of one of the Arkansas model rules of professional conduct because of testimony in my Paula Jones case deposition. The disbarment suit will now be dismissed. 
 I have taken every step I can to end this matter. I have already settled the Paula Jones case, even after it was dismissed as being completely without legal and factual merit. I have also paid court and counsel fees in restitution and been held in civil contempt for my deposition testimony regarding Ms. Lewinsky -- which Judge Wright agreed had no bearing on Ms. Jones's case -- even though I disagreed with the findings in the judge's order.
I will not seek any legal fees incurred as a result of the Lewinsky investigation, to which I might otherwise become entitled under the Independent Counsel Act. 
I have had occasion frequently to reflect on the Jones case. In this consent order, I acknowledge having knowingly violated Judge Wright's discovery orders in my deposition in that case. I tried to walk a fine line between acting lawfully and testifying falsely, but I now recognize that I did not fully accomplish this goal and that certain of my responses to questions about Ms. Lewinsky were false.
I have apologized for my conduct, and I have done my best to atone for it with my family, my administration and the American people. I have paid a high price for it, which I accept, because it caused so much pain to so many people. I hope my actions today will help bring closure and finality to these matters.

Mr. Ray
Fifteen months ago I promised the American people that I would complete this investigation promptly and responsibly. Today I fulfill that promise. 
President Clinton has acknowledged responsibility for his actions. He has admitted that he knowingly gave evasive and misleading answers to questions in the Jones deposition and that his conduct was prejudicial to the administration of justice. He has acknowledged that some of his answers were false. He has agreed to a five-year suspension of his Arkansas Bar license, and he has agreed not to seek attorneys' fees in connection with this matter.
The nation's interests have been served, and therefore I decline prosecution. In doing so, I have tried to heed Justice Robert Jackson's wisdom: "The citizens' safety lies in the prosecutor who tempers zeal with human kindness, who seeks truth and not victims, who serves the law and not factional purposes, and who approaches his task with humility." 
I trust that the decision made today meets the expectations of the American people, who deserve a resolution that acknowledges the president's conduct, respects America's institutions and demonstrates sensitivity to our constitutional system of government. This matter is now concluded. May history and the American people judge that it has been concluded justly.

Questions and Answers
Q . How long have they been in negotiations on both cases? And when did he sign the order? Was that signed today? And what is his mood now? I mean, he's leaving with humiliation.

MR. SIEWERT -- The president's lawyers have been involved over the past several weeks in a discussion with both parties. Obviously, they've been in discussions with the Office of the Independent Counsel for a long time, along with the parties in Arkansas. But the case was brought to a close in the last couple of weeks, and the actual exchange of letters happened this morning.
The president -- I think you saw him last night, and he knew full well then what was happening today. The president is upbeat about his future, looking forward to putting this behind him and returning to life in New York and resuming his duties as a citizen of the United States. . . .

Q. Jake, was this deal contingent on him making this statement while he still held the office of president of the United States?
And why couldn't he have done this next week?

A. The timing was something that was agreed to between the president's lawyers and the Office of the Independent Counsel and the parties involved in Arkansas. But that was an agreement that I can't detail for you.

Q. Does the president feel this deal is fair? Does he feel he was pushed into acknowledging wrongdoing and that this is still kind of unfair?

A. Well, I think the president felt like the punishment in the disbarment case went well beyond what was ordinary in these cases, but he wanted to put it behind him, and he wanted to bring that chapter to a close. . . .

Q. How does the president feel about all of this coming down on his last day in office, a day that's normally a very special day for a president?

A. The president is looking forward to returning to life as a private citizen. He's had a great eight years. In many ways, there have been some difficult times, but he's putting this behind him now. And his record of economic achievement, of bringing leadership on issues of peace and prosperity to the United States, are unchallenged at this point. And he talked about that very directly last night in his farewell address.

Q. Doesn't that somehow stain the last day, though?

A. You can all make that judgment for yourselves. The president has acknowledged making a personal mistake, one that he regrets. . . .

Q. How will the president feel if the people of this country will look him in history as a liar who, during the indictment, was thinking that he was talking about the truth, but now he's telling in different words, "I was lying?"

A. I think it's very important to put this in perspective. The president has acknowledged many times that this was a very painful personal episode in his own life. When he gave that deposition, he was trying to be truthful, but he did not want to talk about the relationship that at that point had been over for an entire year. So he did his best to try to tell the truth but without being particularly helpful to people who were trying, frankly, to embarrass the president in a quest for information that was not particularly relevant and was in no way material to that case.
So the president has said before that that was a painful episode, he has apologized for misleading people about what happened there, but he wants to put this behind him. And he wants people to remember that every day that he was here, that he was working hard on the issues that mattered to them, and that's the reason why they elected and re-elected him.

Q. So Jake, how do you separate these two things: that he says that he knowingly violated the judge's order, but he didn't knowingly give misleading and false answers?

A. Obviously, these are documents written by lawyers and that were negotiated in a very particular way. And I think I'd probably refer you to Mr. Kendall as we get into the more arcane notions of this.

Q. No, but the bottom line ----

A. The bottom line is that looking back now, the president can see where his testimony was false.

Q. But he is not saying that he knowingly gave false testimony?

A. That's right.

HEADLINE: TRANSITION IN WASHINGTON: OVERSEAS -- JAPAN; 
No Honeymoon Likely for New President's Foreign Policy Team

BYLINE:  By Howard W. French

 BODY:
Every president takes office believing he can set the foreign policy agenda for his administration, only to discover that a major portion of that agenda has already been set by the world.
 The crises of the world do not take a time-out for a new American leader. President Clinton arrived hoping to focus on domestic issues, but was immediately faced by crises in places like Somalia, Haiti and Taiwan, along with hardy perennials like Russia and the Middle East. 
 President-elect George W. Bush was confronted by the killing of the president of Congo this week, and might see the election of a hawkish prime minister in Israel and the crumbling of the peace accord in Northern Ireland in his first month in office. Further down the line, Mr. Bush's enthusiasm for a missile-defense system is certain to generate fierce opposition in Europe and in Russia.
Much has been said, too, about Mr. Bush's inheriting the problem of Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi strongman against whom his father went to war, but whom he left in power. In recent years, Washington's focus has been on simply keeping sanctions against Iraq in force over growing opposition, especially from Russia and France.
In Asia, the first big decision, due in April, will be whether to sell destroyers, advanced weapons and radar systems to Taiwan -- a decision that could prompt China to respond by accelerating its own military buildup.
Beyond that a host of other challenges, large and small, will vie quickly for American attention. What follows is a tour of those likely to prove most urgent.
In his campaign, Mr. Bush raised the prospect of strongly reinforced ties with Japan, and if most Americans missed this message, Japanese leaders received it loud and clear. The Japanese are anxious to discuss a variety of fronts, from security matters to North Korea and the economy.
One major question involves the presence in Japan of 47,000 American troops, which are mostly concentrated in the southern province of Okinawa, where they have long drawn strong local opposition.
Foreign policy advisers to Mr. Bush have said that Washington should reduce its military presence there. But military planners say a reduction of the troops in Okinawa would require Washington to upgrade its presence somewhere else. At present Guam, a United States protectorate in the Western Pacific, is cited as the most likely candidate.
In economic matters, Japan, which has the world's second largest economy, remains stuck in a slow growth mode, barely above recession. The slowdown in the United States threatens Japan's nascent recovery, and the two governments will have to coordinate policies to prevent a global recession.
Japan's economic weakness, coinciding with the American slowdown, confronts the Bush team with a dilemma. On one hand, some of Mr. Bush's economic advisers have already strongly criticized the Clinton administration's longstanding advice to Japan to maintain its heavy deficit spending until growth is restored.
On the other hand, Washington will badly want Japan to help pick up some of the slack in global consumption due to the downturn in the United States. Howard W. French

HEADLINE: TRANSITION IN WASHINGTON: OVERSEAS -- AFRICA; 
No Honeymoon Likely for New President's Foreign Policy Team

BYLINE:  By Norimitsu Onishi

 BODY:
Every president takes office believing he can set the foreign policy agenda for his administration, only to discover that a major portion of that agenda has already been set by the world.
 The crises of the world do not take a time-out for a new American leader. President Clinton arrived hoping to focus on domestic issues, but was immediately faced by crises in places like Somalia, Haiti and Taiwan, along with hardy perennials like Russia and the Middle East. 
 President-elect George W. Bush was confronted by the killing of the president of Congo this week, and might see the election of a hawkish prime minister in Israel and the crumbling of the peace accord in Northern Ireland in his first month in office. Further down the line, Mr. Bush's enthusiasm for a missile-defense system is certain to generate fierce opposition in Europe and in Russia.
Much has been said, too, about Mr. Bush's inheriting the problem of Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi strongman against whom his father went to war, but whom he left in power. In recent years, Washington's focus has been on simply keeping sanctions against Iraq in force over growing opposition, especially from Russia and France.
In Asia, the first big decision, due in April, will be whether to sell destroyers, advanced weapons and radar systems to Taiwan -- a decision that could prompt China to respond by accelerating its own military buildup.
Beyond that a host of other challenges, large and small, will vie quickly for American attention. What follows is a tour of those likely to prove most urgent.
General Powell's meetings with Africa analysts at the State Department this month did not register a reaction in Africa, where officials do not expect much of a change between the outgoing president and the new one.
Aside from the uncertainty in Congo, what relatively little attention Africa gets from the White House will be focused mostly on those nations considered important economically to the United States, the largest being Nigeria and South Africa. These countries, which suffer from various degrees of instability, also derive their importance from their critical role in tackling African problems that the West cannot ignore, including peacekeeping and AIDS. South Africa, the continent's economic giant, lurches forward, weakened by social problems, including an out-of-control AIDS rate.
Nigeria remains important because it is the biggest oil producer on a continent that is expected to supply more and more of the crude needed by the United States. And Nigeria and South Africa are the only nations with militaries capable of assuming the role of regional police force.
Like Mr. Clinton, the new president will not want to send American soldiers to Africa, preferring to train soldiers in Nigeria as peacekeepers for places like Sierra Leone. Angola, the continent's second biggest oil producer, remains devastated by its long-running civil war, with Washington now on the side of the government. Adopting a comprehensive policy toward Angola, as well as smaller oil producers like Congo Republic and Equatorial Guinea, might be a tantalizing possibility for the oilman in Mr. Bush. Norimitsu Onishi

HEADLINE: Bull Run 

BYLINE:  By David Warsh; David Warsh is the economics columnist for The Boston Globe.

 BODY:
 ON MONEY AND MARKETS
A Wall Street Memoir.
By Henry Kaufman.
388 pp. New York:
McGraw-Hill Publishing Company. $24.95.
 Henry Kaufman earned the sobriquet "Dr. Doom" during the turbulent 1970's, when he was the chief economist for the investment banking firm of Salomon Brothers. His frequent criticisms of government policies were right on target. So when, on the Tuesday morning of Aug. 17, 1982, Kaufman predicted the market had bottomed out, the effect was electrifying. The huge rally that day in both stocks and bonds was the beginning of what proved to be the longest bull market in history.
It was also more or less the last time anyone beyond the markets heard of Henry Kaufman. A power struggle at Salomon led to his resignation in 1988. He remained a respected commentator on markets throughout the 1990's, and he formed a small hedge fund with a partner in 1997, just in time to lose a bundle in the Asian financial crisis before cashing out last year. Without spectacular returns to brag about, or the big institutional setting he previously had enjoyed, Kaufman was no longer the kind of person whose pronouncements were trumpeted by the news media. He became instead a generous philanthropist. Now he has written a book. That's the capsule public history of Henry Kaufman. 
The deeper story related in "On Money and Markets: A Wall Street Memoir" is much more interesting. Kaufman was a leader of a generation of practical economists who, it can fairly be said, teamed up to save global capitalism at a critical moment. That is, having come to see inflation as a menace threatening to redraw the line between the public and private spheres in the industrial democracies, they capitalized on a lifetime of shared experience, including early years in the Federal Reserve System and the Treasury Department, to do something about it. 
It seems misleading to single out any single individual -- so characteristic a mode was partnership among members of this generation -- but Paul Volcker, then the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, undoubtedly deserves the lion's share of the credit. And it is Volcker who has written the preface to Kaufman's book. As soon as they had won the battle, however, these veterans were displaced by a new generation of traders and salesmen, who rode the financial boom to great heights. 
Born in 1927, the son of a kosher butcher in a small village in Germany, Kaufman had the usual German-Jewish education in extreme civics. The family fled the Nazis in 1937, as the sound of shattering glass and tales of the Weimar hyperinflation rang in the boy's ears. Then came high school in Washington Heights (Henry Kissinger and Alan Greenspan had preceded him by a year or two), New York University and a Columbia M.B.A. After five years as a credit analyst in an industrial bank, a night-school Ph.D. from N.Y.U. and five more years as an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, he was well prepared to join Salomon Brothers & Hutzler in 1962.
"Solly" in those days was mainly a bond house, a specialty player on Broad Street, not a power. Most of its partners sat among the traders and salesmen on the company's wide-open trading floor; they took their meals together in the partners' dining room and knew one another's business. Few had been to fancy colleges; some hadn't been to college at all. Kaufman was the first Ph.D. ever hired by the firm. 
But Salomon, even more than most of the rest of Wall Street, was on the verge of a terrific boom. Kaufman started as apprentice to a single man, the legendary historian of bonds Sidney Homer. He wound up supervising a staff of 450 analysts.
The seminal events of Kaufman's story took place during the roaring 1980's. Those were the years when Salomon, chronically short of capital to support its rampaging growth, merged with the giant commodities trading company known as Phibro and sold shares to the public. Phibro was digested relatively quickly and Salomon went on a borrowing binge to finance its entry into exciting -- and apparently risky -- new lines of business. 
But the gloomy Gus, Kaufman, was excluded from the firm's topmost management, as he had been before -- and he tendered his resignation in 1987, after the firm abandoned its commercial paper and municipal bond businesses in order to pursue high-yield lending (i.e., junk bonds). "I knew that the firm was now headed in a direction I fundamentally opposed and that nothing I would say would change that course."
In a sense, that is the climax of the book. Nothing else is as interesting -- not the takeover attempt by Ronald Perlman, the rescue attempt by Warren Buffett, the scandal of the Treasury auction squeeze in 1991 that led to Salomon's acquisition by Travelers Insurance and finally the merger of Travelers Insurance and Citicorp. Nowhere is Kaufman more succinct than when he describes the differences in culture between his generation and the next, as represented by the ultimate Salomon spinoff -- the group of traders and "quants" who formed Long-Term Capital Management. 
"They are of a new vintage," Kaufman writes, "trained in arcane mathematical techniques, prideful of quantitative risk analysis and not outward-going in demeanor. But like the buccaneers of old, they are eager risk takers, willing to employ huge leverage to succeed." And he continues: "I sensed that they would prefer to internalize the firm, to diminish client relationships and to increase the volume of proprietary activities." A few years later Long-Term Capital went spectacularly bankrupt, taking the international financial system to the brink of collapse. Between the sales-oriented "quants" of the new generation and the highly social "credit men" of the old falls the shadow. The upshot of the difference of opinion between them is not yet clear. 
Kaufman acknowledges the help of David Sicilia, a professional business historian, in the writing of this memoir, but that does not prevent several of his chapters from sounding like the speeches they were when they were young: "Learning From Financial Crises," "The Urgent Need for Regulatory and Supervisory Reform," "Financial Institutions in the New Century" and the like. But they are good speeches, bristling with examples and insights. And all of them support the basic argument of this very useful book: that the tension between entrepreneurial impulses and fiduciary responsibility is the oldest story in finance.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
New Brunswick to Get Two New Rental Buildings

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK 

 BODY:
THEY have been covered with asphalt for more than a decade. But later this year, work will begin to erect housing on two parking lots across Neilson Street from each other and not far from this city's gradually reviving downtown.
 Within three years a total of 767 rental apartments in two buildings, one five stories high and the other 10, are to fill the lots. Between the buildings are to be 28,800 square feet of stores and 1,703 parking spaces, including a 1,025-car garage in the taller structure. 
 Two existing office buildings totaling 210,000 square feet that are adjacent to the lots are to be refurbished as part of the $130 million project, which is being developed by Plaza Redevelopment in partnership with the nonprofit New Brunswick Development Corporation. 
Plaza is a joint venture of Matrix Development Group of Cranbury, known primarily for its development of suburban warehouse distribution centers, and the Applied Development Company of Hoboken and the Roseland Property Company of Short Hills, both active residential builders. New Brunswick's Redevelopment Authority named the group the developer of the 10.5-acre parcel, bounded by Route 18 and Burnet, George, New, Liberty and Richmond Streets.
Matrix is to refurbish the offices. All three partners in Plaza are to be involved in the residential components, but Roseland will be managing partner for the 417-unit mid-rise building, the Highlands at Plaza Square, while Applied is to be the managing partner for the 350-unit high-rise, to be called the Metropolitan. 
The large commitment from the private sector, New Brunswick officials said, is a major endorsement of their 25-year effort to draw investment to the city. It will also bring more market-rate housing to downtown.
Three such projects, Riverwatch Court, Riverwatch Commons and Hiram Square Town Homes, totaling 200 rentals and 35 town homes, were completed by the Applied Company over the last three years on two blocks adjacent to the new project, showing that "people want to live in downtown New Brunswick," said David Barry, a vice president at Applied. The other developers agreed. The new rentals, they added, will surpass the existing ones in amenities and rents. 
"Expanding the housing to two adjacent blocks," said Glenn Patterson, director of the city's Department of Planning, Community and Economic Development, "will help create a critical mass of residents downtown." 
And more residents, said Christopher J. Paladino, president of the New Brunswick Development Corporation, will "impact the retail sector," which still needs a boost. Moreover, he said, the new housing will push forward other projects planned in that immediate area. 
They include a mixed-use building announced in 1999 that is planned to rise across George Street from the new rentals. It is to house hotel rooms, corporate apartments and a new home for the John J. Heldrich Center for Workforce Development, part of Rutgers University. Mr. Paladino said that $12 million is being sought from the state to complete financing for the Heldrich Center project. 
THE 767-apartment housing development conforms with the state's Development and Redevelopment Plan, which encourages growth where highways, mass transit and utilities are in place and discourages it in less developed areas. 
While the plan, adopted in 1992 and now being revised, cannot block development, developers say that it has been made stronger by recent state initiatives, among them state agencies' using the plan to allocate funds and establish regulations, the state's pledge to buy a million acres of land and preserve it as open space, and the state's push to encourage the reuse of former polluted sites in cities. 
Previous plans for the two parking lots involved putting up office buildings. But none of those plans moved forward.
In 1999 Matrix Development Group, with AEW Capital Partners of Boston as a financial partner, bought the lots and the then half-vacant office buildings, for $14 million from a lender who had taken them back from a previous developer.
Joseph Taylor, Matrix's president, said the partners did so because "New Brunswick, with its train and highway access as well as record of investment, is a city whose time has come." He said the purchase also supported his company's ongoing efforts to diversify.
Originally, he said, the plan was to refurbish the office buildings and develop the lot closest to them, which is three acres, with more offices and some stores over a parking garage for existing office tenants as well future users. The other lot, 5.8 acres, would have been developed with housing. 
Mr. Taylor said it soon became clear that both lots should be developed for residential use, given the success of the nearby Riverwatch projects and the feeling that the demand in general in the city was stronger for housing than for more offices. 
One reason for choosing residential, said Marshall Tycher, a Roseland principal, is the competition from the nearby Princeton Route 1 office market, 15 miles to the south. Most of the 1.3 million square feet of office space completed in that market in the last two years has been absorbed, leaving it with a vacancy rate of 9 percent at the end of 2000, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the commercial real estate services firm. 
Mr. Taylor said the Matrix-Roseland-Applied joint venture was formed not only to tap the partners' experience but to spread the risk of so large a project. Matrix and AEW dissolved their partnership after selling the site to the new development group, Mr. Taylor said. He added that plans for the office buildings, now 80 percent leased, include renovating their lobbies and common areas. 
Mr. Tycher said that combining forces would speed the building process, attract financing and better withstand the repercussions in case of an economic slowdown. But, he said, making the economics work also called for getting the public sector involved.
The city amended its redevelopment area to include the site, which Mr. Patterson, the city's planning director, said enabled "us to provide the project with a 20-year tax abatement and to have a little more control on what gets built."
The Applied Company is also working with the New Brunswick Parking Authority to build the 1,025-car garage within the high-rise. The authority will sell tax-exempt bonds for the garage, and ultimately buy the garage, making the economics of high-rise construction viable, said Mr. Barry, the Applied vice president. 
Because the garage will also be used by the Heldrich Center development planned across George Street, its economics also are enhanced, Mr. Paladino said, adding that an underground garage planned for the Heldrich site has been eliminated. Construction of the center is expected to start this summer if the necessary money is obtained, he said. 
That is about the same time work is to begin on the Highlands at Plaza Square, designed by the Lessard Architectural Group of Vienna, Va. Mr. Tycher of Roseland said the mid-rise would contain apartments with one or two bedrooms, or two bedrooms plus dens, ranging from 711 to 1,560 square feet. 
THE brick siding and stucco building is to feature such amenities as washers, dryers and high-speed Internet access for each unit, a health club, a business center and an outdoor pool.
Rents are to be $1,300 to $2,200 a month, Mr. Tycher said, adding that the project is being targeted to young professionals working in New Brunswick as well as along the Route 1 corridor.
The Metropolitan, the high-rise, will feature studio to two-bedroom apartments with 800 to 1,000 square feet and will also have washers and dryers and high-speed Internet access in each unit, said Mr. Barry of Applied. 
Amenities planned for the brick building, designed by the Manhattan architect Peter DeWitt, include a 24-hour concierge desk and a health club. There will also be a landscaped courtyard atop the four-story parking garage, which will have retail stores on the first floor. Apartment rents are to range from $1,000 to $1,750 a month, Mr. Barry said. 
New Brunswick needs a total of 1,000 to 1,500 residences downtown to truly turn it into a 24-hour, seven-day-a-week neighborhood, Mr. Barry said. Adding the 767 new units, he said, will be a huge step in that direction.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Rendering of the Highlands at Plaza Square, above, which is to have 417 apartments in New Brunswick. The Metropolitan, right, is to have 350. (The Lessard Architectural Group); (DeWitt Tishman Architects)

HEADLINE: The La Guardia Syndrome 

BYLINE:  By Glenn Thrush; Glenn Thrush is a writer based in Brooklyn.

 BODY:
At 5:45 a.m., Mike Walker squeezes behind the controls of his fat, happy McDonnell Douglas 88 as it warms up at the Kansas City International Airport. The ground crew has been toiling on the subfreezing Tarmac since 4 a.m., cramming his plane with 22,000 pounds of jet fuel, two tons of luggage, 90 trays of heat-and-serve eggs Benedict and several cases of down-market Champagne. The glow of the control panel reflects against Walker's face as he rubs his hands together.
 "It's a great day to fly!" the 13-year veteran with Milwaukee-based Midwest Express Airlines says. "You live for days like this." 
 The Missouri sky is turning Tahiti blue, and the forecast 1,000 miles in all directions calls for more of the same. As the sun peeks over the plains, it reveals a frost-sprinkled Tarmac so empty and inviting that Walker could tool his aircraft around the runway like a soapbox racer. By 6 a.m. everything's on schedule in Kansas City for a 6:45 departure. 
Then Walker hears the report from La Guardia Airport, and his smile disappears. The tower has ordered a 45-minute "ground hold," meaning New York-bound planes at airports around the country are to be held at their home gates until they receive the go-ahead.
So, Walker puts down his little clipboard with the preflight checklist and plucks his disintegrating copy of "Lonesome Dove" from the dash. Here, on the far side of the Mississippi River, 1,100 miles from his destination, Walker cools his jets in a New York City traffic jam.

7:29 a.m., C.S.T.: We taxi out of the gate 44 minutes behind schedule, to a smattering of applause from the passengers. Rolling to a corner of the runway, we sit for another 15 minutes, awaiting La Guardia's final O.K.
The plane takes off at 7:48.
"You have to try as hard as you can to shave off time in the air," Walker says, "because they're always trying to steal it from you."
At least the weather is cooperating. Taking advantage of a stiff tail wind, Walker cuts our delay down to a little more than a half-hour by the time we enter La Guardia's airspace.
Mike Walker ranks No. 50 out of 359 Midwest pilots in seniority, so he gets to avoid New York most of the time. The pilots who get stuck with the assignment, for Midwest and other airlines, are the younger ones who don't have a choice. Walker says that anyone who needs to take a day off on short notice -- say, for the Super Bowl or a kid's birthday -- is likely to ask a friend, "Can I take one of your La Guardias?"
La Guardia may be the worst airport in the history of airports. Thousands of stranded passengers learned that during the spectacular delays that accompanied the blizzard just before New Year's. But most people understand bad weather. Any airport in the world would have had trouble pulling through a storm like that. It's the waiting for hours on seemingly perfect days that drives people crazy, and La Guardia specializes in that. Last September, the airport accounted for 127 of the 129 most-delayed flights in the United States.
As recently as a year ago, La Guardia was just run-of-the-mill bad. In fact, it used to be better than Newark International Airport, the longtime delay champ. Then, last April, President Clinton, under pressure from the Senate, signed A.I.R.-21, which removed a regulation capping the number of flights at La Guardia at around 1,050. The law was supposed to enable little airlines to compete at La Guardia, which, in theory, would drive down prices. 
But the big airlines muscled right in. Continental Airlines went after 156 of the newly minted slots to fly its 50- to 75-seat regional jets. Delta Air Lines wanted 186 new slots. US Airways, which has the biggest presence at La Guardia, bid for 82 slots. Though the airlines didn't get all they asked for, the number of flights a day at La Guardia jumped to 1,300, with some days running as high as 1,460.
Where were all these new planes coming from? Mostly midsize cities on the East Coast and in the Rust Belt desperate for status in the corporate world. As the economy has boomed, second-tier cities pushed hard for direct flights to and from New York, and this changed the airline business significantly; La Guardia became the hub of a vast commuter network. Meanwhile, delays tripled, which the airlines, to a one, insist is not their fault.
"Who am I to tell the citizens of Rochester they can't have nonstop service to New York?" says Gordon Bethune, Continental's C.E.O. "The market was there. We're not stupid people. If you take the controls off we are going to compete. La Guardia is the biggest market in the world. It's the center of the universe when it comes to business travelers."
The competition, however, seems to have gotten way out of hand. In 1999, there were 9 daily flights from La Guardia to Rochester; now there are 18. "Everybody knows that there's not the demand for all those additional flights," says an airline-industry lobbyist who backed A.I.R.- 21. "It's the dark side of competition."
All of those extra planes converge on the smallest major airport in the United States, a 680-acre wedge of land with two stumpy, intersecting runways, a woefully limited network of taxiways and tiny, overstuffed terminals. Built on landfill taken from Rikers Island in 1939, the place was originally constructed to handle seaplanes and light prop aircraft and was pretty much obsolete the day it opened. By 1942, three of its runways were collapsing under the weight of increased wartime traffic.
Six decades later, the collapse is less physical than systemic. A typical business day starts off badly, with delays snowballing early and wickedly accumulating through the course of the day. By 7 p.m. gate delays average one to two hours, with ground holds freezing planes all over the country. Even if a plane manages to push off from the gate on schedule (which gives the airline the right to claim credit for an on-time departure), it's likely to join a line of 20 or 30 other aircraft waiting for takeoff.
Back in Kansas City, the last flight from New York, scheduled to get in at 9:50, often drags in well after midnight. The late shift of the ground crew, which is supposed to get off work at 11 p.m., sometimes works until 4 a.m., when the early shift starts straggling in. "I'm sick of hearing about La Guardia's problems," says Anthony Goodman, the crew chief who loaded Walker's MD-88. "I wish they would just tear the place down."

11:06 a.m., E.S.T.: We land in New York, 41 minutes late. John Yowell, Midwest's station manager in New York, is waiting for us out on the Tarmac. He's like the chief of an Indy pit crew. His job is to get planes back onto the blacktop as fast as possible, and today his crew is working double-fast. It seems like a waste, considering that while we were landing, I counted 16 planes waiting to take off on the opposite runway.
"Where's the darn fuel truck?" shouts Yowell, standing under the plane's sooty wing, hands jammed in the pockets of his gray trench coat. By the time the first 10 passengers have rushed off the plane, a worker has attached a hose from his little truck to the aft toilet. 
With the fuel truck still M.I.A., Yowell, a painfully conscientious Missouri native in his late 40's, walks over to the conveyor belt and begins to throw luggage with the crew. His lapels flap in a stiff breeze.
Yowell used to ride a desk at Midwest's Wisconsin headquarters, first coordinating its Y2K system and later working on its disaster preparedness program. Cataclysm is his stock in trade, which is why he was sent to La Guardia in August. Some of the bigger airlines want to hire more ground crews to cut down on time between flights, but they can't find enough job applicants. American Airlines' ground-crew union estimates it is about 25 workers short, despite offering fifth-year pay ($8.05 an hour) to new hires.
Yowell has a full crew, but because Midwest Express is such a small carrier (it runs only eight flights a day in and out of La Guardia), the company has been assigned gates deep inside the terminal. That adds an extra hurdle: when the airport is busy it has to wait for other planes in front to clear out. 
Yowell's job has made him a prisoner of La Guardia. "I live at the Wyndham Garden across the highway," he says. "I come in at like 7 and go home at around 10 at night. I eat Wendy's every single day."
The fuel truck finally arrives, and as I hop on the plane, I ask Yowell if he has ever gone into the city to have a beer or see the Rockettes. "Sure," he answers. "Thirty years ago on my senior-class trip."
Yowell's crew did the job, turning the plane around in 26 minutes. While they were working outside, Captain Walker was crawling around the cabin, helping the flight attendants clean up. We leave the gate at 11:45, 40 minutes behind schedule.
At first, bad news comes from the tower. There's a traffic jam in the Midwest Express alleyway; we're hemmed in indefinitely. Then we experience one of those rare parting-of-the-clouds moments. The line for takeoff magically shrinks to six, and Walker skips his usual apology over the intercom. We make up more time when Midwest's flight-control headquarters gives us a northern flight path to avoid a strong head wind. The sunshine is spreading around the cabin.
I'm sitting next to a huge Missouri state trooper, who had been scowling in the airport lounge, scowling at cheerful John Yowell on the ramp, scowling even when the plane was taking off. Finally, he thaws out, chatting about all the people he has busted and ordering himself a club soda. Sara King, the bubbly 24-year-old flight attendant who serves him, tells me that she always wanted a life in the air, but now she's not quite so sure. Every time she comes to La Guardia, King spends at least an hour or two waiting on the Tarmac. "The passengers know what to expect," she says. "But that doesn't stop them from freaking out."
She spends a lot of time keeping customers from using the bathroom -- technically the plane is not allowed to inch forward in line if anyone is standing up. And lately, she has noticed an even more annoying trend: people are faking chest pains just to get the pilot to taxi them back to the gate.
"When things get bad, I end up hiding out," King says. "What are you going to tell people? It's hard to look them in the eye. You don't want to even let them into your personal space."

1:44 p.m., C.S.T.: We land in Kansas City, 29 minutes late. Just after we arrive, Mike Walker rolls his suitcase down the ramp and bids me farewell. The new crew boards, led by the chipper captain, John Leach, who views delays as something of a personal affront. "We'll see what we can do about it," he says, tossing his hat into the cockpit.
When I walk off the plane and into the waiting area, I can practically feel the bad vibes. An elderly woman who had been trying to refold a New York subway map crumples it up and jams it into her purse. I take a look at the schedule board. The departure time has been pushed back from 1:55 to 3:10 p.m.
Another ground hold at La Guardia.

3:10 p.m., C.S.T.: We leave the gate in Kansas City -- 1 hour 15 minutes behind schedule. Takeoff is at 3:20.
As usual, getting aloft gives wing to false hope. With a tail wind at nearly 500 miles an hour, the old MD-88's top speed, we appear to be making up time. Sixty miles south of the approach, Captain Leach gets an order to slow down, relayed from the La Guardia tower. There's no room to land.
It's only natural that pilots like Leach, however reasonable they may be, start thinking that the La Guardia tower is the seat of all evil. "They always do what makes their lives easier," Leach says.
A couple of days later, I visited the controllers in the tower, which is known as the Cab. There, pilots are thought of as Gomer Pyles with wings. "You got to talk to some of these guys like they're kindergartners," says a controller, Leslie Warfield, a Texan whose four-year tour in the Cab has given her major New York attitude. "They just don't see the big picture."
The Cab is a little round room nine stories above the runway filled with seven nervous controllers jabbering into headsets, eyes fixed on distant moving points outside of big plate glass windows. Occasionally, the men gently bump one another, like seven sleepwalkers in seven separate dreams. They place snacks on the windowsill in front of them so they'll never have to turn around -- a jug of grape Gatorade, three bananas, dented coffee cups. Behind them, taped to a wall, is this reassuring quote: "You can be a king or a street sweeper but everyone dances with the grim reaper."
The system is disarmingly low-tech. Each plane is assigned a "flight strip," which is placed in a little plastic caddy. The caddies are then slotted into metal cabinets: there's one for planes that are ready to leave their gates, another for planes lining up for takeoff and one for landing planes.
The controllers love the system because it's so simple, so concrete. When a flight lands, they simply chuck the old caddy into a plastic spackling bucket and move on to the next plane.
Lately, however, the simple, concrete system has been breaking down. Some days, there are more plastic caddies than can fit in the metal cabinets. Burnout is becoming a serious issue. Right now, there are 36 controllers. Roughly a third are new arrivals, and another third are hardened veterans who will never leave. The middle third -- Warfield included -- have submitted their paperwork to be transferred to a saner facility.

6:54 p.m., E.S.T.: We land in New York, 1 hour 19 minutes late. Captain Leach is slumped in a passenger seat shaking his head. He still has one more leg to go, the trip back to the Midwest Express hub in Milwaukee.
In the terminal, John Yowell is a dozen hours into his workday. In the evenings, he administers to the grumbling passengers who crowd the waiting areas. There have been nights, he says, when he can't just lie there watching TV at the Wyndham Garden knowing his customer-service reps are being yelled at. So he'll get up, put on his pants and take the shuttle van across the street.
"The rule in airlines, and I hate it, is that the louder you get, the more we will give you to shut up," Yowell says. "I had a guy in here last month who was yelling and screaming at one of my people, so I turned to him and said, 'Sir, you are looking at the man who decides whether or not you get on my airplane tonight.' That shut him up." More often, he opts for the velvet glove. "A couple of weeks ago we had a four-hour gate hold, so I bought everybody pizza. Pizza for 350 people."
Giving out food can be risky, though. Back at the US Airways terminal, desk agents flinch when they see customers carrying food court trays. "Lately," one clerk confides, "people have been throwing McDonald's."
Things are supposed to get better on Jan. 31. In December, the F.A.A. sliced 140 flights off La Guardia's daily schedule, about half of the new flights. A lottery was held to determine which ones to cut, and the major losers were US Airways, Continental and Delta; Midwest Express got to keep all of its new slots.
That will ease the crisis, but nobody expects a return to normalcy. There are still far too many planes competing for too little space. If there is anything resembling a long-term solution, it lies eight miles south in the Jamaica Bay swamps. Nobody would ever call J.F.K. a sleepy airport, but it runs fewer flights than either La Guardia or Newark, despite having four spacious runways, bigger terminals and acres of open ground space.
But the big airlines aren't interested. When the slot restrictions were lifted at La Guardia, they were also lifted at J.F.K. What happened? The airlines added a grand total of 15 new daily flights.
J.F.K.'s unpopularity can be traced to those extra eight miles from Manhattan, a cabby crawl through the terminally snarled roadways of deep Queens. The airport itself, in a seemingly perpetual state of reconstruction, is another worry.
"The Manhattan business traveler doesn't want to go there," says Continental's Gordon Bethune, who has a vested interest in boosting his company's Newark hub. "Midtown-to-J.F.K. is not competitive, and it never will be."
The crisis at La Guardia may ultimately change that. But so far, the only domestic carrier to run all of its flights out of J.F.K. is JetBlue, a start-up whose slogan is "J.F.K. is New York City's most on-time airport."
"I think it's funny people get fixated on the cab ride," says JetBlue's founder, David Neeleman. "You want to fly into La Guardia? Good for you. Sooner or later people are just gonna have to suck it up, drive the extra eight miles and get over the perception that La Guardia's the only show in town."

7:45 p.m., E.S.T.: We board for the final leg. 8:00: We are still sitting at the gate, doors closed, waiting for six airplanes in our alleyway to move out of the way. Customers get up to fiddle with their luggage in the overheads and to use the bathroom, ignoring the flight attendants. "I'll sit down when the plane moves!" one lady snaps.
8:02: We finally leave the gate, 1 hour 17 minutes behind schedule.
Take off at 8:18. "I know we're running an hour late," John Leach tells the passengers. "But we'll do our best to knock off a few minutes."
Leach is good to his word. 9:10 p.m. C.S.T.: We land in Milwaukee in a driving snow, 54 minutes late. The passengers stagger down the jetway while the MD-88 settles under a blanket of snow, resting up for another day of chasing the clock in and out of New York City. 

GRAPHIC: Photos: Bring a book: For passengers at La Guardia, the holding pattern starts in the terminal. (Barbara Schmidt); Capt. Mike Walker's La Guardia face; a Midwest ground crew; John Yowell, Midwest's 16-hour-a-day station manager at La Guardia. (Jeff Mermelstein for The New York Times)
