SECTION: Section 2; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 3925 words

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
Lincoln Center's Next Big Production: Itself

BYLINE:  By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
FEWER and fewer things are not television. The dwindling list includes music, dance, theater, opera, movies and architecture. All six of these holdouts against post-civilization can be seen struggling for their lives at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. The arts complex itself is a grand artistic synthesis -- an opera, or Gesamtkunstwerk, in Wagner's term -- of pre-electronic communications. Nightly, it stages a meta-performance by artists, audiences and the physical settings that allow contact between them in public space.
 In the interest of survival, the settings are about to be remade. Lincoln Center is in the planning stage of a project that will result in the overhaul of its theaters and public spaces and perhaps even the replacement of some of them. The project could cost up to $1.5 billion and take a decade to complete. Lincoln Center officials hope to present a plan by early summer. 
 Bigger lobbies. More rehearsal space. Comfortable dressing rooms and offices. These are on the reasonable wish lists of Lincoln Center's constituent companies. There is also talk of building a second opera house on the site of Damrosch Park, perhaps with a revenue-producing office tower rising above it. They can build up, down, front and sideways, but space is limited in all directions. There is no excuse, however, to set limits on architectural imagination. Not in a place dedicated to art. 
Much has changed in the decades since Lincoln Center was built: the needs of the resident companies; the city's scale; its relationship to the world; the sources of its native cultural vitality; its economic shift from an industrial to a cultural base; and the impact of mass media on traditional forms. The reconstruction is an opportunity to reckon with these changes, not just forms and functions but the ideas behind them. Even if the visible changes amount to minor alterations (and this is not likely), these should be informed by full awareness of the transformations in urban life.
Above all, the project should be seen as a civic exercise in self-evaluation. Like the plans now being developed for the Con Edison site on the East River edge of midtown Manhattan and the proposal to host the Olympic Games in 2012, the Lincoln Center project is an opportunity to refocus the city's image by architectural means. I have neither prescriptions nor proscriptions to offer Lincoln Center's decision makers on the aesthetic direction their plans should take. I suggest only that they follow the advice of the architectural historian John Summerson and "sort out those aging ideas that get encrusted around past creative achievement and clog the proper workings of the imagination in changing times."
Recently, a friend sent me a photograph of Lincoln Center under construction. If you squint, the site looks like an ancient ruin: a Dionysian festival district, perhaps, dug up on Mediterranean shores. What I want to do here is conduct a kind of archaeological expedition: to dig up other fragments from the ethos that produced Lincoln Center, in the belief that its officials will want to build on an awareness of what they have.
I will hunt around, especially, for shards from the imagination of Philip Johnson, the youngest of the architects who led the Lincoln Center project and the one living member of the group. His role exceeded those of the others. He was architect of the New York State Theater, the most successful of the theaters; he designed the main plaza, and he prepared the site plan for the buildings that surround it. His work reveals the shifting values of the period that produced Lincoln Center.
When the complex was built, architects of major civic projects typically took a blank-slate approach. Under the aegis of urban renewal, they swept away vast tracts of cityscape to create a clean surface for their designs. Lincoln Center is a monument to the tabula rasa way of doing things. Those days are long gone. Instead, there are landmarks laws to protect entire districts from demolition, and community boards who demand that new buildings emulate the appearance of old ones. Architects themselves think in terms of physical context, incremental change and historical continuity. It's possible that these are now among the aging ideas to be sorted out.
No part of Lincoln Center has been landmarked. Nonetheless, it is a historic site. For better or worse, it is the mother of all performing arts centers. It echoes with memories of great performances. And it represents a pivotal moment in the history of architectural taste, a time when the orthodoxies of modern architecture were beginning to crumble. In this sense, Lincoln Center stands at the threshhold of the present state of the art. It ushered in an era of confusion that has since gone by many names: eclecticism, pluralism, postmodernism or the relativity of taste.
It should not be surprising, then, if even the most enlightened of Lincoln Center's officials find themselves without a fixed set of preconceptions for the redesign. They are, in effect, reaping the uncertainty sown at Lincoln Center four decades ago. An excavation of the Lincoln Center era can uncover much about the unfolding of architecture in the years ahead. It can also help clarify directions the designers may wish to pursue.
Planning for Lincoln Center began in 1955. The main theaters opened from 1962 (Philharmonic, now Avery Fisher, Hall) to 1966 (the Metropolitan Opera), with the Juilliard School arriving in 1969. Public and critical reception of the houses and the overall complex was mixed. Lincoln Center had novelty going for it, and optimism, and these qualities were more highly prized in architecture in the 1960's than they are today. But the positive response they generated was offset by negative reactions to the plan.
Many of these had to do with the basic concept of concentrating so many groups in one place. Why should art be set apart from the city, detached in an art zone instead of integrated into the urban fabric? This seemed like a 19th-century view of art. The concept also jeopardized the future of some well-known buildings and the neighborhoods they anchored. The old Met was demolished, and Philharmonic officials hoped that Carnegie Hall would vaporize, too.
Disappointment with the design revolved largely around the idea that the architects had retreated from the prevailing tenets of modernism -- relation of form to function and interior space; expression of structure and materials -- and instead had indulged a preoccupation with style, ornamentation, theatrical effects and historical reference. This, too, betrayed what many considered a 19th-century cast of mind, a throwback to the days when Victorian architects concerned themselves with "the styles."
"Monumental Temporary" was one epithet applied to the result, meaning: such confused intentions could only produce an architectural muddle. This was a reasonable criticism to make according to the standards of the day. In hindsight, however, it seems more likely that the problem lay at least as much with the standards as with the buildings to which they were applied. What seemed then to be an isolated instance of confusion -- a momentary lapse -- turned out to be a crisis in evaluation that has persisted to the present day.
The crisis involved the relationship of form and meaning. Modern architecture initially held strongly democratic, not to say socialist, connotations. Anti-elitist, non-hierarchical, socially as well as aesthetically progressive, it signified, and was intended to foster, solidarity among artists, intellectuals, workers, builders and patrons.
By the 1960's, however, this chain of connotations had broken. So-called Good Design had become a hallmark of elite good taste. The modern office tower was the new emblem of corporate power. And the masses did not universally take to the progressive dispensation initiated on their behalf. Many refused to accept the connection between aesthetic and social reform. Others looked toward buildings precisely as a refuge from the accelerating pace of social and technological change.
Moreover, there was a dawning awareness of the extent to which modern architecture was itself saturated with 19th-century thinking. It was an extension of the historicist idea that each age produced a distinctive style. Modern forms might speak of technology, but this, too, was rapidly becoming a dated concept, a belated reference to the industrial city of the Victorians.
For all these reasons, it was no longer possible for modern architects to maintain control over the public's interpretation of their forms. Nor was it possible to sustain the ideal of a common vocabulary for the era. The era itself was changing. What was to be signified, and by what forms?
Nowhere is the midcentury crisis more evident than in the work of Philip Johnson. In the late 1950's Johnson had yet to establish an identity as a major builder. He was best known for his Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., and the Museum of Modern Art sculpture garden, and as Mies van der Rohe's associate on the Seagram Building.
Because of such projects, people had pegged Johnson as a house architect for the rich and as a tastemaker for those who aspired to live like them. As such, he came to represent the conflict between modernism's egalitarian ideology and its later status as an idiom for the privileged. In the 1930's, as founding director-curator of the design department at the Museum of Modern Art, Johnson became the most energetic and influential promoter of modern architecture in the United States. After the war, he used that influence to establish modernism as the preferred image for the country's enlightened ruling class.
But by the 50's, Johnson had wearied of the Miesian aesthetic. He wrote against what he called the shibboleths and crutches of modern architecture. He argued that references to historical precedent could not be purged. He designed projects with deliberate quotations from classical architects like Ledoux. Given Johnson's tastemaker credentials, these heresies could not be dismissed as the waywardness of a single architect. They signified an erosion of the standards by which architecture had been judged and of the solidarity that had sustained them.
The New York State Theater was one of two New York projects designed by Johnson and completed in 1964. The second was the New York State Pavilion at the New York World's Fair in Flushing Meadows, Queens. (The building's rusting skeleton can still be seen en route to the airport.) Both projects were sponsored by the Rockefeller family, which had supported the modern movement with its unparalleled fusion of social, economic, political and cultural authority. And both departed from modernist norms.
The fair was a watershed event in the redefinition of postwar values. Critically it was a fiasco. Sophisticated people attacked it for lacking a coherent point of view, a governing aesthetic or any larger sense of purpose apart from Robert Moses' desire to create what would later become the world's most hideous park. But if you look at old photos of the fairgrounds, you may well wonder what the carping was about.
No governing aesthetic? In fact, the whole place looks to have been planned down to the last detail just yesterday by a dream team consisting of Rem Koolhaas, Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown. The clash of forms, the automated transportation systems, even the bubbular roofs of the Brass Rail restaurants: this was a preview of "Learning From Las Vegas" crossed with "Delirious New York." In fact, the 1964-65 fair predicted the future with far greater accuracy than the 1939 World of Tomorrow had done.
But in 1964, few could have named the defining quality generated by the fair: irony. This quality was not on conspicuous display in the fair's environment. It was created in the mind of the beholder. Only an ironist would have realized that you didn't have to choose between the austere Spanish pavilion and its kitschy Belgian cousin. Only an ironist could appreciate the installation that Jean Rosenthal designed for Michelangelo's "Pieta" in the Vatican Pavilion. The great marble sculpture looked like a novelty ice cube floating in a Trader Vic's cocktail made with blue curacao. And why not? When else would the "Pieta" get to take a vacation from St. Peter's? Why shouldn't it want to dive into a big blue daiquiri?
The irony didn't come out of nowhere. It was an effect of the cold war, a strategy for coping with the culture of mass consumption on which American prosperity depended. While industry was pumping out the furniture of suburban life -- cars, appliances, situation comedies -- modern architects were trying to keep kitsch at bay. How ironic was that for an aesthetic originally designed to represent the masses?
Perhaps alone among the fair's attractions, the New York State Pavilion captured the ironic stance. A double agent of a building, it carried dual credentials from the realms of high and low art. Technically it was a mature modern building, one that visibly expressed such structural innovations as its perimeter columns of slip-formed concrete. But these were combined with elements of pure Populuxe (to use Thomas Hines's nifty term): the roof of orange and blue plastic (state colors); the flying saucer observation platforms; and the rocket-pod elevators that ascended to them.
The pavilion was a people place. Beneath the garish roof, on a plaza inscribed with a giant map of the state, there were continuous performances by youth orchestras, high school glee clubs and marching bands, pop and jazz combos, and other musical groups of less than stellar profile. The pavilion's exterior was encrusted with works by Lichtenstein, Rosenquist, Warhol.
WARHOL'S "Most Wanted Men" was an American "Pieta." The mural depicted mug shots from a 1962 F.B.I. poster, blown up to the scale of May Day in Red Square. Painted over soon after the fair opened, it was a martyr to puritan sensitivities. The authorities feared lawsuits by families of the wanted, and there were other reasons to feel squeamish. Subliminal homoeroticism; anti-heroism; glorification of the outlaw; recognition that portraiture was alive and well in popular art.
Warhol said Pop Art was about "liking things." This idea marked a turning point in cold war attitudes. Pop Art offered an allegory of redemption. Guilty pleasures were purified. You could like Disneyland without despising yourself. The popularity of the Belgian Pavilion was nothing to be feared. Pop culture just wanted to play with us.
Only an ironist could appreciate that Monumental Temporary was exactly what Lincoln Center wanted to be. If you had put the site on a couch and asked it to tell you its dreams, it would have said: "All my life I have secretly longed to be Monumental Temporary.
"I want glass facades and travertine walls. No diamonds, please. Give me rhinestones. Arches that look paper thin. An opera house with Sputnik chandeliers that rise heavenward at curtain time. A massive grand staircase that goes nowhere. Just a place to pose on yards of red carpet. The biggest bad Chagalls in this poor diva's world.
"And an orchestra hall with movable kite-shaped acoustical panels. We'll call them clouds and put little lights in them. Frame the stage with spindly gold room dividers. And if we don't like it, we can tear it down and start all over again!"
Done!
Wallace K. Harrison, architect of the Metropolitan Opera house, knew all about Monumental Temporary. Another beneficiary of Rockefeller largesse, Harrison had designed the Trylon and Perisphere for the 1939 World's Fair. And his various schemes for the Met, especially those rendered by the incomparable Hugh Ferriss, could have furnished a fair entirely on their own.
The completed building, however, is the most disappointing of Lincoln Center's theaters. The great staircase has Saarinen's fluidity of plastic composition, but the rest of the house is dim. My sense of irony has never sufficed to take in the Chagalls. At the Paris Opera House, Chagall's ceiling had the benefit of contrast. At the Met, the painter's murals set the tone, and it's a bad one. Got gilt?
JOHNSON has described the work of those years as his ballet school period. The term evokes Picasso's neoclassical work in the interwar years -- lightly draped maidens gamboling amid columns on Mediterranean beaches -- and Stravinsky's ballet "Pulcinella," for which Picasso designed the sets. There is, too, a hint of the British cult of the beautiful young man, the Pierrot or puer eternus figure, and of his American devotees, including Pavel Tchelitchew, Paul Cadmus and, not least, Lincoln Kirstein, founder, with George Balanchine, of the New York City Ballet, and Johnson's closest friend.
There is an erotic undercurrent at the State Theater, where the New York City Ballet performs, that you don't find at the other houses. It flows partly from the overt eroticism of the spectacle on stage, and also from the amorous state of anticipation emanating from the other side of the footlights. But it is also in the architecture: the deep red and gold of the auditorium; the tactility of the bronze railings and the quilted pattern stenciled on the balcony fronts; the awesome carnality of the Nadelman sculptures; and the mellow, seductive lighting bounced from the promenade's gold leaf ceiling to the room's creamy marble floor.
Johnson's abiding preoccupation at the time was the idea of procession, the differentiation of spaces through which people pass. This was a departure from the structurally organized spaces of Mies. Procession in architecture is akin to narrative in literature. It describes the passage from an initial state of equilibrium through one or more unbalancing episodes to a heightened state of equipoise. At the State Theater, the narrative unfolds from the outdoor room of the plaza, through the spatial comprehension of the outer and inner lobbies, up the grand travertine staircases and their landings to the promenade: the outdoor plaza's dream of itself.
Auxiliary spaces -- the outdoor loggia, the perimeter balconies -- allow different degrees of distance from the story. Then the performance part of the narrative kicks in: stairs and corridors leading to the auditorium; the membrane of the theater walls; the Baroque organization of the seating; at last, the big gold curtain, brightly lit. The technique is strip-tease. Cultivated citizens are transformed into voyeurs by the progressive shedding of envelopes and wraps.
Beneath the wraps lay the invisible man: Balanchine. The State Theater was designed expressly for him. In the years between its opening and Balanchine's death in 1983, the theater was the brutal city's closest approximation to a temple of art. In the State Theater years, Balanchine was the last heroic figure of modern art -- a bridge from Diaghilev's day to Warhol's. Since no one could predict how long he would go on choreographing, it was urgent to make oneself available to every step his company took.
The 1970's were a good time to drop out of architecture and go to dance. Architecture was being rapidly consumed by a false and corrosive polarity between history and modernity, as if one could exist without the other. It was like oxygen to observe the ease with which Balanchine circulated through time, music, styles and sources, remaining firmly within the tradition of classical ballet while extending it toward the most advanced expressions of theatrical art to be seen on any American stage.
Formal and conceptual analogies to architecture were abundantly evident on Balanchine's stage: cantilevered construction; command of gravity; off-balance compression; music as platform; transitions from private to shared to social space. But what kept me coming back was his relationship to time, starting with the staggering amount of historical integration Balanchine poured into the training of his dancers.
"Agon," choreographed in 1958 to a score by Stravinsky, is the supreme example of this. The Seagram Building was completed the following year, and the ballet's resemblance to it was evident in the absence of sets, costumes and plot; in the positive use of subtraction (Stravinsky's silences, Balanchine's pauses); and in the illusory exposure of bodies that are in fact heavily clothed by classical technique.
The score was loosely inspired by a manual of 17th-century French court dances: sarabandes, galliards and branles. This source material is scarcely discernible in the choreography, though the classical ballet vocabulary was also codified at the French court. The title, "Agon," links the ballet to "Apollo" and "Orpheus," two previous Greek-themed works, story ballets also set to Stravinsky scores.
The plot in "Agon" is abstract: it is the struggle between the music and the choreography and between the two lead dancers. Their duet, a study in the active and passive aggression in romantic pairings, illustrated Balanchine's idea that conflict is fundamental to relationships. Every New Yorker can identify with that idea. We more or less patented it as a form of social conduct.
IT was difficult to leave the State Theater and face a world where architects were arguing over Classicism vs. Modernism. Ballet and architecture are different art forms with different historical traditions, but artists in both fields have faced the same issue: how to look at the relationship between past and present. Balanchine and Stravinsky defined one approach to this relationship. Classicism and Modernism are just names, words, terms for some of the many strands of information that contemporary artists can feed into the future if they have the talent to use them.
Nor was it useful to hear architects debating the relative value of appealing to elite or popular taste, as if it were possible for talented architects to choose one, the other or both. You came away from the State Theater convinced that art finds its own audience (or fails to) when artists say whatever they have to say as well as they can in the course of practice. Regarding the equal devotion Balanchine gave to crowd-pleasing spectacles and more ascetic works, Arlene Croce wrote, "If Balanchine does not discriminate among his poetic resources, why should we?" But perhaps only an artist of Balanchine's gifts can use that degree of freedom.
Architecture, too, is a performing art. Like procession, it unfolds in time as well as space. There is now an opportunity to mount a new $1.5 billion production of an act that has grown stale with age. The pivotal issue confronting the architects is the relationship between Lincoln Center and the city around it.
Forty years ago, the spatial isolation of the complex was a separation from chaos. That meaning has been lost. The cityscape has been substantially drained of its chaotic character. If anything, it is now too orderly, too homogenized, too contextual, too -- suburban. For Lincoln Center to stand out now, it will have to be slightly insane. Not everyone knows how to do this.
And the relationship of forms to meanings has shifted once again. No one seriously equates classicism with popularity, or aesthetic innovation with the elite; not since Bilbao, anyhow. No one goes to cities in search of suburban values. People expect to be wowed. They know that cities have an obligation to produce culture, not just to consume it, and that architecture, our most public art even in the TV age, is the most powerful form in which that obligation can be renewed.

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about a planned overhaul of Lincoln Center referred incorrectly to the surviving members of the group of architects most responsible for the center's original design. Philip Johnson is not the only one; Max Abramovitz also holds the distinction. The article also referred incorrectly to the age of Mr. Johnson, who was born in 1906; he was not the youngest member of the group; that was Eero Saarinen, born in 1910.

HEADLINE: Words on Music, 25 Million of Them 

BYLINE:  By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

 BODY:
FEW writers about music would argue with Charles Rosen, himself one of the best, introducing his recent collection of essays, "Critical Entertainments: Music Old and New": "Of all the arts that have developed something like a complex expressive language, music is one of the most difficult to write about."
 The second edition of The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians, to be published by Grove's Dictionaries on Jan. 30, must therefore stand in its sheer bulk as a monument to the indomitable human spirit. The facts and figures are astounding: 29,500 articles, 6,000 contributors, 25 million words. For the print version, 29 volumes, 119 pounds, 5,000 illustrations, a purchase price of $4,850. And a complete version online, to be updated regularly. 
 None of which might matter much without the expectation of quality raised by Grove dictionaries over more than a century, since George Grove first published his Dictionary of Music and Musicians in installments from 1878 to 1890, and in particular by The New Grove, edited by Stanley Sadie in 1980. At a mere 20 volumes, up 10 from the fifth and last edition of the old Grove (Eric Blom's in 1954), and thoroughly infused with modern scholarship, The New Grove was already overwhelming in its size and scope. 
Among the many practical obstacles it posed, it seemed a sure bet that no one would be able to review the thing with any meaningful breadth. No one, that is, until Mr. Rosen soared over the landscape in The New York Review of Books. "In its new professional form, The New Grove is the greatest musical dictionary ever published," Mr. Rosen wrote in his brilliant review, reprinted in "Critical Entertainments."
(First Grove's and now New Grove's closest competitor in terms of scale and authority has been the German Musik in Geschichte und Gegenwart -- Music in Past and Present. Edited by Friedrich Blume, it appeared in 14 volumes from 1949 to 1968. Ludwig Finscher is now overseeing a second edition, which began in 1994 and is intended to encompass 21 volumes by its completion in 2004.)
Alas, Mr. Rosen's praise came after a withering survey of The New Grove's defects, which were said to include a lack of historical perspective and an isolation from nonmusical culture. Indeed, Mr. Rosen may have played a greater role in setting the agenda for the second edition than anyone but Mr. Sadie and John Tyrrell, the officially titled editors.
"There is not so much in the way of new facts," Mr. Sadie said at a recent reception unveiling the second edition at Carnegie Hall. "But ways of looking at music have changed. The New Grove has to be abreast of its time. It has to reflect changes in the social, political and intellectual atmosphere."
For one thing, the new edition has added a specific entry on "music," Mr. Sadie noted sheepishly, though without acknowledging that Mr. Rosen had cited the lack of one as a fundamental flaw in the enterprise. For music, despite the saw about its being an international language, is many things to many people, places and times. "Dr. Stanley Sadie's point, made in a letter, that they could find no one person who could have written on 'music' and the changing significance of the term through the ages," Mr. Rosen writes in a new introduction to his review, "was disingenuous."
The new edition, in any case, did enlist one person, Bruno Nettl, an eminent Czech-born American ethnomusicologist, for the task. "It was the first article to reach us, five years ago," Mr. Sadie said last fall over lunch at a restaurant near the Grove offices and Victoria Station in London.
Mr. Nettl's entry confirms both the need for a discussion of the subject and the difficulty of supplying one: "Presenting the word 'music' as an entry in a dictionary of music may imply either an authoritative definition or a properly comprehensive treatment of the concept of music, at all times, in all places and in all senses. That last would require discussion from many vantage points, including the linguistic, biological, psychological, philosophical, historical, anthropological, theological and even legal and medical, along with the musical in the widest sense. Imposing a single definition flies in the face of the broadly relativistic, intercultural and historically conscious nature of this dictionary." Accordingly, he goes on to fill a dozen pages.
Other bragging points of Grove's newfound historical and social consciousness are articles on nationalism, by Richard Taruskin; Nazism, by Pamela M. Potter; and feminism, by Ruth A. Solie. The hefty entry on musicology, the work of many hands, makes room for the latest trends, describing and seeming to sanction what some have called "new musicology" without using the term: "More and more musicologists are crossing borders and reconsidering the boundaries of their research, not only that which has separated classical and popular music, written and oral traditions, but also historical musicology from other disciplines including ethnomusicology and music theory."
Still, Mr. Sadie was exaggerating when he discounted the importance of new facts. Much has emerged since 1980, in part because of the spur given to certain areas of research by The New Grove itself, and a new edition was needed. A major selling point of The New Grove in 1980 was that the previous edition was a quarter-century old and thus, in fast-changing times, necessarily out of date. Now, in faster-changing times, The New Grove is 20 years old and more, for it was years in preparation without benefit of the advanced computerized printing processes available today.
Not that the Grove publishers were idle in the meantime. They produced a variety of updated and expanded spinoffs: a series of individual or collected composer biographies, a four-volume dictionary of American music, a three-volume dictionary of musical instruments, a four-volume dictionary of opera, a three-volume dictionary of jazz, The Norton/Grove Dictionary of Women Composers, and Norton/Grove handbooks on performance practice and other subjects. (Not to mention the 34-volume Grove's Dictionary of Art, which is another story.)
The frontal assault on The New Grove began in 1993, with the commissioning of articles. Some of the specialized material from the spinoffs was to be incorporated, though not generally in the same form. New article topics were assigned. The old entries were examined carefully and divided into three categories.
Category A articles were sent back to the original contributors for whatever minor alterations were deemed necessary. Some turned into major revisions.
"A lot of the articles grew," said Laura Macy, the publishing director. "Very few of them shrank." Ms. Macy joined Grove in 1997, in time to field many of those commissioned articles, and she becomes the overall editor, responsible for online revisions, now that Mr. Sadie (who has been recovering from dire injuries suffered in an automobile accident in Russia) and Mr. Tyrrell have retreated to advisory capacities.
Category B articles were sent back to the contributors for specified major revisions. Category C articles were basically rewritten or, more often, replaced with new articles by different contributors.
"We assigned the length, which I think people about universally disregarded," Ms. Macy said plaintively, beginning to sound like a stuck record.
Some entries were jettisoned for obvious reasons, like the Schubert and Verdi articles, roundly criticized by Mr. Rosen. David Brown's Tchaikovsky entry, which put a seal of authority on a briefly fashionable notion of the composer's death ("that he committed suicide cannot be doubted"), has given way to a new article by Roland John Wiley.
"Rumor attached to the famous dies hard," Mr. Wiley writes, "Paganini's pact with the devil, Salieri's poison." He flatly concludes, "We do not know how Tchaikovsky died."
Other articles were quietly reassigned for no obvious reason. Mr. Sadie did not want to be the one to revise his own admired Mozart entry. "Attitudes have changed," he said. "It's good to give another point of view." So he first approached Neal Zaslaw, who was too busy revising the Kochel catalog of Mozart's works, then turned to Cliff Eisen.
Coverage of world and popular music was broadened. And the treatment of Eastern Europe, where reliable information has become much more readily available since the fall of Communist regimes, was revised and expanded.
The new edition, originally projected at 23 volumes, grew incrementally to 29, with Volume 28 consisting of appendixes and Volume 29 being an index, the first in a separate volume since 1890. And all of this was scheduled to come together by last November: Nov. 22, to be exact, the feast of St. Cecilia, the patron saint of music.
The company executives cannot have been entirely sorry to see that fateful date come and go as the occasion for the American unveiling. For at the lavish presentation of The New Grove at the Waldorf-Astoria on the same date in 1980, Leonard Bernstein, invited to perform, unburdened himself of a maundering jeremiad, unforgettably reminding the festive crowd that Nov. 22 was also the anniversary of the assassination of John F. Kennedy and thus no time to celebrate.
Still, the publishers made a concerted effort to finish the project on schedule. In fact, Grove contributors started complaining a year or so ago that the publishers seemed more concerned about the November deadline than about accuracy or clarity of prose; that the editing was slapdash, last-minute and inconsistent; that editors constantly changed at the Grove offices, and the writers were often not sure whom to contact.
Grove representatives, in a typically self-congratulatory appearance at a gathering of American music critics last spring, responded intemperately to a query along those lines, accusing the complaining writers (Grove contributors, be it remembered) of intellectual arrogance. (Or was that charge meant to refer, as it seemed, to this humble questioner?)
The problem, the representatives suggested, was that some of the very writers howling loudest submitted their articles unforgivably late and, yes, long. But at least a few apologies were issued to aggrieved writers from the Grove offices.
"There were legitimate complaints," Ms. Macy said. "Sometimes the editing was too heavy-handed, usually when the copy was way over length. The editors were working within limits. We've been pretty good about setting things straight."
My first perusal of a complete article, the greatly expanded one on Bernstein, was not entirely encouraging, turning up one error -- "Thomson" (Virgil) for Thompson (Randall) -- and two sentences that scanned badly. At the same time, it must be admitted that the project is hopelessly unwieldy: if not yet un reviewable, certainly very nearly un editable. The scholars (Mr. Sadie included) were not entirely happy with even the extended deadline and never would be, for they could never nail down every detail to their ultimate satisfaction. The business managers, on the other hand, had to face the hard economic realities of this $33 million project and bring it to completion.
WHAT'S more, a remedy is at hand in the quickly correctable, expandable online version ($295 a year to individual subscribers). The promise of this new venture, which also offers convenient search capabilities, seems vast if not limitless. Already, areas of coverage are scheduled to be updated on a rotating basis.
Yet here lies another dilemma. For as laudable as it is to make any new or more accurate information available as soon as possible, doing so immediately diminishes the value of the print version in ways unknowable to the owner. Much the same happened with the first edition, rather haphazardly, when those enhanced spinoffs started appearing. But there, at least, owners of the complete dictionary were alerted to areas that might have been revised, and the truly brave could attempt line-by-line comparisons to find out what, specifically, had been changed.
Now anything could be changed at any time, leaving owners of the books none the wiser, in more ways than one. Obsolescence will accrue systematically. The heaviest investors in the new edition, the purchasers of the print version, could well be those most poorly served in the end.
Has the very notion of a print version become obsolete? Some within the publishing house seem to think so, and wonder whether another print edition of The New Grove will ever appear. Mr. Sadie, who has become the rear guard, is not among them.
"I'm not certain that the online version will answer all needs," he said. "Strolling isn't the same as driving. I hope that most people who use Grove want more than bits, that they want to read it."
Indeed, it has been a hallmark of Grove dictionaries over the decades that they make for good strolling, offering quaint, charming and unexpected byways. Grove himself, a civil engineer, was more enthusiast than scholar when it came to music. The early editions were valued as much for their literary qualities as for their sometimes soft scholarship and their often quirky aesthetic judgments.
THE scholarship became considerably more rigorous (and substantially more American) in The New Grove. Still, there were gratifying vagaries. Soon after that edition appeared, it was discovered that a noted contributor, the Scandinavian specialist Robert Layton, had slipped a phony entry past the editors: a description of the life and works of Dag Henrik Esrum-Hellerup, a fictitious Danish flutist, conductor and composer. Less well known is a shorter entry on Guglielmo Baldini, an Italian composer invented long ago by the great German musicologist Hugo Riemann.
The new edition duly expunges these intruders. What's more, it tries to smother their traces in scholarship, discussing them in a new entry on spoof articles by David Fallows.
"Spoof articles are deceptively easy to do," Mr. Fallows writes. "Many articles in Grove and elsewhere are based entirely on unpublished material, and many cite only rare local publications: the item on Baldini was reported as being in the 'Archiv fur Freiburger Diozesan geschichte,' which would (even if it exists) be hard to verify in London and hard to check at all without inquiries to libraries in both places called Freiburg (alongside, for safety, Fribourg) -- plainly not tasks for which subeditors are employed unless they have reason to distrust the author." So irreverent readers may hope for more fictitious delights in the new edition.
Mr. Fallows himself was responsible for one of the loveliest and subtlest touches in the 1980 Grove, which survives in the new edition. In Mr. Fallows's entry for the 15th-century Franco-Flemish composer Gilles de Bins Dit Binchois, that full name is spelled out in the initial letters of succeeding paragraphs in a bit of Renaissance-style sportiveness. But here is a prime example of something that can be taken in easily -- perhaps even discovered by the unsuspecting, though less easily -- in the print version, with the pages spread, but must be ferreted out online, in the fragmented section-by-section scroll, where only parts of paragraphs can be seen at a time.
In 1980, that entry appeared in Volume 4, which was charmingly identified on the spine by its beginning and end points, "Back to Bolivia." Now as then, the overall span runs from A to Zywny (Wojciech, a 19th-century Polish piano teacher and composer of Bohemian origin), and the other snippets on the spines are less poetic. Not that such things are ignored amid the press of more urgent matters.
"It looked for a time like Manilow would make the spine," Ms. Macy said, "but we fixed that." Some people get no respect.
Another part of Grove culture, shared with other British music publications, is an inordinate fondness for all things English. It receded somewhat in 1980 and continues to do so.
"There is probably still a slight English bias," said Ms. Macy, who was born in Evanston, Ill., studied at the University of California at Santa Barbara and the University of North Carolina, and taught at Pennsylvania State University. "It's not that we've shrunk English coverage, but we've expanded everything else."
Grove died in 1900, four years before the second edition of his dictionary would start to appear, edited by J. A. Fuller Maitland and expanded from four volumes (and a thin index volume) to five. Surely he could not have imagined the scale of the present enterprise. But just as surely, as both editor and writer, he would have understood why this grandest of tributes was fated to arrive just after the 100th anniversary of his death. He is undoubtedly still muttering about writers who submit their pieces late -- and long.

HEADLINE: Viewing Craftsmanship, With Fine Arts as a Backdrop 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM ZIMMER 

 BODY:
THE crafts world and the fine arts world have a tango-like relationship. They come together in certain respects, yet they insist on maintaining their individual values and personalities. These days the closeness is emphasized. Much is written and said about the blurring of the lines between fine art and crafts -- but much of that commentary is itself blurry.
 For 20 years, Jack Russell has been the director of Brookfield Craft Center, which he estimates is one of only 12 to 15 places in the United States unaffiliated with an academic institution that teaches a full spectrum of crafts at a professional level. 
 In an interview, Mr. Russell, who used to be a rock and roll drummer and later a sculptor, proved to be an ardent advocate of the values that crafts hold.
Q. What is the essential difference between craft and fine arts?
A. There are two essential ones. First, in craft there is a reverence and respect for the materials themselves, for the actual substances bring used. And secondly there is reverence for the processes and techniques identified with a particular craft -- the way things are put together. These are attractive differences and have brought a lot of fine arts people over to crafts. I know I was always upset about with the lack of craftsmanship in the fine arts. My touchstone is that if an object shows respect for both the reality and the spirituality of the material and the process involved in making it, it's craft.
Q. But is there an obscuring of the differences now? Are painting and sculpture heeding the lesson about the importance of materials and technique?
A. Both the term fine arts and crafts are moving targets; there are no hard-and-fast differences. I'm sure Michelangelo and Leonardo, two of the greatest artists, would have considered themselves craftsmen. Maybe the relationship should be thought of as a pyramid. At the bottom there is a lot of bad crafts and a lot of bad painting and sculpture; at the top there really is no difference.
Q. It's sometimes said of crafts that they're boring, that all vessels look basically alike. But then couldn't it be said that all paintings look basically alike, too?
A. A vessel has an exterior shape and an interior space. Other than that it can be anything. But some of the major differences between craft and fine art issues are more complex and don't all have to do with the items themselves. Rather they have to do with the market aspects of crafts. Essentially there are real, usable teapots and there are virtual teapots.
Q. But you didn't always have "edgy" teapots, did you?
A. Since I have been at Brookfield there have been what I would call undulations in the crafts world. But right after World War II the big revolution, evolution or renaissance occurred. A lot of skilled craftspeople had come over from Europe and returning G.I.'s wanted to learn a trade. Universities began to offer woodworking and ceramics courses, courses that used to be offered only by trade schools. The boomer generation changed things again: in the 1960's the "art" component entered crafts 
But getting back to economics, the actual teapot and the virtual teapot are made for different markets. The marketplace is central to the crafts world in a way that it isn't in the fine arts. Crafts objects are sold wholesale most of the time, to places like Brookfield Craft Center. This last holiday season a woman bought $1,100 worth of hand-blown ornaments to give as presents; it was a great idea because every such ornament isn't alike. The upshot of this merchandising aspect is that craftspeople are probably more savvy about business than arts people, and have a better idea of cost.
Q. Does this mean that the craft world is more tightly knit than the art world?
A. Yes, craftspeople share stories, information. There's an active grapevine. This is possible in part because the craft world has gone completely mainstream. You look at the pages of popular catalogs and it's hard to tell the difference between a teapot made by an individual artist and one that is mass-produced in some third-world country.
All of these marketing factors mean that craftspeople collaborate far more than artists do. It's rare to hear of artists collaborating. We're bound by the marketplace. 
Q. For all their visibility, crafts have less cachet than fine arts. What do you think might be the most helpful in moving the crafts world higher in public perception? 
A. There are several important craft magazines that cover both the aesthetic and business sides. But there's no crafts criticism. Perhaps we don't need it. Perhaps the object itself is its best critique. But there are areas to be worked on. A major one is that major museums display the work of dead craftspeople, but won't show work by living ones. That perception has to be changed.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jack Russell, the director of Brookfield Craft Center, contends that the craft world holds many values and is more tightly knit than the art world. (Don Heiny for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: DINING OUT; 
A Steakhouse With an Italian Sideline

BYLINE:  By JOANNE STARKEY; E-mail: lidining@nytimes.com

 BODY:
PACE'S seems to have all the bases covered. The Hauppauge standby is a steakhouse at a time when big-beef emporiums are leading the popularity parade. It also tosses a bone to its Italian roots (it originally opened as an Italian restaurant) by offering a roster of pastas and an occasional Italian special. This inclusion is an insurance policy on an island where Italian is the favorite ethnic cuisine.
 But Pace's need not hedge its bets. Its steaks can make it on their own. The pastas were less impressive. We tried two of them, with mixed results. A platter of penne tossed with shrimp in a sun-dried tomato-basil cream sauce was worthy of any top-notch Italian spot. But linguine with white clam sauce was not. The tasteless mound of noodles harbored chunks of chewy clams. Chewy is also the adjective for some of the players in the Italian seafood salad, a special one evening. 
 Pace's decor says vintage steakhouse rather than Sorrento. The mood is set by nostalgic black and white photographs of old New York, sports' heros and scenes from classic films. There is a warren of small dining rooms here. Those at the restaurant's bustling center are not as appealing as the tucked-away spots: the cozy library or the barroom with its corner fireplace.
Steak is the way to go and for those who really love it, the porterhouse for one, a frequent special of 32 ounces of meat for $29.95, is the dish to order. The porterhouse for two, on the menu ($25.95 per person), is not twice as large and, on the night we tried it, didn't have the beefy flavor of the single. The velvety double filet mignon ($26.95) and the nicely crusted marinated shell steak ($22.95) were other pleasers. While these prices are not low, they run $5 to $10 less than comparable cuts at North Shore spots.
Pace's prices also include a salad, though it is not noteworthy. It is dominated by iceberg lettuce and includes tasteless California black olives. (Pace's Italian ancestors would shake their fists at this.) The salad dressings also miss the mark. The house vinaigrette is much like straight balsamic vinegar and the blue cheese dressing has no taste at all, unless one is lucky enough to encounter one of the rare chunks of cheese.
We loved the a la carte confetti salad ($8.50) of chopped green beans, shrimp, tomatoes, onions and bacon but found the Caesar ($6.75) overly acidic and out of balance.
For those not going the beef route, roast chicken with a blistered, crackly skin and expertly cooked salmon in a tangy dijonaise sauce are good choices.
Do not miss the steak fries. These medium-cut beauties have a splendid crust, soft interior and assertive seasoning. The crispy onions, creamed spinach and chunky, onion-flecked home fries also got thumbs up.
There is nothing wrong with the shrimp cocktail except the price. Some diners will gag at paying $11.95 for three (albeit jumbo) shrimp. This is especially noticeable at a restaurant that only charges $19.95 for a rack of lamb. A more economical opener is the seafood bisque ($5.50) blessed with nubbins of shrimp.
Two other recommended, though pricey, appetizers are the crab-meat cocktail and the plump roasted oysters (both specials). But say no to the run-of-the-mill, bready baked clams.
All of the desserts (except the imported-from-Italy sorbets served in fruit shells) are homemade. The so-called cobblers (blueberry or apple) are really crisps and are nothing special. The cheesecake is appropriately creamy, the chocolate mousse cake rich and the bread pudding moist and booze-laced.
The numerous servers at Pace's are speedy and attentive. If one's waiter is not at hand, any passing busboy or other staff member will take the check or fill a request for a drink reorder. They exhibit a friendly, can-do attitude that helps make Pace's a mid-Island favorite.

Pace's Steak House
325 Nesconset Highway (Route 347), Hauppauge, (631) 979-7676.

Good

ATMOSPHERE Bustling, traditional steakhouse.
SERVICE The job gets done with a smile.
SOUND LEVEL Loud in centrally located rooms. Better in tucked-away spots.
RECOMMENDED DISHES Porterhouse steak, marinated shell steak, filet mignon, salmon Dijonaise, roasted chicken, penne with shrimp, steak fries, home fries, creamed spinach, seafood bisque, roasted oysters, crab-meat cocktail, shrimp cocktail, chocolate mousse cake, cheesecake, bread pudding.
WINE LIST Twelve by-the-glass selections, a smattering of French, Italian, Australian, Chilean and New Zealand picks, a long California list and a more substantial representation of Long Island choices than usual offer patrons a diverse, interesting, though not inexpensive, array.
CREDIT CARDS All the majors.
HOURS Lunch, noon to 3 p.m. Monday through Friday. Dinner, 3 to 11 p.m. Monday through Thursday, till midnight Friday, 5 p.m. to midnight Saturday and 4 to 10 p.m. Sunday.
RESERVATIONS Needed.
WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBILITY No steps.

HEADLINE: The Twists And Turns Of Pedaling To the Job 

BYLINE:  By MELINDA TUHUS 

 BODY:
THERE'S an old song that goes, "Dead skunk in the middle of the road and it's stinking to high heaven." If you are commuting to work on a bicycle, that sentiment would be putting it mildly. 
 I commute to New Haven on my bike and not long ago on my way back to my Hamden home I saw ahead of me -- upwind -- a beautiful skunk lying in the middle of the road. I was riding right past him, a few feet away, when I got my first whiff, which indicated he was very recently departed. The stench made breathing impossible and almost toppled me from my bike. Because I was cycling uphill at that point, it took some time to pass it. There was no escape -- no windows to roll up, no air recirculation button to push. 
 That's the price I pay to smell the roses -- and the lilacs, and the newly mown grass -- as I bike around greater New Haven. I think of my bike as a two-wheeled convertible in low gear with the top permanently down. I hear the birds serenading each other in the spring and hear the squirrels skitter through the leaves in the fall. 
My cycling goal is to ride every day, which includes a 4.5-mile commute from Hamden to work in downtown New Haven, as well as longer recreational rides on weekends.
Some years -- graced by mild, snowless winters -- I have come pretty close to meeting my goal.
But the brakes fail in wet weather on my 25-year-old, naturally rusted, three-speed, no-name bicycle -- otherwise perfect for commuting -- on which I've logged more than 25,000 miles in the dozen years I've lived in Connecticut. So if it's raining when I'm starting out, I usually don't bike. If I'm out and it starts raining, I slow down and hope for the best.
Last fall, I was riding through East Rock Park. I love the sweep of trees, the narrow stretch of sky visible overhead, the families of turkeys I often see walking around. It was drizzling, and, as I took a sharp right turn out of the park, my bike slid out from under me. I used my hand to brace my fall -- 10 feet from a pick-up truck in the intersection. A few minutes later, I was at work with an ice pack on my pulsating palm. 
There have been a few other mishaps and near-mishaps over the years, none requiring serious medical care, but all making my heart beat faster.
None of these scrapes has reduced my enthusiasm for the freedom, the convenience, the exercise, the economy and the environmental awareness of bicycle commuting. 
I worked in New Haven City Hall for five years, and the amount of work time folks there spent feeding meters or moving their cars around to available parking spaces could have bought me a top-of-the-line bike every month.
Each day I bike, I save money on gas, parking, and depreciation on our car (yes, my family owns one), or bus fare. I also save a lot of money and time not belonging to a gym. I'm not a slave to bus schedules, car-sharing, or traffic jams. I'm making zero contribution to air pollution or global warming. I ride door to door, locking my bike in a bike rack or to a pole.
And motorized commuters think I'm the one making the sacrifice. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Small Airports Are Getting Bigger; 
As Flying Grows, Plans for New Runways, New Terminals, New Hangars

BYLINE:  By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
WHILE Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks grabs the attention of most air travelers in the state, a growing number of business executives, big-name entertainers, private pilots and others are boosting traffic at the state's five smaller airports as well.
 The state's general aviation airports -- Oxford, Hartford-Brainard, Groton-New London, Windham and Danielson -- have seen about 15 percent more use in the last three years and are projecting that growth rate to continue. The airports are completing or planning more than $10 million in improvement projects, including privately funded investments to increase hangar space or improve safety. 
 "A lot of it is just the good economy in Connecticut," said Kenneth J. Robert, the aviation administrator for the State Department of Transportation. "Pleasure flying has always been something that people do with discretionary income, so when you have a good economy you tend to have more activity at the state airports." If the economy continues to slow, so will aviation. 
Richard Polidori, president of Lanmar Aviation, which is building a helicopter hangar and maintenance operation at Groton-New London Airport, said a good economy means Connecticut corporations and residents are more willing to spend money on private aviation because they're not tied to an airline schedule or risk missing a connection.
"There's a lot of frustration with air travel -- people who have money can't get where they want to get," Mr. Polidori said. "If I called a counter today and wanted to get to Fort Lauderdale tomorrow, I probably couldn't get a ticket, and if I could it would be on a shuttle with no first class. That's not what wealthy people want to hear."
For corporations, a missed connection could mean that a group of executives traveling to a meeting in a distant city miss an entire day of work, which affects productivity; flying the same route in a corporate jet eliminates that hazard.
Another big boost for aviation was a change in the tax law governing aircraft in the mid-1990's. Previously, they were assessed as personal property, and there were numerous instances of Connecticut residents parking their planes in New York, Massachusetts and Rhode Island to avoid the tax. Then the state shifted to a registration fee that does not exceed $2,500 for general aviation planes, which meant the cost of keeping an aircraft in Connecticut was reduced to a fraction of its previous amount. A plane that was assessed at $1 million, for example, would have had a tax bill of about $31,500 under the old system.
"Until 1994 it didn't make economic sense to keep an aircraft in Connecticut because all the surrounding states had aircraft registration programs," Mr. Robert said. "Changing the law made us much more competitive."
Kenneth W. Milano, manager of Hartford-Brainard Airport, where aircraft takeoffs and landings have increased from 112,567 in 1997 to 130,000 in 1999, said three new hangars are planned, which will accommodate as many as 58 aircraft. Mr. Milano said a study of the impact of Brainard found that the economic impact of the airport, from the salaries paid to its employees to the cost of fuel and supplies to run the planes, totals about $37 million a year.
"That just looked at Brainard, but the same kinds of things apply to all the general aviation airports in the state," Mr. Milano said. The airport is also used for many tasks that would be much more difficult for flights going in and out of Bradley, such as hospitals flying organs in and out for transplants or National Guard landings in the event of a natural disaster.
"General aviation is a vital cog in the state's transportation system, and a lot of people don't understand that," Mr. Milano said. But increasingly, that fact is recognized by government officials.
"Every bit of economic development promotion that we do, we mention we have the second largest airport in the state right here," said Oxford First Selectman Paul T. Schreiber. "We see it as a great marketing tool for our industrial park and for the entire town."
There are 103 licensed airports in the state, ranging in size from grass landing fields on farms and landing pads for medical helicopters at hospitals, to Bradley, the star of the state's aviation community.
Bradley had a 20.3 percent increase in passenger traffic in September, its 30th consecutive month of growth. Most months this year, its passenger numbers have been up 20 percent or more from the previous year, and it is expected to move more than 7.6 million passengers when the final numbers are in, up from 6.3 million.
According to Airports Council International, a trade group, Bradley's 20 percent annual growth made it the fastest-growing airport in the United States of its size.
The state is also considering proposals to put Bradley under a quasi-private management organization that supporters said would be better able to market and develop the airport. Before the current $200 million renovation and expansion got under way, the last time the state made any significant investment at Bradley had been 1982.
There are also four airports operated by municipalities: Tweed-New Haven, Sikorsky-Bridgeport, Meriden-Markham, and Danbury airports. Bridgeport and New Haven are both considering ways to increase use of their airports.
Paul D. Estafan, manager of Danbury Airport, said general aviation airports take pressure off Bradley for small plane operations and provide convenience for private aircraft because they are geographically scattered around the state.
"Bigger does not necessarily mean better," Mr. Estafan said. "I wouldn't want to see Danbury any bigger than it is right now. It serves the needs of people in this area, and that's what it has to do."
He said Danbury has 120,000 to 130,000 takeoffs and landings each year and has been at that level the last two or three years. In the late 1970's, it was handling 196,000 takeoffs and landings per year, but that dropped to as little as 110,000 in the 1980's and early 1990's, before starting to climb back up. "The first industry into a recession is aviation, and the last one out is usually aviation," Mr. Estafan said. But that downtown means that Danbury can accommodate growth in the future without major changes.
"We do have the capacity to grow," Mr. Estafan said. "Nothing has changed since the 1990's -- it's the same runway, the same taxiway and buildings, so if we could handle it back then, we could handle it again."
The state spends more than $1.8 million a year operating its general aviation airports, not counting the cost of renovations and expansions that are heavily funded by the Federal Aviation Administration. 
The operating budgets of the general aviation airports, including salaries, range from $71,457 at Danielson Airport to $784,654 at Groton-New London, the only general aviation airport that also has commercial airline service.
"I don't think what Bradley is doing is going to have much of an impact on us, because we're serving a different need," said Catherine L. Young, the manager of Groton-New London. "What we see down here is more the corporate traffic and tourist traffic."
Groton-New London is just finishing a $4 million project that includes new runway lights, reconstruction of the main runway and renovation of the terminal. Reconstruction of a secondary runway next year will complete the project, but the airport is also planning a $600,000 safety study that could lead to more improvements.
"We're only at about 50 percent of capacity now, so there's a lot of potential even before the new construction," Ms. Young said. The pharmaceutical company Pfizer, which is headquartered in New York but operates a research and manufacturing operation in Groton, bases its helicopters at Groton-New London. Electric Boat, which builds submarines in Groton, not only operates its corporate jet out of the airport, but also has a shuttle service there to connect it to its shipbuilding partner, Newport News Shipbuilding in Virginia. And Lanmar Aviation is building a $1.5 million helicopter maintenance and storage business there.
"There's only a couple of airports in the state that can accommodate us, and Groton was the best choice," said Mr. Polidori, president of Lanmar. 
Last year, the airport had about 80,000 takeoffs and landings, up about 10 percent from the previous year. 
Electric Boat operates three aircraft out of Groton-New London: a Citation for executive trips and two chartered Beech 1900D shuttles that run between Groton and Newport News, Va.
Neil D. Ruenzel, a spokesman for Electric Boat, said soon after the company began a collaboration with Newport News Shipbuilding in the 1990;s, it realized it could save money over commercial air fares if it had enough people making the trip to fill a small charter plane. Even more important, he said, the charters yield significant savings in employee time and the cost of hotels and restaurants.
"To get down there for a meeting at 7 o'clock in the morning, you have to go down the night before, and if it's going to be an all-day meeting you're probably going to have to stay a second night," Mr. Ruenzel said. "With the charter shuttle, you're down and back the same day."
Oxford Airport, with an operating budget of $370,160, less than half the level of Groton-New London, has seen some of the fastest growth. The number of corporate aircraft based there has increased from 160 in 1996 to 215 now, and almost 20 of those are jets. New runway extensions, a sewer project, and hangars are increasing its capacity. Later this year, it will complete work on an air traffic control tower that will be staffed by federal controllers.
"That will not only provide an extra set of eyes from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m., it means if you want clearance through to another airport you can make your arrangements directly, rather than waiting until you're in the air and making the arrangements through New York," said Michael J. O'Donnell, the airport manager.
Of course, residents are often not happy when an airport expands (there have been complaints about Oxford), but airports try to accommodate their neighbors by limiting flights at night and retaining buffer areas between the airport and homes.
Mr. Robert, the state administrator for airports, said Oxford had become popular with business people from New York and New Jersey who make their home in western Connecticut.
"There's a lot of corporate executives who live in the area down there who want the convenience of being able to step out of their door and get into their aircraft, rather than have to go down to New York," Mr. Robert said.
Mr. Milano said convenience is also the reason singers performing at the Hartford Civic Center, or insurance executives traveling out of the downtown, are increasingly using Brainard Airport.
"If you have business to conduct in Hartford and you have a charter aircraft that you can land on our runways, a short cab ride and you're right in the heart of the downtown," Mr. Milano said. "With general aviation, you can drive right up to the terminal you want and get right into your aircraft."
Even the state's two smallest airports are seeing growth. Windham Airport is just finishing a $1 million taxiway, and Danielson Airport just spent $2 million repaving its taxiways.
Gary Boroughf, the manager at Danielson Airport, said the number of takeoffs and landings there had increased to about 21,000 a year, up about 20 percent since he took over Northeast Air Management, which manages the airport, in 1994. In the last few years Danielson has had its lighting, signs, runways and taxiways improved to international standards for general aviation.
"Recreational flying is where we've seen all our growth," Mr. Boroughf said. A two-seater aircraft in good condition can be purchased for about $13,000 and insured for perhaps $600 a year, he said.
And as more people discover flying is affordable, they are also discovering that Connecticut is a good state in which to take up the hobby, said Mr. Robert of the the State Department of Transportation.
"Connecticut's general aviation airports already have the reputation of being a lot better maintained than state airports in general," he said. "And with the projects that we have under way, that reputation is going to grow."

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
For OSI and Aeroflex, 2000 Was a Banner Year

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
JUST before New Year's, Bloomberg Business News named the 10 publicly traded companies in the United States whose stock had increased the most in value in 2000. The list included two Nassau County companies: OSI Pharmaceuticals Inc. and Aeroflex Inc. OSI's stock had soared ninefold, Aeroflex's nearly sixfold.
 Aside from their stocks' performance, they could not be more different. OSI is a fast-rising biotech company that has recently edged into profitability while squirreling away cash reserves. Aeroflex, an erstwhile defense contractor, has over the last several years reinvented itself as a fiber-optic niche manufacturer. 
 The success of both high-flying small caps epitomizes the region's "new economy" strengths and maybe some of its weaknesses as well.
OSI, based in Uniondale, has become the first local company to play in biotech's major leagues. Earlier this month, Dr. Colin Goddard, its chairman and chief executive, announced that OSI had signed development deals with two major pharmaceutical companies, Genentech and Roche. The deals, which one analyst called a blockbuster, put OSI in a position to dominate the emerging $1 billion cancer drug market, largely on the strength of successful trials of its drug known as OSI-774.
This past fiscal year, which ended in September, OSI finished in the red again, reporting a net loss of $16.3 million. Revenues increased 26 percent, to $28.7 million, and Dr. Goddard, a British-born pharmacologist, again managed to improve the company's cash reserves. 
That strategy impressed analysts like Joel Sendek, Lazard Freres' biotech analyst, because it provides something of a cushion from short-term pressures.
"The first year we have them profitable is 2004," Mr. Sendek said. "In biotech, one investment strategy is to buy well in advance of profitability and then wait. By the time you get the drug to market, you oftentimes have a monopoly position."
But 2004 is a long way off in today's equity market. In the first weeks of this year, despite Dr. Goddard's announcement, the stock tumbled to the mid-60's on Nasdaq. Earlier in the year it had risen 909 percent, from just below $8 to $80. 
"Yes, that was a blockbuster deal, but it was one that was widely anticipated," Mr. Sendek said. "It did not come as a surprise."
Aeroflex, too, is looking forward, although its time frame is far more short-term.
Until about five years ago Aeroflex was known primarily as a vendor to Boeing and other defense contractors, but since then it has set out on a conversion strategy that has clearly paid off. The company now designs and manufactures a range of microelectronic products and instruments for the fiber-optic and wireless communications markets. Its niche is the highest-speed broadband networks, and today, two-thirds of its sales come from the communications sector.
"We are one of the few companies on Long Island to make this conversion successfully," said Michael Gorin, Aeroflex's president since 1988. The company has built up a strong middle management and sales force, primarily by holding on to executives from companies it acquired during the last decade. The company showed a 595 percent rise in its stock price during the last calendar year, from just above $4 to nearly $29.
In terms of origins, Aeroflex and OSI are again disparate. In the early 90's, OSI was one of several local biotech companies to be spun off of research projects conducted at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory. Aeroflex, on the other hand, was formed almost 60 years ago by a Russian immigrant, George Margolin, who, according to legend, worked on the Spirit of St. Louis before Charles Lindbergh climbed into the cockpit. Mr. Margolin manufactured a variety of mechanical products, including aerator motors for hobbyists' aquariums.
"I really don't know much about the company's early years," Mr. Gorin said with a shrug. His real interest lies in what Aeroflex will be doing tomorrow. "Our future is an exciting story," he said. Investors seem to agree. 
Unlike most Long Island executives, who have ascended the ranks with lots of hand-on operational experience, Mr. Gorin came to his position after an early career in financial consulting with Arthur Andersen, followed by a stint with Republic Bank. Last March, he caught Wall Street by surprise when he moved Aeroflex from the New York Stock Exchange to Nasdaq.
In six decades nobody had made that switch, he said, but for Aeroflex, the move made sense. "Trading on the New York Stock Exchange, we were just a very small-cap company, and we were getting lost," he said. "I expected that amidst our peers on Nasdaq, companies like Nortel, Lucent and Cisco, we would be noticed. We have been performing, and we have been noticed."
Last week, Aeroflex's market valuation exceeded $1.5 billion on net income of $185.9 million.
As recently as the mid-90's, Aeroflex was still dependent on military sales; today those sales are dwarfed by the volume of business Aeroflex does with companies like Lucent that are building a global telecommunications infrastructure. 
On a recent afternoon at Aeroflex's headquarters in Plainview, a charmless box from the 1960's that the company has expanded to accommodate increased volume, workers wearing "clean room" hats and masks bent over assembly benches.
"You won't get me to say that women can do this highly precise work better than men," Mr. Gorin said without cracking a smile as he looked over an assembly room in which several dozen workers, almost all of them women, methodically went about the work of configuring electro-photonic circuits according to instruction sheets spread out before them.
About 80 percent of Aeroflex's equity is held by institutions, which tend to invest as much in a sector as in an individual company. Aeroflex has gotten a "buy" rating from five analysts who follow the company.
"The reason we're so excited," said Greg Konezny, a research analyst at Piper Jaffrey in Minneapolis, "is that a big part of their business is serving a very fast-growing sector of the fiber-optics market. They serve the 2.5-gigabyte-per-second market, and that's where the exciting growth is. They're in a market that's going to be doubling this year and will double again in 2002."
