HEADLINE: Health Care Worker Shortage Is Felt Islandwide 

BYLINE:  By DONNA KUTT NAHAS 

 BODY:
SERIOUS staffing shortages at the Island's hospitals, nursing homes and home care agencies put patient safety and care at risk, industry executives and union officials say.
 Health care workers of all stripes are in short supply, from registered and licensed practical nurses and nurse's aides to respiratory therapists, operating room technicians and pharmacists. 
 While there is no conclusive evidence to suggest that worker shortages are linked to medical errors or even patient neglect and abuse, the number of patient abuse cases the state's attorney general's office prosecuted on Long Island rose from one in 1999 to seven last year.
In its most recent survey, conducted last January, the Healthcare Association of New York State, a lobbying group for hospitals and health systems, found that on average it took about 10 weeks to fill a registered nurse position, about 5 weeks to hire a nurse's aide and about 7 weeks for a therapy technician. 
Health care experts speculate that circumstances on Long Island are equally dire if not worse, though most hospitals are loath to admit it. A staffing survey conducted a year and a half ago by the Nassau-Suffolk Hospital Council, which represents the Island's nonprofit hospitals, found that 60 percent of the 21 member hospitals on the Island that responded had difficulty recruiting registered nurses for vacancies in the intensive care unit, and 40 percent had trouble filling openings in the coronary care unit.
"There's no doubt in my mind that the situation has worsened since this survey was taken," said Peter Sullivan, president of the council. "They are looking for technically skilled people to deal with patients who are sicker and the sophisticated equipment required to take care of people like that. They can't find them because they are not out there."
Industry executives blame the shortages in part on a booming economy and low unemployment that has created more job options in less demanding, higher-paying fields that offer more attractive benefits and perks.
Demographic changes, experts say, also play a critical role. While demand for health care is rising as the number of elderly Americans grows, the health care industry has its smallest pool of entry-level workers since the 1930's. The average age of nurses is above 40, and declining nursing school enrollments means fewer nurses will fill vacancies that will be left by the current crop of retiring nurses.
At Nassau University Medical Center in East Meadow, some positions for registered nurses, nurse's aides, respiratory technicians and ward clerks have gone begging. Susan Heidtmann, senior vice president for nursing services, said it took roughly two months to fill registered nurse and nurse's aide positions, double the time it took two years ago. She cited higher salaries and more flexible schedules offered by community health centers, insurance companies and managed care organizations as incentives for some to "jump ship."
Donna Hughes of Center Moriches has often mused about jumping ship. After nearly a decade as a staff nurse at Central Suffolk Hospital in Riverhead, she says she is fed up with the chronic understaffing, heavy workload and mandatory overtime that have become standard in the industry.
"What's the point of quitting to work at another hospital?" said Ms. Hughes, 46. "It's not better anywhere else."
Michael Chacon, a representative for Long Island at the New York Nurses' Association, worries that as nurses are stretched thin by increased workload demands like additional paperwork generated by managed care and caring for sicker patients with complex medical problems, the volume of errors will rise.
"You can't expect to tack on these responsibilities and not expect an increase in the number of mistakes and omissions," Mr. Chacon said. "There's a delay in treatments and medical orders don't get picked up because they were busy doing X, Y and Z."
But while demand for nursing services continues to climb, nursing school enrollments in baccalaureate programs have declined in schools in the Northeast by 7.4 percent, according to the American Association of Colleges of Nursing. Enrollment at some of the Island's two- and four-year nursing programs has declined between 20 and nearly 50 percent during the last five years.
Federal cuts made to the Medicare program three years ago, which hit home care the hardest, are still being felt throughout the industry. Under pressure from the federal government, home care agencies were required to scale back the number of hours patients can receive care. For nurse's aides, the cuts translate into lower wages, which range on Long Island from about $6 to $9 an hour, and chaotic work schedules, where the only way to make ends meet is by stringing together several one- or two-hour assignments.
At hospitals, the nurse's aide employment outlook is just as bleak. At University Hospital Medical Center at Stony Brook, the turnover rate for nurse's aides last year was nearly 50 percent, more than twice that for nurses, said Dr. Lenora McClean, chief nursing officer at the hospital and dean of the SUNY-Stony Brook School of Nursing.
Like many home care agencies on the Island, Better Home Health Care in Rockville Centre has had to turn away customers. Pat Huber, the director and owner, said that on a typical day she didn't have enough workers to accept nearly half of the 30 cases offered to her agency.
Nursing homes throughout the Island are also feeling the pinch. At the Nesconset Nursing Center, a classified advertisement for a nurse's aide vacancy two years ago would yield 15 to 20 resumes, said Erik Anderson, the director of human resources. "Now, we're lucky if we get six," he said.
And applicants' qualifications are declining, Mr. Anderson said. He said he preferred to fill nurse's aide and licensed practical nurse positions with candidates who have at least two years' work in a nursing home or with the elderly. Now, he said, he hires new graduates or those with substantially less experience.
Many nursing homes look to temporary agencies for relief. But while nursing home executives contend that temps can provide basic care, they fear that social interaction, especially with the more demented and frail patients who make up the bulk of the nursing home population, is largely lacking with temps who aren't around long enough to get to know their patients.
Jay Sackman, executive vice president for the nursing home division of Local 1199 of the Service Employees International Union, which serves the metropolitan area including Long Island, argues that overburdened workers frequently cannot keep up with the personal care needs of their residents, let alone social interaction. He noted instances where residents who needed to be walked to the bathroom ended up soiling their beds because workers were unavailable. "We have workers complaining that they just can't do the right thing by their residents," Mr. Sackman said.
The worker shortage also includes pharmacists, who are lured away from hospitals by higher salaries and a more diversified work environment in drugstores, pharmaceutical companies and managed care. And, as in nursing, the pharmacist shortage can also be blamed, in part, on declining pharmacy school enrollments and the recent lengthening of the required course of study from five years to six.
To reduce the shortage, some in the industry, including the New York State Nurses' Association and other advocacy groups and unions, support legislation for mandated staffing levels. Two bills, one in the state Senate sponsored by Carl Marcellino of Syosset and another in the Assembly introduced by Richard Gottfried of Manhattan, establish minimum staffing levels in hospitals and nursing homes, respectively.
Senator Marcellino said his bill would establish an internal review mechanism in hospitals to ensure that staff-to-patient ratios are met. The hospital would be charged with providing feedback to the State Department of Health, which would enforce the legislation.
"We go under the assumption that hospitals vary in their need and function," Mr. Marcellino said. "We don't have a one-size-fits-all philosophy," adding that the Department of Health would work with unions and individual hospitals to work out a suitable ratio to meet patients' needs. 
But a mandatory staffing level won't automatically produce more health care workers. The New York Association of Homes and Services for the Aging, an advocacy group for nursing homes and adult care centers, along with other industry groups oppose the legislation, arguing that there is no money to hire additional workers. Other critics say the legislation will draw workers from one sector of health care to meet a staffing requirement in another, only to exacerbate the shortages.
Industry groups are proposing that the federal government and state restore cuts in Medicare and Medicaid funding to help recruit and retain staff. Other initiatives include recommendations to cross-train health care support staff. Currently, a nurse's aide who works in a hospital cannot work in the same job in a nursing home without being retrained. Tuition assistance, grants and loan forgiveness programs for nurses who agree to work in underserved areas of the country also aim to ease shortages.
Yet another program, which will be run by the State Department of Health and Department of Labor, would recruit and train low-income people to work in hospitals, nursing homes and home care.
Experts agree the industry needs a marketing campaign that will educate young people about careers in the health field and bolster its poor public relations image. 
"Right now, it's all dot-coms and high-tech," said Carl Young, president of the New York Association of Homes and Services for the Aging. "The pendulum doesn't necessarily swing back to the same place it was, but it doesn't stay in one place either. I cling to the hope that we will find a way to make the human services arena more appealing to people."

HEADLINE: Finding a Place for Bicycle Commuting 

BYLINE:  By MELINDA TUHUS 

 BODY:
NO one thinks that bicycle commuting will ever overtake driving as the favored way to get to work in Connecticut, but the use of bikes is being proposed as a way to at least ease the congestion on the state's highways.
 The State Department of Transportation estimates 214,000 hours of lost time commuting daily on state roads -- that would be time over and above delay-free commuting. Various estimates translate that into an economic cost of millions up to $1 billion annually. 
 Responding to the health and economic impacts of transportation gridlock, especially in the southwest corridor of the state, business and government leaders met in late September at the first Connecticut Transportation Summit to try to find a way out. A member of the Connecticut Bicycle Coalition attended the meeting. The summit focused on increasing the use of water and rails to move freight, beyond the 2 percent that currently moves by rail and even less by water, and getting some of the 18-wheelers off the highway. 
The summit also promoted getting some single-occupant cars off the road and increasing mass-transit use beyond the current 4 percent. (Those who travel the state's roads in single occupancy vehicles have jumped from 68 percent in 1980 to 78 percent in 1990, according to the latest census data available.)
One goal of the bicycle coalition, said Georgette Yaindl, who stepped down in November as executive director of the coalition and who attended the summit, is to get bike racks on buses. According to Andrew Clarke, the United States Department of Transportation's bicycle policy analyst, Connecticut is one of just a handful of states that have no bike racks on buses. Mr. Clarke was in Hartford in late October for a conference sponsored by the bicycle coalition; he rode his bike in from Bradley airport.
Federal statistics show that commuters will walk an average of one-quarter mile to a bus stop, but they will bike up to 2.5 miles to a stop, said David Head, bicycle/pedestrian coordinator for the State Department of Transportation. They could then either lock their bikes at the stop and hop on the bus, or put their bikes on a rack and continue their bike commute at the other end of the bus ride. That option would increase commuting flexibility, but would only be feasible if all the buses in one region are fitted with racks.
Mike Sanders, head of transit and ride sharing for the transportation department, said state planners are considering Stamford, with only 36 buses, for a pilot project. 
"We are willing to do something to try and discern what the market is," he said, adding that his office is also looking into providing bike racks and lockers at train stations and/or park-and-ride lots around the state where demand is adequate.
In addition, bike advocates would like to see employers provide amenities like showers and secure bike parking, but the lack of them hasn't stopped two-wheeled commuters.
Bob Hartman's commute is 6.2 miles from Windsor to the Department of Environmental Protection in Hartford.
"Some of the roads are rough," Mr. Hartman said. "A bike lane would be nice, but I don't see it happening."
Sandy Fry is senior transportation planner for the Capital Region Council of Governments, which includes 29 towns. The council endorsed a regional bicycle plan last spring that promotes safer access to roads. 
According to Mr. Head, in 1998 (the last year for which the transportation department has statistics), four cyclists were killed and 833 were injured in Connecticut in accidents involving motor vehicles.
Much of the council's plan speaks to the rights and responsibilities of both cyclists and motorists. 
Essentially, cyclists are to follow all rules of the road and when safety is in doubt, common sense says to yield to the motor vehicle. 
Ms. Fry has also initiated monthly bike-to-work days during seasonable weather, where commuters meet for breakfast in downtown Hartford. About 50 people have participated so far, but she said there are more bikers out there. "The hard-core riders may not show up at our events because biking is just how they get to work," she said. 
Ms. Yaindl said the coalition has written a chapter for the Department of Motor Vehicles manual called, "Sharing the Road With Bicycles." Bill Seymour, a department spokesman, said the chapter "will make existing policies more prominent to citizens who otherwise would have to consult state statutes."
The coalition has a $100,000 budget and includes 500 individuals and families, 25 bike shops, 12 cycling clubs and a dozen "support organizations" that conduct their own rides to raise funds and awareness on a variety of issues. Working with sympathetic legislators, the coalition helped win passage of two laws in the past two years that help govern the unequal relations between bikes and motor vehicles. 
One provides a wider margin of roadway in which a bicyclist can legally operate. The other gives the right of way to a bicyclist when being overtaken by a motor vehicle making a right turn. The coalition also succeeded in getting bike helmets exempt from the state sales tax.
Representative Michael Lawlor, a Democrat from East Haven who is co-chairman of the General Assembly's judiciary committee, is also the informal head of the legislative bike caucus, made up of about 20 legislators. He said their goal is to encourage people to use bikes more often.
He hopes the laws have a ripple effect. "Under the old law," he said, "if a motorist struck a bicyclist who wasn't all the way up against the curb, it was always considered the bicyclist's fault. To the extent that insurance companies become aware that drivers can be successfully sued in a collision with a bicycle, they will start to do their own education."
Mr. Lawlor added that efforts are under way to build in a role for bicycle advocates on transportation advisory committees, but he said that in the departments of motor vehicles and of transportation, "There is a good deal of bureaucratic resistance, like 'Who do these people, bicyclists, think they are?' "
But he pointed out two factors he said he believed will encourage bicycle commuting. One is the reverse migration from suburbs to cities, where getting around by bike is often easier, and certainly cheaper, than driving. The other is the more casual dress code in many workplaces, enabling cyclists to commute in their work clothes. 
About $8 million in federal-transportation enhancement money is available to the state annually for non-motorized transportation, according to state transportation officials, but most of it goes for off-road facilities like bike trails and restoration of historic transportation facilities, not for cycling improvements on the roadways. 
Arthur Spada, state commissioner of public safety, serves with about 10 other government and business leaders on the new Transportation Strategy Board, whose mandate is to come up with solutions to the transportation delays in the state. There are no bicycle representatives. Bicycle commuting "is not a high priority," Mr. Spada said. But he added, once the quasi-governmental agency is created to oversee transportation issues, "people who have an interest in bikes, in mass transit or concerns about the environment will then have access to come before this body and make their arguments."
Ms. Yaindl said she would like to see that scenario reversed, so that instead of coming to make their case before a committee where their interests are not already represented, bike advocates -- and mass transit advocates, and environmental advocates -- could be in on the ground floor. She points to Massachusetts, which just passed a law requiring that bicycle and pedestrian traffic be accommodated "in the planning, design and construction, reconstruction or maintenance of any project undertaken" by the department of transportation. 
Ms. Yaindl said that Connecticut played a pivotal role in the early history of bicycle transportation. 
"In 1866 in New Haven," she said, "Pierre Lallement filed the first patent for a pedal bicycle, and starting in 1878 bicycles were produced in Hartford at the Pope Manufacturing Company. Connecticut has a moral responsibility and a unique opportunity to reclaim its identity as a center for innovative transportation technology."

Sullivan of Wethersfield, who regularly commute to Hartford to their jobs at the Department of Environmental Protection. (Photographs by Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Old Department Store May Get New Life 

BYLINE:  By NANCY DONIGER 

 BODY:
A NONPROFIT agency in Minneapolis with a 20-year track record of purchasing foreclosed buildings and reinventing them as space where artists live, work, exhibit, perform and conduct business has designs on the former J. M. Read Department Store in Bridgeport.
 The company, Artspace, has successfully converted 10 former commercial structures into self-supporting artist quarters in Minnesota, Oregon and Pennsylvania. Seven more Artspace restorations, including the Bridgeport project, are under way in New York, Florida, Nevada, Texas, Illinois and Minnesota. 
 Read's closed its landmark downtown store on the corner of Broad and John streets in 1981, leaving the boarded-up building as a reminder of the city's bygone prosperity. Supporters of the Artspace project hope to contribute to a downtown renaissance by enhancing the city's vision of becoming a major arts and entertainment hub. 
Many -- but not all -- of the plans to revitalize Bridgeport have come to fruition. A controversial casino was rejected, and the main private investor behind the $1 billion Steel Point harbor development project recently backed out, leaving the city to seek new investors and to proceed with the overall plan in smaller increments, according to Joseph Gresko, mayoral press secretary.
Recent successes, he said, include Harbor Yard, home of the Bluefish baseball team; the Polka Dot Playhouse, a live theater; and the 10-000-seat hockey and concert arena under construction, although over budget. Additional plans call for the restoration of the old Palace and Majestic Theaters on Main Street.
William Kraus, a real estate banker from Norwalk, has led the Artspace charge in Bridgeport since October 1999, after a previous initiative to preserve the historic Lock Building in Norwalk as artist quarters fell through, following a long and heated battle for its survival. 
Last August, Governor John Rowland appointed Mr. Kraus as one of 12 commissioners of the State Historical Commission. When the Lock project fell through in Norwalk, Mr. Kraus went to Bridgeport, looking for a suitable site to redirect the thwarted plans. Bridgeport's disposition manager, Robert Halstead, introduced him to the Read's building, which is a perfect fit, Mr. Kraus said. The Artspace plan meshes with the city's goals of preserving historic buildings and encouraging downtown activities, during and after working hours, Mr. Gresko said.
"We welcome Artspace's willingness to permanently locate artists downtown," he said. "We're not looking for any other use for the Read's building. The city believes this a perfect fit for what we're doing to attract people back to the downtown."
The Read's project has the wholehearted support of the mayor's office, the city council, the business community, area philanthropic organizations, artists, and grass roots organizations. Feasibility studies have been conducted, along with a survey of 3,200 artists, with more than 200 indicating an interest in moving to the building. Architectural drawings have been completed, and a development team has been assembled.
As evidence of the city's commitment, it has already taken the property by eminent domain, offered it to Artspace for $1, granted zoning approval, pumped three feet of water out of the lower level and promised to provide other in-kind services, Mr. Gresko said.
The proposed $12 million reuse plan for Read's entails renovating the five-story, granite, limestone and brick building into mixed use living and studio space for 63 artists with a retail center on the first floor. Listed on the National Register of Historic Places and designated an Official Save America's Treasures Project by the National Trust for Historic Preservation, the run-down but architecturally sound structure retains some of its distinctive features. Monumental, three-story pilasters support the classical cornice on the first floor and are enhanced by 22-foot ceilings, a decorative staircase and bank of manual elevators.
The building is centrally located within blocks of the train and bus terminal, Long Island ferry, and the newly renovated Housatonic Community College with its modern art collection and gallery, the Downtown Cabaret Theater, and other enterprises.
Artspace provides a financial model for new initiatives, Mr. Kraus said. Most of the financing will come through applications to foundations and direct requests and referrals to corporations and individuals. He is seeking pledges of $500,000 in private financing from corporations, foundations and individuals to help leverage the rest of the funding. He already has $200,000 and is seeking more investors.
"This base of broad public support has importance way beyond its dollars," Mr. Kraus said. "It's the fulcrum on which the whole project is leveraged." 
Mr. Kraus has a Jan. 31 deadline to submit an application for financing from the Connecticut Housing and Finance Authority, which will be the project's key financial source qualifying it for up to $6 million in housing tax credits. Mr. Kraus is also attempting to secure $2 million in Historic Preservation tax credits and $2.5 million in long-term, low-interest debt mortgaging. The Greater Bridgeport Area Foundation has allocated $40,000 to the project. 
"We're thrilled to be involved," said Lara Herscovitch, foundation director of programs. "This is one of the most exciting initiatives to hit the downtown area in years. I don't know of anything that has gotten this far along and fallen through. It has broad-based support." 
John Clapp, professor of finance and real estate at the University of Connecticut, said the arts community is an interesting one to subsidize because they "add a creative spark" and make an area a more attractive place, pointing to similar, arts-based creative redevelopment projects, such as Boston's Faneuil Hall and the Golden Triangle area of Pittsburgh that have drawn people downtown after periods of decline.
"Whether Artspace comes to pass in Bridgeport will depend on whether the city can get enough synergism going to overcome the financial, technical and political obstacles," Mr. Clapp said. "Is this part of an overall plan that includes cafes, restaurants and other places where artist like to hang out? Is there a large enough community of artists to move there? Can you convince people to invest in something this uncertain? These are issues that will have to be addressed."
Robert T. Keeley Jr., director of the Downtown Special Services District and a Democratic State Representative, concedes the project has "a lot of hurdles to cross to raise the $12 million" but believes medium-size projects such as Artspace are manageable and what Bridgeport requires for revitalization.
"We need to look at hitting singles instead of home runs," he said. "Read's Department Store is an important part of downtown. It contains a lot of memories. We think it's worth preserving, which is why the D.S.S.D. pledged $7,500. Norwalk's loss is our gain."
William Finch, the Democratic state senator and Bridgeport's Economic Development Corporation president, believes Artspace will "prime the pump for other projects. We need to look at revitalization in bite-size pieces. Bringing artists downtown is fun and funky. It's multidimensional, exciting housing and will help downtown businesses." 
Susan Fazekas, a graphic artist who lives and works in Bridgeport, said the concept is garnering excitement among the arts community.
"I know a lot of fine artists who are excited about it," she said. "People believe it will be a thriving city center, not just cheap space. There have been a lot of false starts here in Bridgeport, but this time it just may happen."
Edward Deak, an economics professor at Fairfield University, acknowledges the success of urban redevelopment projects, many of them focused on entertainment and sports themes, in rejuvenating depressed downtown areas. The Artspace proposal would not itself contribute tax dollars but could serve as a catalyst to tax-producing development, he said. 
"It's not a question of whether or not it's a good idea; the question is whether it serves as a magnet to attract private investment," Mr. Deak said. "Most people in Bridgeport would like to see taxable properties to help raise revenues and jobs. Re-positioning Bridgeport as an entertainment and sports center, rather than an old, dying industrial center, creates a picture that's different than the past 20 or 30 years. At the very least, it will create a buzz. The worst thing the city can do is nothing."

Read Department Store, with support from Lara Herscovitch, director of Greater Bridgeport Area Foundation, and Brian Gockley, a community organizer. HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Connecticut; 
2 Stamford Building Sales Reflect Broader Changes

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn. 

 BODY:
THE recent sales of two major office buildings in Stamford and of an 80-acre light-manufacturing and office complex on the Norwalk-Westport line are emblematic of the area's maturing market and increased selectivity by huge corporations about property they own, real estate executives say.
 The Stamford properties that changed hands are First Stamford Place, a 776,000-square-foot complex of three buildings just south of Exit 7 on Interstate 95, and 400 Atlantic Street, the former corporate headquarters of Champion International, containing 482,852 square feet. In both cases, control is passing from owners with national interests to family-owned companies with a more regional focus. 
 "The office landscape has changed dramatically," said Darrell Harvey, co-chief operating officer at Albert B. Ashforth Inc., real estate brokers headquartered in Stamford. "The downsizing of Fortune 500 companies and technology that allows for location anywhere are major factors." 
Christopher Bruhl, executive director of the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association in Stamford, added, "Management that had been defined by its building is defined now by function, and location of a company is no longer influenced by where the chief officer lives."
Fairfield County, and particularly Stamford, lost its standing as the third largest corporate headquarters location in the United States (after New York and Chicago) during the real estate debacle of the 1980's, when Fortune 500 companies like American Can and Singer, which had built, owned and occupied their buildings, left Greenwich and Stamford. Today, said Irene Korin, senior executive at Stamford's Office of Economic Development, "there is no reason for companies to keep real estate if real estate is not their core business." She added, "It's not the best use of their cash."
Demands for large blocks of space are rare these days -- requests are predominantly for 50,000 square feet or less -- leading some real estate professionals to believe that Fairfield County is limited in its potential for future expansion. 
Brian Lipson, executive vice president for acquisitions at TrizecHahn, the Canadian real estate giant, which sold First Stamford Place to W&M Properties of New York and Stamford for $152 million on Friday, said his company had determined that small cities do not offer substantial enough opportunity for growth. "As a public company," he said, "we are more rewarded in major markets. In the case of Stamford, it would be difficult to grow further. Fairfield County is limited in general." His company is looking in those cities where it already owns 50 million square feet of office holdings, he said, including New York, Chicago, Washington, Atlanta, Houston, Dallas and Los Angeles."
Built by TrizecHahn as a multitenanted complex between 1982 and 1984, First Stamford Place contains all the amenities that developers strove to offer their tenants in what was then a hinterland for support services. It has a restaurant, a travel agent, beauty salon, barbershop, carwash, automated teller, fitness center and a shuttle to downtown Stamford and the train station, which is only a block and a half away. 
The three buildings are 99.6 percent occupied and will continue to operate with leases that extend for up to nine years. Its largest tenants are Citibank and the Odyssey Reinsurance Company, each with 100,000 square feet. Annual rents, which average $28 a square foot, "are 30 percent below market," said Anthony E. Malkin, president of W&M Properties, the new owner.
As leases expire, new rents will average around $40, he said. Some $23 million is to be spent on upgrading bathrooms, common areas, dining facilities and elevators and on financing capital improvements and tenant allowances. W&M is a family-owned company founded in 1965 by Lawrence A. Wien and Peter L. Malkin, Anthony's father. It operates in eight states as an owner of real estate; manager of offices, apartments and retail space; and participant in partnerships and financial institutions involved with real estate. 
Unlike Mr. Lipson of TrizecHahn, "we are extremely bullish on Stamford," Anthony Malkin said. "Pricewaterhouse has labeled Stamford a subcity -- a suburban conglomeration of 24-hour downtown activity within proximity of a major city. Stamford has become the only viable subcity to New York in the tristate area, fulfilling a demand for services, nightlife and a sense of community. It is dominated by a mix of smaller businesses -- that's where the growth has been."
Another family-owned real estate company, the Landis Group of Stamford and New York, founded in 1967 by Alan B. Landis, leads the partnership that bought the International Paper building (the former Champion International building) at 400 Atlantic Street on Dec. 28 for $105 million. 
DESPITE a tight market for financing new office construction, capital is available for quality buildings sold well below replacement cost "because, like Rockefeller Center, they can't be replaced," said Kenneth M. Krasnow, regional manager for Cushman & Wakefield, brokers on the sale. 
International Paper acquired the building last June in its $9 billion acquisition of the entire Champion International Company. International Paper also assumed $2 billion in debt.
Another local part of the acquisition was Treetops, the 110-acre estate on the Stamford-Greenwich border that was once owned by the 1930's nightclub singer Libby Holman. When International Paper put the estate up for sale and entertained an offer from a developer, a furor erupted in Stamford and in Greenwich, where 70 acres of the land lies. Conservationists who had been negotiating for the property as green space accused the company of gross insensitivity for failing to notify them of the other offer. The embarrassed company agreed to the conservationists' price of $11.5 million, to be paid by the state and the two towns by Jan. 31. 
In International Paper's view, the Champion building was equally expendable. Jack Cox, a spokesman for the company, explained, "We did not need a 15-story building in Stamford." It was sold to 400 Atlantic Associates L.L.C., a partnership consisting of the Landis Group, the RiverOak Investment Corporation of Stamford and Allegiance Capital Partners of New York City. 
A leaseback was negotiated for 132,000 square feet on the top two floors, to which I. P. will move its headquarters from Purchase, N.Y., in April of this year. "Stamford gives us more visibility than Westchester," Mr. Cox said. In Purchase the company was tucked into an office park, he said, with a number of smaller companies. 
About 140 former Champion and International Paper employees will occupy the new quarters. Some 300 Champion employees who formerly worked in the building were dismissed, and about 60 others got jobs with the company elsewhere in the country. 
Two additional tenants -- UBS Warburg (the former Swiss Bank, which is building a 338,000 square foot addition to its office and trading floor facility a few blocks to the west, for a total of 910,000 square feet) and Arthur Andersen, the accounting company -- have leases with options of up to five and seven years for 73,000 square feet and 36,700 square feet, respectively. "We are delighted to have them," said Scott Landis, a principal in his father's company, "and we are in discussion with our tenants to determine their future needs, including the Whitney Museum of American Art," which has a branch on the ground floor.
The Landis Group is a developer, owner and manager of 10 million square feet of offices in the tristate area, mainly in New Jersey. Its projects include the Carnegie Center, a 600-acre mixed-use campus near Princeton, and the Hilton Hotel in East Brunswick. There are 250,000 square feet left to rent at 400 Atlantic Street, starting at $45 a square foot, Mr. Landis said. The partners have set aside $3 million for work on elevators, air-conditioning, the lobby and parking deck.
On an 80-acre spread at 10 Norden Place in Norwalk, including 2 acres over the line in Westport, the potential exists for redeveloping one of the last large sites in lower Fairfield County. A 635,000-square-foot light industrial and office building was constructed on the property in the 60's by the United Technologies Corporation of Hartford for its Norden Systems subsidiary, a developer of radar equipment. 
United Technologies sold the Norden unit in the mid-90's and sold the property to SSR Realty Advisors and the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company two years ago. On Nov. 16 of last year, Met Life sold it to Greenfield Acquisition Partners II for $40 million. Greenfield's partners are the Summit Development Company in Westport and the Spinnaker Companies, headed by Clayton Fowler, a major Stamford developer of offices and apartments. 
Under Norwalk zoning, up to a total 1.2 million square feet of light industrial and accessory office space could be built on the Norwalk portion. A zoning amendment would be required for putting up office buildings without an industrial component. Zoning for the two acres in Westport allows for single-family homes on one or two acre lots or an assisted-living facility on part of the site. 
A downsized Norden, now owned by Northrop Grumman, occupies about 75 percent of the building and recently renewed its lease with options up to 12 years, according to George Lambros III of Grubb & Ellis Commercial Real Estate, which said it represented Metropolitan Life in the sale. Mr. Fowler said the new owners are planning to convert the 25 percent of the property that is vacant into industrial or office space for a number of companies. The property is just off Interstate 95 between Exits 16 and 17, with views of Long Island Sound.

HEADLINE: Flexible Office Layouts Draw Tenants in Boston 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN DIESENHOUSE 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
RECENTLY occupied offices in the Boston area reflect new ways that space is being used and financed in a market where demand vastly outstrips supply and rents have risen as much as 50 percent in the last year.
 Technology companies and consulting and financial-service firms form a vibrant tenant sector that has led a reconfiguration of office layouts. Where once office layouts featured canyons of cubicles surrounded by closed offices for managers, tech companies with flat hierarchies have shrunken private space and opened floor plans to promote teamwork and communication. 
 They take down ceilings and walls, exposing ducts and power ports, to install increasingly complex data, voice and video systems, which become tools and decor that also draw clients and workers. Staff members or consultants visiting from their own virtual offices find small private spaces where they can plug in and work for a while. 
Despite a gritty industrial or artist-loft look, the standard $50-square-foot tenant fit-up cost has doubled or tripled, but the new approach offers the flexibility to frequently rearrange work groups and upgrade technology without tearing up the office.
So widely accepted has this new approach to office layouts become that even the most conservative technology companies have embraced it. At the end of the month, I.B.M. Global Services will officially inaugurate a 30,000-square-foot Internet consulting center overlooking the Charles River here. 
The center's sweeping circular layout reserves 60 percent of the space for group work. Walls curve, slide and even "speak" since some movable, interactive whiteboard room dividers can send scribbled notes to personal computers. A soon-to-arrive conference table will have overhead projectors that display interactive images on the tabletop that one can click through with a stylus in the way that a user clicks through links on a screen using a computer mouse.
"The interior design is all about how we work -- a one-team concept of creative, technology and business consulting talent," said Roger A. Letalien, manager of the I.B.M. consulting group that began occupying the center last summer. "Before, we couldn't always get all these people in the same room with the clients to quickly deliver solutions for them." 
As at 17 other such centers that I.B.M. has opened in New York, London, Tokyo and elsewhere, the interior design -- cool, curvy, replete with scooters and physioballs -- "is a huge draw for recruitment," he added. The plastic physioballs -- bigger than beach balls -- and the scooters are there to present the informal image of a dot-com company, and, he said, "it says the corporate world is doing more for its people."
EQUALLY design-intensive are some of the technology and new-media business incubator centers that have opened around the region in the last two years. For technology start-ups that cannot afford annual asking rents that reach $70 a square foot in Cambridge, $60 in the suburbs and $100 in Boston, companies have obtained venture-capital financing to lease and fit up blocks of space for budding entrepreneurs. Often the sponsoring company takes some equity in the start-ups in exchange for space, technology, management and consulting services.
Last April, Timothy D. Rowe opened the 18,000-square-foot Cambridge Incubator at One Broadway, an office building in Kendall Square owned by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, one of the city's largest landlords. "We're a venture campus, a community of entrepreneurs," said Mr. Rowe, 34, formerly a management consultant who now invests venture capital in the companies occupying space at Cambridge Incubator.
In 1999, he wanted to start a business but was wary of signing a 10-year lease and the prospect of a two or three month wait for high-speed Internet access. Instead, he decided to provide space for other budding high-tech entrepreneurs and take stakes in their companies. He raised $11 million from the venture capital firm Draper Fisher Jurvetson and others, signed a seven-year lease, did a $2 million tenant build-out and moved into the space last April.
"We realized that we could create a platform of space, technology, furniture, insurance, payroll services, management and technology consulting," he said. 
Scruffy corrugated ceilings and translucent sliding walls define the common areas. Four start-ups now occupy a series of 400-square-foot bays. Each of the 14 bays is fitted with furniture, 24 connections for telephones and high speed Internet access. To expand, simply slide open the wall to the adjacent bay. 
"What makes this work is the layout: open and flexible with tight security," said Mr. Rowe, whose company now has 50 employees. Cambridge Incubator was charging rent of $38 a square foot a year but recently raised it to $60. "We make money on the investment side, not the real estate, but at $38 we couldn't get people to move out" to make room for new start-ups, he said.
Despite the softening economy, sticker shock will still jolt office seekers. In the last year, rents throughout the metropolitan Boston region have jumped 20 to 50 percent as vacancy rates fell to 3.7 percent regionally, 1.5 percent in Boston and Cambridge. Still, demand dwarfs supply. In Cambridge, tenants are searching for 1.4 million square feet of offices but only 400,000 square feet are available; in Boston they want 4.6 million square feet, with only 2.3 million square feet to be had, according to Benjamin Breslau, a research analyst for Spaulding & Slye Colliers, a real estate services firm. 
"The economic slowdown should unlock some sublease space," he said. "That's healthy for this tight market. Rents will stabilize, but they won't drop."
WHILE many publicly held technology companies may be struggling over all, in this region "technology-oriented businesses are driving a good part of the office demand downtown and in the suburbs," said Jon A. Southard, chief economist for Boston-based Torto Wheaton Research. Ten years ago, he noted, they congregated mostly in the lower cost suburbs. In the 12-month period that ended on Sept. 30, technology companies helped to occupy 5.5 million square feet of offices. "That's huge for this market, where the historic annual absorption rate is about 1.5 million square feet," he said.
Although technology companies may have popularized the open office environment, now almost all office tenants are adopting aspects of it. Even staid law firms are shrinking private offices to enlarge common areas, said Steven J. Basque, a principal at ADD Inc., the architectural firm that designed the I.B.M. Internet consulting center and Cambridge Incubator.
"There's been a technology-driven paradigm shift from isolation to community," he said. "New-economy companies tend to work in teams as they brainstorm for new concepts. Also, incubator space isn't offices. It's an environment to create ideas and build businesses."
He added: "In the past, offices just needed phone and computer systems. Now, technology is more complex and evolves so fast, often-upgraded systems can't be covered by drywall or marble." And since 1999, furniture makers have been marketing less costly, lighter pieces on casters for mobility. 
Change is constant for Michael J. Young, managing partner of global real estate programs for Accenture, the consulting and technology firm formerly named Andersen Consulting. "Our business is always evolving, and the more we lock into big lease commitments, the less able we are to adjust," said Mr. Young, whose company was an early, ardent convert to shared office space. "At first, the goal was to lower real estate costs. Now it has to do with technology and employee expectations."
In 1997, the firm moved out of a luxury tower in downtown Boston to occupy an entire 63,000-square-foot building in the Wellesley Office Park about 15 miles to the west. It set up the building as a "hoteling" facility where workstations are shared by road-warrior consultants who reserve space when they need it. 
Last year, the company also opened a business launch center in suburban Lexington and a small office in Boston's Financial District for meeting clients who fly into Logan International Airport. 
After decades of real estate experience, Mr. Young now thinks of office space differently than he did 10 years ago. "Technology decreases the need for people to come into the office, and we've only just scratched the surface," he said. "With wireless, people can work anywhere in the world."
"We no longer think of real estate," he said. "We think of creating the platform of space, technology and services that people need." 
"Work is not where you are," he added. "It's what you do."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Scooters and physioballs are supposed to make the I.B.M. Global Services Internet center in Cambridge appear as cool as a dot-com. Even cooler: a note scribbled on a wall can be sent into a PC. (Rick Friedman for The New York Times) Map of Massachusetts highlighting Cambridge.

HEADLINE: Signs of an Office Revival in Newark 

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
EVEN the murals depicting the city's history were damaged by water that had seeped into the grand two-story room that had once provided a suitably impressive backdrop for officers of the National Newark and Essex Bank, then the state's largest. Now, three years after a change of ownership, the murals have been restored and a dropped ceiling has been removed to expose the rich details of the original plasterwork.
 The building at 744 Broad Street is as good a symbol as any of the revival of the office market in the downtown core of this formerly heavily industrial city. As rents have climbed to near record levels in Manhattan, and the Jersey City waterfront has begun to fill up, investors have been making acquisitions in Newark and tenants have been renting the refurbished spaces. 
 "There have been a lot of false starts in Newark in the past," said Arthur Stern, the chief executive of Cogswell Realty Group, which bought 744 Broad in 1998 and renamed it the National Newark Building. But this time, he said, the demand for well-located office space and other developments in the city are the basis for what he believes will be a sustained comeback. 
Plans for the first new private sector office building in the city in many years were announced recently. The proposed building's developers are Edison Properties, a large landowner and parking-lot operator, and the Rockefeller Group, which owns or controls four Manhattan skyscrapers on the west side of Avenue of the Americas across from Rockefeller Center and is building a million square foot building at 745 Seventh Avenue. The proposed 22-story, 350,000-square-foot building at 50 Commercial Street in Newark would face on the Passaic River adjacent to the refurbished Penn Station with its rail and PATH links to Manhattan.
Most of the major office buildings in downtown Newark have been sold -- and in some cases resold -- during the last three years. The new owners have been investing capital in the properties to restore their faded glory because of their confidence that tenants will be attracted by rents that are one-half to one-third those of comparable spaces in Manhattan.
The participation of major financial institutions in these investments is the best signal of Newark's revival, said Stanley C. Gale, a principal in Gale & Wentworth, a New Jersey-based investment and development company. His company owns two of the office towers in the Gateway office and retail complex, built in the 1970's and 80's near Penn Station, in conjunction with Tishman Speyer properties of New York.
"Jerry Speyer is linked with Citigroup, and my partner is Morgan Stanley," Mr. Gale said. "Lehman Brothers is backing Artie Stern in his projects," he added, referring to Mr. Stern of Cogswell Group. "With Prudential, that's four major investment groups that are active in Newark."
This is not to say all the city's problems have been solved. The population has declined for decades, falling to 246,950 in 1997 from a peak of 438,776 in 1950. Most real estate executives say the city needs a larger residential population near the downtown area to keep it alive after working hours, but say the troubled condition of Newark's school system could discourage young families from locating there. Remnants of the city's industrial past, when the absence of zoning made a mixture of housing and factories common, also inhibit housing development.
The New Jersey state government has developed programs to push development back into cities to preserve what is left of open space in the most suburban state in the country. "The state is putting a lot of money into redeveloping the inner cities," said Seena Stein, the president of Newmark & Company Real Estate of New Jersey. "There are special development zones in Jersey City and Newark." Companies that locate in the designated zones are eligible for tax breaks and other economic benefits. 
The refurbished buildings in Newark are attracting tenants at rents significantly higher than those charged in the recent past. According to Cushman & Wakefield of New Jersey, a brokerage and management company, the overall average asking rental rate rose to $27.14 a square foot a year in 2000, from $20.46 in 1999 and $16.67 in 1996.
"Some small units at Gateway are renting at $29 to $32 a square foot," said Sean P. Brady, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield, who added that other representatives of the city's small stock of Class A buildings -- the most modern and well-equipped category -- are starting rent negotiations at $30 a square foot. Numbers like these, and a vacancy rate that has fallen to an average of 11.1 percent in 2000 from 17.8 percent five years earlier, tend to encourage developers.
Jerome Gottesman, the chairman of Edison Properties, which operates a surface parking lot at the Commercial Street site where the office tower is planned, said a new building could be more attractive to a company moving out of New York than a renovated structure 50 or more years old. Brokers seem to agree, saying renovated buildings are at best Class B+ space, while a new building would be Class A.
"New construction is a big advantage," Mr. Gottesman said, because a new building can be designed for modern communications and other technology, rather than adapted like an older structure. "All new buildings will have a floor devoted to telecommunications," he said.
Leslie E. Smith, Jr., a senior vice president of Rockefeller Group, said the market is ripe for new construction in Newark, although the joint venture will not proceed with the project until an anchor tenant is signed. "Newark is a wonderful alternative to Midtown Manhattan and Jersey City," he said. "The time has come for Class A buildings in Newark."
Both men noted that the building will be adjacent to Penn Station, with its connections to Manhattan, other parts of New Jersey and a monorail connection directly to Newark Airport, the largest air terminal in the region.
Meanwhile, assets the city has long possessed, including a strategic location in the metropolitan area with excellent transportation links and an abundance of fiber-optic cables under its streets, have been rediscovered. Telecommunications companies occupy the lower floors of 744 Broad for this reason, and the old Bamberger's store at Halsey and Market Streets has become a telecommunications hotel, housing servers and other internet infrastructure for multiple carriers.
INVESTMENTS that were made in public facilities in the wake of the devastating riots of 1967 have matured. Improbably to those who remember its days as a thriving blue-collar city, Newark is now a college town, with more than 40,000 students attending undergraduate and graduate classes at New Jersey Institute of Technology, Rutgers University, the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, Seton Hall University Law School, Essex County College and Rutgers Law School.
City planners and developers are looking at these students, who largely now commute from the suburbs, as potential residents once housing becomes available.
And some eyesores that have lingered for decades along Broad Street between the growing campuses and the sparkling New Jersey Performing Arts Center may be close to transformation because of the efforts of private benefactors and the Prudential Life Insurance Company, the financial giant of the city. The New Newark Foundation owns or controls a four block by two block swath of land on the north side of Broad Street that contains the long-closed Hahne's, Griffith and S. Klein stores.
The plan is to develop the area, which the New Newark executive director, James A. Schmidt, calls "the hole in the doughnut," into a 24-hour-a-day neighborhood, with ground-level retail and housing on the upper floors. When the foundation offered the Griffith and Hahne's properties last year, 18 development groups submitted offers, which have since been winnowed to six.
Mr. Schmidt said the goal is to select the winner or winners by early April, complete acquisition of the properties later in the year and begin construction in the first quarter of 2002.
Also under intense discussion is a new indoor sports arena that would house the Nets and the Devils, New Jersey's professional basketball and ice hockey teams. If built as planned, the arena and related development would clear out a faded industrial area on the western side of the downtown core and visually connect City Hall on Broad Street with the Gateway office complex near Penn Station.
Mr. Gottesman said he hoped that an old unused railroad bridge, which is over the main Amtrak lines, can be redeveloped as a pedestrian access from the rail station to the sports arena.
An open air baseball stadium, housing the minor league Newark Bears, is already in operation.
Meanwhile, Newark's already good transportation links are about to get better, with the city's existing light rail system about to be extended. The new loop of mostly surface rail will, for the first time, connect Penn Station with the Broad Street rail station, about one mile away. Thus, a person could board a train in, say, Morristown, get off at Broad Street, take the trolley across town to Penn Station and the use the monorail to get to the airport without having to brave the region's daunting automotive traffic.
Newark city officials say the money is in hand for the Broad Street to Penn Station link and new light rail cars have been ordered. Financing has not yet been secured for further phases of rail development, but plans are to eventually extend the line past the airport and into Elizabeth to the south. 
The convenience of rail transportation has promoted some developers to consider converting the long-vacant former Westinghouse factory that sits just west of the Broad Street station into housing.
Meanwhile, work is proceeding on Allied Junction in the Hackensack Meadowlands, which will connect most of the passenger rail lines in New Jersey and improve not only access to Manhattan but also north-south mass transit in the northeastern corner of the state. "When that is completed, a person could live in Bergen County and easily work in Newark," Mr. Gottesman said.
"Newark is one of the few places in the state with good mass transportation," said Roger Steinhart, director of leasing for the Kushner Companies, a New Jersey-based owner and developer. He said this might give the city an advantage over Jersey City, where most in-state residents still commute by car. (New York residents are able to take the ferry or PATH train.) "Jersey City will be a transportation nightmare when the waterfront fills up," he said.
Dramatic improvement in the region's infrastructure was not what was on Mr. Stern's mind on the day in October 1997 when he and a partner, Peter Marsh, drove to Newark to look at 744 Broad. Given Newark's reputation at the time, he said, his main concern was carjacking. 
ARRIVING safely at the building, they saw a structure much in need of repair. The 70-year-old building, although a national landmark, had been part of the Helmsley portfolio, where it had apparently been ignored for decades. On the first floor, a grand marble staircase had been ripped out to install metal escalators not in keeping with the building's neo-Classical tone. Elevator service was erratic, and the plumbing often did not work.
The building was two-thirds empty and had deteriorated to the point that most of the remaining tenants were threatening to leave, Mr. Stern said.
But the 33-story, 641,000-square-foot building was centrally located and had good bones. It was also cheap. Cogswell paid $7.5 million for the structure and then began a $55 million rehabilitation program, installing new computer-controlled elevators, new double pane windows and disability compliant bathrooms, remodeled common areas and refurbished the lobby.
The murals, painted by James Monroe Hewlett, were restored, the plasterwork on the leaky ceiling repaired and period-type chandeliers installed. Mr. Stern said that the hopes were to eventually lease the ornate high-ceilinged second-floor bank-officer space to a restaurant, with the former bank board room to be used as a private dining room.
He said the building's office floors were being occupied by professional firms, like architects and software designers, who do not want to pay Manhattan rents and need easy access to the airport. He said the building was currently about 82 percent full, compared with 19 percent occupancy when it was purchased.
Telecommunications tenants like MCI and Sprint occupied the lower floors even before the renovation, the space largely occupied by machines that do not care about elevator service, the state of the bathrooms or the cleanliness of the hallways. Mr. Stern said he was able to build on the infrastructure installed by those companies to extend high-capacity lines to the upper floors.
To publicly mark the restoration, the owners have installed lighting that floods the outer surface of the building with light after dark. "The building really stands out at night," said Mr. Steinhart, who said it is easily visible from his hilltop apartment about 10 miles to the west in the town of Verona.
The city's fiber-optic backbone, courtesy of the former Bell Atlantic, which had major operations there, brought a major new tenant to the city late in 1999, when International Discount Telecommunications leased the entire 450,000 square feet in the building at 520 Broad Street. The company, which provides high-speed Internet access and discount long-distance telephone service, is relocating from Hackensack. 
It may seem somewhat odd for a high-tech company to take over a building that was previously occupied by an insurance company, once one of Newark's major industries. The Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company owned the 1950's era building, but its business collapsed in 1991 and its insurance assets and finally its building were sold. The current owner is the Kushner Companies of Florham Park, N.J.
SINCE buying 744 Broad, Cogswell has purchased a building across the street at 765 Broad. The seven-story, 200,000-square-foot structure is currently occupied by Prudential and First Union Bank, which is the corporate successor to the old National Newark and Essex Bank.
Cogswell has also acquired another nearby building at 1180 Raymond Boulevard, a 30-story, 441,000-square-feet structure. It is planning to convert the old office structure into residences, with 300 rooms reserved for students at Seton Hall's law school. The remaining 195 units on the upper floors of the building will be market rate housing. It is scheduled to open in August 2002.
Although a lot of attention has been centered on the performing arts center as the key to Newark's revival, Mr. Gale of Gale & Wentworth said it was a combination of factors, including the arts center, the baseball stadium, the growth of the universities and the improvement of the transportation network, including the rail links and improved access ramps to the interstate highways -- Routes 280 and 78 -- that pass through the city.
"If you look at places like Cleveland and Baltimore, you will see that no one event can do it," he said. "The arts center would not do it, nor any one university. But with all these things in place, it is a much different situation than it was 10 years ago."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 28, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about the Newark office market misidentified the successor of the National Newark and Essex Bank, which once had headquarters in an office building that has recently been refurbished. The bank was ultimately acquired by what became PNC Financial Services Group, not by the First Union Bank.

HEADLINE: At the Last Frontier, A Crucial Tug of War; 
Prosperity Beckons in the Highlands, a Slice of Appalachia

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS 

DATELINE: WEST MILFORD TOWNSHIP 

 BODY:
IT DOESN'T TAKE long to hike to the top of Bearfort Mountain, a 1,300-foot high fold of gneiss and granite that rises above the patchwork of glacial lakes, wetlands and forested valleys known as the New Jersey Highlands. The 20-minute trek from a makeshift parking area here brings hikers to a world ruled by bobcats, bald eagles and black bears, all of it just an hour's drive from the man-made canyons of midtown Manhattan.
 From the top of an old fire tower, a bitter wind turning his cheeks pink, Tim Dillingham points out Farny State Park, the Ramapo Mountains and the icy white patches of reservoirs that provide drinking water for nearly half of the state's eight million residents. 
 "People come up here and they can't believe this is New Jersey," said Mr. Dillingham, executive director of the Highlands Coalition, an organization that looks after the 750,000 acres of forest, farmland and rough-hewn escarpments that arc across the northwest of the state. 
But even in such a seemingly untrammeled landscape, signs of man's civilizing impulses are impossible to ignore. The gleam of new construction pokes through the blanket of oak and hickory, and Mr. Dillingham gestures to distant ridges that developers hope to plant with town houses, luxury homes and a world-class ski resort.
While a decade of prosperity has brought suburbia to vast stretches of rural New Jersey, environmentalists say they are especially alarmed by the forces reshaping the Highlands, a branch of the Appalachian range that rises up near Reading, Pa., and passes through New Jersey and New York before ending at Danbury, Conn. The region, which provides a refuge for 27 endangered and threatened species, is valuable for more practical reasons: at least four million people in New York and New Jersey rely on its 10 reservoirs and underground aquifers for their water, and its forested slopes help absorb rainwater that might otherwise inundate low-lying towns. 
Even though a 1993 study undertaken by the United States Forest Service called it a landscape of national significance, New Jersey's Highlands remain largely unprotected, with 80 percent of the land in private hands. Conservationists estimate that 3,000 to 5,000 acres are lost to development each year, a figure that could increase if New Jersey, as demographic experts predict, receives another one million residents in the next 20 years. 
Stewards like Mr. Dillingham, who dream of turning the area into a forest preserve, say the Highlands are at a crucial juncture.
"This is a last-chance landscape," he said. "It's our last chance to have a wilderness so close to suburbia and the largest city in the country. If we don't do something soon, this will all just be consumed by sprawl."
A growing number of elected officials, including both of New Jersey's Democratic senators, would like to see much of the Highlands preserved as national forest. Senator Robert G. Torricelli, who helped secure Congressional financing for the National Forest Service study, said a piecemeal approach using state open space funds and local tax dollars does not go far enough.
"We could have a green belt from the Hudson to the Delaware," Mr. Torricelli said in a telephone interview. "I want something that is comprehensive and irreversible." 
Of course, not everyone wants to see a Highlands National Park. Developers and even longtime residents worry that such a sweeping designation would lock out economic opportunity, leading to higher tax rates and a shortage of affordable housing. Many municipalities, engaged in the great ratables chase, have long viewed commercial and residential development as the only way to pay for schools and services.
Joanne Harkins, director of land use and planning for the New Jersey Builders Association, disputes the portrayal of the Highlands as a pristine wilderness that should be placed off-limits to construction.
"People have lived here for a long time, and there is plenty of room for development," Ms. Harkins said. "New Jersey already has a tremendous amount of regulations that protect land."
Thanks to strict environmental rules and New Jersey's fractured system of local governance, known as home rule, it is becoming increasingly difficult to build housing in the region, she said.
"Further restrictions would have serious consequences on the supply and price of housing in New Jersey," Ms. Harkins said.
To be sure, the Highlands is no isolated wedge of wilderness. Since the early 17th century, when the first Dutch settlers arrived, the Highlands has been a mosaic of farmland, forest and compact villages. Tilled by Scottish, English and Huguenot farmers, the region's high-grade deposits of iron ore were forged into cannonballs and bullets and helped American forces vanquish the British in the Revolutionary War. But by the 1830's, most of its trees, burned in iron-smelting furnaces, had vanished. Today, miles of abandoned tunnels and dozens of crumbling furnaces are the only remnants of that industrial past. 
"In the past 100 years, the Highlands forests have really bounced back, with many wildlife species returning," said Tom Gilbert, regional conservation director of the Appalachian Mountain Club. "When a forest is logged, it eventually grows. But this new wave of change is different. Once you pave it over, it's forever."
To drive through Parsippany along Route 46 is to get an idea of what Mr. Gilbert is saying. Less than a generation ago, this densely populated suburb was a bucolic town at the foot of the Highlands; today, environmentalists point to Parsippany's spreading crop of low-rise office parks and strip malls as an example of unplanned development run amok. 
Wilma Frey, project director at the Highlands Coalition, said there were at least 100 residential developments of 20 or more units in the region's rural areas, embracing four counties and 87 municipalities.
"The development pressure had become absolutely extreme," Ms. Frey said, driving on I-80, the east-west corridor that, along with Interstates 78 and 287, opened the region to suburban-style development. "People are fighting projects all over the place. If you look in the newspapers, there are more real estate ads than news."
Not far from Parsippany, in Montville, local officials are trying to derail a proposed mountainside golf club that would be ringed by $5 million homes, all of them with stunning views of Manhattan. In Vernon Township, the northernmost corner of the Highlands, a Canadian developer, with the town's blessing, is hoping to build a $500 million, Colorado-style ski resort on Hamburg Mountain, with 1,600 condominiums, hotels, a conference center and a golf course. At the southern end of the range, in Lebanon, the Pulte Corporation has been trying to win approval for 917 houses on a former cattle ranch known as Windy Acres Farm. 
David Epstein, executive director of the Morris Land Conservancy, said open-space preservation groups like his were competing with deep-pocket developers for some of the county's most scenic parcels.
"It's a tug of war, said Mr. Epstein, whose organization has preserved 524 acres since 1997. "Land out here has become amazingly expensive." 
Using a combination of state and local open space dollars, the conservancy hopes to buy 1,000 acres in the next year.
"We've saved a lot of great places," Mr. Epstein added. "But we've lost a lot too. It's really like death by 1,000 cuts."
As far as some of its longtime residents are concerned, Montville has experienced more than a thousand cuts. In the past five years, this Morris county township's population has grown by 4,000 people, to 20,000. Many of the newcomers live in condominium town houses with names like Jade Mountain, Campagna and Rachel Gardens. One Georgian-style complex, Hunting Hills on Heritage Court, surrounds the Henry Doremus House, an 18th-century stone structure where Washington rested in 1780. A year later, French troops camped in an adjacent orchard now filled with a crop of new homes.
Fred Eckhardt, a former town mayor who has lived in and around Montville all his 69 years, remembers when much of the area was peach and apple orchards. "It was a beautiful place, very rural, but now it's just a lot of houses," Mr. Eckhardt said. 
Like many Highlands communities, Montville has been transformed by the opening of I-80 more than 20 years ago, and I-287, which was opened in 1993. Although the highways allowed residents to reach Manhattan in 30 minutes, more significantly it opened the door to the campus-style office complexes that have sprouted in formerly rural areas, fueling an even greater demand for housing. And the economic boom in the 1990's has accelerated that process. 
"Things that couldn't sell 10 years ago are going for astronomical prices," said John Rosellini, Montville's mayor. "These days, anything that's built sells instantly. The average new home sells for over a half- million dollars."
Even though I-80 was recently widened, rush-hour traffic jams have become a fact of life, and Montville's main roads are clogged in the morning and the late afternoon. The water supply, largely drawn from private wells, has reached its capacity. Its schools, prized for their academic excellence, are struggling to keep up with the influx of new students.
"We just can't live this way," Mr. Eckhardt said. 
Many of Montville's residents have also decided enough is enough. The township has the state's most aggressive land acquisition program, which voters have approved three times. Montville's open-space committee, which raises $1.3 million a year from homeowners, has bought 2,000 acres of land since 1990, much of it along the wooded ridge lines that define the municipality.
Deborah Nielson, chairwoman of the open space committee, said it was becoming increasingly difficult to buy land, which has soared to $200,000 an acre. "We have to compete with developers," Ms. Nielson said. "And frankly, there isn't much land left."
Some residents worry about the plans of a local developer, Anthony Pio Costa, who wants to an exclusive golf club on 390 acres he owns atop Waughaw Mountain. Montville officials have expressed concerned that a thirsty 18-hole golf course with 50 homes would deplete the town's aquifer. Environmentalists who dream of creating a greenway along the western edge of I-287 say the project would take away crucial habitat. 
But Mr. Pio Costa, who has lived on Waughaw Mountain for 25 years, says his Sky Top Country Club could not be more environmentally friendly. He said he would leave 90 percent of the site undeveloped, and his water experts have told him the town's underground water supply would be unaffected. He said he was frustrated by opposition to his project, which could have been twice as large under the current zoning.
"It's the same old theory," he said. "The last one in closes the door."
John Capozucca, who lives in nearby Bloomingdale, said he cringed each day as he drives past Montville on his way to his job in Parsippany, where he works as an editor of medical and scientific publications.
"One day you see the beautiful ridge lines, and he next day you can actually see the bulldozers destroying the land," said Mr. Capozucca, the unpaid chairman of the township's environmental commission. 
With 7,900 residents, Bloomingdale remains a bucolic outpost on the fringe of suburbia, although Mr. Capozucca fears for its future. Bloomingdale's residents recently approved an open-space tax, even though he and others are trying to halt the construction of 360 town houses on Federal Hill, a mountain that separates the town from I-287. The mile-square mountain, which is home to wild turkey, bears and raptors, was the site of the Revolutionary War's only attempted mutiny by Washington's troops.
"Our town looks like Wayne did 25 years ago, before all the farms got bought up and developed," he said. "I didn't move here to live in Wayne West."
The same kinds of sentiment can be heard all across the Highlands. Down in Hunterdon County, in Lebanon, Nick Corcodilos and a group of neighbors are resisting the Pulte Home Corporation's plan to build more than 900 houses a few yards from his rear deck. Mr. Corcodilos, 46, an executive recruiter who moved here five years ago, said he had already sold two Mercer County homes to escape a changing landscape. 
"People come here to escape sprawl only to have suburbia chase them out," said Mr. Corcodilos, as he trudged through the snow to show a visitor the proposed site of Windy Acres, with its spectacular, crumbling barn. "This project would really ruin any sense of living in the country."
Wilma Frey of the Highlands Coalition says 113 species of birds have been counted on the farm's 292 acres, and the threatened wood turtle has been found along its marshy fringes. Still, Mr. Corcodilos said he and other opponents were not opposed to development on the site; they just want it scaled down. To them, 145 units would be ideal.
"The land just can't support something this big," he said.
Jeff Meyer, director of land for Pulte's central New Jersey market, said the company had already reduced the project by 41 units, and pointed out that the site, adjacent to I-78, lay within an area that the state plan had designated as a development corridor.
The plan, currently being updated, seeks to encourage growth near existing infrastructure while restricting it in rural areas. The project, he said, would contain a mix of luxury housing, smaller homes for first-time buyers and 145 units that satisfy the state's mandate for affordable housing.
He said that most of the townships farther east, among them Mendham and Bernardsville, had become too expensive for middle-class families.
"This is one of the few developable sites left in the area," Mr. Meyer said. "It's a place where people want to live."
If the Highlands are to retain undisturbed expanses of forest, open fields and untainted aquifers, environmentalists say the government must make hard decisions and dictate where people can and cannot live. 
But turning the Highlands into a national park would seem doubtful during the tenure of George W. Bush, who has expressed displeasure over his predecessor's land conservation policies in the West. Still, Senator Torricelli sees hope, especially because Christie Whitman, as head of the Environmental Protection Agency, will presumably have his ear on such matters. With the greatest population density in the nation, New Jersey offers a compelling case for saving an area that is a two-hour drive for 20 million people -- or one in 12 Americans.
"Unlike Western lands, which are great distances from population centers, the Highlands are easily accessible to millions of people," he said. "I hope to make the case to President Bush that there should be prejudice shown toward New Jersey."
Environmentalists often draw parallels between national treasures like Yosemite and the Highlands. The only difference, they say, is that unlike the Highlands, Yosemite is hundreds of miles from the nation's most populous regions.
"You can't bike there from Hackensack," said Jeff Tittel, president of the New Jersey chapter of the Sierra Club. "And we don't get our drinking water from Yosemite. If we lose the Highlands, we lose our drinking water."
Although Mr. Tittel would like to see the Highlands become federal parkland, he would be relieved if the area were given the kind of status that protects the Pine Barrens, a million acres of environmentally sensitive land where development is allowed but severely restricted. 
While he and other environmentalists acknowledge Governor Whitman's aggressive push for open space, they say she failed to show leadership on the Highlands. Many say they are still disappointed that she dismantled Jim Florio's Highlands task force soon after her election in 1993. Others say the new state plan, which designates the region as a special-resource area, is simply a policy document that lacks teeth. 
"Time," Mr. Tittel says, "is not working in the Highlands favor."
A resident of Ringwood, he said he had watched over the years as some of his most cherished hiking spots gave way to condominiums and shopping centers. He is also tired of fighting a never-ending onslaught of construction projects.
Some of them are defeated, others are not. Three times he and others have fought and defeated proposals that would have obliterated Tory Rock, a local geological and historic landmark in Passaic County. 
"For every parcel of land that gets saved, we lose another three or four," he said. "It's like the Janis Joplin song: "Every new development tears a little piece of my heart out."
