HEADLINE: ON POLITICS; 
A Good Heart but Bad Sense Haunted Whitman on Race

BYLINE:  By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson reports from New Jersey for The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
Think life is unfair? Try politics. 
 No, not the unfairness of Jim McGreevey being slammed for wanting to make businesses in Woodbridge fly the American flag. If anything, the mayor deserved being slammed for not knowing that flag-waving was a crime punishable by extreme ridicule when running for governor. 
 Think instead about the fairness, or lack of it, in the fact that Governor Whitman, who wanted to show good faith and sound policy on matters of race, should be leaving office the same way she came in -- dogged by accusations of racism. 
The governor had her victory in 1993 spoiled when her campaign strategist, Ed Rollins, declared while intoxicated by the heady vapors of victory that her campaign had paid black ministers to keep their Democratically inclined parishioners home on Election Day. Mr. Rollins, suddenly sober, withdrew the boast, but the governor was on the defensive from the start.
Now her departure is similarly tainted by her connection with racial profiling. Local civil rights groups, the New Jersey Black and Latino Caucus and even the Rev. Al Sharpton, who votes in New York, are urging the Senate to reject her nomination to head the Environmental Protection Agency. The fact that profiling barely came up when she was questioned by a Senate panel last week does not mean that it has gone away in Trenton.
Yet between these two bookends, Mrs. Whitman tried to say and do the right thing on racial matters, only to get in trouble by failing to show good sense along with a good heart. She appointed more minorities to her official family than any previous governor, Democratic or Republican, including the state's first black Supreme Court justice, James H. Coleman, Jr., and the first black Secretary of State, DeForest Soaries Jr. She also put dozens of minority members in important administrative and regulatory bodies, including Herb Tate, chairman of the Board of Public Utilities and point man on the tricky business of electric utilities deregulation.
Moreover, Mrs. Whitman made frequent speeches defending her policies of affirmative action, albeit on the milder grounds of inclusiveness and diversity instead of on the ground favored by some, of justice and compensation. She developed programs to speed up brownfields development on former factory sites in the cities, and created an urban initiative that for the first time gave inner-city residents a voice in the placement and design of urban renewal projects.
Yet the Legislature's Black and Latino Caucus voted to oppose her nomination to head the environmental agency, and then the entire Democratic Caucus in the Assembly followed suit. Was that fair? The governor and her staff do not think so, but then, Mrs. Whitman's appointments and speeches do not tell the whole story. Matters of race call for a sensitive ear, not just a good heart.
The governor weathered the Rollins business, but before long she was back in hot water for pointing out that some black men boast about the number of illegitimate babies they father by different women. The term they used was "jewels in the crown," the governor said, stepping over the unwritten rule of politics that white people do not single out black behavior for criticism, although plenty of blacks, including Mr. Soaries, have made the same observations. Mrs. Whitman tried to turn the outcry that followed her statement into a lesson on tolerance by holding free screenings of "Schindler's List," a movie about the Holocaust, but was again criticized for mixing the war against the Jews with the oppression of blacks.
The complaint against the governor on racial profiling was not that she condoned it, but that she did not see the warnings that the problem was real. Members of minorities had for years been complaining that state troopers were picking on them before Mrs. Whitman took office in 1994, but the alarms should have been audible across the Delaware from the governor's office in 1996, when Superior Court Judge Robert Francis ruled that profiling was a fact of life and threw out evidence against several people arrested on the Turnpike. Yet the governor let her staff continue to deny the problem until April 1999, when the state finally admitted what many knew.
But the Black and Latino Caucus did not oppose Mrs. Whitman's nomination to the E.P.A. because of racial profiling, but because of the notorious picture -- later blown up into anti-Whitman posters -- of her frisking an innocent black youth during a police tour of Camden. Mrs. Whitman has always been a get-out-and-try-it governor, teaching fourth grade in dozens of schools and being photographed behind the wheel of the snowplow or in the cab of a locomotive or bouncing down a bike trail and paddling a kayak on the Delaware. But grinning nervously while patting down a black youth seemed to say to a lot of people that the governor lacked that little voice that says, "This doesn't look like a good idea."
As it happened, the racial profiling issue was raised only once during her confirmation hearing last Wednesday, and the Camden photo never was. Instead, the questions were mostly about corporate responsibility to environmental regulations. Yet minority rights are hardly absent from the world of environmental regulation as the people who work in the most polluted jobs and get stuck in the cheapest housing near cleanup sites have attested. So Mrs. Whitman may get a chance to prove that she has good sense to go with her good faith on matters of race.

SECTION: Section 3; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 1024 words

PERSON: Thomas E. Gallagher 

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR; 
Taking a Seat at a Tougher Game

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS 

 BODY:
WITHIN minutes of Thomas E. Gallagher's appointment as chief executive of Park Place Entertainment last October, he called Merv Griffin, the former talk show host. It had been only two days since Mr. Gallagher's charismatic predecessor, Arthur M. Goldberg, had died. 
 Mr. Griffin, who lured Mr. Gallagher into the gambling business a decade earlier from a lucrative job at corporate law firm, picked up his phone and chuckled. "You mean," he told Mr. Gallagher, "the guy who I dragged kicking and screaming into the gaming business is going to run the biggest casino company in the world?" 
 Since then Mr. Gallagher, 56, a tall, even-tempered man with a penchant for renovating his house when he is not working, has immersed himself in the particulars of running 28 casinos, with brand names like Caesars, Bally's and Hilton, in six states and five countries. That is 28,000 hotel rooms, 57,000 employees and two million square feet of slot machines, blackjack tables and baccarat rooms.
He is a stark contrast to Mr. Goldberg, who wheeled and dealed his way through mergers that turned Bally's, a leaky frigate of a company, into the equivalent of an aircraft carrier. Mr. Gallagher now must maneuver the behemoth just as the boom times that enlarged its revenue and cash flow in the 1990's appear to be fading.
One of Mr. Gallagher's first and most unenviable tasks was to deliver the bad news about a company long favored on Wall Street. In December, he warned that fourth-quarter earnings, to be announced on Tuesday, would fall to zero, compared with analysts' forecasts of 13 cents a share. He also cautioned that a $365 million deal to sell the Las Vegas Hilton could fall apart, undercutting efforts to pay down Park Place's $5.3 billion debt. The deal collapsed last week.
But for Mr. Gallagher, the bad news was temporary -- and all in a day's work.
"Unfortunately, I got my feet wet in what turned out to be a tough quarter," he said in an interview at his Las Vegas office, which has a view of the Hilton but not the prime intersection of the Strip and Flamingo Road, where Park Place casinos occupy three corners. "This is a very strong, stable company." 
Park Place was spun off from Hilton Hotels in 1998, a few years after Hilton merged with Bally's, which Mr. Goldberg had turned into a cash machine. He then bought Grand Casinos and Caesars World. With his company looming over the industry, he opened the $110 million Wild Wild West, a kitschy Gold Rush-theme casino in Atlantic City, and the $780 million Paris casino-resort hotel in Las Vegas. 
Mr. Gallagher attributed the company's fourth-quarter problems to winter storms that blanketed Atlantic City and the Midwest and kept gamblers away on New Year's weekend. He acknowledged that profits were also hurt by competition in Mississippi and by some extraordinary luck for gamblers in Las Vegas.
But he has also moved pointedly to fix problems created in the Goldberg era. When it became clear that revenue had plunged last year at the Paris, Mr. Gallagher replaced its president. 
Stephen F. Bollenbach, the chairman of Hilton Hotels and Park Place, said he picked Mr. Gallagher to run the company because of his managerial skills. But Mr. Goldberg's death at 58 also allowed Mr. Bollenbach to install his own executive at Park Place. According to several executives, Mr. Bollenbach often clashed with Mr. Goldberg, who had wanted Mr. Bollenbach's job. 
Mr. Bollenbach played down reports of friction. "The company is now strategically complete," he said. "Its value in the future doesn't depend on transactions. It depends on operations. Gallagher is suited to that."
Mr. Gallagher's ability to parachute into a new situation is clear from his resume. He graduated from Harvard Law School in 1969 and went to work for the Los Angeles-based law firm of Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher. After serving as chief counsel for then-Senator John Tunney of California for two years, he opened Gibson's London office, the first of many jobs, he said, as the firm's "fireman." He then opened an office in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, where he advised the Saudi royal family and American corporations. 
His start in gambling came in 1988, when a partner recommended him to Mr. Griffin, who had just bought the troubled Resorts International from Donald J. Trump. Mr. Gallagher eventually became chief executive of the Griffin Group, expanding its hotels and media and gambling operations, before selling Resorts in 1996 to Sun International.
Just as he was leaving Griffin, Mr. Bollenbach recruited him as general counsel for Hilton Hotels. From there, he was a natural for the Park Place job.
"Tom is an enormously quick study," said James P. Clark, a partner at Gibson. "He sees problems, he figures out solutions and he's not afraid to pull the trigger." 
Mr. Gallagher's real test may be yet to come, if an economic slump threatens Park Place.
"Gallagher faces an increasingly difficult marketplace," said Anthony Gerstein, a gambling analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. "We don't see a catalyst for the same level of growth in revenue and earnings that investors have become accustomed to in the last two years." 
He may have an ace in the company's strength in Atlantic City, which predominantly attracts day-trippers and is less vulnerable to a downturn than the expensive theme-park casinos of Las Vegas. Analysts expect revenue to grow in Atlantic City, where Park Place owns some of the most profitable casinos -- Caesars, the Atlantic City Hilton, Wild Wild West and Bally's Park Place. 
Mr. Gallagher said Park Place's geographic diversity enables it to handle weakness in any one area. One word continually crops up in his conversation about the company: discipline. 
"We're not going to scramble around acquiring for the sake of acquiring," he said. "The challenge is to be smart and disciplined in how we spend our money."
That discipline also applies to Mr. Gallagher's own financial habits. Although Mr. Griffin convinced him years ago that gambling was a growth business, Mr. Gallagher said he did not gamble. He acknowledged, though, that his wife and in-laws were "serious nickel slot players."

METRO-NORTH RIDERSHIP INCREASES

BYLINE:  By Elsa Brenner 

 BODY:
 Metro-North Railroad reported that overall ridership increased 5 percent last year, rising to 70.3 million rides, the most for any year in the rail line's 17-year history. 
The gain was not in suburban commuters going to Manhattan, but in overall riders traveling within Metro-North's service area north of New York City. A strong economy, reduced crime in Manhattan and renovations at Grand Central Terminal have helped attract more riders, Marjorie Anders, a Metro-North spokeswoman, said. "It means more people are trying the railroad as a viable alternative to auto travel within the county," she said. Elsa Brenner

HEADLINE: THE RIGHT THING; 
An Offer You Can't Refuse. Well, Maybe.

BYLINE:  By JEFFREY L. SEGLIN; Jeffrey L. Seglin teaches at Emerson College in Boston and is the author of "The Good, the Bad, and Your Business" (John Wiley & Sons). His column on business ethics appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to: righthng@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
A GOOD employee is not only hard to find but also hard to keep. With the nation's unemployment rate holding steady at 4 percent -- the lowest in more than 30 years -- it is no wonder that many employers are having a difficult time tracking down and retaining top talent. But as the offers and counteroffers fly, an ethical question arises: Once you accept a job offer, is it ethical to go back on your word because someone else makes you a better deal?
 Clearly, courting employees and making offers can be time-consuming and expensive. Anecdotal evidence from the Society for Human Resource Management, a trade group based in Alexandria, Va., suggests that employers need, on average, 50 days to fill a vacant position. The average cost of the process is $4,588, according to the Saratoga Institute, a human resources research and consulting firm in Santa Clara, Calif., although many top executive recruiting firms charge a fee of one-third of the candidate's total annual financial package. It is no wonder that an employer becomes upset when a dream candidate gets away. 
 It's perfectly reasonable for anyone to want to shop around for a new job from time to time, even if only to establish a sense of worth in the marketplace. "People do go on interviews for jobs they don't really plan on taking, but then wind up taking them," said Amanda Bennett, 48, a former Atlanta bureau chief for The Wall Street Journal, who did precisely that before signing on two years ago as managing editor of The Oregonian in Portland. In general, she likened such experiences to that of someone who goes on a blind date and ends up marrying the match, "quite to the amazement of both."
When people merely window-shop for positions, and ultimately stay put, executive recruiters miss out on hefty rewards. Still, they accept such practices. "There's nothing wrong with poking your head outside and taking a look," said Janet Tweed, chief executive of Gilbert Tweed Associates, an executive search firm in Manhattan. "But once you acquiesce and accept the offer, ethically you should take that job."
Everyone understands that during negotiations for a new job, neither side is totally forthcoming. It is a courting ritual, and either would be ill-advised to lay himself bare, warts and all, for the other to see. But, said Laura Nash, a business ethics consultant and a senior research fellow at the Harvard Business School, "they cross the line to unethical when they deliberately misstate the situation to deceive the other side."
It is not uncommon, however, for someone to accept a job offer, then receive a counteroffer from another company that is also courting him. But what should he do if his current boss walks into his office and smacks down a better offer? 
Ms. Tweed says that succumbing to such an enticement once you have made a commitment to go elsewhere is fraught with peril. The current employer, though successful in keeping you, may see your job hunt as a terrible breach of loyalty. "In the 20 years I've been doing this, I've worked for any number of companies where at the moment a counteroffer was made and accepted, the employer gave us the assignment to find someone to replace that person," she said.
It could be a no-win situation. Once a candidate goes back on his word of acceptance, he may well hurt his chances of ever working for the company that made the offer. The main reason isn't the time and expense of the courtship -- or the lost productivity of having held a crucial position open for so long, only to have to reopen the search. After a candidate steps over that line and says "yes," he has given his word, he has made a commitment, and he is ethically bound to take the position. Such breaches don't sit right and are not soon forgotten.
Of course, anyone can have a change of heart from time to time. But the time for reflection and rejection should come before accepting the job. It's the fair way to treat the company making the offer and the right way for any prospective employee to act.

HEADLINE: PRELUDES; 
On the Dole, Without the Guilt

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IT is a Thursday afternoon, and I have spent the better part of the day trying to get through to the New York State Department of Labor. I have just joined 5.7 million of my fellow Americans -- 4 percent of the working-age population -- who are unemployed.
 And, yes, I'll say it: I would love nothing more than to sit at home and receive a weekly government check for $405, the maximum for New York State. 
 My most recent ex-boyfriend, however, views unemployment insurance as "charity." 
"If I'm collecting, it means I choose not to work," he said. "If I choose not to work, it means I need to provide for myself. That's not the government's responsibility." 
His point is well taken, but I disagree (which could explain the "ex" before boyfriend). I see unemployment checks as a governmental reprieve. 
I'm not alone in my sentiments. The dot-com shakeout is affecting not only Internet companies, but also investment bankers, venture capitalists, public relations executives and business editors and writers, to name a few. Many of them are also calling their unemployment offices.
Should they be embarrassed about their situations? Should they take jobs they hate instead of money from the government? 
None of this would have ever made a difference to me as a longtime freelance writer, since independent contractors are not eligible for unemployment -- though we are more than welcome to pay the same taxes as our fully employed peers. (To be fair, we don't pay the unemployment tax.) 
But last June, I also took a senior writing position at a start-up business and lifestyle magazine, Fuse, which offered benefits that freelancers don't usually receive, like steady paychecks and health care insurance. At the end of November, after we had just published our first issue, management in San Francisco pulled the plug. The reasons had to do with the plummeting stock of the parent company, volatile markets in general and cost-cutting. 
I wasn't especially surprised; my seven colleagues weren't, either. But we were sad, not to mention annoyed. How could we have no control over our futures? How could they kill the magazine after one issue, just as we were getting into our groove? Then financial realities set in. I, for one, had never made as much money freelancing as I did as a full-time employee. I had become used to regular deposits in my bank account the second Friday of each month. Now what? 
The answer flashed before me: I'd collect unemployment! I set about finding the phone number. 
Not all of my former colleagues were as excited. "I never thought I was the type of person who'd take unemployment -- there was always a stigma attached," said the magazine's managing editor, Elizabeth Wallace, 29. 
She had no intention of applying for unemployment benefits until friends -- actors, stylists, other freelance types -- persuaded her. "They told me the government takes taxes out of paychecks for a reason, that there was money with my name on it set aside for me," she said. "I still wasn't convinced, but when I realized that I had no income, I decided to call."
Indeed, the stigma of collecting is slowly evaporating. The Labor Department would like to take some of the credit for this.
"We're completely focused on putting people back to work, in occupations that are in demand, and matching them with their job skills," said Betsy McCormack, a Labor Department spokeswoman in Albany. "The unemployment rate is so low you can get a job in any industry you want to work in." 
The department has also eliminated those mind-numbing in-person visits in favor of telephone filings. Simply punch in your vitals -- Social Security number, country of citizenship -- and then wait to speak with a real person (generally the most maddening part of the transaction, because they are usually swamped, which means you have to keep calling). Not everyone is eligible, of course: You must have worked at least two of the last four calendar quarters. You are permitted to collect benefits for a maximum of 26 weeks, but after 13 weeks you are required to accept a job if it pays at least 80 percent of the wages you made before being laid off. 
All in all, not a bad way to earn "fun and enjoyment checks," as Ann Sisco, a film editor in Los Angeles, called them. Ms. Sisco, 36, is often unemployed, as are most of her friends in the entertainment industry. "Everybody in L.A. collects in between jobs, even people in TV production whose shows are on hiatus. My friends and I call it the '$240 club,' because the most you can collect in a week is $240. No one looks down on it. That's the way it is." 
IN other industries, unemployment is not as routine. In 1998, after a restructuring, Keishi MatsumUra was laid off from his economic development job in Phoenix. It was a time when jobs were plentiful. "I felt like such a loser," applying for unemployment benefits, Mr. MatsumUra said. "But I needed the money, so I took it," even though it was only a fraction of his usual earnings. 
Mr. MatsumUra, 30, now an independent consultant, acknowledged that he would probably feel less embarrassed if he were collecting today, because more people of his age range and education level are in the same boat. Still, he said, he would rather have his old job back.
As for me, I'm not sure if I'm eligible for unemployment benefits, because I might not have worked enough hours in the quarters leading up to my claim; I filed only recently. Until I know for sure, I'll keep placing those weekly calls to the Labor Department to see what happens. 
Ms. Wallace, who will soon collect weekly unemployment checks, now looks at these benefits this way: "I need it; I have bills to pay. I feel like I've worked for it." She paused. "It's frustrating, because I can't figure out if this makes me more of a Democrat or a Republican."
Neither. It makes her a citizen.

HEADLINE: Fido, Your Table Is Ready 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
DORIE GORDON has two children, and sometimes one or the other might be a bit cranky when she comes home to her apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. But her cocker spaniel, Dudley, is all tail wags and gaiety. 
 "To come home to a smiling dog, that's worth everything," she said. "I'd definitely, definitely spend as much money as I could to keep him happy." 
 To Nestle S.A., Ms. Gordon's tender emotions -- shared, as they are, with millions of other pet owners -- are worth $10.3 billion. That's the amount the Swiss food behemoth paid last week for the Ralston Purina Company. By combining forces -- specifically the Alpo, Purina, Friskies and Meow Mix brands, among others -- Nestle stands to dominate one of the world's fastest-growing food businesses: high-end vittles for pets.
In recent years, global sales of pet food have increased 4 to 5 percent a year, compared with 2 to 3 percent growth in the total food industry. Pet food in the United States outsells fruit juice, pasta and baby food. Total pet care expenditures, which also include veterinary care and other things, amount to $28.5 billion -- up from $17 billion in 1994 -- and now exceed the value of all the toys sold in the United States.
And the arrows all seem to point up. The Pet Food Institute reports that the number of dogs has steadily increased to 58.5 million in 1999 from 53.8 million in 1981, while the number of cats shot up from 44.6 million to 72.6 million. The American Pet Products Manufacturers Association said 62 percent of the population, or 63 million households, own pets, up from 53 million in 1994.
There are many explanations. More people are living alone, more work at home and incomes have steadily risen. But the most basic reason is that 84 percent of dog and cat owners consider their pets their children, according to a survey last year by the American Animal Hospital Association.
"A dog is as much a part of American family life today as baseball and apple pie," exulted Dennis Sprung, vice president of the American Kennel Club.
Perhaps more so. "In a way, pets are less complicated than other members of the family, because their love remains unconditional throughout their entire life with you," said Alan Manevitz, a psychiatrist at the Weill Cornell Medical Center in New York City.
The slathering of love on beloved creatures is a far cry from the days when Snoopy and his brethren were banished to backyard doghouses. Not only has Rover moved inside, he can now go to day care; be covered by health insurance or join an H.M.O.; and get organ transplants or room service in expensive hotels. Doggie perfume? Sure. Might darling Socks have a taste for venison cat food? No problem.
All of which is nirvana for pet food makers. As companies offer ever-tastier and more nutritious products (or so they claim), consumers -- often feeling guilty because they fear they spend too little time with their loved ones -- line up to pay more. The product mix keeps being upgraded along with profit margins, in contrast to the trend in human foods toward cheaper generic brands. 
Another plus, says John M. McMillan, an analyst with Prudential Securities, is that pets, unlike their owners, aren't eating more and more meals away from home. "Thankfully, we're not taking our dogs to McDonald's," he said. After a pause, he added, "Yet."
The pet food industry began in the late 1800's when a London butcher tossed a failed batch of tea biscuits to an appreciative pooch, and gathered steam when Milk Bone Dog Biscuits appeared in the United States in 1908. Perhaps the industry's supreme accomplishment was convincing pet owners that the table scraps on which untold generations of household beasts had dined were dangerously unhealthy.
The pitch has since become more sophisticated, running the narrow but proven spectrum from warm and fuzzy to cute. An ad for Friskies cat food, a Nestle product, shows a tabby cat chowing down next to a tiger doing the same thing. The caption reads: "He's a Tiger at Heart. Feed Him Like One."
From the industry's perspective, the greatest thing about the appetite for healthier pet cuisine is that it is eminently exportable. Duane Exedahl, president of the Pet Food Institute, said foreign markets from Mexico to South America to the Far East offer the chance for double-digit sales in coming years. "There is an emerging middle class in many part of the world, and pet ownership kind of reflects that," he said.
Take Singapore, where retail sales of pet food have doubled over the past five years, according to the Department of Agriculture. A mix of lamb and rice is moving particularly well, because it is said to be good for doggie dermatitis in Singapore's steamy climate.
Though some think a recession could burst the pet food balloon, Mr. McMillan believes the need of so many to express tangible, edible love for their animals is unstoppable. The survey of the animal hospital group showed that 83 percent of respondents would risk their lives for their pet.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
If Earnings Depend On Investing, Watch Out

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
UNTIL 10 days ago, Yahoo had been in a class almost by itself -- a high-profile Internet concern that had figured out how to turn a profit for its shareholders. But on Jan. 10, after the market had closed, it reported that even though revenue rose 53 percent, to $311 million, in the fourth quarter of 2000 it would incur a net loss of almost $100 million for the period. By contrast, Yahoo earned $38 million in the fourth quarter of 1999.
 With the new economy slumping even more than the old one, Yahoo is facing, as it acknowledged, a tough year. But troubles in its core operations were not at the root of its fourth-quarter loss. The chief culprit was a $163 million write-down on the value of investments it had made in other companies. 
 As Yahoo goes, so go Apple Computer and Gateway, as well as older-economy companies like J. P. Morgan Chase and Nordstrom. And the list goes on. Halfway into the earnings announcement season, it is clear that the rapid slowdown in the economy is wreaking havoc on companies' results. 
But something else is putting pressure on corporate earnings today -- and to a degree never before seen -- that has little to do with the economy and even less to do with corporate operations. Yes, the economy is slowing, but that alone is not responsible for the double-digit declines in net income that so many companies are reporting. Also at work is the declining stock market that across industries is having a decidedly dampening effect on companies' earnings.
That the fortunes of the stock market can have an impact on corporate earnings is a relatively new phenomenon and a direct result of the decade-long bull market in stocks. 
As Yahoo shows. Like many other technology companies, it spent hundreds of millions of dollars in recent years investing in smaller concerns that it hoped would expand its reach, round out its business and increase its earnings. For a while, that strategy paid off, revving up its financial performance. The strategy also worked at companies like Gateway, Intel and Microsoft. 
Now, however, with the market for Internet stocks in the cellar, these investments are no longer producing gains; in many cases, like Yahoo's, they are damaging companies' results. 
But corporate investment was just one of the earnings-enhancement strategies tried by companies. Drawing from a well of creativity, they turned the market's climb to their advantage by offering millions of stock options as a substitute for paying higher wages. They also sold put options in their own stock to generate income, and they recorded gains that resulted from the rising value of assets held in the pension plans of their employees. 
In every case, reported earnings looked better than they would have if they had been based only on company operations. And each one worked only when stock prices were rising. 
"The rising stock market was a great boon to reported corporate earnings, and all of these things were buried so you had to look awfully hard to find them," said H. Bradlee Perry, former chairman of David L. Babson & Company, a money management firm, who has been an investment professional since 1952. "In past bull markets, these sources of earnings enhancement really were not available. So all these things sort of snuck up on people."
Now, however, stock prices are no longer galloping. And as many veteran money managers point out, shareholders are suddenly learning just how much of their companies' high-powered financial performance came from the bull market. At the same time, they are getting a whiff of how much their companies' earnings may be hurt in coming months if stock prices continue to stagnate.
"What every one of those things did was overstate earnings," said William Fleckenstein, president of Fleckenstein Capital, a money management firm in Seattle. "Even without economic weakness, the earnings are going down. What's going to be shocking is how fast and how sharply the earnings collapse."
CONTRIBUTING to the earnings shortfalls, of course, is the first significantly slowing economy in almost a decade. As the speed of that slowdown sinks in, Wall Street economists have been steadily paring back their forecasts for earnings this year at hundreds of American corporations. 
But there is another reason that this earnings season will look grim. With managers less able to pad results with stock-market related gains, earnings will suffer by comparison to last year, when rising stock prices were contributing handsomely to profits.
With investors tripping over themselves to get into the stock market in recent years, it is not surprising that corporate executives felt the urge to join the crowd. Intel was perhaps the biggest and most aggressive corporate investor. In its third quarter, which ended last September, Intel's portfolio was valued at $5.86 billion and produced investment and other income of $966 million.
How quickly those profits can evaporate. When Intel announced its fourth-quarter earnings on Tuesday, it said that the value of its portfolio had fallen to $3.7 billion and that it had produced $800 million in gains and interest income. More ominous, Intel said it expected gains and interest income to fall to $180 million in the first quarter of 2001, adding that it forecast "no net gains from the sale of equity investments" in the coming quarter.
Aside from making investments to propel earnings, many technology companies made a habit of lending to smaller companies, their customers, that needed money to buy equipment. Nowhere was this practice, known as vendor financing, more prevalent than in the telecommunications industry. Companies like Lucent Technologies, Nortel Networks and Qualcomm lent billions to their customers.
All went well until the stock market swooned last year and the corporate bond market froze -- leaving many of the fledgling companies that had received the financing unable to raise the additional cash they needed to keep their businesses operating. Now, with many of these companies experiencing severe financial difficulties, the companies that made the loans are being forced to write them off as bad debt.
CONSIDER the news last week from Globalstar, a company founded by Loral Space and Communications and Qualcomm to design and operate a satellite-based wireless telecommunications system. Globalstar, which has yet to make a profit, announced on Tuesday that it was suspending indefinitely the principal and interest payments on all of its debt, including its credit line and vendor financing agreements.
According to the company's regulatory filing for the third quarter, its loans from vendors totaled $765 million. Some $528 million, or 69 percent, was owed to Qualcomm. Globalstar also had a $250 million credit line with a bank that was guaranteed by other companies, including Qualcomm to the tune of $22 million. 
When Globalstar made its announcement, Qualcomm played it down, saying it would result in only a "small negative impact" to operating earnings in its quarter ended on Dec. 31. Qualcomm's stock barely budged, falling just 1 percent that day, even though the company owns 9.5 percent of Globalstar. Shares of Globalstar fell 48 percent.
Cecilia Wagner Ricci, professor of finance at Montclair State University in Upper Montclair, N.J., has studied vendor financing among telecommunications companies. "There are several problems for companies doing a lot of vendor financing," she said. "First, they are going to see increasing bad debt among their customers. At the same time, the companies they sell to are going to be spending less, because they will not have the money. I think the effect on earnings is going to be absolutely terrible." 
Making matters worse, Ms. Ricci said, many companies do not divulge how much they have lent to customers, leaving investors in the dark as to the depth of the potential problems caused by the practice. For example, while Lucent has stated how much credit it has extended to customers, some $8 billion, Cisco Systems has not. A Cisco spokeswoman said its vendor financing is very conservative. 
Rising stock prices have also plumped up corporate earnings through gains in assets held in employee pension funds. Accounting rules allow companies whose pension assets exceed their liabilities to feed the investment gains into their profits. The practice is commonplace. Although those gains certainly reflect the able administration of pension fund assets, the profits are less reliable than income from continuing operations. With stock markets at record volatility, those profits could quickly become losses. 
Thanks to the roaring stock market, pension gains became a significant contributor to profits at some companies. Northrop Grumman is a prime example. Roughly half of its earnings last year were a result of a strong stock market -- the company has 62 percent of its pension assets invested in stocks.
But last month, the company warned investors that diminished pension gains could slice $50 million, or 7.6 percent, from earnings expected by analysts in 2001. 
If taking pension gains to enhance earnings became popular in corporate America, so did using stock options as a form of employee compensation. In corporate accounts, options are "free," not deducted as an expense. By cutting the wage costs of a company, options make earnings look better than they would if it had to pay cash to employees. 
But stock options work as a form of pay only when a company's shares are rising. Now that many stocks have been crushed, many employee options are under water -- below the strike price that makes them valuable -- and some workers are beginning to demand fewer options and more cash. So corporate expenses will rise, and earnings will diminish.
Microsoft was one of the largest beneficiaries of the use of stock options in recent years. In 1999, according to Pat McConnell, an analyst at Bear, Stearns, if Microsoft had taken the $1.13 billion worth of stock options it dispensed as a business expense, the company's earnings would have come in 8 percent lower.
With the company's stock trading at about half its peak value last year, roughly 40 percent of the options that Microsoft has granted and remain outstanding are under water, based upon their weighted average prices. Not surprisingly, Microsoft executives recently warned that they might incur higher wage costs in coming years.
THERE was another type of option that helped companies bolster results: put options on their own stocks that they sold to private investors. Through such deals, companies like Dell Computer, Microsoft and Intel were essentially betting that their stock prices would not fall below a certain level within a specified time. The investors who bought the options from these concerns, for example, paid for the right to sell the shares back to the issuer at the specified price.
As these companies' share prices raced higher in the 1990's, sales of put options generated cash and never required the exchange of a single share of stock. Now, however, many stocks are below the so-called strike price of the put options, meaning that Dell and other companies may have to pay to buy back the shares covered by the puts at a higher-than-market price. In some cases, these purchases will require hard-earned cash that could otherwise be put back into the company's operations.
Consider the obligations that Dell faces because of its put option sales last year. Dell pocketed $59 million in proceeds from option sales. But if the company's stock remains at its current depressed price of $25.63 until its put options expire by September of this year, the company will have to pay $1.06 billion if the options are exercised at the average price of the range noted in the company's filings. That figure is 64 percent of Dell's net income last year. 
Baruch Lev, an accounting professor at New York University's Stern School of Business, said: "I really don't understand why would they speculate in the stock market. What you want to do is have built-in stabilizers if the market goes down that would protect you automatically, not make it worse."
MR. LEV said there was another bull-market practice that is no longer effective but that may leave companies struggling for future earnings growth: corporations' use of their own high-priced stock to make expensive acquisitions.
Between May 1999 and June 2000,Cisco Systems used its shares to make acquisitions totaling $15 billion. The purchases, a way for Cisco to get technologies needed to round out its business, had the additional impact of increasing sales and, it is hoped, future earnings. 
But with Cisco's stock down 51 percent from its peak last March, this currency is no longer as valuable. "Where is the future growth coming from now that they don't have this currency anymore?" Mr. Lev asked. If the company has to pay cash for its purchases, earnings will suffer. And if Cisco chooses to generate earnings growth from internal research, that will be more costly as well.
Without all of these financial devices, many companies may have a lot of explaining to do as they announce earnings this year.
"People thought the party was going to go on forever, and now it's over and they don't know what they're going to do," said Ms. Ricci, the professor. "Remember in high school when you went to a dance and they kept the lights down really low and when they turned the lights on at the end of the night, nobody looked as good as when the lights were low? This is what it reminds me of. Because the lights are definitely on."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: John Davenport; 
Evergreen Capital Growth Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
FOR John Davenport, running a mutual fund has had its ups and downs. His $540 million Evergreen Capital Growth fund lagged behind its large-capitalization value stock group by two percentage points in 1999, then soared past it in 2000 by more than 12 points. 
"I don't think most people realize how extreme the 1999 and 2000 markets were," Mr. Davenport said from his office in Richmond, Va., overlooking whitewater rafts bobbing down the James River. "I think the goal from here on out is not to take dramatic stands, but to grind out a return that's above the S.& P. 500 without taking a lot of risk." 
 Despite the volatility, he has kept his balance. The fund returned 15.9 percent a year, on average, for the three years ended Jan. 18, compared with 13.8 percent for the large-cap value group and 17.0 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, according to Morningstar Inc. 
 In 1999, Mr. Davenport sold off many of his technology holdings too soon, while they were still rising. But in 2000, when technology stocks collapsed, his fund had little exposure to them. 
Mr. Davenport, 37, works with four analysts to pick 35 or so blue-chip stocks for the fund. "We're classic growth-at-a-reasonable-price managers," he said. "If you look at our portfolio, you'll recognize most of the names."
The team starts with the 500 biggest of the Russell 1000 index of the largest United States companies, then eliminates about 200 cyclical, slow-growing classic value stocks like those of automobile and commodities businesses. Mr. Davenport's team also eliminates what he calls "extremely highly valued hyper-growth names, like Yahoo, that trade at 100-plus times earnings."
About 150 companies make the cut; he and the analysts closely follow about 30 stocks each, searching for a portfolio of companies that they believe can collectively sustain annual earnings growth of at least 15 percent over the next three to five years. (They expect that rate to be about double that of the S.& P. 500 for the same period.)
He expects the chosen stocks to flourish. "The Federal Reserve's very aggressive reversal is likely to provide some support for the financial markets," Mr. Davenport said of its decision on Jan. 3 to cut interest rates, "But there's no way the Fed can turn the economy around in the near term. Because earnings are likely to continue to be broadly disappointing, particularly in the first half of 2001, the markets are going to favor companies with high-quality earnings and franchise stability."
To find these companies, the team uses tools like the "DuPont model," which forecasts profitability by examining growth in sales, operating margins and capital investment. The team gathers more data during company visits, then projects each company's earnings for three to five years.
Next, Mr. Davenport and the analysts decide how much they should pay for a stock. They consider long-term earnings forecasts and the stock's trading history, compared with the records of others in its industry and the S.& P. 500.
Over all, they want the average price-to-earnings multiple of the portfolio companies to be in line with the S.& P. 500 over the last five years. Mr. Davenport starts trimming a position as a stock approaches 120 percent of his target valuation, and he generally dumps shares after several disappointing quarterly earnings reports. Because the managers shift the weightings of portfolio stocks as valuations change, annual turnover averages 60 percent. 
Mr. Davenport recently bought more shares of Tyco International, calling it "one of the most under-followed and misunderstood global businesses because it has emerged so rapidly over the last eight years."
A series of acquisitions, including AMP in 1998, has made Tyco the pre-eminent player in the electronic connector business, he said. "It's one of the most stable and attractive areas of technology," he said, "because it increases as technology spending increases but doesn't have the volatility of other electronic components." Tyco also has big businesses in disposable health care products, like syringes, and in alarms and sprinklers for the fire protection and security industries, he added.
Over all, he predicts earnings growth of 22 percent, annualized, over three years. He originally bought shares in July 1994 at an average of $6; they now trade at $61.13. He figures that the stock could hit $80 in 12 months.
Another favorite is the First Data Corporation, a transaction processor based in Atlanta that owns Western Union. He calls Western Union's domestic business a "mature, stable cash cow" but expects its international business to grow 50 percent a year over the next three years. First Data is also a huge processor of credit card transactions.
"It's a play on the ongoing transition from paper money and checks to electronic transactions," he said, adding that he saw much room for growth.
He bought shares in March 1999 at an average of $42; the stock now trades at $55.63. His 12-month price target is $65. 
MR. DAVENPORT bought shares of Newell Rubbermaid, formerly Newell, at $30 in December 1999, after they tumbled because of problems with Newell's acquisition of Rubbermaid earlier that year. The company, based in Freeport, Ill., owns a stable of household products, including Sanford writing instruments.
Difficulties in integrating the Rubbermaid acquisition were compounded by rising prices of resins used to produce plastic, he said. A new chief executive, Joseph Galli, took over this month, and resin prices are dropping, Mr. Davenport said, adding, "I believe that for the most part, they are finally realizing the benefits" of the Rubbermaid deal. 
Expecting earnings to grow 11 percent a year for the next three years, he predicts that the stock, now at $27.13, will reach $31 within 12 months.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 28, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about investing in the Evergreen Capital Growth fund misstated the three-year annualized return through Jan. 18 for both the fund and its category, large-capitalization value funds. The figures were also incorrect in the adjoining chart. The fund returned 16.7 percent, not 15.9, and the category returned 8.9 percent, not 13.8. 
The article also misstated the three-year annualized return of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index over the same period. It was 13.4 percent, not 17.0.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
The Parties Are Over. So, What's Next?

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
IN this opening weekend of the Bush administration, the parlous economy makes the inauguration less festive. Stock market shock mutes the music, and bad news about the economy gets more attention these days than good news. Rarely in past slowdowns have there been so many warnings that a recession is just ahead, if not already upon us.
 Not that the Bush team minds the cold water. Somber recession talk on Inauguration Day makes it easier to blame the departing Democrats if a recession does develop this year. Paul O'Neill, the designated Treasury secretary, raised the "R" word at his Senate confirmation hearing last week. "There is no doubt that we are experiencing a slowdown," he said, and a few minutes later spoke of the "lingering uncertainty about whether this is an inventory correction or the possible unfolding of a recession." 
 The case for recession is strong. Manufacturing is already contracting, and companies in every industry are shedding workers. The stock market, sapped of its exuberance, is sapping consumers in turn. Consumer confidence plunged in December and is falling again in January, according to the University of Michigan's consumer surveys. The downsizing announcements and the stock market are making Americans nervous about their jobs, income and wealth -- and, as a result, more cautious about spending, says Richard T. Curtin, director of the Michigan surveys.
Reflecting the spreading pessimism, the nation's most prominent forecasters are regularly scaling back their estimates of economic growth in 2001. And companies everywhere, having stockpiled merchandise last fall in anticipation of strong sales, find that they cannot sell all they had ordered. What happens next to the economy may hang on what these companies do. If they stop ordering while they sell off some of their enlarged inventories, recession will surely follow.
So far, they have not stopped ordering, although there has indeed been a "slowdown in order rates," as Mr. O'Neill put it last week. For all their nervousness, people are still borrowing and buying. Retail sales over the Christmas season may not have shown the great improvement everyone had expected and yearned for, but sales were not weaker than the good Christmas of 1999. When summer finally comes, the worst of the slowdown may have passed -- without a recession.
The odds are against such a favorable outcome. But there is just enough good news to keep hope alive. Stock prices, for example, appear to have stabilized -- for the moment -- after the Federal Reserve's unexpected slash in interest rates Jan. 3. Despite the job-cut announcements, the unemployment rate is still low. Home construction, a pillar of the economy, was strong in December. And falling rates have set off a new round of mortgage refinancing, which means families are borrowing more against their homes without raising their monthly mortgage payments. The extra money becomes available for spending.
THEN there is capital spending. The 1990's drew much of their prosperity from the huge investments that corporate America made in machinery and equipment. And now the best hope of avoiding a recession is more strong investment. That does not normally happen in hard times. Businesses, like consumers, cut back. But the investment boom came mainly from spending for computers and software as companies pushed to keep up with advances in information technology. Now the hope is that the same drive will keep investment strong, despite the slowdown.
Dale W. Jorgenson, a Harvard economist and the president of the American Economic Association, offered just such an outlook this month in an address at the association's annual conference in New Orleans. As semiconductors double in speed every 18 months and fall in cost, companies hasten to upgrade their equipment, he said. And that investment will stave off a recession.
Maybe. Faster chips stimulate investment, but mostly when a new product emerges to take advantage of the speed. The advent of spreadsheets drew an investment rush. So did desktop publishing. "We always need new software to justify faster chips," said William Dudley, director of domestic economic research at Goldman Sachs.
The chips are still doubling in speed every 18 months. Moore's Law still holds, and any number of executives swear they will keep spending through a slowdown just to catch up with the new information technology already out there. That might be enough to stave off a recession, even if new software fails to materialize to stimulate investment. 
So hold the pessimism, and the optimism. Whatever the politics, the slowdown so far is still a slowdown.

HEADLINE: Favorite Feasts: Good Brands Hit by Bad Luck 

BYLINE:  By RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
VULTURE investing may be an obscure financial discipline, but the bottom-fishing capitalists who engage in it come into contact with a surprising number of consumer brand-name companies. And they typically know which ones are in trouble long before it becomes apparent to the average person.
 Vultures are fond of companies with powerful brands because their assets are easier to value and, if necessary, to sell off. Over the last decade, vulture investors have feasted on the carcasses of the parent companies of the Vail ski resort; retailers like Barneys, Bloomingdale's and Macy's; and Continental Airlines, to name a few. In recent months, the roster of troubled companies has grown to include Polaroid, Trans World Airlines, Vlasic Foods and Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts -- and it is on the rise. 
 Vulture capitalists often have an easy time spotting a company in trouble. One tipoff occurs when stocks are trading at $5 or less. More important, they monitor the less-visible world of junk bonds or bank loans, watching for debt that trades at severe discounts.
Trouble usually turns up first in the bank loan market. "Banks get information from companies on a weekly basis, so often they are the first to sell out," said Marc Lasry, senior managing director at Amroc Investments, a brokerage firm that specializes in trading the bank loans of distressed companies.
Consider Xerox, whose stock fell to $3.75 in December and now is at less than $8. That price implies concern among stockholders about the company's future. But the prospects may be even worse than that price suggests. Xerox has a $7 billion revolving line of credit that trades at just 60 cents on the dollar, according to Amroc. If Xerox falters, bank claims must be satisfied before stockholders get anything, so the deep discount at which the loan trades implies a chance that shareholders could be wiped out.
The range of companies with securities at low levels is a bad sign for the economy, Mr. Lasry said: "Things are worse than people believe. In the distressed debt market we see things as they really are."

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR; 
From the Grave Dancer, Rhyme and Contrary Reason

BYLINE:  By Riva D. Atlas 

 BODY:
Friends of the Chicago investor Sam Zell know not to expect the ordinary season's-greetings card at the end of the year. For six years now, a favored few have received an unusual gift from him -- an elaborate, sculptured music box meant to illustrate some theme in the markets that reflects the contrarian bent of Mr. 
Zell, whose taste for troubled or bankrupt companies earned him the nickname "Grave Dancer."
 This year's music box, which bears the legend "No Free Lunch," plays Mr. Zell's version of "What Kind of Fool Am I?" 
 The lyrics include: "What fools these mortals be, dreams of new economy. Consuming capital insatiably. How high grows a tree?" 
Mr. Zell's staff began work on the music boxes soon after Thanksgiving; they were mailed this month. Writing the lyrics, typically parodies of popular tunes, can be a challenge, said Peter Szollosi, Mr. Zell's creative director. "Often, Wall Street words are difficult to sing," he said. Riva D. Atlas

HEADLINE: BUSINESS: DIARY; 
Seller's Market for Spokesmen

BYLINE:  By Julie Dunn 

 BODY:
Corporate America may be downsizing again, but it is still looking for a few good spokesmen and spokeswomen. 
More than a few, actually.
 The Council of Public Relations Firms, a New York-based trade association, says the industry is expected to grow at double-digit rates for the next three years. "Public relations is traditionally seen as recession-proof," said Sarah Drennan, vice president of the council. Even companies cutting jobs, she said, "are still demanding public relations services." 
 Ms. Drennan said there was such demand that employers must look for nontraditional public relations candidates with transferable skills. "You need to find new sources of talent or we will begin to cannibalize off each other," she said.
 Julie Dunn

HEADLINE: DATABANK: JANUARY 15-19; 
Looking Beyond All the Bad News

BYLINE:  By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN 

 BODY:
Earnings results poured in last week and, for the most part, companies met expectations that had been sharply lowered by the weakening economy. 
 There were some noticeable disappointments, like Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing and J. P. Morgan Chase, as well future profit warnings from the bellwether companies Intel and Caterpillar. 
 For the most part, though, investors shook off the bad news, buoyed by good results from I.B.M. and Citigroup and the expectation that the Federal Reserve would move to cut rates in the wake of a report of the biggest decline in manufacturing activity in more than two years and signs of moderating inflation. 
 The major stock indexes finished up for the week. The Nasdaq was at 2,770.38, up 143.88 points or 5.5 percent. The S. & P. 500 ended at 1,342.54, up 24.22 points or 1.8 percent. The Dow industrials also advanced, ending at 10,587.59, up 62.21 points, or 0.6 percent.
 Treasury prices rallied early in the week as investors fled to quality in the face of a looming default by two giant California utilities. By Friday, those concerns had eased, but the yield on the 10-year Treasury still stood at 5.16 percent, down from 5.24 percent a week earlier. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: Unions Hit Lowest Point In 6 Decades 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The percentage of American workers belonging to unions fell last year to 13.5 percent, its lowest point in six decades.
 In releasing its survey of union membership last week, the Bureau of Labor Statistics also found that the number of union members declined by 200,000 last year to 16.3 million, a discouraging development for the labor movement at a time it is straining to reverse the decline. 
 Economists offered several explanations for the decline, including retirements by union members, layoffs of many unionized workers because of foreign competition and the failure of unions to organize enough additional members to offset such losses.
"There are still many large economic forces acting against labor's holding on to the numbers it has," said Tom Juravich, director of the labor studies center at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. 
Last year's membership decline was a blow to union leaders after they had boasted of an apparent turnaround in 1999. That year union membership climbed by 240,000, its largest increase in more than a decade. In addition, the percentage of workers in unions remained steady at 13.9 percent, giving unions hope that they had arrested a steady decline in that percentage.
Despite small jumps and declines from year to year, the overall unionization rate has fallen compared with recent decades. Last year's 13.5 percent unionization rate was down from 20 percent in 1983 and a peak of 35 percent in the 1950's. 
For unions, one embarrassing aspect of the report was that the membership among private-sector workers fell to 9 percent, down from 9.4 percent in 1999. That has left unions with strong bargaining leverage in a handful of industries, including aircraft, steel and autos. 
In contrast, membership among government workers rose to 37.5 percent from 37.3 percent. About 9.1 million of the nation's union members work in the private sector, while 7.1 million are government workers.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. sought to put the best face on last year's slide, noting that membership was still up 150,000 from three years ago. Leaders of the labor federation said much of the drop stemmed from the loss of 160,000 manufacturing jobs in 2,000.
The decline came after John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., had prodded unions to invest more money and personnel toward organizing more members. Last year, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. said, unions organized 400,000 new members, compared with less than 100,000 in 1995, the year Mr. Sweeney became the federation's president.
But Mr. Sweeney said that for unions to add members on a net basis, after accounting for retirements and layoffs, they needed to recruit 500,000 to one million new members each year.
Leo Troy, professor of labor economics at Rutgers University, voiced skepticism that American unions would ever substantially increase their numbers. Professor Troy noted that the most rapid job growth was in fields like financial services and high technology where unions have little presence. He added that globalization was causing layoffs and even plants closings at many unionized operations, which often have higher wage and benefit costs than foreign competitors. 
"What happened last year is a continuation of a long-term decline in the unionization rate," Professor Troy said. "I don't think unions can turn it around. We've had the most favorable pro-union administration in office since President Carter, and maybe since President Johnson, and the unionization rate has declined steadily. And now there will be a new administration that's not going to be very supportive of unions."
Union officials were more upbeat. Several labor leaders asserted that unions organized fewer members last year because they threw so much money, energy and manpower into electoral politics. These leaders said labor would step up its organizing efforts, partly because the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has set organizing goals for its member unions.
Labor leaders said they had grown increasingly successful in organizing low-paid workers, like janitors and home health aides, as well as high-paid professionals, including doctors and psychologists. But such gains have been offset by the steady erosion of employment in labor's core industries, like autos and steel. 
"What's clear is that to stop any future decline organizing needs to stay absolutely on the front burner," Professor Juravich said. "There is no substitute for organizing."

HEADLINE: Searching for the Right Words For Saying 'Gotcha' in Turkey 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Jan. 20 

 BODY:
You need a scorecard to keep track of the nearly two dozen corruption investigations unfolding in Turkey these days. Fortunately, the country's law enforcement officials conveniently coin names for each new inquiry. 
 Some are just punchy, like Hurricane, Matador, Parachute and Storm. Others are related to the subject. And where American newspapers often attach the suffix gate to major investigations, the Turkish authorities prefer Operation in front of another word. 
 So there is Operation Harvest, an investigation of fictitious exports of agriculture products, and Operation Buffalo, an inquiry into allegations that frozen buffalo was sold as beef. Operation Dirty Curtain involves possible fraud in the government theater system. 
Operation Whale is, fittingly, the biggest inquiry to date. So far, 85 people have been arrested, including government officials, in an alleged scheme to receive tax credits by falsifying export records. 
The people who think up the names seem to be working overtime these days because Turkish authorities are engaged in a big anticorruption drive.
About 400 people have been detained as part of 21 corruption investigations going on across the country, according to a tally this week in the Turkish Daily News.
The biggest impact has come from Operation Hurricane, which revolves around allegations of corruption in the banking industry. News reports and fears about an imminent industry collapse contributed to a financial crisis that sent the Istanbul stock market plunging last November and required an emergency bailout from the International Monetary Fund. 
During the last week, Operation White Energy has become a headline staple. It reportedly focuses on officials in the Ministry of Energy and Natural Resources who may have been bribed to approve contracts. 
The investigation led to a dispute between politicians and the military over who initiated it and how far it will reach into the ministry. It also threatens to cast a pall over construction of a natural gas pipeline between Russia and Turkey. 
There seems to be a consensus among the authorities that an investigation needs to reach a certain prominence before it earns a name. For instance, allegations this week that a new police chief blew the whistle on colleagues who take bribes is only known as Bribery Bag because the scope is unclear. 
The bag part of the name comes from a story that when the chief arrived at his new job, a subordinate put a bag of money on his desk and suggested that he take his share. 
"The names come from the police and the prosecutors and sooner or later you become fascinated with them," said Yavuz Baydar, a Turkish newspaper columnist and television host.
The names are a mixed blessing to Turkey's good-government types. As the Federal Bureau of Investigation and American military know, people pay attention to something with a catchy name, like Operation Desert Storm. Along the same line, scandals with names increase public awareness of corruption.
"One of our goals is to increase awareness of corruption," said Ozdem Sanberk, director of the Turkish Economic and Social Studies Foundation. "If you name the investigations, of course people talk about it. It stays in their memories." 
But many of those caught up in the high-profile investigations are stigmatized without ever facing formal charges. 
Still, the foundation Mr. Sanberk runs is in the midst of an analysis of corruption and when the results of interviews with 3,000 people nationwide are unveiled in March, he would love to earn a nickname. Maybe something like Operation Clean Sweep.

HEADLINE: January 14-20; 
Power Blackouts Afflict California

BYLINE:  By James Sterngold

 BODY:
 After weeks of near misses, it happened: on Wednesday and Thursday, power utilities had to switch off the lights temporarily across a broad swath of central and northern California because they simply ran out of electricity. The state's utilities have been struggling with power shortages, which grew more severe because of some generator shutdowns and a financial crisis caused by soaring prices on the overheated wholesale market. 
 Several million people and businesses lost power for about an hour at a time and had to figure out how to cope in the unpredictable environment. But no puzzle was greater than the one faced by the governor and the legislature. A bill was passed that made the state a major buyer of power; this will temporarily help the utilities, but the lawmakers did not craft a comprehensive solution that will cover billions of dollars in losses and, most important, keep the lights on in the nation's largest state. James Sterngold

HEADLINE: Harlem Renaissance 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 I take issue with John Tierney's Jan. 16 Big City column, "Politicians Stand in Way of Harlem." The groundwork for Harlem's revival was laid by collaborations between community-based nonprofit developers, for-profit developers, New York City, nonprofit housing intermediaries, private lenders, foundations, block associations and tenants' associations. 
 These developments transformed neighborhoods, creating an environment where moderate-income rental and homeownership developments could be successfully marketed.
More recently, brownstone development programs have resulted in an increase in homeownership opportunities. Harlem's public officials understand that this community needs housing that is affordable. If this goal is not addressed, New York's economic growth may suffer.

KEVIN MCGRUDER
New York, Jan. 16, 2001

The writer is the former chief operating officer, Abyssinian Development Corporation.

HEADLINE: A Tribute To King Focuses on Laborers 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT WORTH 

DATELINE: GARRISON 

 BODY:
FOR five years, the Desmond Fish Library here has been holding educational programs about race and American history in honor of Martin Luther King's Birthday. This year, the library chose to focus on labor issues, including one that is current for many residents of Westchester and Putnam Counties: the working conditions of Hispanic day laborers.
 "It's a huge economic justice issue," said Stephen Kent, a Garrison resident and library trustee who organized the event as part of a series on civil rights history in the Hudson Valley. "These people come into Garrison to landscape our yards and renovate our houses, but they don't live here. And many of them still lack the most basic rights and workplace protections." 
 Last Sunday night, some 75 guests attended a potluck dinner, listened to a Latin band called Los Afortunatos and a lecture on labor history, and watched a new documentary on the circumstances of local immigrant workers produced by Voices From History, a videography team based in Peekskill.
The event's title, "Looking Backward: Civil Rights and Labor Issues 2000-1864," comes from an 1888 utopian novel by Edward Bellamy titled "Looking Backward," Mr. Kent said. In the novel, a man is transported forward to the year 2000, when labor struggles and economic inequality have been eliminated. 
The featured speaker was David Montgomery, a professor emeritus of history at Yale University, who described a little-known strike at the West Point Foundry in Cold Spring in 1864. 
The strike began on March 10, 1864, when 150 unskilled workers began marching through the plant, demanding raises. The plant usually had 300 to 400 workers, but under the pressure of the Civil War, which was then raging in Virginia, 1,100 workers were working overtime to make cannons for the Union army. 
Federal troops were quickly called to quell the strike, and some workers may have been killed, Mr. Montgomery said.
The strike was partly inspired by William Sylvis, a labor leader who began touring the Hudson Valley after the New York City conscription riots of 1863. The strike and others like it eventually helped lead to better working conditions and an eight-hour work day, Mr. Montgomery said.
A few years later, Mr. Sylvis became one of the first labor leaders to urge white workers to make common cause with blacks, Mr. Montgomery added.
Civil rights have come a long way since then, but Americans are still a long way from the utopia Edward Bellamy imagined, Mr. Kent told the crowd.
Besides their poor living conditions, many local day laborers have been cheated of their wages, said David Loretan, a member of the Hispanic Employees Labor Project at St. Anne's Parish in Ossining who attended the library event. The project, founded by the Rev. Edward Byrne, is one of the groups featured in the new documentary, which was shown at the library for the first time last Sunday night and is titled "The Newest Immigrants." 
In one case, five workers who helped build a house in Putnam Valley were cheated out of $7,000, Mr. Loretan said. In another, a laborer fell and broke his back, and the homeowner is refusing to take any responsibility. The Labor Project has tried to help many of these workers, and in some cases has taken employers to court to recoup their wages, he added. 
The legacy of Dr. King is relevant to these workers, Mr. Loretan said, because their civil rights have been violated. 
"The employers don't treat them as human beings," he said. "They take advantage of the fact that they can't speak English, they don't know the law and they don't know their rights."

GRAPHIC: Photo: David Montgomery, left, with Stephen Kent, at the King program. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)
