HEADLINE: NOTICED; 
Living the Edited Life: The Materialism of Scaling Back

BYLINE:  By RUTH LA FERLA 

 BODY:
IRENE ALBRIGHT longs for a life of stylish, self-imposed austerity. "I've always looked yearningly at movies and magazines that show you a room beautifully lit, with nothing in it but three magazines on a black coffee table," she said plaintively. "I've looked at those pictures a thousand times," added Ms. Albright, the owner of Imelda's Closet, a rental showroom clotted, as its name suggests, with handbags, suits and shoes. "But each time I've had to ask myself, 'God, how do people live like that?' "
 Her desire for a pared-down refuge and life to match mirrors that of many of her contemporaries, women, and not a few men, whose vision of Eden is replete with material comforts, yet so rigorously edited that it seems to contain almost nothing at all. They are the subscribers to new women's magazines like Real Simple and O: The Oprah Magazine, which encourage readers to carve out breathing room in hectic lives. They are consumers of products promising to lift one's mood and soothe the soul, like aromatic candles and feng shui fountains. And they are the devoted readers of the popular authors Elaine St. James ("Simplify Your Life") and Sarah Ban Breathnach ("Simple Abundance"), who advocate clearing life's clutter in order to leave space for reflection and other uplifting pursuits. 
 At a time when many Americans feel queasy about their wealth and simultaneously fearful lest it vanish in an impending recession, the idea of a streamlined life is seductive indeed. A recent Yankelovich Monitor survey of 2,500 Americans reported that 76 percent "are increasingly looking for a way of simplifying their lives." 
Ministering to them is an army of publishers, admen and merchants who know a promising market when they see one. A recent ad for Dockers pants, for example, shows a mother and child, the mother's eyes shut in blissful reverie. "Wouldn't it be nice," reads the copy "if we could all live like children? No calendars, no meetings, no bills?" The California Closet Company's most recent ad features a woman wearing a monastically plain-looking long skirt and sweater, posed in front of a closet emptied of all but the company's organizational systems. 
Sound familiar? It ought to, to anyone who remembers the Gap ads of the early 1990's, with their semi-celebrity models wearing pocket T-shirts and other wardrobe basics. The austere fashions of that time, often in black or white, coincided with the styles of an earlier economic downturn, and a desire to repent for the conspicuous consumption of the 1980's. Then, too, a simplicity movement sprang up, drawing inspiration from a 1993 book, "Voluntary Simplicity," and a periodical, the Tightwad Gazette, and fueled by the downsizing of hundreds of thousands of white-collar jobs. True believers took new positions at half their old salaries, sold big homes to move into rental apartments and traded down from Audis to Nissan Sentras. 
But there's a difference between the simplicity then and the simplicity now. Scaling back today takes a lot more purchasing power. Fostering balance and serenity requires the acquisition of a flood of goods. Spawned, though it was, by earlier waves of antimaterialism, the new simplicity is a call to guilt-free consumption, a movement that is material to its core. 
"Simplicity is the hot buzzword," said Irma Zandl, the president of the Zandl Group, a New York consumer research firm, who views the notion of getting back to basics as little more than a sales pitch. "Marketers," she said, are pushing the concept "that to be more simple you have to buy more stuff." 
"People are looking for balance in their lives," she added. "But the bottom line is that they're looking in a way that does not involve a significant lifestyle sacrifice." 
In the winter 2000-1 issue of SoHo Style, Deepak Chopra, the celebrity promoter of self-enlightenment, contributes an essay, "In Praise of Indulgence." O, the phenomenally successful creation of Oprah Winfrey (it has sold as many as three million copies a month since its debut in April), counsels scaling back and getting in touch with one's authentic self, but remains all the while a vociferous cheerleader for the lush life. 
In the January issue, sandwiched between uplifting features like "Are You Listening to Your Life?" in which subjects boast of ditching flourishing careers to find their bliss, there are catalogue-style editorial pages promoting indulgent purchases like Mont Blanc fountain pens ($350) and cashmere sweaters ($350 to $425). The magazine is a hymn to psychic self-invention -- and not less, a "look book" lavish with Ms. Winfrey's favorite things. They include an Hermes teacup ($135) because, as Ms. Winfrey croons in the caption, "I've discovered tea tastes better when it's sipped from a pretty cup." Elsewhere readers are urged to "jump start their spirit" by jettisoning unproductive habits -- and products. But it's hard to miss the implication that starting life fresh requires an array of fresh purchases.
"In this country, the longstanding solution to getting what you want is to buy something," said J. Walker Smith, president of Yankelovich Partners, a market research firm. "With such a tradition, it stands to reason that if what you want is simplicity, the knee-jerk response is, Find something to buy." 
A harsh statement, perhaps, but one with which Judy Jennings-Moritz, a Northern California real estate broker, would not disagree. Late last year, Ms. Jennings-Moritz, 61, and her husband traded the rambling house they had lived in for a more modest dwelling, to relieve themselves of financial pressure. Their deliberate downsizing left Ms. Jennings-Moritz feeling elated but somewhat incomplete. "I had the peace of mind I have prayed about for years," she recalled, revealing, however, that no sooner had she moved than she purchased the four-poster bed and plush carpet of her dreams. "I will be buying other furniture, too, so in a way I will be expanding," she acknowledged gaily. "But to me, simplifying is getting what I want, not compromising with something that just came to me."
More skeptical people than she have likewise succumbed to the blandishments of streamlining. Tony Peet is a freelance writer who left San Francisco several years ago for the calm of Pacific Grove, near Monterey. A former Madison Avenue advertising executive, Mr. Peet, 43, scoffs at the new simplicity's marketers, a highly diverse group that includes Ms. Winfrey, International Coffees and Bliss, the spa and purveyor of beauty balms and potions. 
"What these people are really doing is selling spiritual materialism," Mr. Peet chided, confiding in the next breath that he, too, had occasionally taken the bait. "My own first step toward simplifying was to buy a Ford Explorer," he said with a rueful laugh. More recently, he enlisted Christy Best, a professional organizer with a Web site called Clutterbug.net, to excavate his closet and bring some calm to his life. He shrugged off the folly of having paid Ms. Best to do a job he could just as easily have done himself. During a similar round of soul searching and streamlining several years ago, he found himself in California's Big Sur at the Esalen Institute, the fabled center for self-actualization. At the time, "we all wanted the pure, unencumbered life," he said of his fellow seekers, adding, "so we stowed our stuff in storage lockers." 
The publishers of O, Real Simple and Hush, a Hearst publication subsidized in part by California Closets, have embraced simplicity as a multipurpose mantra, one that subsumes both the latest wave of Asian-tinged spirituality and more recent Western strains of antimaterialism. A far less loaded word than spirit or soul, simplicity "is sort of like a Rorschach," said Carrie Tuhy, the managing editor of Real Simple. "It means many things to many people."
The magazine editors interpret simplicity as "an expensive stripping away of detail," said Paul H. Ray, the co-author with Sherry Ruth Anderson of "The Cultural Creatives" (Harmony Books, 2000), about people who value social justice and the environment more than getting and spending. "It's 'simplicity' in the way that the Bauhaus was about simplicity -- in other words, only an arbitrary style."
Ms. Tuhy of Real Simple sees no contradiction in promoting the kind of simplicity that can be bought. "We're not preaching a monastic life," she said. "We're talking about the edited life." The magazine's mission is to "help readers pare down in order to get to the things they really want to do," she continued. "One of those things, we presume, is to be good to yourself," she added. 
To judge from the proliferating temptations featured by the editors, from weightlifting gloves to cashmere blankets to pricey Richart chocolates, being "good to yourself" is code for self-indulgence. "But that's O.K.," Ms. Tuhy said brightly. "This is not sackcloth and ashes time. This is enlightenment living."
Her argument speaks to Ms. Albright, the fashion showroom owner. A move last month forced her to winnow her possessions to a few essentials that could be shoehorned into an 800-square-foot space. "I'm living in three little boxes and that's liberating," she said. "Now, I have time for myself." 
But she has also found time to purchase a gleaming glass-topped dining table and sisal rug. She confides she has her eye on a large flat-screen television and an even larger glass-topped dining table. "I hope I can stick with the basics," she said, gazing at rooms that to her mind plainly cried out for embellishment. "It's just there's no telling how long this mood will last."

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS; 
Sublime Vegetables For a Demanding Niche

BYLINE:  By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Davenport Institute for Public Policy at Pepperdine University. His column on the Main Street economy appears on the third Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to grassrts@nytimes.com.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
SOME entrepreneurs dream of ruling Wall Street while others imagine themselves as Hollywood moguls or as the next Bill Gates. But for Harbhajan Singh, founder of Samra Produce here, the quest has been to become America's "king of okra." 
 Raised and educated in India's fertile Punjab region, Mr. Singh, 41, came to Southern California in 1985 as a trained agronomist with a master's degree in economics. As a member of the agricultural Jat caste, it was natural for him to think about growing and selling food. He saw California as ideal for growing the kind of Indian specialties -- okra, eggplant, bitter melon, beans -- that he ate as a child. 
 "In Punjab, you can grow anything," Mr. Singh said. "It's like California."
Once he arrived, and with $500 borrowed from his family, Mr. Singh started buying vegetables from wholesalers and selling them to local Indian markets and restaurants from the back of a pickup truck. In the mid-1990's, he opened a 1,400-square-foot stall at the 7th Street Produce Market in downtown Los Angeles and started a small farm in Delano, in the Central Valley. But he found that because of the climate, the region grew only inferior versions of the okra and other produce traditionally used in South Asian kitchens.
Mr. Singh said he lost that farm, falling heavily into debt, but he eventually found his ideal spot in a hot, dry farming area near Indio, southeast of Palm Springs. Relying largely on credit from his customers, he slowly built Samra into a substantial business. His 150-acre farm grows okra -- a vegetable with a subtle, eggplant-like taste that also makes it popular in Southern dishes like gumbo -- as well as chiles, opo squash and daikon radishes. He also buys from other local farmers who produce vegetables suitable for the growing Indian, Pakistani and Bangladeshi immigrant market.
THAT area grows the best okra in the world," Mr. Singh asserted, sitting in his spacious warehouse in the sprawling produce market. As the business has grown, his space has grown to 18,000 square feet. 
Being the best, he said, has always been his obsession. By producing only the highest-quality produce and delivering it quickly, he could lead a market that was largely ignored by others. 
"At first, no one would listen to me," said Mr. Singh, who arrives at the market at 5 a.m. daily and usually stays past 4 p.m. "People ignored me. But when I delivered the best quality, they got confidence. Now they see I really am the king of okra."
Virtually a one-man operation in the mid-1990's, Mr. Singh's business now employs eight people. Last year, it had sales of more than $10 million, five times the 1998 total. He sells his produce -- some of it delivered in a company-owned 18-wheeler -- as far away as Vancouver, British Columbia; Toronto; Chicago; the New York region; and London, where there are large Indian populations.
His success reflects a broader reality in the nation's produce market. As ethnic populations -- and interest in ethnic food -- grow across the country, so do the opportunities for entrepreneurs like Mr. Singh, said Richard Meruelo, president of the Alameda Produce Market, which owns the 300,000-square-foot 7th Street market, built in 1919.
Mr. Meruelo also owns 600,000 square feet of space in the adjacent area and plans an additional half-million by 2002. He said that most of his clients were not the big produce companies that had been in Los Angeles for generations, but rather Asians and Latinos who ran small businesses with 400 to 20,000 square feet of space and sales of less than $2 million annually. They concentrate on traditional ethnic foods -- Thai, Korean, Chinese, Mexican, Salvadoran, Caribbean -- that are consumed by immigrants and an increasing percentage of the native-born population. 
"The growth in this business comes primarily from Asians and Hispanics who know what sells well in their own communities," said Mr. Mereulo, himself the son of Cuban immigrants. "The key is to specialize in something."
Supermarket chains like Lucky's and Ralphs, he said, "know how to sell an orange to the mass market, but these guys sell a special product that is not mainstream."
Immigration from India and elsewhere in South Asia has been rising steadily over the last 40 years; the number of South Asians in the United States and Canada is now estimated at 1.4 million to 6 million, concentrated in several large urban areas.
Wholesalers like Anuj Patel, who owns Darpan Vegetables in Maspeth, Queens, say that until they met Mr. Singh, it was difficult to acquire a consistent supply of high-quality okra and other vegetables used in Indian kitchens. "People can tell the difference," said Mr. Patel, an Indian immigrant, who says his business has tripled since two years ago, when he began buying produce from Mr. Singh. "The radishes he grows, the okra, it's like from back home. You have other growers but the quality is not there."
Such concern about vegetables may seem a bit unusual to many Americans. But Mira Advani, a leading Indian food critic in Los Angeles, pointed out that many South Asians are vegetarian. Quality takes on a greater significance because produce makes up the bulk of their diet -- the base for sauces, stews and soups, she said.
"Indians are very picky about their vegetables, their okra and their eggplant," said Ms. Advani, a native of India. "Their okra has to be the best -- small and firm. Nothing else will do."
Such demands suit Mr.Singh well. Now the self-proclaimed "king of okra" hopes to enlarge his kingdom: he plans to start a farm next year in Mexico and eventually to expand to major supermarkets.
"It's basically a tough business, and you win by using your mind and technique," he said, with evident pride. "People don't understand my kind of product. You have to know every detail. Okra and other vegetables are not boring. Okra is not just okra. It is very special."

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Jerking The Other Knee

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
Remember the knee-jerk liberals? Washington used to be full of people who viewed greedy businessmen as the root of all evil, who thought that a new government program was the answer to every problem. Some of them wielded influence in the early Clinton administration. But after the defeat of the health care plan, they were sent into exile. Bill Clinton became a pragmatist, someone who appreciated the virtues of the market without deifying it and understood the limits of government without demonizing it.
 Out with the old knee-jerks, in with the new. The new guys in town are knee-jerk conservatives; they view too much government as the root of all evil, believe that what's good for big business is always good for America and think that the answer to every problem is to cut taxes and allow more pollution. 
 In a way, the controversy over John Ashcroft has actually obscured the picture. With all eyes focused on the startling prospect that a champion of the religious right will become attorney general, George W. Bush's hard line on other issues has not been fully appreciated. 
One of those issues is, of course, the question of whether we ought to have a huge tax cut tilted toward the affluent. Many pundits thought that Mr. Bush would scale back his tax plan. Not a chance; instead, his people have only intensified their push, insisting that the tax cut is needed to prevent a recession.
To his credit, the nominee for treasury secretary has been a less than enthusiastic team player. In his Senate hearing, Paul O'Neill came remarkably close to damning the whole sales pitch with faint praise. "I'm not going to make a huge case that this is the investment we need to make sure we don't go into a recession," he conceded. "But I don't know why we wouldn't want a tax cut now. It wouldn't hurt." The good news here is not that Mr. O'Neill knows that his boss is making a bogus argument; Mr. Bush's inner circle knows that too. It is that the new treasury chief has some scruples about saying things that he knows to be untrue. I wonder how long that will last. 
Meanwhile, the clear and present danger to the economy is not the putative recession, but the power crisis in California. Mr. Bush made his first remarks on the subject last week, and they were revealing.
First, he rejected summarily the idea that the federal government might impose a temporary cap on wholesale electricity prices. One wouldn't have expected him to endorse such a cap just yet. Although there is actually a very good case for a price cap as an emergency measure -- under current circumstances it would probably lead to increased production -- that case takes some explaining. But it is a bit surprising that Mr. Bush would so thoroughly foreclose his options, especially when one bears in mind the political embarrassment that the profits from those soaring prices go in large part to generating companies based in, yes, Texas. 
Even more surprising was Mr. Bush's decision to use the occasion of the Western power crisis mainly as an opportunity to criticize environmental regulations, declare that when it comes to restoring salmon he won't give a dam, and call for oil drilling in wildlife refuges. It's true that federal (not state) air-quality rules are among the factors limiting power production in California. But they are not central to the crisis, and Alaskan oil has nothing at all to do with it. One can only conclude that just as Mr. Bush sees the economic slowdown as an opportunity to sell tax cuts, he sees the power crisis as an opportunity to sell weakened environmental protection.
There will soon be other economic tests for the new administration. How, for example, will it deal with the prospect of a series of airline mergers -- mergers that will further reduce competition in an industry where monopoly pricing is already a big problem? Somehow I have a feeling that I know the answer.
So in case you imagined that given the fact that the other guy got half a million more votes something bipartisan might be about to happen, forget it. Even before taking office Mr. Bush has made a number of policy decisions, and on not one of them has he deviated an inch from a knee-jerk conservative position. Were you expecting something different?

HEADLINE: A Cliche-Free First 100 Days 

BYLINE:  By William F. Buckley Jr.; William F. Buckley Jr., editor-at-large of National Review, is author of the forthcoming "Elvis in the Morning."

 BODY:
George W. Bush is president of all the people, as he does not tire of reminding us, but he is also leader of the Republican Party and custodian of its prospects in the future.
 Clearly, Mr. Bush felt the pull of cliches, the most frequently reiterated of them, in the days before his inauguration, this one about all the people, and earlier, the one about compassionate conservatism. His task in the 100 days ahead is to make his way around these cliches, because he is not likely to make any progress in fulfilling these sentiments. Thomas Aquinas explained how it is that God cannot make two and two equal other than four, and President Bush is fated to discover this. 
 What he can seek to do is make the losers smile through their tribulation, and this is not inconceivable, because ideological deprivation can be anesthetized by material benefits. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. didn't wage a very blary campaign in 2000 protesting free trade and Nafta because unemployment at less than 4 percent gets in the way of ululation.
President Bush needs concretely to appeal to American conservatives, who put him in the White House. To do this is in part a rhetorical challenge, in part a call to achievement.
On the matter of taxation, he needs quickly to rescue the question from the utilitarian hole it was stuffed into by his treasury secretary, Paul O'Neill, who pondered exclusively, in his confirmation hearing, the question of the economic impact of lowered taxes. Conservatives will want to hear from Mr. Bush that there is a moral problem in the government's withdrawing from taxpayers' pockets more than is required by a conservative estimate of the government's obligations. He must avoid the endless arguments about whom to benefit, whom to deprive. This is accomplished only by a call to evenhanded reductions, on the order of the Kemp-Roth approach 20 years ago. He can speedily recommend a 3 percent tax decrease down the line, a modest figure, the uniform application of which would help in restoring conservative philosophical confidence.
On the matter of abortion, Mr. Bush might profitably startle both polarities by recommending to Congress a freeze on any federal action, while appealing to the governors of 50 states to conduct plebiscites soliciting community sentiment on modifications, if any, on absolute, mother-exclusive rights. Multiple claims -- those of the mother, the unborn, the father, the community -- invite multiple approaches. The president could note the preemptive passage, in l990, by the Connecticut Legislature of a bill assuring abortion rights in the event of a repeal of Roe v. Wade. Abraham Lincoln, after all, endorsed the Missouri Compromise permitting the continuation of slavery but barring its export into uncontaminated territories: precisely a political compromise on a moral issue.
Mr. Bush will find the growing church-state polarization most challenging to his good nature. He cannot, of course, reveal what is probably foremost on his mind, which is the ideological makeup of the Supreme Court. He has pledged that there should be no litmus test for membership in the court, but to remain true to this pledge would lead him to choose only candidates of the sort of philosophical impalpability that Justice David Souter once exhibited.
Mr. Bush can take comfort in the absence of any pending call for federal legislation that bears directly on the church-state question. The president's obligation will then be to reiterate his own position about the rights to practice religion and the desirability of doing so. He can ask the attorney general to file amicus curiae briefs defending, in federal courts, initiatives authorizing public funds for parents who elect to send their children to nonpublic and religious schools. On this issue, President Bush will need to be emphatic, and therefore divisive. But he can study the presidency of Ronald Reagan, who, on many questions, managed to make his point, and even occasionally to prevail, without inducing mutinous dissent.
On the matter of relations with minority groups, Mr. Bush will find it hard to increase disfavor for the G.O.P. among African-Americans, who voted overwhelmingly against him. He can do little more on this front than to take every opportunity to acclaim the progress made by minorities in the past 30 years on such indices as education and minority representation in legislatures and the courts. He might attempt, in his amiable way, to ask members of the Congressional Black Caucus to show how the president can demonstrate his concern for all Americans.
As party leader, he can encourage black political dissenters to press upon the black community the credentials of aspirant, conservative-minded, black leaders. The trouble with pointing to Gen. Colin Powell's appointment as secretary of state as an example of the kind of opportunities the G.O.P. can offer to minorities is that General Powell is not thought of primarily in terms of his race.
There is some political condescension out there in the assessment of Mr. Bush. It is based on the progenitive launch of his career. If Abraham Lincoln had had a son who contended for and won political power, he'd have had the same problem, even as John Quincy Adams did. George II can satisfy his conservative constituency by reaffirming the best in the blood line and improving on it where he can -- God, subject to the restraints of the First Amendment, willing.

HEADLINE: Taking Power, With People's Blessing 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
Like nearly everyone in the Philippines, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo slips into reverent tones when talking about Corazon C. Aquino, the heroine of the 1986 uprising known as people power.
 "She is a role model to me," Mrs. Arroyo said in an interview in Manila last October. "She ousted a dictator in a peaceful manner." 
 Yesterday, Mrs. Arroyo toppled another Philippine leader, Joseph Estrada, to become the second woman to be president of this politically turbulent country. While Mr. Estrada's supposed crimes are penny ante compared with the epic larceny of Ferdinand E. Marcos, the uprising against Mr. Estrada has turned Mrs. Arroyo into a symbol of healing, much as Mrs. Aquino was.
But that is where the similarities end. Far from being thrust into her historic role by tragic happenstance, Mrs. Arroyo planned her ascension to the presidential palace with discipline and foresight.
Mrs. Arroyo, 53, was one of several cabinet officials to abandon Mr. Estrada after he became engulfed in a corruption scandal last fall. She resigned as social welfare secretary but remained vice president, which kept her in line for the presidency. While not openly calling for his resignation, she quickly unified the opposition to Mr. Estrada around herself.
"My role is to be leader of the united opposition," she said at the time. "It is a more modest role. We don't want a revolution."
In fact, Mrs. Arroyo assembled a shadow government during the three months of political upheaval. When the military withdrew its support of Mr. Estrada on Friday, it seemed not only proper but inevitable that the defense secretary and armed forces chief would stand behind the 5-foot-1-inch vice president.
Certainly, she will be a stark contrast to Mr. Estrada, the hard-living former movie actor who reveled in his popularity among the poor. An economist trained at Georgetown University, Mrs. Arroyo is the daughter of Diosdado Macapagal, who was the president of the Philippines from 1961 to 1965.
At Georgetown, she became friends with a classmate, Bill Clinton, whom she still visits on trips to Washington. Mrs. Arroyo had settled into a career as an academic before she entered government in 1986 as the under secretary of trade in the Aquino administration. She was elected to the Senate in 1992 and the vice presidency in 1998, forging an alliance with Mr. Estrada.
The two made an odd pair. Mr. Estrada is shambling and plain-spoken while Mrs. Arroyo is neatly groomed and tightly controlled -- a politician who never gives a two-word answer where one word will do.
Like Mrs. Arroyo, her husband, Mike, is the scion of one of the Philippines' elite families. The couple, who live in one of Manila's best neighborhoods, have three children.
In her speech after being sworn in, President Arroyo drew a contrast between herself and Mr. Estrada, saying she would "promote a work ethic and a dignified lifestyle."
"The presidency is not a position to be enjoyed," she declared. "It is a position where one must work very hard."
Whether diligence alone will endear Mrs. Arroyo to the Philippine people is not clear. Her popularity ratings hover above 70 percent, but analysts say she lacks the affection among poor voters that until recently sustained Mr. Estrada.
"Gloria has always been popular as long as there was no competition," said Karina Constantino-David, a sociologist who served in the cabinet with her. "Whether she can convert that popularity into loyalty is another question."
Perhaps the most immediate test for Mrs. Arroyo will be the economy. Her first appointment on Saturday was of a new finance secretary, Alberto Romulo, who served as budget secretary under President Aquino. She said her top priority would be to eradicate poverty in the Philippines.
Analysts said Mrs. Arroyo was also determined to win back the confidence of foreign investors, which had been badly shaken by the metastasizing corruption scandal. As a senator, Mrs. Arroyo helped draft the legislation that enabled the Philippines to join the World Trade Organization.
Still, at the Edsa Shrine in Manila where thousands gathered to protest last week, the focus was so much on getting rid of Mr. Estrada that the demonstrators had given little thought to Mrs. Arroyo. "We're fed up with all politicians," said Kathy Sage, 15. "My God, how they rip off the Philippines."
Mrs. Arroyo is not immune to some of the criticisms leveled at Mr. Estrada. Her family has had close ties with Bong Pineda, a reputed leader of illegal gambling rings. She said she has no involvement in the kind of rackets from which Mr. Estrada is accused of skimming $8 million in kickbacks.
Indeed, Mrs. Arroyo said any future president of the Philippines would have to combat the gambling culture that is deeply ingrained here. "There are places in the Philippines where there is very little gambling," she said. "In the end, it comes down to political will."

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
Tradition and Legitimacy

BYLINE:  By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 

 BODY:
Inevitably, a question mark hung over George W. Bush as he raised his right hand in the chill, damp air of the capital today and swore to "preserve, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States." But at that very moment, through that very act, the new president started to dispel the challenges to his legitimacy.
 Unlike most of his precursors -- but like John Quincy Adams, Benjamin Harrison and a handful of other presidents past -- Mr. Bush entered the White House without an unchallenged, universally accepted title to office. 
 A half-million more Americans voted for Al Gore than for Mr. Bush, which counted for nothing in the legal sense but for something, at least, in the political sense. Mr. Bush became the first president since Harrison in 1888 to lose the popular vote but win in the Electoral College. Only the intervention of the United States Supreme Court, itself as deeply divided as possible, 5 votes to 4, tipped the Electoral College vote in Mr. Bush's favor.
Arguments about the legitimacy of the Texas governor's victory have persisted even as the country accepted the fact that he had won. Thousands of the doubtful and disenchanted took to the streets of Washington today in angry protest.
But the debate is likely to grow softer as the nation grows accustomed to pictures of Mr. Bush speaking from the Oval Office, boarding Air Force One, accompanied everywhere he goes by the strains of "Ruffles and Flourishes" and "Hail to the Chief." In the television age, those images, more than anything else, confer the mantle of authority and legitimacy on a leader.
The process began, in a sense, with the ceremony in which Florida's secretary of state, Katherine Harris, certified Mr. Bush as the winner of that state's pivotal electoral votes. Carefully staged in a tribunal setting, nationally televised, it was immediately challenged as bogus and premature. But it solidified the conviction of many Americans that Mr. Bush had won the election.
What counted for far more was the inaugural ceremony itself, one of the surpassing rituals of the American democracy, connecting Mr. Bush and the United States of today, a military and economic colossus that bestrides the world, with the young, small and frail country that chose George Washington as its first president.
Today's events will align in the nation's collective memory with Franklin D. Roosevelt's ringing assurances that a people battered by Depression had "nothing to fear but fear itself" and Robert Frost's struggle to read the poem he had written to celebrate John F. Kennedy's inauguration and Jimmy Carter's unprecedented walk down Pennsylvania Avenue. And surely one of the symbols that will last is that of Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, who cast one of those five votes that assured Mr. Bush of victory, administering the oath of office to him.
That and the new president's speech (short but not all sweet, with references to the need for character and responsibility that seemed to many to be aimed at the departing president) and the 21-gun salute by the massed howitzers and the parade down Pennsylvania Avenue -- all the pomp and ceremony could not help but solidify Mr. Bush's claim to the presidency.
Bill Clinton -- who rode to the Capitol with his successor, following another hoary custom -- spoke this morning in his final radio address from the Oval Office of "the magic, the mystery, the miracle of American democracy" encapsulated in the ceremony marking "the peaceful transfer of power from one administration to the next." The United States does not do coups.
The protesters made a point of pledging that they would demonstrate peacefully, however intense their feelings of "outrage about the trampling of the electoral process and the disenfranchisement of voters," in the words of Les Souci, an organizer for Voter March, one of the protest organizations.
There were more protesters than at any inaugural since 1973, when the placards denounced the war in Vietnam. But no matter how many voices were lifted in protest, the presence on the platform of Al Gore -- departing vice president, defeated presidential candidate -- spoke just as loudly of acceptance and ratification.
No doubt Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore, along with hundreds of thousands of Democrats, felt that they had been cheated of something.
A new CBS News poll, made public on the eve of the inauguration, attested to that. Although 51 percent of the respondents said they considered Mr. Bush's victory a legitimate one, only 19 percent of Democrats -- and 12 percent of blacks -- said so.
It is often like that in the first months after a very, very close election like this one. Rutherford B. Hayes, chosen president by a special commission after an election marred by widespread fraud and endless legal maneuvering, said this in his Inaugural Address in March 1877: "Human judgment is never unerring, and is rarely regarded as otherwise than wrong by the unsuccessful party in the contest."
John Quincy Adams said the odd manner of his election sent him into office with little confidence.
Mr. Bush made no such allusion to the agonizingly close result of the 2000 election and its controversial resolution by the courts. But like Mr. Clinton, he celebrated what took place this morning.
"This peaceful transfer of authority," he said, "is rare in history, yet common in our country. With a simple oath we affirm old traditions and make new beginnings. As I begin, I thank President Clinton for his service to our nation, and I thank Vice President Gore for a contest conducted with spirit and ended with grace."
In the end, of course, it will be Mr. Bush's actions, not his words, that will ratify his legitimacy, or fail to, in the electorate's eyes. But he began his presidency as he had conducted his campaign, by emphasizing moral behavior -- and implicitly contrasting himself with Mr. Clinton, who ended his presidency with what amounted to a plea bargain with a special prosecutor.
"Together," he said, in what he had described as the key sentence of his speech, "we will build a nation of character." At another point, he spoke of fulfilling the nation's promise through "civility, courage, compassion and character."
And at yet another point, he made this promise: "I will live and lead by these principles: to advance my convictions with civility; to pursue the public interest with courage; to speak for greater justice and compassion; to call for responsibility and try to live it as well."

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
A Road Not Traveled: The New Era of G.O.P. Control

BYLINE:  By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
WHEN George W. Bush took the presidential oath of office yesterday, the Republican Party took control of not only the White House but also Congress. The accession of Richard B. Cheney to the vice presidency puts him in position to break the 50-50 tie in the Senate in the Republicans' favor, and they already held a narrow margin in the House of Representatives.
 For the first time since 1955, in the presidency of Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republicans control all three of Washington's centers of elective power. But much has changed since then. Gone are the spittoons, the high-top shoes and the party discipline on Capitol Hill. Gone is the urgency of the Cold War and the Imperial Presidency it engendered. Gone is the interparty comity. 
 So there are only obsolete road maps to the political terrain Republicans and Democrats must navigate.
For the Republicans, the biggest problem is the tenuous margins by which they hold power. Essentially, the country split down the middle in November, giving the Republicans their tiny majority in the House, an even split in the Senate and a man with an asterisk at the other end of Pennsylvania Avenue. 
So what should the Democrats do? Their man Al Gore prevailed in the popular vote, and came so agonizingly close in the Electoral College. Along with many Democratic voters, and Bill Clinton, many Congressional Democrats believe he won, only to be cheated by the Republicans' machinations. So the instinct is fight back.
Their "great dilemma," as Lloyd N. Cutler, one of their senior statesmen, called it last week, is this: They have the theoretical power to block many of President Bush's initiatives, by using the filibuster and other procedural devices, but in doing so they risk exposing themselves to public scorn and electoral retribution. By flexing their muscles, in other words, they risk making Mr. Bush stronger. The country is down on partisanship.
That is one big reason why a Democratic filibuster against John Ashcroft, whose nomination for attorney general has generated immense hostility among liberals and some moderates, is so unlikely.
Though the parallel is not exact, there are lessons for both parties in the early years of the Clinton administration. Elected by a narrow margin after proclaiming himself a centrist, Mr. Clinton nonetheless mounted attacks on the status quo, reversing Reagan-era policies on abortion, nominating such controversial figures as Lani Guinier for office, pushing for gays in the military and proposing a massive health care reform plan.
The 1994 election turned into a referendum on the president, which he lost. But then the newly rampant Republicans in the House, led by Newt Gingrich, fought bitterly with Mr. Clinton, challenging him at every turn and ultimately closing the federal government down in a dispute over spending policy. Having seemed on the ropes, Mr. Clinton bounced back and won in 1996.
He learned the lesson; given a second chance, he walked as moderately as he talked, and on most issues, he prevailed. The new president has learned it, too, or so he says. Asked last week in an interview on CNN to appraise Mr. Clinton, Mr. Bush said he was "very good at the politics of dealing with the Congress."
In an earlier era, another feisty Republican Congress gave another Democratic president, Harry S. Truman, a severe battering on a series of economic and labor issues, passing the Taft-Hartley Act and a tax bill over presidential vetoes. Campaigning against Congress as a collection of good-for-nothings, Truman won a famously unexpected victory in 1948 as his party gained nine seats in the Senate and 75 in the House.
So the Democrats would be wise to tread softly, at least at first. Their leaders, especially Thomas A. Daschle of South Dakota in the Senate, have been speaking the language of compromise, and Mr. Daschle proved his mettle by working out a temporary power-sharing agreement with the Republicans.
On some issues, Democrats can let the Republicans do the heavy lifting. Even before Mr. Bush raised his right hand outside the Capitol, for example, Republican lawmakers expressed skepticism about the president's campaign proposal to give limited help to low-income elderly people for drug purchases. Mr. Bush "should be very flexible," warned Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the chairman of the finance committee.
On other matters, compromise should not be out of reach if Democrats fight their corner with skill. A tax cut that is neither as targeted as the Democrats would like nor as large as Mr. Bush has proposed is possible, for example, and Democrats should be able to help shape the changes in the Pentagon that seem inevitable.
But bipartisanship and good will cannot bridge every chasm, especially in the Congress, where suspicion and sheer nastiness have taken root. That is especially true on the social issues that Mr. Bush played down during his campaign, like abortion and gun control, and the most vexed question of all, racial relations.
Mr. Bush ran abysmally among blacks, pulling no more than 9 percent of African-American votes. The divide was no less evident on social issues. He ran poorly in states that favor gun control, gay rights and abortion rights, such as New York, Illinois and California, building his electoral majority in the Plains and Rocky Mountain states and the South. He vowed during the campaign to "draw a moral line," and he has begun by nominating Mr. Ashcroft, a Christian conservative, to a key position, and by opposing United States government support for international groups that favor abortion.
The Democrats will fight him on social issues. Mr. Bush will, no doubt, look for support among conservative Democrats from states he carried, such as Texas and Florida. But the more he pushes, the more fiercely the Northern, urban Democrats will fight. The question is will the two sides be able to keep the ensuing struggle from poisoning debate on the more tractable issues.
MANY of the most successful presidents used control of Congress to mobilize support for major programs. Thomas Jefferson, Woodrow Wilson, Franklin D. Roosevelt and Lyndon B. Johnson are in that category. But since Johnson, the first president of the television era, shoved through an enormous package of legislation in 1965, no president has been able to count on solid partisan backing on the Hill. By making it possible to run without much party support, television deeply eroded party loyalties.
Mr. Bush, who has reportedly been reading about Theodore Roosevelt, will have the benefit of the bully pulpit that T.R. found the White House to be. For all the changes in the last half-century, one fact remains: Executive power is concentrated in the president and the presidency, but legislative power is diffused.
Senator Fred Thompson, Republican of Tennessee, said recently that he expected Congress to revert to its old scrappy ways. What happens then, he said, "will depend on the degree to which he can successfully go over our heads to make his case to the public."
If he is half as good at it as Bill Clinton, the Democrats will find themselves in a real bind.

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION: THE AGENDA; 
To Do: 1. Undo Most Recent Actions of My Predecessor

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 

 BODY:
Faced with a to-do list that is long and getting longer, President Bush got off to a fast start today, acting to delay or block some of the Clinton administration's final initiatives.
 Less than two hours after taking the oath of office, Mr. Bush had his chief of staff, Andrew H. Card Jr., take steps to keep his predecessor's last flurry of rules and regulatory decisions from taking effect. 
 In his final month in office, President Clinton had used his full range of executive powers to reshape policy on a wide range of issues. He issued new guidelines for health maintenance organizations serving Medicare patients, proposed new safety standards for meat and poultry products and created new environmental protections for wetlands. In a proclamation signed on Friday, Mr. Clinton granted new protection to a part of Governors Island in New York Harbor by declaring it a national monument; it is unclear whether Mr. Bush's action would affect that designation. Page 44. 
In announcing his action in a memorandum to executive departments and agencies, Mr. Card said it was necessary "to ensure that the president's appointees have the opportunity to review any new or pending regulations." Even as he was seeking to undo the last administration's work, Mr. Bush was looking ahead to a heavy workload on other issues.
Power shortages in California are threatening to set off an economic and political crisis in the nation's most populous state. Peace negotiations in the Middle East are again approaching a critical stage. Mr. Bush's choice for attorney general, John Ashcroft, is under attack from Democrats on Capitol Hill.
The economic outlook is murky and the stock market is edgy. The new president must make a choice in a matter of weeks about whether to proceed with one version of a national missile defense system. He has a thick stack of initiatives that he wants to send to Congress, but he has not formulated a budget to show how he will pay for them.
Mr. Bush and his aides were clearly eager to get to work. They had signaled for weeks their intention to review and reverse some of Mr. Clinton's recent actions.
The steps Mr. Card took today blocking publications of some rules in the Federal Register and delaying the effective date of others are tactics often used by incoming administrations to give themselves time to deal with complex issues left behind by their predecessors.
While bureaucratic, today's order vividly illustrated the shift in power from a Democratic administration to a Republican one, the immense authority inherent in the presidency and the scope of the ideological battles taking place as Washington adapts to a new set of leaders.
And if they do not know it already, Mr. Bush and his team will soon learn that pushing their own agenda will be only part of what occupies them, even in a time of general peace and prosperity.
"There are issues that are pushing in on him, and there are things that he has in mind to do, and the two are not synonymous," said Thomas Mann, a political analyst at the Brookings Institution, the research group.
"As far as the first group goes, the California energy crisis is front and center, although it's not clear what policy role there is for him to play," Mr. Mann said. "Getting a budget ready to send up to the Hill will be important. And third, I would say, is the Middle East peace negotiations. A decision will have to be made pretty quickly about what role, if any, the Bush administration wants to play in what is shaping up as another marathon negotiation before the Israeli elections."
Mr. Bush and his team will not only have to deal with the unexpected and events beyond their control, but also have to confront the reality of the 535 legislators of both parties on Capitol Hill, who are intent on pressing their own issues in their own way.
It is no coincidence that the first member of Congress that Mr. Bush is scheduled to meet with one on one next week, other than House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert and Trent Lott of Mississippi, his party's leader in the Senate, is Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona. Mr. McCain, who battled Mr. Bush in the primaries last year, is going by the White House for a private chat on Wednesday evening.
Mr. McCain has pledged to push quickly for his proposed overhaul of the campaign finance laws, and he seems close to having enough votes to win. The initiative is opposed by Mr. Bush, and has the potential not only to give the new White House a case of political heartburn, but also to slow the president's push for early consideration of his own priorities. 
Mr. Bush's aides are planning an intensive push next week to build support for the new president's education proposal, which he intends to send to Congress on Tuesday as his first legislative initiative.
The proposal is built around giving the states more money and streamlining the federal requirements for using it, in return for greater state and local accountability for improving student performance.
It will also include a provision to allow parents of students in some failing school districts to take their share of federal financing and put it toward private or parochial school tuition, so-called vouchers.
"You can anticipate a lot of action on education next week," said Ari Fleischer, Mr. Bush's spokesman.
On foreign policy, the new administration will confront difficult questions about how to deal with unstable and potentially aggressive nations like Iraq and North Korea.
At the Pentagon, Mr. Bush faces pressure from the uniformed leaders of the armed services to immediately increase spending. Even then, the services' programs for buying new weapons -- from the Air Force's F-22 to the Army's mobile artillery system -- far exceed projected spending levels. 
The Ballistic Missile Defense Organization at the Pentagon has outlined a schedule for the new team that requires Mr. Bush to decide by March whether he will proceed with the initial steps of a limited missile shield this year. 
Most of Mr. Bush's energies in the first few months, however, are likely to be focused on domestic issues.
Mr. Bush's team, including Paul H. O'Neill, who will lead the Treasury Department, and Lawrence B. Lindsey, the chief economic adviser in the White House, are busy revising the president's $1.6 trillion tax cut plan.
The administration is also looking at proposals to help retirees pay the cost of prescription drugs, an issue that both parties in Congress have near the top of their list as well.
But Congressional leaders said they did not anticipate any push to help Mr. Bush ring up quick legislative victories on his priority issues. 
"The issues George W. Bush wants to address are big issues," Mr. Lott said. "You need to take a little time to get that right."
Still, by moving quickly to frustrate the last pieces of Mr. Clinton's agenda, the new administration served notice that it would not wait until every post was filled.
In a memorandum to the heads and acting heads of executive departments and agencies today, Mr. Card ordered these steps:
*No proposed or final regulation may be sent to the Office of the Federal Register unless it has been reviewed and approved by a senior department or agency official appointed by President Bush.
*Rules that have been sent to the Federal Register office, but not yet published, must be withdrawn, in accordance with the procedures of that office. These rules will be reviewed by the new administration.
*The effective date of new regulations will be postponed for 60 days if the rules have been published in the Federal Register, but have not taken effect. Rules typically take effect 30 to 90 days after they are published.
The breadth of Mr. Card's order surprised some Clinton administration officials.
Timothy M. Westmoreland, director of the Center for Medicaid and State Operations at the Department of Health and Human Services, said: "The Bush administration is being extremely short-sighted. Some of our rules would save money. Others would provide basic protections for H.M.O. patients and for children subjected to abuses in psychiatric hospitals."

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION; 
President: 'I Ask You to Be Citizens'

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of President Bush's inaugural address yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
 Thank you all. Chief Justice Rehnquist, President Carter, President Bush, President Clinton, distinguished guests and my fellow citizens. The peaceful transfer of authority is rare in history, yet common in our country. With a simple oath, we affirm old traditions and make new beginnings. As I begin, I thank President Clinton for his service to our nation. And I thank Vice President Gore for a contest conducted with spirit and ended with grace. 
 I am honored and humbled to stand here, where so many of America's leaders have come before me, and so many will follow. 
We have a place, all of us, in a long story, a story we continue, but whose end we will not see. It is the story of a new world that became a friend and liberator of the old. The story of a slave-holding society that became a servant of freedom. The story of a power that went into the world to protect but not possess, to defend but not to conquer. It is the American story, a story of flawed and fallible people, united across the generations by grand and enduring ideals.
The grandest of these ideals is an unfolding American promise: that everyone belongs, that everyone deserves a chance, that no insignificant person was ever born. Americans are called to enact this promise in our lives and in our laws. And though our nation has sometimes halted, and sometimes delayed, we must follow no other course.
Through much of the last century, America's faith in freedom and democracy was a rock in a raging sea. Now it is a seed upon the wind, taking root in many nations. Our democratic faith is more than the creed of our country, it is the inborn hope of our humanity, an ideal we carry but do not own, a trust we bear and pass along. And even after nearly 225 years, we have a long way yet to travel.
While many of our citizens prosper, others doubt the promise -- even the justice -- of our own country. The ambitions of some Americans are limited by failing schools, and hidden prejudice and the circumstances of their birth. And sometimes our differences run so deep, it seems we share a continent, but not a country.
We do not accept this, and we will not allow it. Our unity, our union, is the serious work of leaders and citizens in every generation. And this is my solemn pledge: I will work to build a single nation of justice and opportunity. I know this is in our reach, because we are guided by a power larger than ourselves, who creates us equal in his image. And we are confident in principles that unite and lead us onward.
America has never been united by blood or birth or soil. We are bound by ideals that move us beyond our backgrounds, lift us above our interests and teach us what it means to be citizens. Every child must be taught these principles. Every citizen must uphold them. And every immigrant, by embracing these ideals, makes our country more, not less, American.
Today we affirm a new commitment to live out our nation's promise through civility, courage, compassion and character.
America, at its best, matches a commitment to principle with a concern for civility. A civil society demands from each of us good will and respect, fair dealing and forgiveness.
Some seem to believe that our politics can afford to be petty because in a time of peace the stakes of our debates appear small. But the stakes for America are never small. If our country does not lead the cause of freedom, it will not be led. If we do not turn the hearts of children toward knowledge and character, we will lose their gifts and undermine their idealism. If we permit our economy to drift and decline, the vulnerable will suffer most.
We must live up to the calling we share. Civility is not a tactic or a sentiment. It is the determined choice of trust over cynicism, of community over chaos. And this commitment, if keep it, is a way to shared accomplishment.
America at its best is also courageous. Our national courage has been clear in times of depression and war, when defeating common dangers defined our common good. Now we must chose if the example of our fathers and mothers will inspire us or condemn us. We must show courage in a time of blessing, by confronting problems instead of passing them on to future generations.
Together, we will reclaim America's schools before ignorance and apathy claim more young lives. We will reform Social Security and Medicare, sparing our children from struggles we have the power to prevent. And we will reduce taxes to recover the momentum of our economy and reward the effort and enterprise of working Americans. We will build our defenses beyond challenge, lest weakness invite challenge. We will confront weapons of mass destruction, so that a new century is spared new horrors.
The enemies of liberty and our country should make no mistake, America remains engaged in the world, by history and by choice, shaping a balance of power that favors freedom. We will defend our allies and our interests. We will show purpose without arrogance. We will meet aggression and bad faith with resolve and strength. And to all nations, we will speak for the values that gave our nation birth.
America at its best is compassionate.
In the quiet of American conscience, we know that deep, persistent poverty is unworthy of our nation's promise. And whatever our views of its cause, we can agree that children at risk are not at fault. Abandonment and abuse are not acts of God, they are failures of love. And the proliferation of prisons, however necessary, is no substitute for hope and order in our souls.
Where there is suffering, there is duty. Americans in need are not strangers, they are citizens; not problems, but priorities; and all of us are diminished when any are hopeless.
Government has great responsibilities, for public safety and public health, for civil rights and common schools. Yet compassion is the work of a nation, not just a government. And some needs and hurts are so deep they will only respond to a mentor's touch or a pastor's prayer. Church and charity, synagogue and mosque, lend our communities their humanity and they will have an honored place in our plans and in our laws.
Many in our country do not know the pain of poverty. But we can listen to those who do. And I can pledge our nation to a goal: When we see that wounded traveler on the road to Jericho, we will not pass to the other side.
America at its best is a place where personal responsibility is valued and expected. Encouraging responsibility is not a search for scapegoats, it is a call to conscience. And though it requires sacrifice, it brings a deeper fulfillment. We find the fullness of life, not only in options, but in commitments. And we find that children and community are the commitments that set us free.
Our public interest depends on private character, on civic duty and family bonds and basic fairness, on uncounted, unhonored acts of decency which give direction to our freedom.
Sometimes in life we are called to do great things. But as a saint of our times has said, every day we are called to do small things with great love. The most important tasks of a democracy are done by everyone.
I will live and lead by these principles: to advance my convictions with civility, to pursue the public interest with courage, to speak for greater justice and compassion, to call for responsibility and try to live it as well. In all these days -- ways -- I will bring the values of our history to the care of our times.
What you do is as important as anything government does. I ask you to seek a common good beyond your comfort, to defend needed reforms against easy attacks, to serve your nation, beginning with your neighbor. I ask you to be citizens. Citizens, not spectators. Citizens, not subjects. Responsible citizens, building communities of service and a nation of character.
Americans are generous and strong and decent, not because we believe in ourselves, but because we hold beliefs beyond ourselves. When this spirit of citizenship is missing, no government program can replace it. When this spirit is present, no wrong can stand against it.
After the Declaration of Independence was signed, Virginia statesman John Page wrote to Thomas Jefferson: "We know the race is not to the swift, nor the battle to the strong. Do you not think an angel rides in the whirlwind and directs this storm?"
Much time has passed since Jefferson arrived for his inauguration. The years and changes accumulate. But the themes of this day he would know: our nation's grand story of courage, and its simple dream of dignity. We are not this story's author, who fills time and eternity with his purpose. Yet his purpose is achieved in our duty and our duty is fulfilled in service to one another.
Never tiring, never yielding, never finishing, we renew that purpose today: to make our country more just and generous, to affirm the dignity of our lives and every life.
This work continues. This story goes on. And an angel still rides in the whirlwind and directs this storm.
God bless you all, and God bless America.

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION; 
President: 'I Ask You to Be Citizens'

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of President Bush's inaugural address yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
 Thank you all. Chief Justice Rehnquist, President Carter, President Bush, President Clinton, distinguished guests and my fellow citizens. The peaceful transfer of authority is rare in history, yet common in our country. With a simple oath, we affirm old traditions and make new beginnings. As I begin, I thank President Clinton for his service to our nation. And I thank Vice President Gore for a contest conducted with spirit and ended with grace. 
 I am honored and humbled to stand here, where so many of America's leaders have come before me, and so many will follow. 
We have a place, all of us, in a long story, a story we continue, but whose end we will not see. It is the story of a new world that became a friend and liberator of the old. The story of a slave-holding society that became a servant of freedom. The story of a power that went into the world to protect but not possess, to defend but not to conquer. It is the American story, a story of flawed and fallible people, united across the generations by grand and enduring ideals.
The grandest of these ideals is an unfolding American promise: that everyone belongs, that everyone deserves a chance, that no insignificant person was ever born. Americans are called to enact this promise in our lives and in our laws. And though our nation has sometimes halted, and sometimes delayed, we must follow no other course.
Through much of the last century, America's faith in freedom and democracy was a rock in a raging sea. Now it is a seed upon the wind, taking root in many nations. Our democratic faith is more than the creed of our country, it is the inborn hope of our humanity, an ideal we carry but do not own, a trust we bear and pass along. And even after nearly 225 years, we have a long way yet to travel.
While many of our citizens prosper, others doubt the promise -- even the justice -- of our own country. The ambitions of some Americans are limited by failing schools, and hidden prejudice and the circumstances of their birth. And sometimes our differences run so deep, it seems we share a continent, but not a country.
We do not accept this, and we will not allow it. Our unity, our union, is the serious work of leaders and citizens in every generation. And this is my solemn pledge: I will work to build a single nation of justice and opportunity. I know this is in our reach, because we are guided by a power larger than ourselves, who creates us equal in his image. And we are confident in principles that unite and lead us onward.
America has never been united by blood or birth or soil. We are bound by ideals that move us beyond our backgrounds, lift us above our interests and teach us what it means to be citizens. Every child must be taught these principles. Every citizen must uphold them. And every immigrant, by embracing these ideals, makes our country more, not less, American.
Today we affirm a new commitment to live out our nation's promise through civility, courage, compassion and character.
America, at its best, matches a commitment to principle with a concern for civility. A civil society demands from each of us good will and respect, fair dealing and forgiveness.
Some seem to believe that our politics can afford to be petty because in a time of peace the stakes of our debates appear small. But the stakes for America are never small. If our country does not lead the cause of freedom, it will not be led. If we do not turn the hearts of children toward knowledge and character, we will lose their gifts and undermine their idealism. If we permit our economy to drift and decline, the vulnerable will suffer most.
We must live up to the calling we share. Civility is not a tactic or a sentiment. It is the determined choice of trust over cynicism, of community over chaos. And this commitment, if keep it, is a way to shared accomplishment.
America at its best is also courageous. Our national courage has been clear in times of depression and war, when defeating common dangers defined our common good. Now we must chose if the example of our fathers and mothers will inspire us or condemn us. We must show courage in a time of blessing, by confronting problems instead of passing them on to future generations.
Together, we will reclaim America's schools before ignorance and apathy claim more young lives. We will reform Social Security and Medicare, sparing our children from struggles we have the power to prevent. And we will reduce taxes to recover the momentum of our economy and reward the effort and enterprise of working Americans. We will build our defenses beyond challenge, lest weakness invite challenge. We will confront weapons of mass destruction, so that a new century is spared new horrors.
The enemies of liberty and our country should make no mistake, America remains engaged in the world, by history and by choice, shaping a balance of power that favors freedom. We will defend our allies and our interests. We will show purpose without arrogance. We will meet aggression and bad faith with resolve and strength. And to all nations, we will speak for the values that gave our nation birth.
America at its best is compassionate.
In the quiet of American conscience, we know that deep, persistent poverty is unworthy of our nation's promise. And whatever our views of its cause, we can agree that children at risk are not at fault. Abandonment and abuse are not acts of God, they are failures of love. And the proliferation of prisons, however necessary, is no substitute for hope and order in our souls.
Where there is suffering, there is duty. Americans in need are not strangers, they are citizens; not problems, but priorities; and all of us are diminished when any are hopeless.
Government has great responsibilities, for public safety and public health, for civil rights and common schools. Yet compassion is the work of a nation, not just a government. And some needs and hurts are so deep they will only respond to a mentor's touch or a pastor's prayer. Church and charity, synagogue and mosque, lend our communities their humanity and they will have an honored place in our plans and in our laws.
Many in our country do not know the pain of poverty. But we can listen to those who do. And I can pledge our nation to a goal: When we see that wounded traveler on the road to Jericho, we will not pass to the other side.
America at its best is a place where personal responsibility is valued and expected. Encouraging responsibility is not a search for scapegoats, it is a call to conscience. And though it requires sacrifice, it brings a deeper fulfillment. We find the fullness of life, not only in options, but in commitments. And we find that children and community are the commitments that set us free.
Our public interest depends on private character, on civic duty and family bonds and basic fairness, on uncounted, unhonored acts of decency which give direction to our freedom.
Sometimes in life we are called to do great things. But as a saint of our times has said, every day we are called to do small things with great love. The most important tasks of a democracy are done by everyone.
I will live and lead by these principles: to advance my convictions with civility, to pursue the public interest with courage, to speak for greater justice and compassion, to call for responsibility and try to live it as well. In all these days -- ways -- I will bring the values of our history to the care of our times.
What you do is as important as anything government does. I ask you to seek a common good beyond your comfort, to defend needed reforms against easy attacks, to serve your nation, beginning with your neighbor. I ask you to be citizens. Citizens, not spectators. Citizens, not subjects. Responsible citizens, building communities of service and a nation of character.
Americans are generous and strong and decent, not because we believe in ourselves, but because we hold beliefs beyond ourselves. When this spirit of citizenship is missing, no government program can replace it. When this spirit is present, no wrong can stand against it.
After the Declaration of Independence was signed, Virginia statesman John Page wrote to Thomas Jefferson: "We know the race is not to the swift, nor the battle to the strong. Do you not think an angel rides in the whirlwind and directs this storm?"
Much time has passed since Jefferson arrived for his inauguration. The years and changes accumulate. But the themes of this day he would know: our nation's grand story of courage, and its simple dream of dignity. We are not this story's author, who fills time and eternity with his purpose. Yet his purpose is achieved in our duty and our duty is fulfilled in service to one another.
Never tiring, never yielding, never finishing, we renew that purpose today: to make our country more just and generous, to affirm the dignity of our lives and every life.
This work continues. This story goes on. And an angel still rides in the whirlwind and directs this storm.
God bless you all, and God bless America.
